HEADLINE: Deportation, and Family Ruin; 
Immigrant Breadwinners Are Held Far Away for Years

BYLINE:  By CHRIS HEDGES 

 BODY:
When Congress passed sweeping legislation in 1996 mandating that all immigrants who had been convicted of crimes be deported, it said it intended to rid the country of even legal immigrants who had committed crimes. 
 The implications for those immigrants were straightforward, but as the laws have been enforced, the consequences for their families in this country have begun to sink in, often with painful results. 
 Tens of thousands of the immigrants have been deported, and many others have been sent to federal prisons or some 225 remote jails around the country used by the Immigration and Naturalization Service because of low costs and available bed space. They had been convicted of crimes both minor and major, some of which had been committed long before 1996. 
Many of those awaiting deportation do so without basic legal representation. Before 1996, almost all the immigrants now in custody would have been allowed to remain in the country. 
Some families recognize that it is appropriate that their relatives are punished for their crimes, while others maintain their innocence. But nearly all of them say that the circumstances of their detention -- held in jails hundreds of miles away and often without regular communication -- make the challenge of holding a family together all the more difficult.
The effects of the laws on immigrant families have perhaps been felt most acutely in New York, which has more immigrant residents than anywhere else in the country.
In Brooklyn, Min Wen Zheng has been trying to hold her family together since her husband was arrested in August 1997. Without the $2,000 a month her husband earned as a kitchen worker in a Chinese restaurant, she has had to rent out one of the rooms in her three-room apartment in Sunset Park to a boarder to help pay the rent. She has borrowed cash from relatives over the last two weeks as she waits impatiently for the garment factory where she earns $5 an hour to call her back to work. 
"Our life has collapsed," she said.
Her husband, Wei Yeung, 38, was convicted of helping to smuggle Chinese immigrants into the country and served 12 months in prison. Since then, he has been held nearly two years by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Oakdale, La., in deportation proceedings.
Although Ms. Zheng and Mr. Yeung are able to talk on the telephone, the last time she saw him was in August 1999 when she traveled to Louisiana with their sons.
During the visit in prison, Ms. Zheng and her husband told their two boys that he was working in a factory. "They are young, only 6 and 7," said Ms. Zheng, 34. "I tell them their father is working far away. When they grow up I will try and explain." 
Alone and unemployed, she worries most now that her husband will be deported. Deportation, she said, will destroy her family completely, since China imposes lengthy prison sentences on smugglers.
"If Mr. Yeung is sent back to China, he will be scooped up and sent to a labor camp where he will bust rocks for years," said his lawyer, Craig Wilson.
The accounts of immigrants who have had their lives turned upside down by this legislation are many. Antoni Runierc, an immigrant from Poland who arrived in the United States in 1980, watched from a jail cell as all he had built -- a stable home, a job and a place in American society -- vanished because of his 1995 arrest for driving a car with stolen plates. Mr. Runierc, 48, says the car belonged to a customer of the auto body shop where he worked in Amherst, Mass. But because he had been convicted of an aggravated felony, he faces deportation. 
After his conviction, the bank foreclosed on his house. His wife filed for divorce so she could receive public assistance. And his children have spent the last five years without him.
He has shuttled between six I.N.S. detention centers and, when he last called a reporter collect, was in the Hudson County Correctional Center in South Kearny, N.J. 
His wife supports their three children as a nurse's aide in Massachusetts, he said. After spending $3,000 for a lawyer, he could not keep paying those fees and lost representation. He is still awaiting a ruling.
"In the meantime," he said in an interview, "everything my wife and I built for ourselves in this country has been taken away from us. We are ruined. My oldest daughter is being treated for depression. My two younger children, at this point, do not even know their father." 
The immigration agency has asked Congress to amend the law. I.N.S. agents have also begun to back away from a strict interpretation of the statutes in an effort to temper the impact of the law on some of those convicted and their families.
Russell A. Bergeron Jr., the director of media relations for the I.N.S., said the agency's field offices would begin "exercising prosecutorial discretion" in certain cases where longtime legal residents have been deemed deportable and where they can no longer expect relief in the immigration courts.
"While we hope the exercise of this discretion will reduce the incidents of families' being separated under these circumstances," Mr. Bergeron said, "we still believe that the best remedy is to amend the law so immigration judges can once again review the cases of those individuals who are deserving of a possible second chance." 
An effort to rescind some of the harsher provisions of the laws collapsed when the Republican leadership in the Senate decided to adjourn for the year without passing the legislation, which unanimously passed in the House in September. The new bill would have halted the deportation of immigrants who had committed crimes in the years before the act was passed. The decision was a body blow to many immigrant families.
"We have documented beyond any refutation the terrible harm that this bill has done to people who, having once committed offenses, turned their lives around and became responsible residents," Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a fierce critic of the 1996 laws, said in a statement. 
Many of the families have lost not only their primary wage earners, but also the vital anchors that two-parent families provide to their children, who are especially vulnerable because of financial, linguistic and cultural difficulties.
The strain on the immigrant families left to make their way after their relatives have been detained for prior offenses has not been eased by the fact that there have been widespread complaints about the conditions in which their relatives are imprisoned.
For years, there have been complaints and lawsuits alleging abuse and deprivation at the often small county jails in which their relatives are kept. Lawyers and other advocates for the detainees have asserted that many immigrants held in the jails have been beaten, forced to live in unsanitary conditions or denied access to lawyers.
Late last year, the I.N.S. said it was going to start to enforce uniform basic standards at the institutions that hold the detainees, who number as many as 20,000 on any given day. The new standards cover everything from visitation rights to grievance procedures.

HEADLINE: Whitman Keeps It Personal in Trenton Farewell 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
She came to this city in 1994 with no reputation, no record and no experience in elective office beyond two terms on the Somerset County Board of Freeholders.
 But her annual address to lawmakers here today bore the indelible stamp that Christie Whitman has put on the governorship in the years since then: She made the afternoon both rather grand and rather personal. 
 The grandiosity was lent by about 10 minutes of video clips, costing $8,900 and paid for by the state, showing the governor in a montage of photo opportunities set to uplifting music: Mrs. Whitman taking her first oath of office in 1994, shaking hands with players at a ball park and flashing her big, lopsided grin and cheerful thumbs-up from the cab of a locomotive. 
At the same time, Mrs. Whitman showed her knack for personal contact with people not only by having her daughter, Kate, introduce her, but also by saluting particular citizens for work they had done for the state during her two terms. There was Harry Kels Swan, who has lent his vast collection of Revolutionary War artifacts to Washington Crossing State Park, representing the governor's proposals to spend more on parks. There was Andrea Baden, a former welfare recipient who is now employed and independent, symbolizing the cuts in welfare rolls during her administration. 
And there was Dana Christmas, the student at Seton Hall University who was badly burned helping others escape the dormitory fire there a year ago. Mrs. Whitman's critics have poked fun at the governor over the years for seeming to let the aloof manners of her privileged life show through her public persona. But when Ms. Christmas climbed stiffly to the stage, the marks of her burns on her face, the hugs and kisses the two women exchanged seemed heartfelt enough to produce one of the relatively few standing ovations of the afternoon.
The longest and loudest applause erupted not when Mrs. Whitman itemized her triumphs or saluted heroic New Jerseyans in the audience, but when she turned to thank the man who would succeed her if she leaves to join the Bush administration, Donald T. DiFrancesco, the State Senate president.
Mr. DiFrancesco blessed the applause with a pontifical wag of his upturned hand.
Even before Mrs. Whitman began to speak, the focus of attention and ambition under the pink domed ceiling of the War Memorial auditorium had shifted to Mr. DiFrancesco, who will become acting governor if Mrs. Whitman is confirmed as President-elect George W. Bush's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency later this month.
Mr. DiFrancesco, who hopes to be elected in his own right in November, took pains to say this afternoon that he would not begin making his own proposals for running the state "until we move to the other side of the Capitol," where the governor's offices are. But the legislators and lobbyists who packed the hall were already watching and talking about him. 
"Donnie would have been a better governor seven years ago than she is now," Dan Tauriello, a banker, said loyally.
Mr. Tauriello said he was worried about the debt the state has assumed since Mrs. Whitman came to office seven years ago, a theme the opposition Democrats sounded as well today.
But Mrs. Whitman focused on the positive today. She said she was leaving with a catalog of accomplishments, from increasing prescription services to the elderly to preserving hundreds of thousands of acres of open space. As usual, she used numbers to drive her points -- the number of children lifted from poverty, the number of dollars saved from tax cuts, the number of new jobs created during the long economic boom that eased so many of her administration's economic programs into being.
"We are the home state of Nobel laureates and innovative geniuses, of electrifying performers, inspiring teachers and gifted writers," Mrs. Whitman said, speaking from a text on the teleprompter. "We are the crossroads of the American Revolution and the proving grounds of the high-tech revolution." 
She had plenty of friends in the hall. William E. Best, the director of the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority and a Whitman appointee, praised the governor for the work she did for the cities, both in providing seed money for new investment and by making it easier to develop old, often polluted industrial sites.
"I think the governor has made New Jersey a national leader in urban policy," Mr. Best said.
Yet the divide that remains between city and suburb in New Jersey was also on display today, in two school choirs that performed at each end of the program. The student choir from Public School 26 in Paterson, an old textile city, did not have a white face in it as it sang the national anthem. The choir from the Upper Freehold Elementary and Middle School, in suburban Monmouth County, did not have a black one.
The singers from Upper Freehold were responsible for leading the audience in a tribute to Mrs. Whitman, written by Paul Solyok, a teacher a their school and sung to George M. Cohan's "It's a Grand Old Flag."
"By some chance of fate, in this great Garden State, we are run by someone who's first rate," the children set out, singing the song through twice. 
Although the spectators had the sheet music handed to them by ushers as they entered, no one joined in.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
M.I.T. Performs A Hat Trick In Recruiting

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
The dance begins in hotel suites and at cocktail parties. It continues by phone and e-mail messages. And it finishes, for a lucky few, with an exhausting few weeks of cross-country travel, with stops in Cambridge, Chicago and Palo Alto, Calif.
 All the while, the nation's top business schools and the most sought-after doctoral students in finance, management and a host of other subjects are sizing one another up. By spring, the schools converge on a handful of young stars with job offers. Some schools go bust, unable to fill an opening with a prized candidate. Now and then, though, a school hits the jackpot. This is precisely what the Massachusetts Institute of Technology did last year. 
 In arguably the most competitive field -- finance, where Wall Street firms also try to woo Ph.D. students -- M.I.T. landed three of the top students. It beat out Harvard, New York University, Stanford, the University of Chicago, the University of Pennsylvania and about a dozen others. "For any school to get three of the top candidates in one field in one year is a real coup," said Bill Broesamle, the director of M.B.A. programs at the University of California at Los Angeles.
The achievement even came with an unusual bonus: all three of their new finance teachers were women. At a time when business schools are struggling to catch up with law and medical schools in increasing their female enrollments, the feat gave M.I.T. a nice recruiting tool.
It also coincided with a resurgence of female appointments to male-dominated finance departments after a decade-long slowdown. "It was the year of the woman," said Kenneth French, an M.I.T. finance professor who helped recruit the three. 
In the past, Professor French added, "there have been top women, but never this number." At the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, for example, two of the three new junior faculty members in finance are also women.
Still, across the country, only 23 percent of business school teachers are women, up from 18 percent a decade ago and 10 percent two decades ago, according to the International Association for Management Education. The numbers are lower among full professors and at top schools like the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., where 16 percent of the faculty is female.
M.I.T.'s new finance teachers are Jun Pan, a native of China who has doctorates in physics and finance; Anna Pavlova, a native of Russia, who received a Ph.D. in economics from Wharton; and Antoinette Schoar, a native of Germany, who wrote her dissertation at Chicago about the decline in productivity at companies that diversify.
They chose M.I.T., they said, because of its faculty and its location. And they chose offices on the same drab hallway in Building E53 so none would find herself isolated. "We're all economists," Ms. Pavlova said. "We colluded."
The job market that the three found waiting for them bears little resemblance to most overcrowded academic fields. Business schools are flush with money after the long bull market, and openings outnumber qualified candidates at many of them.
That disparity has helped drive up starting salaries. For finance professors, the biggest beneficiaries, these have risen to about $150,000 from $110,000 five years ago, professors said.
In the mid-1990's, said David M. Kreps, the senior associate dean of academic affairs at Stanford Business School, "Wall Street was paying a lot of money for rocket-science finance; to keep the people we wanted to keep, we had to pay more."
The recruiting season begins in the fall, when Ph.D. students who are nearing the end of their dissertation send out recommendations and transcripts to potential employers. "Then you wait," Ms. Pan said.
It was particularly bumpy for Ms. Pan, who had already been rejected by M.I.T. -- her first choice -- in 1995 when, as a disaffected graduate student in physics at N.Y.U., she began applying to finance programs. Last year, she applied again -- and never got a response.
So when she heard that a friend had received a call from M.I.T. to schedule an interview during the annual meeting for finance experts, Ms. Pan recalled, "I called and said, 'Maybe you forgot my name.' They said, 'No, you're not on the interview list.' "
The next day, however, she got an e-mail message from M.I.T. that spelled out the happy reason: the school was so impressed with Ms. Pan and her dissertation on risk aversion among options investors that it decided to invite her to give a talk to the M.I.T. faculty without going through the traditional interview first.
For most strong candidates, the interview schedule at the annual finance meeting -- which was held in Boston a year ago -- is grueling. Ms. Schoar, for example, sent out 18 applications in the fall of 1999, and every one of the schools wanted to interview her in Boston. So she sat down for a rapid-fire series of half-hour interviews during the 72-hour conference. 
She returned to Chicago, where she was then a student, with the flu, which her boyfriend said came from all the hands she shook. But it seemed to be worth it: Ms. Schoar received invitations from all 18 schools to visit their campuses. She said no to two foreign schools and then spent much of the winter bouncing around the country, presenting her paper on productivity.
"You basically don't do anything else for two months," said Ms. Schoar, who received a job offer from all 16 schools she visited.
It seems exotic. Famous institutions buy expensive plane tickets for graduate students, and long-revered professors practically plead with them to accept jobs. Indeed, Ms. Pan, Ms. Pavlova and Ms. Schoar all said they were grateful simply for the chance to meet so many leading people in their field.
But the driven, highly focused minds that gravitate to academia rarely treat the trips as miniature vacations. When Ms. Pavlova flew to France for interviews at Insead, a business school in Fontainebleau, for example, she turned down the chance to spend a Saturday night in Paris, opting instead to stay in the suburbs and work on a paper on import quotas.
"They asked for clarification several times," Ms. Pavlova said. "They kept saying, 'Are you sure you don't want a hotel room in Paris?' "

HEADLINE: Proposal Could Leave Only a Little Bit of the Sky for the Also-Rans 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Since May, when United Airlines announced its $4.3 billion bid to take over US Airways, the conventional wisdom in the airline business has been that if regulators approve the deal, the domestic airline industry, now dominated by six airlines, would shrink to three mega-carriers.
 But the American Airlines plan to buy some of the US Airways' assets and take over the faltering Trans World Airlines has convinced many experts that the chance of a third airline's challenging United and American will be slim if the complicated set of deals is consummated. 
 The very antitrust authorities that American and United have designed their deals to placate will have difficulty approving agreements among Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines, analysts said. 
"There is no question that American and United want to form a Big Two," said Michael E. Levine, a former airline executive and an architect of deregulation who now teaches at Harvard Law School. "Both have had the ambition to be, if possible, numero uno, but realize that if they can compete with each other on equal terms and everyone else on unequal terms, they are still better off." 
After days of speculation since news of the transaction emerged over the weekend, American intends to announce its plans at a news conference in New York today. The boards of the UAL Corporation, United's parent; T.W.A.; and the AMR Corporation, the parent of American, all met yesterday to approve the moves. 
American has agreed to pay United $1.5 billion to buy 86 jets and 15 gates at six East Coast airports and to jointly operate the lucrative Boston-New York-Washington shuttle.
It has also agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in DC Air, a carrier created to operate many of US Airways' assets at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington. 
American will also take over most of T.W.A.'s assets for $500 million after the 75-year-old carrier declares bankruptcy today for the third time in less than a decade. "What this flurry of activity does," Mr. Levine said, "is present a question of public policy that hasn't been addressed before. Deregulation was about getting government out of questions of industry structure. The idea was you would use the antitrust laws as an interventionist tool when monopoly was threatened. This is more subtle because it is really about competitive advantage without monopoly."
The deals are meant to address competition concerns raised by Justice Department officials reviewing United's bid for US Airways. But it would also leave the archrivals United and American roughly the same size, with each carrying about one-quarter of all domestic passengers.
And each would be much larger than Delta, Northwest and Continental, which together carry about 35 percent of domestic passengers. United and American would compete with each other for lucrative corporate contracts but would have a major advantage over the three other major airlines. 
"In the airline industry, he who has the biggest network wins," said Steven A. Morrison, an economics professor at Northeastern University who has written widely about the industry, "because passengers and the firms that business travelers work for would prefer to deal with a carrier that goes to all the places they go."
As the third-largest airline behind United and American, Delta is eager to keep up and has said that it has not ruled out making a deal of its own. But investment bankers and analysts said it had few places to turn. It could pursue America West or Alaska Airlines, but those much smaller carriers would not add that much to Delta's existing route network.
Its most attractive partner is Houston-based Continental, which it tried to buy in 1998. But according to a recent agreement, Northwest has the power to block a takeover of Continental unless it is involved in some deal first. 
"The only way Delta can make a major counterresponse right now is to buy Northwest," said one investment banker who spoke on condition of anonymity. But that would get strong opposition in Washington, he added. 
Delta might be able to figure out a way to get Northwest's permission to bid on Continental, but that deal, too, would face opposition from regulators. Delta, Northwest and Continental are all healthy airlines, but T.W.A. and US Airways are seen as weak competitors that might fail unless they are taken over.
Gaining a long-term competitive advantage is the only rationale that some analysts can see behind United's and American's moves. Mergers in the heavily unionized airline industry have often been highly disruptive. Few of the dozens of deals since deregulation have ended up being profitable. 
Every airline in the industry has taken at least one hard look, and some two or three, at T.W.A. over the last decade as the once venerable airline declined. All passed because T.W.A. was seen as a lot more trouble than it was worth. 
Its unions are well entrenched and unwilling to permit the kind of wage and job cuts needed to make T.W.A. a profitable low-cost carrier, said several airline executives. The airline's major asset, its hub in St. Louis, is shared with Southwest Airlines, the country's largest and most successful low-fare airline. That has kept fares down, robbing T.W.A. of the premiums rival airlines receive at hubs where Southwest does not fly.
Since investors got wind of the proposed deal, AMR stock has fallen 11 percent. Yesterday, it closed at $38.94 a share, down $2.56. UAL stock has fallen nearly 7 percent over the same period, closing yesterday at $42 a share, down $1.06. US Airways stock is up slightly, closing yesterday at $42.69, up $1.31, but it is still trading far below UAL's offering price of $60 a share.
T.W.A. shareholders are expected to receive nothing out of the deal because of the bankruptcy. The airline's shares have been suspended on the American Stock Exchange since Friday. 
American thinks it can make money in St. Louis by connecting T.W.A. with American's larger route network and using it to relieve congestion at O'Hare International in Chicago, a hub it shares with United. 
"They've got a structure that makes sense," said one person close to American's plans. "T.W.A. has a hub in St. Louis that is looking for a network."
But critics fear that United and American will use their increased size to pry customers away from Delta, Northwest and Continental and to bully low-fare competitors, even one as large and successful as Southwest. 
"The problem with industry consolidation is that the number of monopoly markets increases," said Kevin Mitchell, the chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, which lobbies for large corporate buyers of air transportation. The big airlines then threaten to revoke discounts in markets where they have a monopoly unless the company signs a contract to fly with them in markets where they compete against smaller rivals. 
"That is how these two mega-carriers are going to siphon business away from Northwest and Delta in Minneapolis, Detroit and Atlanta," Mr. Mitchell said. 
Yesterday, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, wrote to the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, expressing concern over the dominance American would have at Kennedy Airport if its planned deals were approved. 
He said that together, United, American and Delta would control more than 83 percent of the airport's domestic traffic. American alone would control more than half the traffic and three of the airport's nine terminals, posing a threat to low-fare competitors like ATA and JetBlue Airways. 
"Without the ability to expand and compete at J.F.K.," Mr. Schumer wrote, "these low-cost carriers's operations in the New York City market will be harmed and their survival could be jeopardized."

HEADLINE: Bush Is Pressed to Keep Trade Negotiator in His Cabinet 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush has come under pressure to maintain cabinet rank for his top trade official, with lawmakers and business leaders arguing in unusually strong language that any downgrading of the position might cripple the nation's chief trade negotiator at a critical time.
 The idea of stripping the trade representative of cabinet rank, a status the position has carried since the mid-1970's, was floated by senior Bush advisers last week and was effectively confirmed by Mr. Bush on Saturday. Bush aides said today that the president-elect had not made up his mind on the matter. 
 The change in status is seen as a way to give Donald L. Evans, Mr. Bush's choice for commerce secretary, greater purview over foreign trade. Officials involved in the Bush transition had said that the president-elect wanted to keep his cabinet relatively small and to concentrate decision-making authority in fewer top administration officials than was the case in the Clinton administration.
But the idea was quickly and vigorously attacked by lawmakers and business lobbyists who said that a demotion would undercut the trade representative in negotiations with foreign partners and might cause other nations to think that the new administration considered trade a relatively low priority. The top trade officer in many other countries and regions, including the European Union and Japan, is a minister with cabinet-equivalent rank.
The office of the United States trade representative is a White House agency, not formally a part of the cabinet. But Congress has endowed the office with statutory authority over trade matters and treats the trade representative as the most senior trade official other than the president. In recognition, every president since Jimmy Carter has invited the top trade official to sit with the cabinet.
Representative Bill Thomas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said through a spokesman that he had been assured that the president-elect did not intend to downgrade the post.
"Chairman Thomas spoke with high-level officials on the team and was given assurances that it would not happen," said Trent Duffy, a spokesman for the Ways and Means Committee. But Mr. Duffy declined to say who made those assurances, and people involved in the Bush transition said the president-elect had yet to rule on whether he would keep the trade representative in his cabinet.
Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, also said today that "no decision has been made" about the trade representative -- either the person who will hold the post or the position's status. But he suggested that concerns about a possible downgrading had been heard.
"It's a position that will have to fight throughout the world for the president-elect's free trade positions," Mr. Fleischer said. "And the president-elect has every intention of moving on that position to afford it the priority it deserves."
As recently as Saturday, Mr. Bush appeared to confirm that he was considering a downgrade, though he emphasized that the position would remain a vital one.
"Whether or not the person is called cabinet or not, it will not in one way or another diminish the position," Mr. Bush said.
The reaction against such a move has been furious and bipartisan. Mr. Thomas weighed in strongly on the issue, his spokesman said. Senator Max Baucus, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, said through a spokesman that he was "100 percent, absolutely opposed to the idea" and would "go to the mat" to fight it.
Thomas Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said he had called several senior people in the Bush camp to express his alarm. "I told them that there is just no reason to fight on this issue," he said. "Diluting the power of this person is just a tremendous mistake."
Charlene Barshefsky, Mr. Clinton's trade representative, called any such move "absolute folly." She said the top trade officials of America's leading economic partners would be "dumbfounded" if asked to negotiate with a United States official who held lesser rank, especially because the United States is often viewed as the power most eager to expand trade between nations.
It is unclear how closely tied the decision about the job's status is to Mr. Bush's thinking about whom to choose to fill the trade slot, the only senior economic member of his team the president-elect has yet to name.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE, EDWARD WYATT, KAREN W. ARENSON and LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
Advising on the Transition
 ROBERT L. KING, the chancellor of the State University of New York, has been named by President-elect George W. Bush as one of 31 members of the education advisory team for the presidential transition. The team will work with RODERICK R. PAIGE, the superintendent of schools in Houston, who has been nominated as secretary of education. Other members of the group are LAMAR ALEXANDER, a former education secretary and presidential contender; the education scholars DIANE RAVITCH and CHESTER FINN; and the Rev. FLOYD H. FLAKE. Chancellor King said, "Serving on this panel will provide the opportunity to share our views on the importance of higher education to the growth of the national economy." 

For Clean, Safe Schools
The Healthy Schools Network, a coalition of environmental, health and educational organizations, and Cornell University's workplace health and safety program have released the second edition of a guide that provides parents with information about a variety of health hazards that are potentially present in schools, including poor air quality, toxic chemicals, structural dangers and fire hazards. The publication, the Environmental Action Guide for New York State Schools, calls for new standards to protect schoolchildren's health and provides instructions in recognizing symptoms of illnesses caused by environmental hazards. The guide is available through the network's Web site, www.hsnet.org.

CUNY Officer Is Leaving
The City University of New York is losing its chief operating officer, DAVID H. FREED, who is leaving to become president of Nyack Hospital in Nyack, N.Y. A former president of Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., Mr. Freed was part of the new senior management team at City University assembled last summer by Chancellor MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN. The university has begun a national search for a replacement.

Internships With a Developer
The Durst Organization, a major New York City developer, awarded nine students from eight Manhattan public high schools 18-month internships on Monday. The students will work in various disciplines in the development of the company's $100 million six-story, 500,000-square-foot NYCyberCenter building on 57th and 58th Streets between 11th and 12th Avenues. The building will house not people, but machinery, including computer servers and routers. The students will be learning from contractors and other professionals in areas like information technology, mechanical engineering, architecture and design, structural engineering, leasing and marketing and corporate communications. The internships will begin in March, and students are to work 10 hours a week during the school year and 30 hours over the summer. KATE ZERNIKE, EDWARD WYATT, KAREN W. ARENSON and LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Getting Fiscal

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
If Milton Friedman weren't still alive, he'd be spinning in his grave. His legacy has been betrayed -- not by big-government liberals, but by the conservatives about to take power. 
 Nowadays Mr. Friedman is mainly famous as an apostle of free markets. But through much of his career he was best known as the champion of the conservative doctrine known as monetarism. Basically, monetarists wanted to get the government out of the business of short-term economic management. First and foremost this meant rejecting the use of fiscal policy -- discretionary tax cuts or spending increases -- to fight recessions. 
 By and large this was an argument that the monetarists won on the evidence. Few economists now accept Mr. Friedman's further view that even monetary policy should be placed on cruise control. Alas, it turns out that a stable money supply is no guarantee of a stable economy. But almost all economists now agree with the position that monetary policy, not fiscal policy, is the tool of choice for fighting recessions. 
Almost all economists, that is, except those who have been or hope to be tapped for jobs in the new administration. Indeed, it's remarkable how thoroughly George W. Bush's people seem to have been converted to a crude Keynesian view of economic policy -- a view that, it just so happens, offers them another justification for a tax cut that even moderate Republicans think is excessive.
The latest exposition of that view came from Mr. Bush's choice as chief economic adviser, Lawrence Lindsey, who last weekend stood Milton Friedman on his head, declaring that monetary policy is ineffective and fiscal policy reigns supreme. Here's what he said: "Let's contrast the typical credit card borrower on monetary policy versus fiscal policy. The interest rate cut of last week helps the typical credit card borrower about two bucks a month, two dollars a month, whereas Mr. Bush's tax cut for a family making $40,000, gets a $1,600-a-year tax cut, 32 bucks a week. That's a much bigger heft." 
You have to admire Mr. Lindsey. It's not often that an economist manages a triple play. But he did it: his statement was specious on three distinct levels. 
First, he exaggerated the impact of Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut on ordinary families. Most families would get far less than he suggested; independent estimates indicate that on average even families with an income of $50,000 would get only half as much tax relief.
Second, he loaded the comparison by comparing the full impact of tax cuts with only one minor effect of interest rate reductions. Won't lower rates (which can, incidentally, be reduced much further) also reduce mortgage payments -- not to mention the burden of debt on corporations? 
Finally, and most important, he misrepresented the way interest rate cuts work. Their main effect on demand isn't via a reduction in the payments people make on the debt they already have; lower interest rates work by stimulating investment, that is, by inducing businesses and individuals to borrow more, or to put their money into real assets instead of parking it in bonds. That's how rate cuts led to recovery from the last recession even while Bill Clinton was raising taxes.
It was a remarkable display of bogus economic analysis. It would be alarming if the new chief economist believed any of the things he said. But we needn't worry; this was merely a cynical attempt by someone who knows better to build support for that tax cut. After all, Mr. Lindsey would have defended that cut even if the economy were still booming. 
Still, Mr. Lindsey's remarks were not a good omen.
One little-noticed but important virtue of the Clinton administration was its honesty in economic analysis and reporting. In general -- and in contrast to some of their predecessors -- Mr. Clinton's economists avoided misrepresenting the facts, using convenient but specious arguments, or employing scare tactics to sell their policy ideas. 
But it's already clear that henceforth things will be different. It seems that the incoming administration regards it as perfectly acceptable to say things that are demonstrably untrue, and even to abandon conservative economic principles, if by so doing it can sell its preferred policy.

HEADLINE: Mr. Giuliani's Last Opus 

 BODY:
In his final address on the state of New York City, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani compared himself to Giuseppe Verdi writing "Falstaff," in which the maestro included every theme he could imagine. It was an apt comparison. In his rambling but entertaining two-hour speech, the mayor covered lots of territory, both emotional and otherwise. He made a pitch to burnish his record in fighting crime and boosting the city's economy. But he also tried to take some of the hard edges off his mayoral legacy before it is too late. In contrast to previous years, Mr. Giuliani praised others, talked about progress being a team effort and worked to defuse some of his more explosive past criticisms. 
 His most compelling proposals came in the areas of education and housing. He promised to continue his valuable battle to give the next mayor control over schools, thereby ensuring political accountability for education. He proposed adding weekend schooling, a concept that could be especially helpful to those children who can use all the time they can get with skilled educators. He ladled out a series of inviting promises from enhanced school libraries and athletic fields to speedier construction of 12 schools in unnamed areas. But he also vowed to promote vouchers, a more troubling concept that is not supported by most of the city's political leaders or educators. 
 Mr. Giuliani's plan to expand low-income housing, an area in which he has previously done very little, looks like a promising step toward relieving a growing housing gap. He proposes to spend $600 million over the next four years in order to leverage another $600 million in private investment for housing. The proposal came with ambitious plans to reform the city's building code and rid the construction industry of organized crime.
Mr. Giuliani also offered a nicely tailored reworking of last year's plan to sell off the Board of Education offices in Brooklyn and build something smaller and more stylish. He promised an important early start to the Brooklyn Bridge Park, which now has money and crucial political support from Gov. George Pataki as well. The mayor also gave a nudge to a promising proposal for Manhattan's West Side, with a football stadium for the Jets that converts into an expansion of the Jacob Javits Convention Center. So far, however, neither the mayor nor the Jets has come forward with a financing plan that spares taxpayers the bill.
The mayor's long speech, oddly, made no mention of some critical tasks he must face. Although his housing and education proposals will help minorities, he still needs to cultivate better relations with minority communities. He should also consider peace negotiations with Governor Pataki, his fellow Republican. Completing labor negotiations with teachers, police and other city workers now toiling without a contract would present the next mayor with an easier passage. Mr. Giuliani also needs to revamp the city's voting system and provide extra protections for the watershed. He has promised to be "very aggressive" in his last year, but he has only a few short months to push through the last pieces of his agenda.

HEADLINE: CALLS FOR CHANGE IN THE SCHEDULING OF THE SCHOOL DAY 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
The newest educational mantra may as well be: Never let them leave the building.
 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York wants Saturday classes. The state's governor, George E. Pataki, says students should stay in school until after dark. And in California, Gov. Gray Davis plans to tack 30 days onto the academic year -- stretching it by 17 percent -- for middle school students who have fallen behind in an era of mounting expectations. 
 The proposals, made in recent days during the annual parade of politicians' speeches on the state of their respective domains, add to a mounting sense that America's school schedule -- which was based not on educational needs but on those of an agrarian economy -- should be ripped up and redrawn. 
"Our traditional school calendar has simply outlived its usefulness," said Ruy Teixeira, a senior fellow at the Century Foundation, a public policy research group based in Washington that published a paper last summer on the concept of all-day, all-year schools.
"This ideological limit on what schools can do and when they can be open is so clearly a remnant of the past," Mr. Teixeira added. "Twenty years from now, we're going to look back on the way schools are today and have been for a long time and think, 'How could anyone possibly believe that system would work?' "
In the last four years, federal financing for after-school programs has skyrocketed to $846 million from $1 million. At the same time, millions of schoolchildren have been sent to summer school: nearly one in five in the nation's large urban districts were in class last July. Year-round schools, which sprinkle vacations throughout the year rather than have a long summer break, now serve about 2 million of the nation's 52 million students. And many of the 2,000 charter schools that have sprouted across the country since 1990 are luring families in part by offering longer hours.
Meanwhile, Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers, has called for a fifth year of high school for those who are struggling, and Richard W. Riley, the secretary of education, has suggested making teaching a 12-month job, largely to make more time for professional development. Teachers' unions generally support this idea.
The trend is powered by a troika of sociological forces: more parents working outside the home; research showing that children get into trouble during the late afternoon and lose educational ground during summer breaks; and the higher standards that have been embraced from coast to coast over the last decade.
Support for the more-time movement is broad and bipartisan, but considerable obstacles include the enormous price tag and the gaping teacher shortage. Educators and politicians also caution that more of the same is not necessarily better, and that expanded calendars must be filled with creative curriculum overseen by qualified personnel.
The Knowledge Is Power Program in Houston and the South Bronx, which has won national recognition for high test scores and has been showcased by President-elect George W. Bush, requires attendance from 7:25 a.m. until 5 p.m., two or three Saturdays a month, and several weeks in summer.
"When we started, everyone thought we were nuts -- now everyone wants to do it," said David Levin, principal of the program's New York outlet. "Excellence requires sacrifice. That's a value that's essential to be successful in any endeavor. When you put in all this extra time with kids, they don't get the sense that you're just punching the clock."
The call for increased time in school began in 1983 with the landmark "Nation at Risk" report, but the volume was turned up in 1994 with a pair of papers, by the Department of Education and the Carnegie Corporation, that focused specifically on the calendar. "Time should be adjusted to meet the individual needs of learners," the federal report said, "rather than the administrative convenience of adults."
Since then, the pressure has only mounted, as virtually every state has adopted more rigorous curriculums, and many have introduced tough exit exams. With teachers and principals being held accountable for results on standardized tests, many have complained that they cannot cram more into already crowded days.
"We have asked more of our students and schools than ever before," Governor Davis said in his speech Monday night. "Educators tell me that for all the new investments we've made, the main thing they need is more time to teach."
In part, the motivation is international competition: a 1990-91 study showed that the average number of required school days in the United States, 178, fell behind that of 16 European and Asian countries, many of whose students outperform Americans: Italy, Israel, Germany, Japan, Taiwan and Korea all had more than 200 days; China had 250.
"If we want American kids to catch up with kids who learn more in other countries, American kids might need to spend more time learning like kids in other countries do," said Chester E. Finn Jr., an education official in the Reagan administration.
Noting that most juvenile crime and teenage pregnancies occur between 3 and 6 p.m., and that thousands of children spend those hours parked in front of TV sets, Mr. Finn added, "For an awful lot of kids, school is a more salubrious environment than where else they're likely to be spending their time."
But time is money.
Many state legislatures have rejected proposals to add days after considering the bottom line. The California plan would cost at least $770 per student per year -- or $900 million annually once it was fully implemented in three grades. Mayor Giuliani's proposals, to send 45,000 students to weekend science classes, and 45,000 new immigrants to English immersion workshops, would cost an estimated $34 million a year -- for only 8 percent of the city's students. Governor Pataki wants to double his $15 million allocation for after-school programs, but that would bring the total number of children served to just 40,000.
"It's going to be very expensive, and we have to be prepared to pay for it," said Diane Ravitch, a pre-eminent educational historian.
Many politicians and educators believe that now is the time to try, since states are swimming in surpluses and the public's interest in education is at an all-time high. But a parallel problem comes in finding people to fill the classrooms for all those extra hours. The nation needs 2.5 million teachers by 2010 as it is.
"Whatever you do, you're going to need the committed, trained and talented people to execute these reforms," said Mr. Levin of the Knowledge Is Power Program, KIPP. "The danger is that the reforms themselves could be devalued."
Another debate is over content. Researchers say the longer day and year should be used to address students' varied learning styles, and to add enrichment activities, like theater.
"We don't believe in repeating what teachers are doing during the day," said Lenore Neier of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York, which runs school-based programs for 11,000 children, featuring plays and journal writing, among other activities. "It's literacy made fun."
Jose Hernandez, a KIPP eighth grader, said he appreciated the Saturday and summer sessions because "you get more opportunities to learn." As for the politician's proposals, 13-year-old Jose said added time should not be used for recreational activities that children could do on their own, but for productive ones. "If," he explained, "it's like anything that could help us in the future."

HEADLINE: A Teacher's Gift 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 At a time of unrelenting criticism of the public schools in this country, it is refreshing to read Thomas L. Friedman's moving, though belated, tribute to his high school journalism teacher, who died last year ("My Favorite Teacher," column, Jan. 9). 
 If others gave proper credit for the life-changing or life-enhancing contributions of their public school teachers, it might help refocus the education debate from the politically and economically motivated diatribes to matters of more substance, like the relationship between student and teacher. 
It is time for others who understand the value and purpose of public education to speak of its importance for creating effective citizens in a democratic society. 

TEDD LEVY
Norwalk, Conn., Jan. 9, 2001

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Leader Calls for Hastening Bush's Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, called today for a rapid reduction in income tax rates to help head off a recession, giving a lift to President-elect George W. Bush's proposal for a broad package of tax cuts.
 In a memorandum to Republicans in the House, Mr. Armey said the party's priorities should be a reduction in all income tax rates -- the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's plan -- and expanding individual retirement accounts and 401(k) retirement savings plans, a measure that overwhelmingly passed the House last year only to die in the Senate. 
 The cuts, he said, should be enacted promptly and should be retroactive to the start of this year. Mr. Bush's aides are considering accelerating their $1.6 trillion tax-cut plan, which as first formulated would not take effect until 2002. 
Though they have made a big tax cut a primary goal, Republican leaders in Congress have been lukewarm until now in their support for an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates, in part because most benefits would go to the wealthiest taxpayers. Many Republicans have indicated a preference for measures like repealing the federal estate tax and giving a tax cut to married couples. 
But the bad economic news in recent weeks has provided Mr. Bush with an argument in favor of rate cuts, one that Mr. Armey expanded on today.
"It is vitally important that Congress move quickly to enact a pro-growth tax cut that could help avert a recession," he wrote. "Some are arguing that we should put off the income tax rate cut until later in the year. I disagree. The income tax rate cut must move first, whether alone or as part of a larger tax-cut package."
Democrats have blocked most Republican tax-cutting efforts over the past few years. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the party's leader in the Senate, and Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee, signaled today that they remained opposed to the approach advocated by Mr. Armey.
But with the economy slowing and the federal budget surplus continuing to grow, opposition to tax cuts among Democrats is softening, and Democratic leaders are considering offering their own tax-relief packages, possibly built around a reduction in the bottom income tax rate of 15 percent.
"There is a growing sentiment that a tax cut may very well be necessary," said Michael Siegel, a spokesman for Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee. 
But, he added, Democrats would insist that any tax cuts be "reasonable, equitable and not interfere with our ability to pay down the debt, shore up Social Security and Medicare and provide a prescription-drug benefit to seniors."
In one indication of changing attitudes among Democrats toward tax cuts, Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier and former ambassador to France, said last week he believed a substantial tax reduction now would be good economic policy.
"It would not be a bad thing to have a reasonable tax reduction now," he said, "not so much because it will stimulate the economy overnight, but because taxes are relatively high and we can afford a tax cut of one kind or another."

HEADLINE: School Officials See Tough Task In Creating Sixth Class Day 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Board of Education officials said yesterday that they were scrambling to meet the February deadline set by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to add a sixth day of school for nearly 84,000 struggling New York City schoolchildren.
 Even so, the officials said, the board will probably be able to get the program only partly under way. 
 The mayor's proposal, unveiled in his address Monday on the state of the city, would bring about the biggest mobilization of teachers, students and resources since the board instituted mandatory summer school in 1999. Several officials said that although the plans for a sixth day of extra English, science and mathematics classes had been discussed with Mr. Giuliani over the last few weeks, they were stunned to hear that the mayor wanted to carry them out by sometime next month. 
The weekend program would provide remedial instruction on either Saturday or Sunday to 45,300 8th through 12th graders who are lagging in science and math and to 38,600 immigrant students who are failing to learn English.
Education advocates, while enthusiastic about the concept, warned yesterday that the scheduling presents a logistical nightmare. Within a few weeks, the board will have to recruit about 5,600 teachers qualified to teach math, science and English as a foreign language; provide a strong curriculum; and notify students that they have been selected to attend. Just opening a building requires the presence of custodians, security guards and principals. The plan calls for the use of 503 school buildings, about half the citywide total.
One school district official, who spoke yesterday on the condition of anonymity, said the board had not yet sent out any directives telling local officials how to proceed. "Telling everybody to come to work on Saturday is not going to be easy," the official said. "It's too much, too soon. This could be a disaster."
Anthony P. Coles, the deputy mayor for education, said that Mr. Giuliani and his staff had had conversations with Chancellor Harold O. Levy and his staff about the proposals for several weeks, and that the mayor expected the chancellor to have the program "up and running by February."
But Mr. Levy, in an interview yesterday, said that while he expected to begin the weekend sessions sometime next month, he was not committing to opening the full program all at once. "It was announced yesterday," Mr. Levy said. "It isn't as though we started working on it yesterday. On the other hand, it's not going to be done overnight. The goal here is to have a quality program as soon as possible."
Of opening the 503 schools, he said, "We will do as many of them as is feasible and sensible."
Although the Giuliani administration said a sixth day could be added without any contract negotiations, Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, hinted yesterday that she would make an issue of it. Ms. Weingarten, who is now in labor negotiations with the city and the board, said she had sent a letter yesterday to Mr. Levy and to James F. Hanley, the city's labor commissioner, demanding details of the sixth-day plan.
"If you want to do the same old same old, then there's no bargaining issue here," Ms. Weingarten said. "If you want to do something that really tries to create value-added course work for children on weekends, then there are bargaining issues."
Ms. Weingarten predicted that it would be hard to attract first-rate teachers, noting that for years, the biggest shortage of licensed teachers has been in math, science and bilingual education.
She noted that in proposing his program for math and science, Mr. Giuliani had cited international studies showing that students in the United States lag behind those in many other countries.
A closer look, she said, would show that the difference is not in the time spent on instruction, but in the quality of instruction, including how well teachers prepare, polish and master their lessons.
Mr. Coles said the National Academy of Sciences had agreed to advise the city on the math and science program. Board of Education officials said students would be urged to attend if they had scored in Levels 1 or 2, the bottom of four levels, on the state's eighth-grade math test, or if they had failed the math and science requirements for high school graduation.
At Mr. Levy's urging, Mr. Coles said, the mayor agreed to open the program to some students who wanted enrichment, rather than remedial education.
The science and math program is expected to cost $25 million a year, and the English-language program $9 million, including an additional summer session for 10,000 students struggling to learn English.
Raymond Domanico, senior education adviser for the Metro Industrial Areas Foundation, a network of churches and civic groups, said the three hours a week of English instruction proposed by Mr. Giuliani was a significant addition to the 45 minutes a day of English now required by bilingual-education programs in city schools. Often, he said, children get as little as 15 minutes a day of instruction in English.
For his final year in office, Mr. Giuliani, in his annual address, also promised to spend $31.5 million to create libraries in 21,000 classrooms in kindergarten through eighth grade; to open a high school military academy in the Bronx; to create in-school suspension centers for 45,000 students, so they could continue their studies even while suspended for bad behavior; and to accelerate the construction of 12 schools.
Meyer S. Frucher, a former trustee of the School Construction Authority, said the system needed repairs and maintenance to aging and rapidly deteriorating buildings more than new construction.
"If you really look at all the underlying capital needs of the system, we are barely keeping pace with the number of seats that we lose versus the number of seats that we gain," Mr. Frucher said. "New York City has 50 percent of its schools that are 50 years old or older. So while it is a question of increasing the number of seats, it is also a question of replacing seats that are falling off line because of leaks and other issues."
Mr. Giuliani expanded yesterday on his proposal for a military high school, saying it would turn students into prime candidates for West Point, Annapolis or other military academies. "Maybe it could bring some real distinction to the New York City school system the way some of the great high schools do," he said. "The intent here is not for troubled youngsters. The intent is for highly motivated youngsters who want to be in a military academy and who want to consider the military as a long-term career as officers."
He said he hoped that the United States Military Academy would help.
But Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx said he was puzzled by the plan, which the Giuliani administration had described as an economic development initiative for the Bronx, rather than an educational one. "That isn't even 25th on my list for the borough," Mr. Ferrer said. "I don't want to appear unkind. But I don't get it." 

CORRECTION-DATE: January 18, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 10 about the Board of Education's reaction to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal for a sixth day of extra English, science and mathematics classes misidentified the organization that will advise the city on the program. It is the New York Academy of Sciences, not the National Academy of Sciences.

HEADLINE: White House Acted On Global Warming 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Bill McKibben is right that global warming is our greatest environmental challenge, but he is wrong to suggest that the Clinton administration has done "nothing" about it ("Too Hot to Handle," Op-Ed, Jan. 5). 
 When we took office, economic growth in the United States was low, and growth in greenhouse gas emissions was high. 
This administration believed, however, that we could have economic growth while reducing emissions. In both 1998 and 1999, the economy grew by more than 4 percent while carbon dioxide emissions grew by less than 1 percent.
Despite strong resistance in Congress, we secured record financing to develop the clean, efficient energy technologies that can help us fight climate change. Acting without Congress, this administration started more than 50 major initiatives to improve energy efficiency and develop clean energy sources.
Our new efficiency standards for home appliances will save consumers $50 billion and avoid 225 million metric tons of greenhouse gases over the next 10 years. We also made the federal government more efficient; in 1999 alone, we reduced our yearly energy bill by $800 million. 
Eight years ago, few politicians dared take this issue on. President Clinton defied conventional wisdom and forced global warming to the center of our public dialogue. More remains to be done, but the momentum is more easily sustained if we acknowledge, rather than denigrate, the progress achieved.

JOHN PODESTA
Chief of Staff to the President
Washington, Jan. 8, 2001

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton: The French Years 

BYLINE:  By Patrick Weil; Patrick Weil is a senior research fellow at the French National Center for Scientific Research, University of Paris 1-Sorbonne.

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
Dear President Clinton:
 As you prepare to move out of the White House, you are no doubt wondering what you will do next. Perhaps you assume that your time as a president has come to an end, that you must now move on to other, less attractive, alternatives. I have good news for you: You may have the opportunity to be president of France. 
 Under Section 5 of Article 21-19 of the French civil code, citizens of states or territories over which France has ever exercised sovereignty or extended a mandate or protectorate may apply immediately for naturalization, without the normal five-year residency requirement. 
Arkansas, where you were born, was once part of French Louisiana. And as a naturalized French citizen, you would have the same full rights as all other French citizens. That includes running for the presidency.
Our next election is scheduled to take place in May 2002. The front runners, Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and President Jacques Chirac, have been obvious candidates for such a long time that many French citizens are looking for a promising outsider. The media have been asking about a likely "third man" in recent opinion polls; your name didn't come up, but that's only because almost nobody knows that you could soon be eligible.
Of course, to become a citizen, you must fulfill a few legal requirements. You will need an official residence in France. (Paris is probably less expensive than Chappaqua.) And you will need to speak French. (Pas de probleme: Political French is filled with words that are familiar to you. "Election." "Globalisation." "Recession.") But you will be happy to know that France will not require you to renounce your American citizenship.
Mr. President, if elected, you would find the French presidency affords many advantages. Should you have a majority in the Parliament, you would enjoy much more power than as an American president. Should your opposition win a majority in the Parliament and make your life difficult, you would not have to tolerate it for long. At a time of your choosing, you could dissolve the National Assembly and call for new elections. I bet you would have liked to do that with the last United States Congress. And you could be reelected every five years without end. There are no term limits for the French presidency.
You should know that as head of the French state, you would be required, now and again, to utter rather harsh words about America. The United States is a close ally of France and Europe, but also the main economic rival. Like most politicians, however, you will not have to mean what you say. You need only appear to be standing up to the Americans.
There remains only one problem: You will have to apply soon. The time-lag for processing a naturalization application is almost as long in France as it is in the United States. Of course, the French naturalization service could choose to honor you with an expedited processing of your application -- just as they do with top soccer players or other athletes before important international championships.
If you do end up facing delays, I suggest you remind French officials of the words of Marcel Prelot, the French senator who introduced the law that now enables you to become France's next president: "I pray that the Senate make a generous gesture, that it tell those who come from a land which was once French, that France their mother considers them as having been her children, and that at the instant they want to return to the fold, they will be entirely welcome."
President Clinton, welcome to Paris!

HEADLINE: A Welcoming Midwest Bids Clinton Goodbye 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
President Clinton hit the road today in a farewell tour of the Midwest that retraced some of his steps from the 1992 campaign and sought to highlight how far the country had come over the course of his presidency.
 "When I came here -- unbelievably almost nine years ago now -- our economy was profoundly troubled and our society was divided," Mr. Clinton told a spirited crowd of 12,000 packed inside the basketball arena at Michigan State University. "Think about where we are now and where we were eight years ago." 
 Mr. Clinton first rolled past East Lansing, Mich., in the bus tour in 1992 that campaign strategists considered key to his victory that November. Michigan State was also the site of the third of his presidential debates in 1992, a town-hall encounter in which he outshone his two opponents, President George Bush and Ross Perot.
Just 11 days from the end of his presidency, Mr. Clinton acted very much like a candidate today, shaking every hand he could and soaking in the applause. At Michigan State, he posed on stage with the men's basketball team and likened the players' competitive spirit to his own.
"If you play any game in life long enough, once in a while somebody will sink a three-point shot, falling backwards with your hand in their face," Mr. Clinton said. "It will happen if you play any game long enough -- the equivalent will happen to you. It is not fatal. The only thing that's fatal is quitting."
Mr. Clinton reminded students that college graduates were earning less than $26,000 when he took office, compared with more than $36,000 today. And he recited a litany of economic indicators that he said had moved in the right direction since he left the governor's mansion for the White House.
"This is about more than the statistics," he added. "It's about more than money. I think there is a new feeling in America of possibility."
Instead of a single farewell address, Mr. Clinton has opted to deliver numerous goodbyes. He heads to New Hampshire on Thursday to acknowledge that state's key role in reviving his flagging campaign in 1992.
Before he leaves office on Jan. 20, he will also drop by Little Rock, Ark., where he first entered politics as attorney general.
Mr. Clinton tonight returned to the same hotel ballroom in Chicago where he celebrated his clinching of the Democratic presidential nomination on St. Patrick's Day in 1992. Hundreds of his supporters turned out for a rally at the Palmer House Hilton that was heavy on nostalgia.
"I remember marching in the St. Patrick's Day parade in Chicago," Mr. Clinton said. "Most people were waving all five fingers. A majority of people gave me their votes and I knew then it was just a matter of time."
Earlier, the president stopped at a Chicago elementary school to promote his administration's education record. With a multiracial cast of schoolchildren behind him, Mr. Clinton said he hoped future politicians would continue his proposals to renovate schools, recruit teachers and improve student performance. "As I leave office I don't want America to let its concern about education reform and improvement to abate," he said.
Then, Mr. Clinton offered one more sentimental goodbye.
"It's doubtful I could have become president without the support I received from the people of Chicago and Illinois," he said. "We began way back in 1991, nine years ago, when only my mother thought I could be elected president."

HEADLINE: Consumers Holding Off On Buying Computers 

BYLINE:  By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
CATHERINE DAWKINS had visions of bulky computer boxes dancing in her head when the holidays rolled around last year. Planning to surprise her husband, Peter, with a shiny new 600-megahertz, Pentium-chip desktop, Ms. Dawkins, of East Northport, N.Y., spent part of an early December weekend configuring different hardware setups at the Dell Computer Web site. 
 On Christmas Day, however, Mr. Dawkins unwrapped only a few books and some miniature toy trains from his wife. Although Ms. Dawkins had found a desktop she liked at the Dell site with an attractive payment plan, she ultimately decided to forgo the big purchase. 
 "My husband said, 'That would have been great, but I'm glad you didn't,' " Ms. Dawkins said. "Our computer runs, though not as fast as we'd like, but it felt better to save our pennies rather than go into debt for faster Internet service." 
Unless you are a Tom Hanks character stranded on a Pacific island, it would be pretty hard to miss the rumblings about slagging sales in the personal computer industry -- especially over this past holiday season. Whether because of a sense of economic uncertainty or the fact that so many people already have PC's and don't feel the need to upgrade, Ms. Dawkins was far from alone in her decision. 
"People just aren't buying PC's," said Stephen Baker, vice president of technology products at PC Data, a research firm in Reston, Va. In early January, PC Data released a report saying that retail revenue from PC sales last month had declined almost 30 percent compared with December 1999 revenue. "A lot of PC's were sold over the last couple of years, and there doesn't seem to be a compelling reason to buy right now," Mr. Baker said. 
But does the slowdown mean anything for consumers? Does the fact that people have steered clear of the computer aisles mean exciting deals for those who venture into them? The answer varies, depending on whom you ask. 
As spring spring approaches, computer manufacturers and retailers typically clear their shelves of older inventory to make room for new models, and some analysts say the slow holiday season has resulted in inventory levels that are higher than usual. 
"Inventory rates were much higher than in past holiday seasons because demand was overaccounted for by manufacturers and retailers," said Matt Sargent, senior industry analyst at ARS Inc., a research company in La Jolla, Calif., that tracks retail inventory. "This will prompt a need to clear out a lot of stuff."
PC manufacturers and retailers have been slow to commit to significant price reductions. "We have no price cuts planned at the moment, but we're going to continue to do everything we can to stay competitive," said Brad Williams, a spokesman for Gateway. 
Mr. Williams said that Gateway had lowered prices on its Essential line of entry-level desktops in September and that it would continue to offer a variety of configurations and peripheral bundles. 
Chris Bates, senior marketing manager in the consumer business division at Dell, said the company is offering $100 off its Inspiron notebook line. In December, Dell also cut prices on its Latitude notebooks by as much as 20 percent. 
"We don't speculate beyond that," Mr. Bates said, "but we'll continue to provide the best value and run specials like these. One thing about selling computers directly is that it allows us to be very aggressive with pricing." 
Many computer analysts say shoppers can expect significant price reductions. "Come February, there will probably be some very good deals," said Roger Kay, an analyst at IDC, a technology research company in San Jose, Calif. "The big consumer manufacturers will need to get their 2001 lines out, and they'll get more desperate as they get closer to launch dates." 
But even price cuts of several hundred dollars might not be enough to entice consumers who have purchased computers within the last two or three years. IDC released a report early last month predicting that worldwide PC shipments would grow by only 16.6 percent in 2001, well below the 20 percent and higher averages the industry has seen in the last several years. 
"People are buying accessories for PC's instead of PC's," Mr. Kay said. "I don't think it's a matter of people waiting for the better model or price. It's a matter of not feeling that rich." 
Although consumers may see price cuts in the coming weeks, they are likely to be disguised by rebates and other offers. Peter Christy, research director at Jupiter Communications in New York, said that as in many industries, computer manufacturers are loath to advertise price reductions for fear of starting pricing wars with competitors. 
"Once an advertised price war starts, everyone can lose money," Mr. Christy said. "If they can find things that seem like a call to action to consumers while keeping the prices from going down, then they'll do it." 
One company that is advertising significant price cuts is Apple. On New Year's Day, the company lowered prices on its high-end 500-MHz G4 Server by $1,100, to $3,099 from $4,199. The company also lowered prices by several hundred dollars on its Cube and 500-MHz PowerBook. The cuts don't surprise some Mac users, who say they have come to expect lower prices before the release of newer models. 
Some retailers are hoping that the availability of broadband Internet access will lure computer users back to the stores. Laura Conover, a spokeswoman for The Wiz, said PC sales were strong over the holidays because of the high-speed Internet service The Wiz offered in conjunction with CableVision, its parent company. Circuit City, which offers cable modem access with the computers it sells in 186 stores and D.S.L. access in 141 stores, is planning to expand its high-speed offerings. 
"We are seeing that when people increase the performance of their Internet connection that they look to increase the performance of their computer," said Bill Cimino, a spokesman for Circuit City. "Broadband at retail is just starting to come into its own and this year you'll see it in much greater availability." 
Consumers who did buy computers over the holidays noticed that they got more for their money than in recent years, a trend that manufacturers say will continue. "The price of an average entry-level system in 2000 was sort of equivalent to an intermediate level computer in 1999," said Tom Kehoe, a spokesman for Dell. "As time passes, performance increases and prices decrease." 
David Lown, an investment banker in Manhattan, said, for example, that the 600-MHz Pentium computer system he bought his sister in December was both more powerful and about $450 cheaper than the 500-MHz system he bought his parents in December 1999. 
"I think the values increased at a higher percentage than they normally have over the years," Mr. Lown said, adding that he might have waited longer to buy his sister's computer because he believed prices would drop further this winter. "But when it comes to your sister or your parents and Christmas, you end up doing what's right."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In stores like The Wiz in midtown Manhattan, customers are shopping for computer accessories, but seldom for computer systems. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)
