HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS; 
Book Clubs With a Mission

BYLINE:  By Martin Arnold 

 BODY:
In a book of essays that he compiled and edited and that will go on sale next week, Tavis Smiley, the black television and radio talk show host and commentator, admonished blacks to tell themselves: "I must find someone Black for this job. I must find someplace Black to spend this money." This being a column about books, the question is, How does this challenge relate to books?
 Well, more than 150,000 people have joined a new black book club in just over a year, an almost colossal example of people responding quickly when someone meets a perceived need, in this case the desire to read fiction and nonfiction books relevant to their experiences. Clearly Mr. Smiley is onto something with his new book, "How to Make Black America Better" (Doubleday). 
 Looking through publishing's retrospective scope, this is probably not as surprising as it appears, for one of the more invigorating happenings in the industry in recent years has been the emergence of black readers as an economic force. Or, more precisely, the recognition that blacks are such a power. There are, for instance, five new or relatively new imprints in major publishing houses devoted to fiction and nonfiction by black writers on black subjects.
As important, in the fall of 1999, Bookspan, the largest book club organization in North America, started the Black Expressions Book Club. Expecting an initial 5,000 applications, it received 15,000, and now the club has grown to 150,000 members, according to Seth Radwell, president of BooksOnline.com, the Bookspan subsidiary in charge of all its online operations and its new book clubs. (Bookspan is owned jointly by Time Warner and Bertelsmann and has more than 40 book clubs, including the Literary Guild and Book-of-the-Month Club.)
Black Expressions also has a Web site, www.blackexpressions.com, which attracts about 150,000 visitors a month. The book club publishes 17 catalogs a year, one each month plus special issues. It is a traditional "negative option" club; its members automatically receive a selection each month, which they can decline, although they must buy four books every two years, at discounts from 20 to 50 percent.
The club's editor, Monica Harris, said, "We were serving an underserved market. We've made known to readers the existence of books they may not have heard about through traditional media or through normal publishing advertising." Each catalog has 24 pages.
"We are trying to make it more like a magazine," Ms. Harris said, "with author interviews, excerpts from books and guest editors and contributors." Unfortunately, as strong as Black Expressions is, the appeal of black book clubs has not yet been wide enough to allow for much diversity.
Thus the Black Literary Club, founded in 1994 to promote more serious nonfiction and literary fiction, is in search of a partner to keep it in business. It publishes a catalog four times a year, and members, about 2,000, are under no obligation to buy. Its president, Annette Leach, said the club needed 10,000 to 20,000 members to survive.
"The numbers are out there," she said, "but we probably need to become part of a publishing group to reach our target audience, especially for writers of histories and serious fiction." Which shows, if nothing else, that for the middle class, black or white, commercial and mass market sell better than literary.
There are some online services that specialize in books for blacks, in addition to the one operated by Black Expressions. The most successful is the African American Literature Book Club (www.aalbc.com), which was started in 1997 and now gets between 1 million and 1.3 million visits a month, said its founder, Troy Johnson. "We sell books, build Web sites for authors, run author interviews," he said. "We promote books because we like them, not just because they're best sellers." The club is affiliated with the Barnes & Noble Web site.
Is there a downside to these clubs and Web sites specializing in black writing? Mostly no, although one literary agent had a reservation. "I'm not sure it wouldn't take customers out of black bookstores," said Denise Stinson, who is also founder of a new black imprint for Warner Books, Walk Worthy Books, specializing in Christian fiction and nonfiction. "There's substantially fewer possibilities to sell black books. I'm not sure too many people will shop in both, clubs and stores, and if a quarter of the people who buy through clubs went to black bookstores, that would be very nice." She was, she said, just raising the question. Black Expressions was, after all, the first outside supporter for her publishing venture, she said.
Max Rodriguez, the publisher and editor of QBR: the Black Book Review, said that "a book club validates the strength of the reading public it serves; it means there's a sufficient and active buying power, and it's a very big push toward establishing African-American readers as a viable market for publishers."
Janet Hill, an editor who acquires and edits hardcover African-American books for Doubleday and heads Harlem Moon, a new black imprint at Random House Inc., said, "It's too early to tell if black bookstores will be hurt, but the clubs are really great for blacks who don't live near a black bookstore."
Mainstream book clubs feature only one or two black books in each catalog; the black clubs give more of a choice, covering small presses, university presses and self-published books, said Anita Diggs, the director of One World Books, a Random House Inc. imprint.
Of course black bookstores, like other independent and specialty bookstores, offer services like community meeting centers, book signings and space for readers' groups. Book clubs, on or off the Web, are not apt to change that.
There's little doubt that in the last several years many positive things have taken place in book publishing for black Americans. The next leap forward, of course, will be the appointment of a black publisher -- the person who actually writes the checks -- to head a mainstream publishing house. But that's the subject for another column.

HEADLINE: Essay; 
California Power Failure

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
In the past decade, California has become the most Democratic state in the nation. It has a Democratic governor, two liberal Democratic senators, and both houses of its legislature are firmly in Democratic hands. Not for nothing is it called the Left Coast. 
 Then why, Californians now ask themselves, is their state the most troubled in the nation? Bad enough that Hollywood's writers are preparing to strike; worse that speculators in Silicon Valley start-ups are watching their stack of chips dwindle; worst of all is the unforeseen electricity shock that is making the state's hair stand on end. 
 The price of electricity is soaring, yet the big electric utilities are threatened by bankruptcy. Who's to blame? 
The chosen villain: deregulation. As soon as cruel market forces were allowed to work, cry liberal voices, those heartless capitalists drove up prices. Bring back the cool, calm days of inefficient monopolies under government control. 
But in fact, the first villain is botched deregulation -- not as bad as in Russia, but 'tis enough, 'twill do. 
California's politicians deregulated halfway, which is the worst way: wholesale prices were freed from controls, but retail prices were not. Consumers remained seemingly protected, but the utility companies -- which foolishly thought wholesale prices would go down forever -- were enabled to buy on the spot market. Legislators believing they were protecting consumers forbade long-term contracts, which are hedges against sudden price fluctuations.
This halfway dereg ran smack into the inexorable law of supply and demand. The good times of the 90's sharply increased demand for electric power. But all sorts of obstacles were put in the way of increasing the supply of that power.
Result: upward pressure on prices, calls for rationing, utilities going broke, government intervention that frightens off private investment, and the danger of an economic Big One in the state responsible for 13 percent of the nation's product.
The unspoken issue in this bastion of liberalism is "nimby" -- the real villain in the current supply crisis, that says "not in my backyard" to power plants. In San Jose, epicenter of the computer industry's drain on electric power, New Economy voters recently rejected a new power facility that offended their aesthetic sensibilities. Red tape and purple rhetoric are the reasons no major power station has been built in California in 10 years.
Contrary to popular belief, electricity does not come from the socket in the wall. The steady flow of low-cost power comes from factories that convert energy from other sources into the stuff that makes toasters pop, air-conditioners wheeze and computers beep. Unless energy is dug up and produced in real places and transmitted through real lines, nothing comes out of the wall.
Environmentalists recoil in horror at suggestions of nuclear power, now a safe and clean source of electricity, or the use of cleaned-up coal to lower the price of natural gas that generates it. Reducing pollution sensibly is laudable, but clean-air extremists become local heroes without telling constituents the danger of loss of Intel jobs and cheap electricity's household convenience. 
The answer is not re-regulation, nor more halfwayism, nor federal bailout. When Gov. Gray Davis of California raced to Washington, D.C., to ask for wholesale price controls, he found Bill Clinton too busy carving up Jerusalem to mediate; Clinton-appointed federal energy bureaucrats offer only palliatives, with photo op to follow. 
Davis's panicked proposal to build state-owned plants (in Nevada? On the moon?) and his threat to seize the assets of "price gougers" may please some new breed of dot-communists. But such populist pap destroys private incentive to invest and is hardly the path for a presidential hopeful professing to be a centrist. 
After short-term action to alleviate hardship caused by past and present political-industrial blindness, our biggest state should avoid regressing into more stultifying regulation and instead get out of the way of stimulating supply. 
Why do I sound like a reformed drunk on this? Because I wrote the Nixon speech imposing wage and price controls. They never work in peacetime. Never.

HEADLINE: Wholesale Inventories Grew 0.4% in November 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
Inventories at wholesalers grew in November as unsold autos, paper goods and computer parts accumulated on docks and in warehouses, government figures showed today.
 Wholesale stockpiles rose 0.4 percent, matching the October increase, the Commerce Department reported. Sales were unchanged after a 0.1 percent decline in October. 
 Slower consumer demand, which is causing inventories to grow and leading to sluggish manufacturing, signals that the economy's expansion is limping toward its 10th anniversary in April. Automakers have cut output as stockpiles of vehicles on dealer lots have risen. Altera, the computer chip maker, and Bowater, the biggest United States newsprint maker, recently announced cuts in production.
Slower growth prompted the Federal Reserve to cut its benchmark overnight interest rate earlier this month to give the economy a boost.
As sales slumped and stockpiles rose, the inventory-to-sales ratio, which measures the time goods sit at wholesalers, held at 1.31 months in November, the government reported. That is the highest since 1.32 month in April 1999, figures showed.
Wholesale stockpiles of electrical equipment rose 1 percent in November after October's 2.7 percent increase. Those inventories are 15.7 percent higher than they were in November 1999, government figures showed.
Wholesale inventories of all durable goods like imported automobiles and electrical equipment rose 0.3 percent, the same as October. Sales of durable goods rose 0.1 percent after falling 0.3 percent the previous month.
Inventories of nondurable goods like food and paper rose 0.5 percent after a 0.6 percent increase in October. Sales of nondurable goods fell 0.1 percent after a 0.2 percent increase in October.
Wholesale stockpiles of petroleum products rose 5.9 percent after a 2.5 percent increase in October. Inventories of food were up 1.5 percent in November after rising 0.7 percent in October. Drug inventories at wholesalers increased 1.8 percent after rising 1.3 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
New Interest in Technology Lifts Nasdaq in Late Rally

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technology stocks rallied yesterday as investors shifted out of defensive old-economy shares in a bet that cuts in interest rates would revitalize the high-technology sector.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 82.88 points, or 3.4 percent, to 2,524.18, as late buying sent the index up about 2.2 percent year to date.
 "There is the feeling that techs suffered a great deal, and you take your profits in the old economy and move into the new economy," said Milton Ezrati, a senior economist and strategist at Lord Abbett. "There is a feeling that because these stocks are down so much, valuations are more reasonable than people have seen in years and that is a tremendous temptation." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.72 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,604.27. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 12.47 points, nearly 1 percent, to 1,313.27. 
J. P. Morgan Chase, up $2.25, to $50.94, offered support to the blue-chips after Merrill Lynch called its stock "deeply undervalued." But capping the Dow's rally was a decline in defensive sectors like drugs, energy, retailing and manufacturing.
Investors snatched up what they saw as bargains in the beleaguered high-technology sector, including the shares of software companies like Microsoft, Oracle and Veritas Software.
Telecommunications issues, including WorldCom and Nextel Communications, and computer makers like Dell Computer, also gained, as did fiber optics companies, including JDS Uniphase.
"Some on Wall Street believe that you have to look at the glass half full, and take a positive outlook," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist for Weatherly Securities. "Clearly there could be some concern as we go through the earnings season, but you have to look forward to what will happen 6 or 12 months from now," he said.
But Nasdaq's advance, which came on heavy trading of 2.4 billion issues, was far from smooth. Cisco Systems, one of Nasdaq's most highly valued companies, fell more than 8 percent, to an intraday low of $33.64, but recovered late in the day, to finish down 88 cents, at $36.25. Traders said Cisco's stock gyrated after comments from its chief executive, John Chambers, who told a technology conference in Scottsdale, Ariz., that the current quarter was "a little bit more challenging" than expected six weeks ago because of a slowdown in capital spending. --------------------

Treasuries Lower
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as sales of more than $30 billion in federal agency and corporate debt this week sapped demand for lower-yielding government bonds and notes.
The 10-year note fell 28/32, to a price of 104 30/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.09 percent from 4.98 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1/32, to 110 31/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.49 percent from 5.43 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Uruguay's Chief Is Frank (and Frankly Insulting) 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay Jan. 9 

 BODY:
At 73, President Jorge Batlle likes to say he is in the Carnelli Station of life -- that is the second to last stop on the railroad tracks into Montevideo. So he has nothing to lose by speaking his mind. 
 And speak his mind he does, challenging all the taboos and sacred cows of Uruguayan politics in an impetuous style that can be charming but also shocking and insulting. 
 Eleven months into the first year of his five-year term, Mr. Batlle (pronounced BAH-zhay) is the first civilian president since the military gave up power 15 years ago to promise to search for the remains of dissidents who disappeared in the 1970's and 1980's in the wake of a nasty urban guerrilla war. He stunned the army by publicly saluting the mother of a disappeared dissident in the presidential office and pledging to take her orders. 
When Gen. Manuel Fernandez, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, suggested in a newspaper interview last year that the armed forces might eventually have to intervene in political affairs again to combat leftist extremists, Mr. Batlle fired him immediately. 
The Uruguayan president has tackled the cumbersome welfare state with plans to infuse private capital into the government telephone company and allow private imports of natural gas while using his bully pulpit to challenge Uruguayans to begin to rely more on themselves and embrace the new global economy. Defying reported death threats, he has begun to challenge powerful smugglers by overhauling the customs service.
And in recent months, Mr. Batlle has taken his audaciousness onto the world stage by becoming the first leader of a Latin American country to call for the legalization of drugs.
"I don't know if drugs kill more than alcohol or tobacco but I know they kill thousands on the battlefields of Colombia," he said in an interview in which he argued that legalization would lower drug prices and cut into the profits of the cartels. Asked what his solution for the long-drawn out Colombian civil war was, he answered, "Legalize drugs and bring Colombia into Nafta," the North American Free Trade Agreement that includes the United States, Canada and Mexico. 
Coming from a tiny cattle-producing country of 3.2 million people, Mr. Batlle's ideas are not likely to carry much weight beyond Uruguay. But he stands out in a continent where weak, uncreative leadership has become the rule in most countries over the last few years.
And at a time when Latin Americans are increasingly cynical about their governments, Mr. Batlle has a habit of driving his own car and, at red lights, shocking fellow drivers by rolling down his window and asking for their opinions. Despite a deep recession, an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease and a severe drought, his popularity ratings are better than 50 percent in a country known to be hypercritical of its leaders.
"I am the way I am and I am not about to change," Mr. Batlle said in an interview in which he seemed to bask in his idiosyncrasies by banging his fist on the desk, tossing a cigar across the room to a friend and occasionally making points by switching from Spanish to English in a playfully exaggerated British accent. (He speaks four foreign languages fluently, and a smattering of Yiddish learned from his childhood nanny.) 
Mr. Batlle, whose ancestors came from the Catalonia region of Spain, can get away with a lot not only because of his age, but because of his pedigree. His great-grandfather was president, as were his great-uncle, who founded Latin America's first and most expansive social welfare state, and his father. He was groomed to be president as a teenager, when his father, President Luis Batlle Berres, dispatched him to meet foreign ambassadors and represent him in other official functions in the late 1940's. His mother, who is still alive, picked out the presidential residence that he lives in today. 
Four times Mr. Batlle ran for president and lost in large part because of his habit of shooting off his mouth. But he finally eked out a victory in a runoff in November 1999.
His first major initiative was to help track down a granddaughter of the Argentine poet Juan Gelman who was born in captivity after her pregnant mother was abducted by the Argentine military and was then adopted by an Uruguayan family. Mr. Gelman did the detective work to find his granddaughter, and then Mr. Battle helped out by personally pleading with her to take a blood test for DNA identification, which showed that she is in all probability related to Mr. Gelman. 
Mr. Batlle appointed a peace commission to locate about 160 disappeared people, and has promised to take the results personally to their families. "I felt this was something the country had to confront with a clear voice," he said, comparing the issue of the disappeared to "a splinter in your foot that won't kill you but impedes your ability to walk."
Luz Ibarburu de Recagno, 76, a leader of the Group of Mothers and Family Members of the Detained-Disappeared whose son went missing in Argentina in 1976, gave Mr. Batlle cautious praise. "You don't need to do much to be better than our previous presidents, who would not even meet with us," she said. 
Congresswoman Margarita Percovich, a member of the leftist Frente Amplio opposition, said, "He's opening doors on subjects that were taboo in the past and that is good for the country." But she added, "He sometimes acts and speaks too fast and impulsively without reaching consensus first."
Mr. Batlle can also get carried away with his own glibness and say things that can be hurtful. While talking about his family history, and how his ancestors came from the Spanish fishing town and resort of Sitges, he said: "It was a better place when they lived there. Now it is full of gay Germans." 
Challenged to explain his remark, he said: "I prefer normality. I say what I believe and I am not a hypocrite. In a few words, I like women."
Told that he would certainly receive a lot of mail for his remarks, he answered: "And I will respond. I don't hide my opinions."

HEADLINE: Fort McMurray Journal; 
For a Big Job, Big Trucks and Women to Use Them

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta 

 BODY:
Driving the world's biggest dump truck to and from the world's biggest electric shovel might be a dream job for little boys the world over. But here was Valerie A. Wagar, gold earrings and fingernail polish in place, gripping the wheel of her Caterpillar 797B one recent afternoon as each shovel scoop dumped 100 tons of sand laced with oil into her load box.
 From her gently swaying cab, she checked her three-foot-tall side mirrors and her rear television camera, then eased her load of nearly a million pounds through an open pit mine here, controlling 3,400 horsepower with a tap on the accelerator. 
 "Heavy haulers are the best," she shouted as her 12-foot-high tires left tracks streaked with oozing oil. "You get to see a little scenery, you have wheels." 
Asked if it was a bit odd for a 46-year-old mother of two to be driving a monster dump truck that rises five stories above the ground, Ms. Wagar, a former legal secretary, replied: "If it was in another city, people would be fascinated. But this is normal for Fort McMurray."
Increasingly, 21st-century Rosie the Riveters are commonplace here, working for Syncrude Canada Ltd., the world's largest producer of oil from oil sands. Left behind by a vast inland sea, northern Alberta's oil sands here typically contain about 12 percent oil. The sands are mined and the oil is separated with hot water.
With a new oil boom convulsing this northern frontier city, women now make up a quarter of Syncrude's heavy equipment operators.
With mining becoming increasingly high tech -- as evidenced by Ms. Wagar's air-conditioned truck cab with classical piano music on the CD player -- brains are taking precedence over brawn, said Jim E. Carter, the company president. Reflecting the transformation in the work force here, a 15-minute documentary film on oil production shown at the Oil Sands Discovery Center, a regional museum, does not show a single woman's face. 
What is behind the change is an acute labor shortage as Alberta, Canada's energy province, throws itself in high gear to meet the growing American demand for oil and gas. Long the largest supplier of natural gas to the United States, Canada supplanted Saudi Arabia in the first 10 months of 2000 as its largest supplier of oil and petroleum products.
The boom is greatest in Fort McMurray, one of Canada's fastest growing cities, with a population most recently clocked at 42,000. In this frozen wilderness, a five-hour drive north of Edmonton, the provincial capital, workers arriving here confront the nation's third-most-expensive housing market -- after Vancouver and Toronto.
In a reversal of Canada's chronic south-flowing brain drain, Alberta has attracted 80,000 migrants over the last three years, some from as far away as Texas and Chile. Since the newcomers are not coming for low-paying service jobs, Fort McMurray's city pools were on shortened hours last summer for lack of lifeguards. Every eatery, from the Oil Can Tavern to the Boomtown, has posted help-wanted signs. 
To house workers, Suncor Energy Inc., an oil producer in the throes of a $1.8 billion expansion, opened the Borealis Lodge last spring, a 1,500-room labor camp that the company bills as "Canada's largest hotel." Last summer, parked buses stretched in milelong lines, waiting to shuttle shift workers to the camp. Traffic jams became so great that the oil companies helped pay to build another 25-mile access highway from town to the oil-sand production plants.
In 2000, Alberta's economy expanded by about 6 percent, and the energy-based boom has prompted grumbling in the rest of Canada about the province's "blue-eyed sheiks." 
Energy companies, flush with record revenues from last year's increases in oil and gas prices, have announced exploration and production budgets for this year running into the billions of dollars.
But the labor shortage threatens to keep drilling contractors from meeting their goal of increasing the number of gas wells drilled in Western Canada this year by 44 percent, to almost 10,000. Desperate for 3,000 apprentice roughnecks, contractors have advertised in 250 rural newspapers across Canada, posting their new toll-free number: 1-800-RIG-WORK.
Contractors prefer rural workers who know how to weld, fix machinery, and work outside in the cold. Here in Canada's northernmost city of substantial size, winters regularly record temperatures of 40 degrees below zero. But, working against employers, modern Canada now is more urbanized than the United States. So the companies are turning to previously overlooked groups, luring elderly workers out of retirement and setting goals to double aboriginal employment. 
In Fort McMurray, the boom is fueled by technological advances that have lowered extraction costs from the vast oil-sands deposits to around $10 a barrel, slightly above local costs for discovering and producing oil the conventional way, with wells. 
"You have to mine two tons of material to make a barrel of oil," Mr. Carter, Syncrude's president, explained in an interview here. "Because we have economies of scale, we use the largest scale equipment you can get."
By working with Caterpillar, Syncrude and Suncor dreamed up what some people here call "Franken-trucks" -- $3 million dump trucks that can carry 380 tons, or six times the loads of the wimpy mining trucks of the 1970's. 
Fully loaded, Syncrude officials say, a Caterpillar 797 weighs as much as two DC-10 jets. Last August, when Syncrude opened its new Aurora mine here, part of a $5.3 billion expansion, a 797 drove past a reviewing stand with a hand-painted "Just Opened" sign on the back. In a flash of mining humor, the truck dragged empty oil drums behind instead of newlyweds' traditional cans.
As if Gulliver had been transported to the Canadian North, Ms. Wagar barely ducks her head to walk below an axle of her idling truck, checking the oil and brakes. With each tire weighing six tons, a new set of six costs $140,000. Tire changing takes place in the garage, a building that looks like an aircraft hangar.
Hoping to make truck drivers behave like gentle giants, the mining companies teach new recruits to scan terrain with their two external television cameras before engaging the automatic transmission. In a safety video, a 797 crushes a passenger car like a bug.
"For the girls here, the opportunity to operate a heavy hauler means money, excitement," Ms. Wagar said before driving off in what she calls "a small house on wheels." Noting that one of her sons operates heavy equipment for Syncrude while the other cooks in a restaurant, she said, "I know it's not for everyone, but I wanted to have the opportunity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Valerie A. Wagar, a former legal secretary, now drives a dump truck five stories high in the mining of oil sands in Fort McMurray, Alberta. "Heavy haulers are the best," she said. "You get to see a little scenery." (Ted Shehinski for The New York Times) Map of Alberta, Canada showing location of Fort McMurray: Because of an oil boom, Fort McMurray, Alberta, is growing fast.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Judge's Ruling on School Financing 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from yesterday's ruling by Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court requiring the state to change its formula for financing schools: 
 The court holds that the education provided New York City students is so deficient that it falls below the constitutional floor set by the education article of the New York State Constitution. The court also finds that the state's actions are a substantial cause of this constitutional violation. 
 With respect to plaintiffs' claim under Title VI's implementing regulations, the court finds that the state school funding system has an adverse and disparate impact on minority public school children and that this disparate impact is not adequately justified by any reason related to education. . . . 
A capable and productive citizen doesn't simply show up for jury service. Rather she is capable of serving impartially on trials that may require learning unfamiliar facts and concepts and new ways to communicate and reach decisions with her fellow jurors. To be sure, the jury is in some respects an anti-elitist institution where life experience and practical intelligence can be more important than formal education. Nonetheless, jurors may be called on to decide complex matters that require the verbal, reasoning, math, science and socialization skills that should be imparted in public schools. Jurors today must determine questions of fact concerning DNA evidence, statistical analyses and convoluted financial fraud, to name only three topics.
Defendants argue that passage of the Regents Competency Tests -- which measure the reading, writing and mathematic competency required of eighth to ninth graders -- is a sufficient indicator that a student is capable of voting or serving on a jury. . . . The court was not persuaded by this testimony. . . . Beyond voting and jury service, productive citizenship implies engagement and contribution in the economy as well as in public life. . . . An emphasis on the economic needs of society requires that this court look at the current and projected labor needs of the state of New York in general and the needs of New York City in particular. However, the labor needs of the city and state must be balanced with the needs of high school graduates. For example, while the greatest expansion in the local labor market might be composed of low-level service jobs, such jobs frequently do not pay a living wage. A sound basic education would give New York City's high school graduates the opportunity to move beyond such work. 
Poverty, race, ethnicity and immigration status are not in themselves determinative of student achievement. Demography is not destiny. The amount of melanin in a student's skin, the home country of her antecedents, the amount of money in the family bank account, are not the inexorable determinants of academic success. The evidence introduced at trial demonstrates that these negative life experiences can be overcome by public schools with sufficient resources well deployed. It is the clear policy of the state, as formulated by the Regents and S.E.D. State Education Department , that all children can attain the substantive knowledge and master the skills expected of high school graduates. The court finds that the city's at-risk children are capable of seizing the opportunity for a sound basic education if they are given sufficient resources. 
Even if the state aid formulas were designed to allocate education aid more fairly, it would be difficult to change the orientation of state education funding because any annual increase in state aid has historically been divided without reference to the formulas. The evidence at trial demonstrated that the formulas and grant categories are not allowed to operate neutrally, but rather are manipulated during the state's annual budget negotiations by state officials to produce consistent funding allocations of aid increases among school districts around the state. 
Focusing then entirely on the state component of education funding, the court finds that from 1994-95 to 1999-2000, New York City has consistently received less total state aid than its percentage share of enrolled students. In those years, New York has approximately 37 percent of the state's enrolled students and has received a percentage of total state aid ranging from 33.98 percent to 35.65 percent. This is evidence of disparate impact. 
That said, the court's deference to the coordinate branches of state government is contingent on these branches taking effective and timely action to address the problems set forth in this opinion. The parlous state of the city's schools demands no less. The court will not hesitate to intervene if it finds that the legislative and/or executive branches fail to devise and implement necessary reform.

HEADLINE: THE RULING ON THE SCHOOLS: THE PLAINTIFF; 
Eight Years and a Lawsuit Later, Better News to Report

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Eight years ago, Robert Jackson, father of three, product of New York City public schools, president of Community School Board 6 and lifelong renegade, simply got fed up.
 Every year, he said, school board members would meet with the schools chancellor and his representatives, who would tell them their share of the latest budget cut. "One year it was $1.5 million, the next $1.8 million," he recalled. "As school board president, I was always the bearer of bad news. One year, I just said, 'Enough.' " 
 Mr. Jackson went to Michael A. Rebell, then the lawyer for Board 6, in Washington Heights, and asked him to file a lawsuit that would stanch the hemorrhaging and turn the public schools into places where Mr. Jackson could ask his neighbors to send their children without feeling guilty.
Mr. Rebell was reluctant, but "this man would not take no for an answer," he said of Mr. Jackson yesterday.
Mr. Rebell took the case in 1992, and they sought out Norman Fruchter, then an outspoken member of School Board 15 in Brooklyn Heights, and Noreen Connell, head of the Educational Priorities Panel, a watchdog group, and formed Campaign for Fiscal Equity. With grant money, they hired a small staff and another lawyer, Robert Hughes. In 1993, they went to court.
Yesterday, Mr. Jackson was the bearer of good news, as Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court ruled that the state's financing system for public education violated New York's Constitution by failing to provide children with a sound, basic education.
The victory probably comes too late for Mr. Jackson's three daughters. After attending public schools, Saadiya, 25, is a medical student at Case Western Reserve University in Ohio, and Asmahan, 20, is a junior at the State University at Buffalo. The youngest, Sumaya, 14, went to Public School and Intermediate School 187, in Washington Heights, but switched to the Dwight School, a private school on the Upper West Side, this year, in the ninth grade. She is a dancer with Alvin Ailey's company, "but my wife and I believe in academics," Mr. Jackson said, and wanted a school that offered things public schools did not, like Latin and small classes.
Mr. Jackson, 50, a slender, bespectacled man with a salt-and-pepper mustache, was born in Harlem and raised in Harlem and the Bronx. He attended P.S. 86 in Washington Heights, then P.S. 146 and Junior High School 120 in the Bronx. 
His mother, Zelma Jackson, was African-American. His father, Eddie Chu, was a Chinese immigrant who commuted home on weekends from his job as a waiter on Long Island. 
As a child, Mr. Jackson hawked papers in Harlem. If he brought back unsold papers, he said, the newsstand owner would tear off a piece and make him eat it.
He followed his older brother, Raymond, to Benjamin Franklin High School in the Bronx, where Raymond was a track star. Mr. Jackson was a mediocre runner. But the coach, Irving Goldberg, thrust an application for Upward Bound into his hand and told him to return it the next day. Upward Bound, a federal program, helped him get to the State University of New York College at New Paltz, where he met his wife, Faika, a student from Tanzania. After college, he investigated unemployment fraud for the State Labor Department, then took a job with the Public Employees Federation. He is now director of field services for the union.
His foray into education began when his wife volunteered him for the Parents Association at P.S./I.S. 187. He was elected in 1986 to the school board, on which he still serves.
At a Midtown news conference yesterday at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, the law firm that eventually stepped in on the case pro bono, the lawyers, Mr. Rebell and Joseph F. Wayland, a partner at Simpson Thacher, took the spotlight while Mr. Jackson stood off in the crowd, sipping a soft drink. 
When it was over, he picked up his daughter from school. "Did we win?" Sumaya asked. "Yeah, we won," Mr. Jackson said. "We won big."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Jackson, right, who initiated the lawsuit over school financing while a school board president, hugged Richard Beattie, chairman of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, the law firm that handled the case. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: State Officials Are Faulted On Anti-Tobacco Programs 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Only six states spend even the minimum amount on programs to prevent and stop smoking that is recommended by the Centers for Dsease Control and Prevention, the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, an advocacy group in Washington, says in a report to be released today.
 A majority of states spend less than half of what the centers advises, the report says, while at least two, Michigan and North Dakota, support no antismoking programs at all with their money from a $206 billion national tobacco settlement. 
 The surgeon general has sharply criticized state lawmakers for neglecting prevention and spending too much on programs unrelated to smoking. 
"We're going to pay sooner or later if we allow children to start smoking," said the surgeon general, Dr. David Satcher. "The tobacco settlement funds represent an opportunity that we've never had before to save lives, and we're missing it."
Dr. Satcher and numerous tobacco opponents worry that as the economy slows, lawmakers may use settlement money to offset reductions in tax revenue. Montana and Maine have already begun cutting back on efforts to prevent smoking and applying the money elsewhere. Virginia may use part of its settlement money to help phase out a property tax on cars.
"This is definitely something we're going to see played out through all of the states as the economic downturn affects state revenues," said Lee Dixon, health policy director for the National Conference of State Legislatures. 
Under the 1998 agreement with tobacco companies, states are free to spend their settlement money as they see fit. Most use it to offset Medicaid expenses, support children's programs or improve education, but the payments have also gone to run boot camps for juvenile offenders in Alabama, build levees in North Dakota and provide tax cuts in Illinois and Connecticut.
Over all, less than 10 percent of the nearly $8.2 billion in settlement money allocated by states in fiscal years 2000 and 2001 has gone to combat smoking, less than half of the percentage that the disease control centers recommends. 
Dr. Satcher predicted that if all states had aggressive antismoking programs like those in California and Massachusetts, smoking rates could be halved in a decade.
Cigarette sales have been falling by 1 percent to 2 percent a year since the mid-1990's and dropped sharply in 1999 when tobacco companies raised prices to an average of $3 a pack. But sales have since returned to their old rate of decline.
The centers estimates the cost of treating tobacco-related illnesses at more than $50 billion a year, and states bear at least $6 billion of that in Medicaid expenses alone.
A 1999 study by M.I.T. found that antismoking campaigns cut health care costs in Massachusetts by $85 million a year.
But in some states, money for to fight smoking is increasingly scarce.
The National Conference of State Legislatures reports that state revenues are increasing 3.5 percent this year on average, down from the 5 percent growth many states expected just months ago and the smallest increase in at least three years.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
OPEC Faces Balancing Act As It Seeks to Cut Output
Next week, leaders of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting in Vienna will face the delicate task of setting production levels that keep prices high enough to sustain their economies without helping place the United States into recession.
 OPEC officials have announced they will sharply curtail petroleum output, although the size of the cut will not be known until next week. The Clinton administration, meanwhile, is scrambling to limit the damage, with the energy secretary, Bill Richardson, planning a round of talks with key OPEC officials in Europe and the Persian Gulf. Page A1. 

Rules Planned to Curb Tax Shelters
The Treasury Department proposed rules to take some of the financial incentives away from the lawyers, accountants and investment bankers who promote abusive tax shelters and from the companies that use them. C4.

FedEx and Postal Service in Deal
FedEx and the United Postal Service reached an agreement under which FedEx will transport express and priority mail for the post office and be allowed to place collection boxes at postal branches nationwide. The post office will pay FedEx about $6.3 billion over the next seven years for the service, which is scheduled to begin in August. The new agreement should provide savings of more than $1 billion a year, the post office said. Shares of FedEx declined 36 cents, to $41.91. C4.

Motorola Earnings Decline 41%
Motorola said that its fourth-quarter operating earnings fell 41 percent, in line with estimates, as higher sales failed to offset an increase in manufacturing costs, an announcement that underscores the challenges faced by large manufacturers of mobile telephones. C6.

Nasdaq Rises at Expense of Dow
Technology stocks rallied as investors shifted out of defensive old-economy shares in a bet that cuts in interest rates would revitalize the high-technology sector. The Nasdaq composite index gained 82.88 points, or 3.4 percent, to 2,524.18. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.72 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,604.27. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 12.47 points, or 1 percent, to 1,313.27. C10.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved the Nasdaq stock market's plan to centralize display of its best stock quotes. C4.

Bush Faces Crucial Move on Tax Cut
Faced with political and economic risks on both sides of the argument, President-elect George W. Bush will have to make a critical decision in the next few weeks about whether to seek quick action in Congress on a tax cut, Republican leaders said. A20.

Miller to Join Marsh & McLennan
Heidi Miller, who made headlines twice last year by quitting chief financial officer posts, first at Citigroup and then at Priceline.com, will join Marsh & McLennan. Ms. Miller, 47, considered one of the most powerful women on Wall Street, will be vice chairwoman of the company's flagship business, Marsh, the world's largest insurance broker. C2.

NBC Recruits Winner of 'Survivor'
In its effort to catch up in reality programming, NBC has turned to Richard Hatch, the winner of the biggest reality hit so far, "Survivor," as part of an attempt to create an American version of a British game show. C8.

Leno Agrees to a 5-Year Extension
Jay Leno agreed to a new contract with NBC that will extend his tenure as host of the "Tonight" show for five years. E13.

Higher Prices Likely in Power Crisis
The reason for the California electricity crisis can be summed up in four words: demand grew, supply didn't. Because supply responds slowly, the only way to alleviate the crisis in the short run is to manage demand more effectively. This means that prices will have to rise. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: It's Buying Time Again; 
With Rivals Regrouping, Forstmann Prepares to Pounce

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Theodore J. Forstmann was planning to spend the winter in Los Angeles as usual, avoiding the New York weather and relaxing away from the Fifth Avenue office of the leveraged buyout firm bearing his name.
 He just canceled his vacation plans. 
 "I told my partners, 'I'm going to be here. I want to see every memo. I'm going to be back running this thing,' " Mr. Forstmann said at the end of a long day recently, his necktie loosened as he slouched in a chair surrounded by memorabilia of one of his biggest deals, the turnaround of the Gulfstream Corporation. From his corner office on the 44th floor of the General Motors building in Midtown Manhattan, he has a striking view of Central Park. 
"When you're not seeing anything interesting, there's nothing to run on a day-to-day basis," he shrugged. "Now, there's a lot going on."
Indeed, for most leveraged buyout firms on the make there is almost too much going on, most of it bad: the stock market is falling, a recession may be looming and the junk bond market has nearly evaporated. But for Mr. Forstmann, the billionaire chairman of Forstmann Little, now is prime time.
The credit market, which usually provides the debt that most of the big leveraged buyout firms need to finance their takeovers of public companies and some that are already private, has all but dried up. Except for Mr. Forstmann's special kitty.
While most of his competitors, like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, were buying into many highly leveraged telecommunication and technology investments that went bad, Mr. Forstmann was squirreling away his money -- over $4 billion -- in a special subordinated-debt fund and his more traditional equity fund, waiting for a moment like this to pounce. While just about everybody else is down, he is feeling up.
"There's a lot of shots on goal," he said gleefully. "Lots of meetings to have, things to investigate." He demurs, though, when asked exactly what he plans to buy. "There are a couple of deals in here right now," is about all he is willing to say.
Not talking comes hard for Mr. Forstmann. Indeed, he is known for rarely missing an opportunity to trumpet his own successes or take a dig at his rivals. And there, at least, he remains in character. "I can only surmise that these other guys are shut down," he said. "Investment bankers, when they call here," he adds, "they say, 'You're the only one we're calling.' "
This is familiar territory for Mr. Forstmann. A decade ago, junk bonds were all but unavailable, bank debt was tight, the prices of companies were falling, and almost no one could put together a leveraged buyout -- except Mr. Forstmann. As recession loomed, he bought the General Instrument Corporation and the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation for a combined $2.6 billion; less than 10 years later, he sold them both for a total profit of $10 billion. 
Not all of Mr. Forstmann's investments have been home runs, but his slugging average seems to be higher than his rivals'. He boasts that his firm has had an annual average rate of return of 55 percent a year on its equity funds and in excess of 20 percent on its debt funds since he founded the firm in 1978. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, a much bigger firm that has invested much more capital over the years, has averaged an annual return of 24 percent over its 24-year lifetime.
Mr. Forstmann may be ready to count his rivals out, but they are not. Henry Kravis, a founding partner of Kohlberg Kravis, while acknowledging that last year was not a particularly good one, sees himself as on the prowl as well.
Last year "was a dismal year for many private equity firms, and the reason for that was they had the wrong focus," Mr. Kravis told a group of investors last week at a conference sponsored by Goldman, Sachs.
"Everybody," he added, "got excited about the whole Internet mania, the technology mania. Having said all that, I really believe that today we, K.K.R., and some others in the business of private equity, are absolutely in a gold mine."
But mining gold requires capital, and it is not as easy for firms like Kohlberg Kravis to raise money as it once was. 
Buyout firms pay for their takeovers mostly with debt, a lot of it from the sale of junk bonds. But in a slowing economy, investors are reluctant to buy such below-investment-grade debt, forcing borrowers to offer yields so high that many takeovers do not make sense. Moreover, leveraged buyout funds are typically backed by pension funds and endowments, which can be counted on to be much more cautious as the economy sours.
Not only are leveraged buyout firms having a hard time raising money from pension managers and other institutional investors -- Kohlberg Kravis hired Merrill Lynch to help court foreign investors for the first time this year -- they are having a rough time structuring the buyouts themselves. Hicks, Muse was recently forced to abandon its deal to acquire the Johns Manville Corporation because it would have been forced to pay too much to borrow in the junk bond market.
The credit shortage comes at the worst time for most of these leveraged buyout specialists because so many takeover targets are ripe for the plucking as the stock market has weakened.
"If you rolled back the clock to the 1980's, it should be like -- bam! -- L.B.O.'s would be doing deals everywhere," said Deane Dray, research analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "They're ready to go, but with the markets the way they are, they are stuck on the runway."
Mr. Forstmann's approach -- using his own special subordinated debt fund rather than high-yield debt to finance his deals -- limits his dependence on the junk bond market. Forstmann Little is one of a handful of leveraged buyout firms with such debt funds. 
If he were to buy a company for, say, $1 billion, Mr. Forstmann said he might invest $300 million from his equity fund and $400 million from his debt fund and borrow the rest from a bank. "On our $300 million, there are no interest payments," he said, referring to the equity fund investment. "And on our total $700 million, there is no amortization.
"So all the money that the other guys have to be paying people off with, we are using to grow."
Without having to pay terribly high interest rates, he is able to make his money go further, though it also could potentially lower his total returns. Mr. Forstmann has used his capital structure to his advantage. Most notably, he bought Gulfstream, the leading maker of corporate jets, in 1990 for $850 million from Chrysler, improved its profits and then sold it to General Dynamics in 1999, making $5 billion for his investors.
Most recently, he bought a big share of McLeodUSA and XO Communications, two telecommunications companies, along with substantial chunks in Yankee Candle and Community Health Systems, an operator of hospitals in the Southeast and Southwest.
"We interviewed six different private equity companies before choosing Teddy. We were looking for more than capital," said Clark McLeod, the founder of McLeodUSA. "He's not trying to be a bank."
And though Mr. Forstmann typically eschews Internet investments, he did make a $80 million investment in Metiom, a software developer of business-to-business e-commerce sites.
"The dot-com thing was really just so stupid," he said, blithely waving his hand.
By avoiding running with the crowd, he has never had any flameouts in the class of the 90 percent-plus plunges in the values of a host of dot-coms. Nonetheless, his stakes in the Pullman Company and in Lear Siegler in the late 1980's turned out to be duds.
But he has avoided other disasters that lured big-time investors, like the widespread collapse of the movie theater business because of overbuilding. "Don't make the mistake of thinking we didn't see every single one of those things," he said. "We saw them all and passed."
"Teddy would die if one of his investments died; he's that intense" explained Eli Broad, the home builder and insurance company owner who worked for the fund in 1978.
Mr. Forstmann has also invested in an e-learning company called Capella Education. The investment is probably less about business than it is a vehicle for advancing his pet project of remaking the world of public education so that it runs more like a business. Toward that goal, he was a founder of the Children's Scholarship Fund, with John T. Walton, the son of the Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton, and has offered more than $50 million in scholarships for underprivileged children to attend private schools.
For much of the 1990's, while his fortune was rising even as the climate for his kind of deal making cooled, Mr. Forstmann spent a lot of time raising his political profile. He is one of the top fund-raisers for the Republican Party, and a major supporter of George W. Bush. And he is not shy about suggesting that his fund-raising prowess might give him an inside track to Washington.
"If the president of the United States asked me to do something," he said, "I'd give it very serious thought."
For now, he plans to keep up his busy business schedule. While he will not say who he is in talks with, he hinted that the deals would most likely be in technology, medical products or education.
And after lying low for a long time, he hopes to take advantage of the many opportunities he now sees as others lick their wounds.
"It is like the hunt," he said. "When that fox is out there, and they're all in the hunt, it's a good time to be playing Ping-Pong." Now, he says, it is time to stop playing and start prowling.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
No Secrets, Just the Shock Of the Familiar

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
ONLY after you've read through the book-size decision that so thoroughly condemns the New York City public schools and everyone responsible for them does it hit you.
 Guess what, folks? Nothing new here. No shocks, surprises or deep, dark secrets. What is most stunning about yesterday's decision by Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court in Manhattan is that he orders what amounts to an education revolution in New York based on the blatantly familiar. In detached but passionate language, Justice DeGrasse indicts a society for choosing to ignore the known and knowable, at the expense of mostly poor and minority students. 
 As Joseph F. Wayland, the tenacious chief lawyer on the winning side, said yesterday, "There is absolutely nothing new that anyone with a passing knowledge of New York City's schools doesn't already know."
Mr. Wayland is with the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the nonprofit corporation that brought a lawsuit in 1993, contending that the state deprives New York City of enough financing to give students the sound, basic education required under the State Constitution, and disproportionately hurts minority students.
Justice DeGrasse agreed, saying that the state's system of financing schools is unconstitutional, does have a discriminatory impact and has to be revised.
In his 189-page decision, he takes on all the arguments, making unsparing judgments about matters more often subject to political spin. One stands out in particular, for a city whose minority students account for almost three-quarters of the state's minority public school population. 
To those who say that poor ethnic and racial minorities cannot succeed no matter what government spends on them because of economic and other disadvantages, the judge, who is African-American, acknowledged the problems and the impact they have. But, he concluded:
"Demography is not destiny. The amount of melanin in a student's skin, the home country of her antecedents, the amount of money in the family bank account, are not the inexorable determinants of academic success."
Justice DeGrasse proceeds to take the air out of many common assertions about the success of public education, particularly about the value of diplomas. He notes that about 30 percent of ninth graders fail to get a high school diploma by the time they are 21, and 10 percent get general equivalency degrees, which require only "marginal skills." Forty-eight percent get local diplomas, which require skills of a sixth- to ninth-grade student. 
That leaves only 12 percent getting diplomas that actually demonstrate that they've received a sound education. "This evidence," he wrote, "depicts a public school system that is foundering."
A few of the judge's other blunt findings were these:
*That "the quality of New York City's public school teachers -- in the aggregate -- is inadequate" and that the city generally attracts the least qualified teachers in the region.
*That teacher salaries are not competitive in New York City and that problems in recruiting are likely to get worse as teacher shortages grow.
*That "decaying and decrepit" schools hurt student performance.
*That to compare Catholic schools with public schools -- as politicians, especially Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, love to do -- is "not apt" because the Catholic schools have few special-education students, can expel disruptive students and have fewer students who are poor or limited in English.
HE rejects outright the idea that the city has enough money for education if it doesn't waste or misspend it. And he debunks the state's contention that the state education formula is diligently negotiated with students in mind. Instead, he writes, "the formulas are manipulated" during contentious budget negotiations between the governor and the Assembly and Senate leaders.
In other words, as the plaintiffs argued, they are a sham.
If the judge's ruling stands -- the state hasn't said if it will appeal -- the Legislature will have to revamp the formula by Sept. 15. That would be nothing short of cataclysmic in Albany, where the school formula has always been Albany's souk.
It is hard to believe that one judicial decision can change habits of decades. But other states have changed. Maybe Justice DeGrasse's decision -- by implicitly humiliating scores of New York's public officials with their own records -- has a chance of doing the seemingly impossible.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING: E-COMMERCE; 
SEND.COM FOLDS ITS TENT

BYLINE:  By Catherine Greenman 

 BODY:
 Citing economic uncertainty and the inability to generate additional financing, Send.com, the online gift-giving service, said it would cease operations and close. 
The company, which had raised almost $45 million during its four years of operation, said it would honor all orders received before Monday. Ken Cassar, senior retail analyst at Jupiter Communications in New York, said many companies have struggled in the online specialty gift market. "One reason for Send.com's failure would be its exaggerated sense of potential when the reality was they didn't have the capability to become anything more than a niche business," he said. Catherine Greenman

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

BROOKLYN: HOLTZMAN ROBBED -- Elizabeth Holtzman, the former Brooklyn district attorney, was robbed in front of her home in Boerum Hill on Tuesday as she left a taxi, the police said yesterday. Ms. Holtzman, 59, told the police that as she approached the gate to her brownstone she was confronted by a man with a silver-colored gun who demanded her wallet. She said she gave the man $100 and he ran away. Ms. Holtzman was also robbed at gunpoint in 1995 at an automated teller machine in Manhattan. Ms. Holtzman, who served as city comptroller as well as a congresswoman representing Brooklyn, is a lawyer with the firm of Herrick, Feinstein.
Kevin Flynn (NYT)

ROCHESTER: WOMAN CLAIMS POLICE RAPE -- A 20-year-old woman says she was chained to a chair and raped by three sheriff's deputies while in custody six weeks ago. The woman's lawyer, Johnnie Cochran Jr., notified the authorities yesterday that she planned to sue. Mr. Cochran filed a notice of claim in which the woman, who is black but not otherwise identified in court papers, maintained that she was falsely detained Nov. 30 and then assaulted by the deputies, who are white. No criminal charges have been filed, and the officers remain on the job at the Monroe County Sheriff's Department. (AP)

MANHATTAN: LAWYER SENTENCED FOR FRAUD -- A Manhattan lawyer was sentenced on Tuesday to 7 to 21 years in prison for eight counts of grand larceny. The lawyer, Domenick Crispino, was convicted of stealing more than $2 million from 14 clients whom he represented in a lawsuit. Among his clients were accident victims who had received financial settlements, and in the course of representing them, Mr. Crispino stole some of their settlement, according to indictments.
Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

BROOKLYN: MOTHER CHARGED IN DEATH -- A Brooklyn mother was charged on Tuesday with killing her 15-month-old baby, said the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes. The woman, Nicole Hamilton, 23, is accused of repeatedly striking the baby, Kyron Hamilton, with her hand and fist. The infant, who had multiple injuries, died on Dec. 3. Ms. Hamilton was charged with murder, assault, criminal possession of a weapon and endangering the welfare of a child. She faces a maximum prison term of 25 years to life. Her 3-year-old son, who the authorities said had also been beaten, was placed in foster care.
 Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

MANHATTAN: APARTMENT BURGLARIZED -- A burglar tied up a cleaning woman and ransacked an apartment yesterday in one of the Upper West Side's most elegant apartment buildings, the police said. The burglar had entered an apartment in the Apthorp, a Renaissance Revival landmark at Broadway and West 79th Street, when the cleaning woman walked in about 5 p.m. and surprised him, said Officer Gary Cillo, a police spokesman. The burglar bound the 45-year-old woman, finished ransacking the apartment and left with an undetermined amount of jewelry, Officer Cillo said. The woman was not injured, he said. Residents of the gated, four-building complex, which is home to celebrities like Nora Ephron and where rent-decontrolled apartments go for as much as $20,000, said the police told them that the burglar was on the loose inside the complex. The police searched the building in vain, Officer Cillo said. Andy Newman (NYT)

MANHATTAN: FIRE CLOSES POST OFFICE -- An underground electrical fire yesterday forced the shutdown of the Peck Slip post office, near the Brooklyn Bridge, the authorities said. Consolidated Edison was still working on the cables in the building early this morning and postal officials said they did not know when the post office, which serves the northern part of the financial district, would reopen. The fire started in an underground secondary cable leading to the post office about 4:30 p.m, said Michael Clendenin, a Con Edison spokesman. The smoke from the fire forced the evacuation of the 30 employees inside, and a small explosion from the fire damaged a wall inside the post office, said Lt. Kevin Ganun, a Fire Department spokesman.
 Andy Newman (NYT)

MANHATTAN: PESTICIDE USE -- Even before the 1999 discovery of West Nile virus forced the city to spray for mosquitoes, New York City used nearly a third of the pesticides applied in the state, according to a report released yesterday. In 1998, the city reported 1.6 million gallons and 7.8 million pounds of pesticides, according to the report by Environmental Advocates and the New York Public Interest Research Group. The figures do not include pesticides bought by individuals. Statewide in 1998, 4.5 million gallons and 29.4 million pounds of pesticides were reported used by commercial applicators or sold to farmers. (AP)

CONNECTICUT

DERBY: TEENAGER ACCUSED IN NASA WEB ATTACK -- A former high school student has pleaded not guilty in State Superior Court here to defacing a NASA Web site last February. The former student, Matthew Lawrence, 19, was a senior at Shelton High School when he hacked into the site for the office of human resources at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., the police charge. Mr. Lawrence is scheduled to return to court Feb. 5. If convicted, he could receive up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. (NYT)

HARTFORD: FIRST HOMICIDE OF 2001 -- This city's first homicide of the year occurred on Monday night. Marvin Blunt, 30, was shot and killed in the city's North End at 10:30 p.m, said Lt. Mark Pawlina. Mr. Blunt drove up to a convenience store, got out of his vehicle and had a brief conversation with a man in a ski mask. When he turned to go back to the vehicle, the masked man fired several shots at Mr. Blunt, who was pronounced dead at St. Francis Medical Center at 11:13 p.m. (NYT)

MONTVILLE: PRISON SCUFFLE -- Three corrections officers were injured yesterday during a scuffle with two inmates at Corrigan Correctional Institution, the state police said. An inmate reportedly attacked a corrections officer at the high-security prison about 9:45 a.m. The officers were not seriously injured, and the reason for the attack was not given. (AP)

NEW JERSEY

NEWARK: BLACK REPRESENTATION -- New Jersey gained 7 black elected officials from 1998 to 1999, a 3 percent increase that put the total at 239. New Jersey's increase outpaced a national rise of less than 1 percent, according to the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies. According to representation in the state legislatures, New Jersey ranks better than most states in racially proportionate representation, the group said. The Legislature is 12.5 percent black, nearly equal to the black voting-age population in the state of 13.6 percent. (AP)

MORRIS TOWNSHIP: DEER BIRTH CONTROL -- A three-year project to reduce the growing deer population with birth-control inoculations has ended in futility at a Morris County park. Of 12 does injected since 1997 with a vaccine preventing fertilization, some disappeared from the 127-acre park and others were hit by cars on a nearby highway, said Carl Zafonte, director of park maintenance. The two does still in the park have been seen with fawns, he said. Still, scientists believe that the birth-control method shows promise. On Fire Island, N.Y., 80 percent of 200 does treated in the last seven years have not given birth, said Nina Austenberg, regional director of the Humane Society of the United States, which sponsored both tests.
Robert Hanley (NYT)

Today

QUEENS BOULEVARD SAFETY -- The City Council's Transportation Committee plans a hearing on accidents and injuries on Queens Boulevard. Committee Room, City Hall, Manhattan, 11:30 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7120.

SCOOTER HELMET PLAN -- City Council's Health Committee plans hearing on proposal to require minors under age 14 to wear helmets while riding scooters. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7120.

HEADLINE: FleetBoston Sells Package Of Bad Loans 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
The FleetBoston Financial Corporation said today that it had sold $1.35 billion of troubled loans to Patriarch Partners, ridding itself of some customers who have had trouble paying back debt.
 Patriarch, founded in April by the investors Dennis Dolan and Lynn Tilton, paid about $1 billion for the loans, about 26 percent less than their face value. The sale shrinks FleetBoston's nonperforming loans to about $925 million from $1.03 billion in September, said a spokesman, James Mahoney. 
 FleetBoston, which had about $115 billion in loans at the end of December, is selling at a time when defaults are up because a slowing economy has made it harder for corporate borrowers to make debt payments. The bank said it hopes the move, which was reported by The Wall Street Journal, will convince investors that bad loans will not pull down profits, analysts said.
"Fleet is getting out in front of it," said Lanny Thorndike, a portfolio manager at Century Capital Management in Boston. "Fleet's thinking, 'By selling at a 30 percent discount, I now get everyone off my back.' "
Shares of FleetBoston rose $1.61, to $42.69.
Rising levels of bad loans have dragged down banks' earnings in recent months. Analysts expect bank earnings per share to fall by an average of 14 percent in the fourth quarter, in large part because banks are setting aside more money to cover possible losses from loans.
FleetBoston said the sale to Patriarch, completed on Dec. 28, would not affect fourth-quarter earnings. Mr. Mahoney said the company endorsed analysts' forecasts of 84 cents a share. Patriarch paid $725 million in cash, plus zero-coupon bonds with a face value of $275 million for the loans. FleetBoston's nonperforming assets are higher than those of most large banks. While the percentage of nonperformers to total loans will fall to about 0.8 percent from the 0.92 percent of September, the bank will still be in the bottom third in terms of asset quality among the top 50 banks, according to Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Leaders Say Time for Bush Decision on Speeding Tax Cut Is Becoming Crucial 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
Faced with political and economic risks on both sides of the argument, President-elect George W. Bush will have to make a critical decision in the next few weeks about whether to seek quick action in Congress on a tax cut, Republican leaders said today.
 Aides to Mr. Bush said they had not yet decided how to proceed. But they said they were considering whether the apparent deterioration of the economy required pushing a tax cut through the House and Senate on an accelerated schedule, and whether the tax cut should take effect this year, rather than next year as they had originally proposed. 
 "That is all under review right now," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman. Mr. Bush said last weekend that he would make a decision after taking office on Jan. 20.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said he had discussed the issue this week with officials from the incoming administration, and had pointed out to them the pros and cons of moving quickly on tax cuts.
"It's going to have to be under active consideration, and quick," Mr. Lott said.
On the plus side, Mr. Lott said, speedy action could provide a boost to the economy just when it needed it most, and Democrats might be reluctant to oppose Mr. Bush's first big initiative. 
But moving on tax cuts right away would create procedural problems in the Senate that could subject the legislation to delaying tactics and a flood of amendments, Mr. Lott said. And depending on the size and composition of the tax cut, he said, it could strain the ability of the Senate, which is divided 50-50 between Democrats and Republicans, to maintain any semblance of bipartisanship.
"But we're going to make this new situation work," Mr. Lott said. "Maybe this could be a mighty test of whether it could work."
In the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush proposed a package of tax cuts that would be worth about $1.6 trillion over the next 10 years. Its centerpiece was a reduction in all income tax rates, a provision that accounted for more than half the value of the package.
Mr. Bush's team has been discussing whether to accelerate the income tax cut, and Republicans in Congress have been pressing for any plan to include additional provisions like expansions of individual retirement accounts and the 401(k) retirement savings program.
Democrats said they were open to a substantial tax cut, and clearly do not want to be blamed for blocking action that could help forestall a recession. But they said they would be unlikely to support a plan as big as the one Mr. Bush has proposed, and that they would like to see the benefits of any reduction directed mostly to low- and middle-income people. Most of the benefits of Mr. Bush's plan would go to people at the high end of the income scale, those who pay the most in taxes.
"This may very well be the first true test of what bipartisanship means in the new Congress," said Michael Siegel, spokesman for Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. 
"There is certainly a sense that the Bush tax plan as proposed during the campaign is simply too large," Mr. Siegel said. "At the same time, there's a growing sense that there very well may be a need for a tax cut. But it doesn't make sense to provide a huge tax cut that leaves little room for flexibility to continue to pay down the debt, to shore up Social Security and Medicare and to provide a prescription drug benefit for seniors."
In the House, where Republicans have a clear majority, there is growing support for taking up a substantial tax cut as one of the first orders of business. In a memorandum sent on Tuesday to all Republicans in the House, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, urged quick action to cut income tax rates.
Mr. Armey's position was more aggressive on tax cuts than previous statements by other Republican leaders, including Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, who has urged taking up a series of smaller tax cut measures one by one.
But it will be much easier for Republicans to move a tax cut through the House than through the Senate. That is in part because the House's procedural rules make it easier than in the Senate to limit debate and amendments. But it is also because of the nearly even division of power between the two parties in the Senate.
"Tax bills don't become law without bipartisan support," said Jill Kozeny, a spokeswoman for Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, who will be chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
Ms. Kozeny said Mr. Grassley was "considering every option at this point."
Mr. Lott said he had not recommended any particular course of action to Mr. Bush's team. But he said he had told the incoming administration that if it decided to move ahead under standard Senate procedures, which call for adopting a budget before considering tax bills, then it would be June or July before there could be final action on a tax cut.
"You have to consider, if you want to do something quick, the politics of it as well as the economics," Mr. Lott said. 
"Unlike some people from the House, who are saying do it now or do it this way or do it that way, I think we ought to at least have a little time for input from the administration," he said. "Tell them what the options are, what the pitfalls are, get their reactions and come to a conclusion together."
