HEADLINE: For OPEC, Cuts in Production Are a Delicate Balancing Act 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Next week, a dozen men will gather in a room in Vienna and make a decision that could cushion the fall of the American economy -- or pull the rug out from under it. 
 Those men, the leaders of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, have watched -- like Alan Greenspan -- with mounting concern as spending and investment in the United States have slowed with each passing week. For OPEC, a sluggish American economy could lead to a decline in oil consumption worldwide and, with it, a free fall in oil prices. 
 So the delicate task that the cartel's leaders face as they prepare for their meeting next Wednesday is setting production levels that keep prices high enough to sustain their economies without helping shove the United States into recession.
Toward that end, OPEC officials have announced they will sharply curtail petroleum output, although the size of the cut will not be known until next week. The Clinton administration, meanwhile, is scrambling to limit the damage, with the energy secretary, Bill Richardson, planning to leave this evening for a round of talks with key OPEC officials in Europe and the Persian Gulf. 
"We don't want severe, precipitous cuts," one senior Energy Department official said yesterday.
Often in the past, the OPEC nations have resolved to manage production and prices with Greenspan-like precision, only to see their plans crumble as members pursue their individual interest, rather than the cartel's. Over the last two years, however, a freshly invigorated OPEC has found new cohesion, and the confidence that it can shape the global economy rather than struggling to adapt to its shifts. 
For now, the cartel is betting that it can have its hefty oil export revenues without damaging the weakened economies of the United States and Asia. But analysts note that is a fine balance that will be tough to strike in the volatile realm of oil prices. 
"We're on the precipice of something serious, and OPEC needs to be very careful right now," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist with economy.com, a consulting group. "Just the mere fact if OPEC tightens supply and the price of oil jumps by $5 a barrel could be debilitating for consumers and investors reeling with lots of other worries."
OPEC enjoyed the windfall of oil prices higher than $30 a barrel for most of the last half of 2000 thanks to a robust American economy and Asia's rebound from its collapse in 1997 and 1998.
Amid the slowdown in the United States, prices fell below $26 last month. But cold weather and tight supplies pushed prices in the futures market up 6.7 percent yesterday, to $29.48, the biggest one-day rise since October.
Now, OPEC wants to ensure that the price of oil stays somewhere between $25 and $30 a barrel -- something it rarely has been able to sustain for long.
OPEC ministers have called for cuts ranging from one to two million barrels of oil a day. The cartel pumped 30.4 million barrels daily in October, according to the latest data available from the Energy Information Administration in Washington. 
Some oil industry experts said the range of proposed decreases signaled the existence of two camps within OPEC. The so-called price hawks -- Iran, Kuwait and Venezuela -- want, these experts say, a drastic, immediate reduction of two million barrels a day. Another group, led mainly by Saudi Arabia, would like to phase in cuts over the coming months, eventually removing the same two million barrels a day from the market by April. 
The Saudis, considered the de facto leaders of OPEC, have traditionally listened to United States concerns and have been a moderating force in the cartel. But analysts say that the Saudis were rattled by the 30 percent drop in oil prices during December, making them less receptive to American entreaties. 
So in a rare interlude of unity within a group that historically has been fractious, all the OPEC nations agree that a reduction is crucial. And neither Mexico nor Norway, two large non-OPEC producers that lately have worked with the cartel, seems likely to undermine it now.
"Iran believes OPEC's output should be reduced," the Iranian oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, was quoted as telling an Iranian news agency this week. "The rest of the members hold the same view, too, but with a little difference regarding the level of the reduction."
Many analysts expect OPEC to announce a decrease of 1 million to 1.5 million barrels a day, or 5 percent of total output. The actual decrease may be a bit smaller because of chronic overproduction by OPEC members, which would soften somewhat the blow to the global economy. 
OPEC's decision will come at a time when Americans, accustomed to low fuel prices for nearly a decade, have seen the havoc that high energy costs can wreak. 
In early summer, airlines, trucking companies and motorists experienced steep rises in fuel prices, only to have them settle at levels as much as 50 percent higher than a year earlier. The price of natural gas has increased more than fourfold in the last 18 months, leading to higher costs for manufacturers, steeper heating and electric utility bills in many parts of the country. In California, this has contributed to a crisis that has brought the state's biggest utilities to the edge of bankruptcy. Last fall, the White House ordered the release of 30 million barrels of crude oil from the nation's reserves to help make up a heating oil shortfall in the Northeast. 
Though the OPEC countries are almost entirely dependent on oil revenues to finance their budgets and ensure political stability, recent declines in oil prices have again shown how hard it is for the cartel to navigate through the global economy. 
Under pressure from the United States over the last year, OPEC increased production by about 3.5 million barrels a day. Because it takes weeks for production increases to work their way from wellhead to customer, the oil swell is washing into the world's economies only now, just as those economies are slackening and consumption falling.
"If they don't make production cuts now, 45 days from now there will be a glut of oil and it will cost $15 a barrel," said Ed Morse, executive adviser at the Hess Energy Trading Company. "If you were in their position, what would you do?"
Concerned that a production cut could lead to recession, Mr. Richardson met Ali Rodriguez, the Venezuelan who serves as OPEC's president, in Vienna last weekend -- to no apparent effect. The Bush administration-in-waiting has also asked OPEC not to cut output, though just how Spencer Abraham, the energy secretary-designate, will approach relations with oil producers is unclear. 
But OPEC fears something much worse than Washington's ire: a repeat of what happened after it met in Jakarta, Indonesia, more than three years ago. At the time, OPEC decided to increase output, unaware that the Asian economic crisis would worsen. As a result, the price of oil plummeted to $10 a barrel.
Like war-scarred veterans, OPEC found greater solidarity by enduring the crash in oil prices. Cartel members cut output sharply in 1998 and 1999, then realized over the last year that by working together, they could keep prices high. 
Moreover, countries once at odds with each other have made an effort to cooperate. Saudi Arabia and Iran, usually at loggerheads, have strengthened diplomatic and military ties; industry experts say that President Mohammad Khatami of Iran and the Saudi crown prince, Abdullah bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, have a good personal relationship. President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela has reached out to other OPEC members; previously, Caracas had often flouted OPEC's decisions.
But for all its apparent discipline and unity, OPEC's efforts to micromanage the oil market could backfire. Unlike the Federal Reserve, OPEC relies on information that is often incomplete and inaccurate. Members fib to one another about their output and production capacity. Data about worldwide consumption often arrives months late. 
Working from such a sketchy picture, OPEC could tighten supplies too stringently. Some oil traders have said that if next week's cut exceeds 1.5 million barrels a day, the price of oil could jump significantly. If it stays high -- say, $30 a barrel or more -- the global economy could slow even more, demand would fall more drastically, and OPEC would find itself struggling with lower prices once again.

HEADLINE: TURF; 
With a Chill in the Air, Builders Blink

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
IN the midst of New York City's biggest building boom since the mid-to-late-1980's, there is now a certain hollow silence: the sound of developers and bankers holding their collective breath.
 With cranes perched over snow-dusted steel skeletons in virtually every neighborhood in Manhattan, the city's best-known residential developers say they are still pushing to build, negotiate and scout for new sites in the coming year, but they also say they are moving with a new caution, given signs of an economic downturn. 
 "We're looking over our shoulder," said Joshua Muss, a Queens developer, whose six rental buildings are now rising behind the boardwalk at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn.
Besides those already under construction or close to ground-breaking, there are few new condominium projects on the horizon, a pronounced change from last year. 
Stephen M. Ross, the chairman of the Related Companies, one of the most active mixed-use developers in Manhattan -- and one of the developers chosen to build the Coliseum project, with its 203 condominiums -- said he would not even consider initiating new condominiums now, which often require two years of work before a shovel is put in the ground. Nevertheless, he said, he was not worried about building more rental apartments, which developers regard as more resistant to recession. 
But Thomas Elghanayan, the president and chief operating officer of Rockrose Development, one of the largest builders of rental housing in the city, does worry about rentals. "I'm stepping back a little bit," he said last week. Even Donald J. Trump, whose multimillion-dollar condominiums across from the United Nations are selling for record sums, was uncharacteristically hesitant. "The market is at least as strong as it was six months ago," he said. "But talk to me in six months. It's an evolving story."
For the banks, too, the future is up for grabs. "Short term, we're rolling right along; no problems," said William C. McCahill Jr., an executive vice president of Fleet, which last year lent half a billion dollars for apartment construction in the Northeast, most of it in Manhattan.
It's unlikely that that level of activity will be maintained this year. "Long term, well, there's nothing in the pipeline," Mr. McCahill said.
The developers said that while New York City is still among the country's most desirable locations, there has been a shift. "The biggest difference between today and a year ago is the buyers' perceptions, the buyers' confidence," said Daniel Brodsky, a partner in the Brodsky Organization. "Something's going on, a hesitation. Everyone says that. Retail sales are down, everyone has less confidence. In buying apartments, there is a little hesitation."
Like the other developers, Mr. Brodsky said he was concerned about the condominium market. Would he start planning a condominium development tomorrow? "I would hesitate," he said. "The sales of condominiums follow the economy, follow Wall Street."
Interviews with the city's top developers all seemed to start with rosy reflections on the past year. "I can tell you that 2000 is the best year I ever had in business," said Donald Zucker, a 40-year veteran developer and president of the Zucker Organization, echoing almost exactly the words of several other residential developers.
But what about 2001 and beyond? And if the economy continues to slow down? Mr. Zucker, Mr. Ross and the rest say they will be shrewdly positioned to capitalize. If other developers are overleveraged, as many were in the last boom, said Mr. Zucker, who is currently beginning 77 rental apartments at 30th Street and Ninth Avenue, "then guys like me are going to come along and buy up their buildings."
The developers insist that the coming downturn -- if there is one -- will not catch them unprepared.
"I'm not going to be surprised at anything," said Mr. Muss, the Queens developer. "Because I've been there, and we will never build such an oversupply."
In the late 1980's, there were nearly 40,000 apartments built in Manhattan, according to the Real Estate Board of New York. Many of them were shoddily constructed studios and one-bedroom units that, when financial trouble hit, were left to languish on the market.
The number of units built in the mid-to-late-90's was about the same, but the apartments erected are much bigger and more solidly constructed, developers and real estate agents say, so their value may hold up better.
Mr. Ross said the difference in quality is evident even in rentals. "We're putting in granite countertops and quality lobbies," he said. In a downturn, he argued, the quality will separate the best product from the rest.
Right now, Mr. Ross's Related Companies has 1,500 apartments under construction (meaning the ground has been broken), almost all of them in Manhattan. Of those, only 314 are condominiums. In addition, Bruce Beal, a spokesman, said the company had 1,000 more units on the drawing board, with options for the land signed and financing secured. They are all rentals. Mr. Muss said he was just finishing 200 units, had 260 under construction and planned to begin 200 more in the next two months. All of Mr. Muss's are rental units.
At Rockrose, there are 836 units in three new buildings, all scheduled to come on the market by the end of summer, said Kevin P. Singleton, the general manager. All three projects -- at 15 Cliff Street in the Financial District, 22 River Terrace in Battery Park and 200 West 26th Street in north Chelsea -- are rentals. (Mr. Singleton said the company had no new projects planned beyond those three that meet the criteria of having secured both financing and land options.)
Larry Silverstein, the president of Silverstein Properties, with 921 rental apartments nearing completion at the western edge of 42nd Street, said the current rental market "seems to be unabated in its demand, but naturally I'm cautious." He added, "I read the paper like everybody else." 
Initial planning for new condominiums -- perhaps with the exception of those of Mr. Trump, whose imprimatur has its own momentum -- seems to be grinding to a halt. In a recession, there is always some market for rentals -- young people coming to work and study in the city -- but less demand for condominiums, which in the last two years have broken all price records for Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn.
"Condos aren't a real alternative right now," Mr. Ross said. One reason is the high cost of construction in New York City, which makes the price of the condos sky high. "To make a profit, you'd have to get $700 a square foot," he said, "and there aren't many proven locations -- and they certainly couldn't command $700 a square foot." (At $700 a square foot, the average-size one-bedroom apartment would sell for almost half a million dollars.)
But with New York's recent boom, those proven locations have increased, the developers say. Because of the runaway market of the last eight years, more and more of Manhattan has been opened for development: Mr. Zucker's rentals at 30th Street and Ninth Avenue are rising in a residential location unheard of just a few years ago.
Thus, every cloud, for these developers, may have a rentable lining.
If rents and sales prices do drop, they say, those who can't now afford Manhattan prices may come back and settle in these marginal neighborhoods, and the developers will be ready for them.
Whatever happens, the developers say, they'll keep going.
"Why would I keep building if I'm worried?" Mr. Elghanayan asked rhetorically. "I'd probably do better if I just waited and could pick up things at a lower level later. But there are people who work here, an office to keep going; the overhead is pretty big."
"I'm still out there looking, but not as enthusiastically," he continued. "It's just in our nature to look. We just want to make sure we can carry on if the bottom falls out."
Mr. Zucker, who is building his 23rd Manhattan building, agreed. "I must have the ability to weather the storm, because it's going to get stormy," he said. "The five-year run we've had is going to end, but we'll keep making money." He paused. "There will just be less of it."

HEADLINE: Iraq Is Focal Point as Bush Meets With Joint Chiefs 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT and JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
George W. Bush, the nation's commander in chief to be, went to the Pentagon today for a top-secret session with the Joint Chiefs of Staff to review hot spots around the world where he might have to send American forces into harm's way. 
 About half of the 75-minute meeting in the secure conference room where the military chiefs conduct their most sensitive business, focused on a discussion about Iraq and the Persian Gulf, two participants said. Iraq was the first topic briefed because "it's the most visible and most risky area" Mr. Bush will confront after he takes office, one senior officer said. 
 Mr. Bush did not say how he would deal with Iraq, the participants said, but asked several questions about President Saddam Hussein and American allies in the region, before the generals briefing him addressed other possible flashpoints, including the Balkans and the Korean peninsula. 
"Iraqi policy is very much on his mind," one senior Pentagon official said. "Saddam was clearly a discussion point." 
Iraq looms large among the national security challenges Mr. Bush will face. During the campaign, he criticized the Clinton administration as allowing the international coalition against Iraq to erode, and for permitting sanctions against Iraq to loosen. 
But it was the president-elect's father, President George Bush, who left Mr. Clinton with what critics say was unfinished business, by defeating Mr. Hussein in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, but not dislodging him. 
In the past year, Mr. Bush and his advisers have talked about strengthening the sanctions and bolstering the fragmented Iraqi opposition groups, but the president-elect has been careful not to lay out a specific strategy.
Mr. Bush arrived at the Pentagon this morning surrounded by a cast familiar with the building: Vice President-elect Dick Cheney, who was secretary of defense under Mr. Bush's father; Gen. Colin L. Powell, the secretary of state-designate and former chairman of the Joint Chiefs; Donald H. Rumsfeld, a former secretary of defense who is Mr. Bush's choice for the same job; and Condoleezza Rice, the president-elect's pick for national security adviser. 
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen held a 45-minute briefing in his office for the group, touching on a variety of issues, including the nation's nuclear arsenal, before the session with the Joint Chiefs. 
Hours after his meeting with Mr. Bush, Mr. Cohen gave a speech that was part valedictory and part rebuttal to Mr. Bush's repeated criticisms against the Clinton administration's military policies during the campaign.
On Iraq, for instance, Mr. Cohen argued that sanctions had worked.
"Saddam Hussein's forces are in a state where he cannot pose a threat to his neighbors at this point," he said. "We have been successful, through the sanctions regime, to really shut off most of the revenue that will be going to rebuild his military."
In a courtly manner, without mentioning Mr. Bush or his supporters by name, Mr. Cohen time and again suggested that the Republicans had oversimplified defense issues like peacekeeping in the Balkans and building a ballistic missile defense system, a subject that did not come up at today's Pentagon briefings.
In the campaign, for instance, Mr. Bush asserted that Mr. Clinton's defense policies had caused military morale to plummet and weapons systems to fall into disrepair.
But Mr. Cohen argued today that policies supported by the Clinton administration and approved by Congress in the past two years would lead to an increase in Pentagon spending of $227 billion by the year 2007. 
Much of that increase will be for personnel costs, including pay increases and improved pension and health care benefits. But much will also go toward maintaining and modernizing weapons systems.
The increase outlined by Mr. Cohen today is actually significantly more than what Mr. Bush proposed during the campaign, which was $45 billion over 10 years. Though Mr. Cohen did not lay out that contrast, he seemed to be suggesting that the Clinton administration had already achieved more than anything Mr. Bush had even proposed during the campaign.
Mr. Cohen also took issue with suggestions by Ms. Rice that it might be necessary to set up international police forces to carry out peacekeeping functions that are now the responsibility of soldiers.
"Some people say, 'Why don't we just train people to be peacekeepers, a certain segment of our military to be peacekeepers, and the others will be the warriors?' " Mr. Cohen said in his address at the National Press Club here. "It doesn't work that way. We have to train our people to do everything, all the way from being peacekeepers to peacemakers to humanitarians to diplomats to being war fighters, because the situation on the ground can change like that."
Throughout the campaign, Republicans also accused the Clinton administration of dragging its heels on building an antiballistic missile defense system. Mr. Cohen, who supports building a limited missile shield, said Mr. Clinton had been deliberate about building support for a system among American allies.
And he strongly warned Mr. Bush to do the same and not rush into deploying something that might trigger a new arms race or alienate America's friends.
"Working with our allies, persuading them that we're doing the right thing and the reasonable thing, is going to very important," Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Cohen also warned Mr. Bush about cutting spending on three expensive fighter plane programs that Mr. Cohen strongly supported during his tenure. Those programs could cost well over $300 billion over the next two decades, and advisers to Mr. Bush have suggested that the new administration would take a hard look at cutting or canceling one of them, investing the money instead in futuristic skip-a-generation technology.

Cohen; and Vice President-elect Dick Cheney. Mr. Bush was briefed on global hot spots. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Long a T.W.A. Town, St. Louis and Its Airport Cheer 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Word that the owners of American Airlines would acquire T.W.A. -- and probably bring a season of stability to employees of a storied airline that has slipped in and out of bankruptcy for a decade -- was greeted as good news here today.
 After years of worrying about the very survival of T.W.A., which has its headquarters in St. Louis and dominates operations at the airport here, the city rejoiced in the expectation that thousands of jobs and perhaps billions of dollars in regional spending would be secured by the deal. 
 Mayor Clarence Harmon of St. Louis and the city's business leaders cheered the deal; everyday citizens said it would strengthen the local economy, and T.W.A. employees of every stripe seemed to walk a little more confidently at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport, even though T.W.A.'s name and rich heritage would disappear after three-quarters of a century. 
"The employees of this company finally have some long-term security," said Paul Gerling, 57, a T.W.A. pilot for nearly 36 years. "We're thankful we've stayed in business this long. A lot of people could have put us out of business, so this is a joyful day."
While top executives from the AMR Corporation, the parent of American, and Trans World Airlines held a news conference at the T.W.A. headquarters in downtown St. Louis this morning, scores of T.W.A.'s 8,900 local employees gathered in knots at the airport to talk about what joining the American team would mean. Many liked what they heard. Several ground employees said they were told that their salaries could rise as much as $4.50 an hour, because of higher pay scales at American.
Nancy Nagel, a customer service agent checking in passengers at Gate C6 for a Chicago flight, pointed at the American Airlines pin she had placed just below the T.W.A. button on her sweater.
"T.W.A. has been struggling for the past 15 years, and I've been working for them for 20 years," she said. "It'd be nice to work for a company that's profitable."
T.W.A.'s losses for most of the last decade and its third Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, made today, were enough to win over Harry Brooks, 65, an employee for 39 years who works the skycap luggage service.
Standing between the two airlines' ticket counters, Mr. Brooks said he would be happy to move over a few steps and exchange his blue T.W.A. uniform for the red and blue of American. 
"The name T.W.A. is good," he said, "but there are a lot of airline names that are gone, and people don't have jobs. I think this saved the airline."
Others here say that the deal may have helped salvage Lambert airport, one of the nation's oldest, where more than 19,000 people work each day.
Like other airports in big cities, it is struggling to overcome congestion and improve outdated quarters -- goals that might have been unreachable if T.W.A. had collapsed rather than falling into American's arms .
City officials have plans to spend hundreds of millions to add a third runway in hopes of ridding the airport of its reputation as a bottleneck in bad weather and making Lambert a more efficient alternative to O'Hare International in Chicago. 
Those plans follow years of battling over how to expand the airport. Without T.W.A., which flies 76 percent of the travelers who pass through St. Louis, the odds that Lambert would grow into a major airline hub seemed dim.
"The importance of the hub to the St. Louis economy is very substantial," said Richard Fleming, president of the Regional Chamber and Growth Association of St. Louis. "We estimate the economic value of the airport to be $5 billion a year, and after our expansion, it could be $12 billion to $15 billion a year."
Travelers had mixed feelings about what the deal will mean for them. Several people interviewed at the airport today said they were pleased that jobs were being saved, but they lamented the loss of a great brand name and said they worried about the prospects for service and ticket prices.
"T.W.A. has been the most reliable in the last four years," said Jack Pledger, a retired Air Force pilot from the St. Louis suburbs . "The last few times I got canceled, I was on American. I'd rather see T.W.A. acquire American. They've got a better service record."
Indeed, for many here in St. Louis, and even for travelers passing through, news of the deal was bittersweet. Jobs were saved, they said, but a part of aviation history was being lost. 
"I'm 55, and I remember having a T.W.A. plane when I was a kid," said Ron Six, a passenger from Albany, Ohio, passing through on his way to Houston. "I used to fly Eastern and Pan Am, airlines that when I was young I never dreamed would disappear."
T.W.A. had celebrated its 75th anniversary a year ago, a time for reflecting on an airline that in its earliest years acquired an aviation company from Charles Lindbergh, the pioneer aviator who flew from Lambert Field. 
Howard Hughes once owned T.W.A.; so did the financier Carl C. Icahn. It is a name that people here grew up with, but for the last few years, T.W.A. has represented little more than the prospect of bankruptcy, and worries about the demise of the St. Louis hub.
Today, it was the object of wistfulness.
Michael Knox, who works at a Paradies news and gift shop at the airport, said he planned to hang onto some trinkets bearing the T.W.A. emblem, like a fuzzy toy airplane that, when squeezed, makes the sound of a plane taking off.
"What are we going to do with stuff like this?" he asked, squeezing the plane again and again. "But if this deal benefits the city, I'm all for it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Ford, right, a skycap for T.W.A. in St. Louis, has worked for the airline for 40 years. He hopes to add to that total if the company is sold. (Tim Parker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Electric New York 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "To Fix the Electricity Mess, More Power Plants Are Needed" (Business Day, Jan. 5):
 New York State needs new, more efficient and cleaner power plants in order to meet our growing economy's demand for electricity. 
The cushion between the demand and our generation capacity is shrinking. This not only puts upward pressure on the price of electricity, but it also threatens the reliability of a system that is absolutely critical to our well-being. 
 Power plant siting decisions are not easy. But today's state-of-the-art facilities will provide environmental benefits by displacing, and eventually replacing, older and less efficient plants. Failure to take action now will cost New Yorkers money, undermine our economic recovery and jeopardize the reliability of an electric system we too often take for granted.

MAUREEN O. HELMER
Chairwoman
Public Service Commission
Albany, Jan. 5, 2001

HEADLINE: Clinton Team's Final Forecast: No Recession 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Eight years after taking office with a promise to focus like a laser beam on the economy, the Clinton administration offered its own final economic report card today, saying the country is not slipping into recession and that its long-term prospects have been enhanced by technology and fiscal discipline.
 In a generally optimistic forecast that stands in contrast to the increasing gloom of many private analysts, the White House's chief economist said the economy remained fundamentally sound and should continue to benefit from three factors that drove the long expansion of the 1990's: improvements in the growth rate of productivity, better business management and a shift from federal budget deficits to surpluses. 
 "We don't think the new economy is dead," said Martin N. Baily, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers. "We don't think we're going into recession." 
Mr. Baily said the economy was slowing more than the administration had anticipated when it decided on the forecasts contained in the Economic Report of the President for 2001, which will be sent to Congress on Friday.
But while some industries, like automobiles and steel, have been particularly hard hit, he said, the administration still expects the overall economy to grow around 2.7 percent this year, a full percentage point lower than last year and half a percentage point less than the White House had expected when it completed its forecast for 2001 just a few months ago.
Many economists on Wall Street have been marking down their forecasts in recent weeks and concluding that the risks of a recession are growing. Although there is no precise definition of a recession, it is generally considered to be two or more consecutive quarters in which gross domestic product, or total output, shrinks.
Economists at Credit Suisse First Boston said today that they had cut their growth forecasts for the first half of the year "aggressively," to zero growth in the first quarter and 1.3 percent in the second quarter, down from 2.2 percent and 2.0 percent, respectively. 
"The difference between our forecast and a recession is semantics," their report said. "Outright contraction in G.D.P. in the first half of the year is well within the range of possible outcomes." 
Mr. Baily said one of the keys to keeping the economy going would be to stick to a path of using the budget surplus to pay down the national debt -- another way of warning the incoming Bush administration not to push for a tax cut so big that it would risk a return to deficits.
"This is not the time to abandon fiscal discipline in favor of large tax cuts," he said. Mr. Bush's team has said the surplus should be large enough to accommodate both a substantial tax cut and debt reduction, and that the stimulus of a tax cut would help kick-start the economy if it proves to be stalling.
The prosperity of the last eight years has provided Mr. Clinton and his team with perhaps their strongest claim to a positive legacy. As they prepare to leave office they have emphasized not the possible downturn in the business cycle but the broader changes in the economy since 1992.
Much of the report released today is taken up with a discussion of whether the economy has been fundamentally transformed in recent years by advances in computers and telecommunications, adept management by businesses and better economic policy at the federal level.
Its conclusion is that there is something new and different going on.
"The new economy is pervasive," Mr. Baily said. "It has transformed not only high technology, but virtually all sectors of the economy."
Mr. Baily said the changes were not a panacea and did not mean the business cycle was dead. But he said the economy was now characterized by a mutually reinforcing set of positive characteristics, including strong productivity growth, low inflation and unemployment, budget surpluses and strong growth in the United States relative to other industrialized nations.
The report touches on two of the biggest potential problems facing the economy, the low personal savings rate and the large trade and current account deficits. But in both cases, it suggests that the problems will more or less take care of themselves as the economy slows.
The administration's long-term forecast, while basically upbeat, also notes that two of the most positive trends of recent years will reverse somewhat over the next decade. The improvement in productivity, the most critical indicator of the economy's potential to grow without generating inflation, will throttle back somewhat, from its current rate of 3 percent a year to 2.3 percent in the middle of the decade and to 2.1 percent by the end of the decade, the administration forecast said.
At the same time, the unemployment rate is expected to drift upward, reflecting a gradual increase in the level at which unemployment can be expected to start generating inflation. By late in the decade, the administration said, the so-called nonacclerating inflation rate of unemployment, or Nairu, is expected to rise from its current level of just over 4 percent to just over 5 percent. 
The unemployment rate, which was 4 percent in December, has hovered around that level for more than a year, and is expected by many analysts to begin rising this month as the economic slowdown becomes pronounced.
The administration also waded into a debate among economists about whether the improvements in productivity in recent years have been confined largely to the computer business. Its conclusion was that while technology companies have enjoyed outsized productivity gains, the improvement was also widespread across the economy.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Getting Credit Where Blame Is Due

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
A DEMOCRATIC judge who did not attend public schools and has no children in public schools has just overruled the governor and the Legislature to impose his own educational theories on public schools. In theory, this sounds to conservatives like the kind of arrogant judicial activism that has produced so much trouble in New York.
 In practice, though, it's hard to argue with Justice Leland DeGrasse's conclusion that the Legislature has shortchanged New York City's students. And in practice, it's hard to see how his decision Wednesday ordering the Legislature to revise its formulas could make city schools any worse, although one should never underestimate the creativity of our legislators. 
 When it comes to schools, they have interfered with everyone else's job while shirking their chief educational task: redressing the financial inequities among school districts. Almost every other job can be left to the local level, but redistributing wealth can only be done in Albany or Washington. 
Equitable redistribution, though, has been of less interest to the Legislature than dictating how school districts can spend the money. Besides promoting pet programs, legislators are experts at blocking reforms. Even when local officials are united in their desires, as Democrats and Republicans have been in calling for more mayoral control over the New York City school system, legislators can be counted on to put up a fight. 
They can afford to oppose even the most popular reforms, like charter schools, because parents have no way to punish them. Legislators virtually never face more than token opposition for re-election. As long as they avoid the wrath of the teachers' unions, criminal indictment and death, their seats are safe.
The judge's order, coupled with Gov. George E. Pataki's call for more control of schools at the local level, may spur some reforms in the way state aid is given out. At the very least, New York City should get a fairer share of state aid. At most, the city schools could get a hefty infusion of money, although the legislators are in no rush to provide it themselves. 
As usual, they are more interested in telling school districts what to do. Democratic legislators yesterday promoted new legislation that would force New York City to spend more of its own money on schools, a strategy that is brilliant in its brazenness. The legislators stand to get credit for handing out money to teachers and schools, and the mayor of New York stands to get blame for raising taxes.
In their eagerness to spend other people's budgets, the legislators seem to have caught the spirit of Justice DeGrasse's decision. His enthusiasm for higher teacher salaries was not dimmed by thoughts of higher taxes, or by evidence that the money might not buy much.
HE was not impressed by the studies of Eric Hanushek, an economist at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University, showing that higher spending does not correlate with higher student achievement. Although the studies are detailed and well regarded even by academics who favor more spending on schools, Dr. Hanushek's work was not rigorous enough for the judge.
"His analyses, which focus only on gross per pupil spending," Justice DeGrasse wrote, "are of limited value absent an examination of the effects of particular inputs." If you can understand that sentence, you might want to contact Dr. Hanushek. He could probably use some help in figuring out what kind of study would meet the judge's exacting standards.
Justice DeGrasse's need for precision, though, waned when he dealt with another question: how do urban Catholic schools (which the judge himself attended) provide such a good education for so little money? He said the comparison was "not apt," dismissing it with a few highly debatable generalities about the supposed advantages of the Catholic system.
"Catholic schools enroll very few special-education children," he wrote, ignoring the fact that Catholic schools are cheaper even if you exclude those students. He said the Catholic system has fewer low-income students, ignoring studies that compare schools with similar socioeconomic populations and find better performance in the Catholic schools.
Justice DeGrasse also said, "The vast majority of Catholic schoolteachers are not unionized," as if that were somehow unfair or wrong. Unionized teachers should prosper if he and the State Legislature join to take control of the city's school budget. What the students will gain is anybody's guess.

HEADLINE: Sotheby's to Cut Staff 8%, With $14 Million Charge 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Bracing for mounting fines, legal expenses and a possible downturn in the art market, Sotheby's, the troubled auction house, said yesterday that it planned to cut about 8 percent of its worldwide staff, to about 1,900 employees from 2,050. The downsizing will result in a fourth-quarter charge of about $14 million, mostly for severance-related expenses. 
 "We have spent months reviewing all of our auction operations around the world," said William Ruprecht, president and chief executive, "and it's fair to say that our focus in the United States is principally on the high-end markets while in London we're making a commitment to the secondary sales room because we see an opportunity there in the middle market." 
 "We are not abandoning the markets that make Sotheby's Sotheby's," he added. 
About 75 departments of the company now hold auctions in areas ranging from paperweights and rare porcelains to old master and Impressionist paintings. But Sotheby's plans to operate its biggest money-making departments -- namely Impressionist, contemporary, old master and 19th-century paintings as well as jewelry and Asian art -- globally rather than regionally to sell objects most profitably.
Mr. Ruprecht estimated that over the next two years the reorganization would save the company $20 million in its live auction business and an additional $25 million in Sothebys.com, its Internet operations.
Sotheby's said yesterday that as of March 5 it would increase the amount it charges customers who buy on Sothebys.com to 15 percent of the first $15,000 that they spend and 10 percent thereafter. They now pay a flat rate of 10 percent.
Since introducing its online auction site a year ago, Sotheby's has spent about $80 million. The company originally had two sites, Sothebys.com and Sothebys.amazon.com, but abandoned its Amazon site in October. 
The company's expenses have risen significantly over the last year because of a continuing federal antitrust investigation into price-fixing and collusion with its archrival, Christie's. In October, Sotheby's pleaded guilty to violating antitrust laws and agreed to pay a fine of $45 million, a figure that is still subject to approval by a federal judge. In February, its chairman and controlling shareholder, A. Alfred Taubman, resigned, as did Diana D. Brooks, its president and chief executive. Ms. Brooks pleaded guilty to violating antitrust laws in October. Her sentencing is scheduled for May 23.
In November, a federal judge gave preliminary approval to a $512 million settlement of a lawsuit filed by more than 100,000 angry buyers and sellers against Sotheby's and Christie's. Mr. Taubman agreed to pay $156 million of Sotheby's $256 million share of the settlement. But this still leaves Sotheby's with $100 million to pay, $50 million in cash and $50 million in the form of certificates to sellers. The auction house is waiting for the judge to evaluate the economics of the coupons; he has asked both Sotheby's and Christie's to show their ability to pay the civil settlement. A hearing is scheduled for Feb. 2. 
Last month, Moody's Investors Service, citing multimillion-dollar settlements growing out of civil litigation related to the antitrust investigation, downgraded the company's credit and debt rating to junk status.
Mr. Ruprecht denied that the cutbacks were a result of troubles with the Justice Department. "This is a thoughtful review," he said. "It is a set of strategies and directions for the business we began discussing last spring and summer. There's no question that the cost of the Justice Department investigation is significant, but this review is not driven by it."
In addition to the antitrust investigation, Sotheby's is completing a $150 million expansion of its headquarters on York Avenue. As part of cost-cutting efforts, the company plans to consolidate its five office and warehouse premises around Manhattan into its headquarters.
Shares of Sotheby's rose $1.13 yesterday, to $25.19.

California Barely Avoids First Scheduled Blackouts
California barely avoided its first-ever planned statewide power blackouts as longstanding electricity shortages combined with a storm that cut output at a nuclear power plant.
 In midafternoon, state officials said the blackouts, which would have affected about 1.5 million people, were inevitable. But about 5 p.m., the California Independent System Operator said it had just barely managed to avoid the cutoffs by purchasing some more power from out of state and persuading many customers to cut their use. Page A1. 

The distant struggle of California's big power companies may leave Wall Street more than a little bruised. Market Place. C5.

Ratings High for 'Temptation Island'
The new Fox network series "Temptation Island" scored higher in the ratings on its first night than "Survivor" did. C2.

First Microsoft Employee Returns
In a twist on the trend of failed Internet start-ups sending workers back to former employers, Microsoft's first official hire is returning to the fold. Marc McDonald, a programmer originally hired in April 1976 by an Albuquerque company then known as Micro-Soft, rejoined recently as part of the company's acquisition of a Seattle electronic publishing company called Design Intelligence. HEADLINE: Import Prices Fell in December 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Prices of imports fell modestly in December, and unemployment claims fell in the latest week despite a trend of growing joblessness, government reports showed today.
 The mixed economic news offered little fresh perspective to the overall picture of a slowing economy. 
Economists said the data would not distract the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates at the end of the month. 
 Import prices fell 0.5 percent in December after gaining 0.1 percent in November, the Labor Department said. Economists had expected a drop of 0.2 percent.
Import prices were driven lower largely by a 9.3 percent plunge in the price of petroleum imports, while prices of natural and manufactured gas soared 32.3 percent. Excluding petroleum products, import prices rose 0.9 percent in December after a 0.1 percent dip in the previous month.
Export prices, meanwhile, dropped 0.1 percent in December after being unchanged in November.
The overall decline in import prices could encourage domestic producers to keep their prices down, which in turn will help keep domestic inflation muted.
Since last year, overall import prices have increased 3.5 percent, although much of that gain came from petroleum. December's 0.9 percent rise in import prices excluding petroleum goods was the biggest increase on record since the Labor Department began issuing such monthly data in December 1988.
The Labor Department said weekly jobless claims fell 36,000, to 345,000, in the week ended Jan. 6. Economists had expected 374,000.
But a four-week moving average of the claims data, viewed as more indicative of the trend in the labor market, rose to 363,000 from 356,750 in the previous week.

HEADLINE: THE POWER CRISIS: THE RESULTS; 
The Dog Day in June The Lights Went Out

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
As California energy officials initiated rolling blackouts today to conserve thinning power reserves, companies throughout Silicon Valley dimmed lights, turned off heating systems and switched on backup generators to keep the high-technology industry humming.
 The actions, taken by leading companies like Cisco Systems, Intel and Sun Microsystems, reminded many here of the scorching day last summer when the lights went out. 
 In Silicon Valley, where electricity has been the mother's milk of the technology boom, the risk once again of blackouts like the one last June threatens the economy's very lifeblood.
Steve Lane remembers June 14 as the day his employer, SDL Inc., like many companies in the Valley, lost millions of dollars as its manufacturing plant sat idle without electricity. Mr. Lane, a senior facilities manager, also recalls it as the day diesel fuel ruined a fine dress shirt and pair of slacks. 
With temperatures soaring to 109 degrees that day, straining California's already fatigued power grid, SDL received a call from Pacific Gas and Electric, California's biggest utility, saying that the state's power grid operator had ordered the local electricity supply temporarily shut down to reduce stress on the system.
And so, Mr. Lane recalled recently, he and several colleagues found themselves crouched above the company's burly diesel generator in dress clothes, struggling with five-gallon buckets to keep the fuel tanks filled and emergency power in the plant, which makes lasers for fiber optic networks.
In the end, SDL, which has since bought stronger generators, said the failure that day cost it more than $3 million in repairs and lost production.
"Most of us had no idea, before June 14, how serious that problem was," Mr. Lane said. 
The problems at SDL and Silicon Valley in general serve as a magnified illustration of the energy crisis in California, where a three-year experiment with deregulation has made wholesale energy costs soar as rising demand collided with scarce supplies of power. State price caps prevent utilities from passing on higher prices to consumers. Utilities say they have lost about $12 billion from the situation and will go bankrupt without some government help.
Like most problems in the peninsula just south of here, including increased traffic and housing shortages, the energy problem is caused largely by good fortune. The population has boomed, but the improvements to the infrastructure used to move energy around the region have lagged. High-technology companies, the legions who came to work for them and the computer devices they create have voracious appetites for electricity.
The region's need for power has grown about 5 percent a year, triple the statewide rate. Consumption in Santa Clara County, the heart of Silicon Valley, has grown by one-third since 1994, and utilities officials expect demand to grow another 11 percent by 2004. Over that decade, peak electricity use is expected to increase by 1,052 megawatts, enough energy to power more than one million homes.
"Every time a company expands, every time a home is built, every time somebody, thank God, gets enough money into his hands to buy a computer for the kids, that's another kilowatt or megawatt in a state and a region that doesn't have a lot to spare," said Scott Blakey, a spokesman for Pacific Gas and Electric, a unit of PG&E. "And if it does have it to spare, it's at a price the utilities are becoming fast unable to afford."
Many high-technology companies also demand an unrelenting flow of power round the clock. Even momentary blackouts are disastrous: semiconductor plants can take days to recover, and companies that are hosts to Web sites for e-commerce can lose angry customers if the sites go down. Trade associations estimate that the industry lost hundreds of millions of dollars during the June 14 failures. 
Ed Quiroz, a regulatory analyst with the California Public Utilities Commission, said a typical commercial office building consumes 10 to 15 watts a square foot. In contrast, a building that houses Internet networking centers or servers for Web hosts uses 120 to 200 watts a square foot. A 10-story building filled with Web host centers can consume up to 40 megawatts, enough energy to power 40,000 homes.
These companies settled into Silicon Valley, the region that grid officials call the most susceptible to power failures in an already energy-starved state. The population boom, insufficient transmission lines and the region's own failure to produce more power locally, despite its needs, are making a tight energy market even tighter.
"The digital economy's demand on electric reliability far outstrips what the current infrastructure is able to provide," Mr. Quiroz said.
So far, most of the largest high-technology companies have been spared from catastrophic blackouts, which industry leaders estimate could cost companies anywhere from $1 million a day to $1 million an hour. Intel, Agilent and others have struck deals with the power system's operators, promising to turn off lights and air-conditioners to reduce demand in exchange for being bypassed in rolling blackouts like those called for today.
Yet the threat of more power shortages like the one that crippled SDL has frightened executives far more than the temporary rate increases announced last week that will raise their energy bills by 7 percent to 15 percent.
Carl Guardino, president of the Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group, a powerful trade association with 190 member companies, said nearly every high-technology manufacturer in Silicon Valley had drawn up plans to shift production out of state if necessary. Craig Barrett, chief executive of Intel, announced this week that his company was unlikely to expand in California until energy became more consistent.
"What Craig said is echoed by just about every C.E.O. that I have spoken with," Mr. Guardino said. "The message is, 'Either get a reliable source of power or we can't expand here.' "
Added Mr. Guardino, "This is probably the biggest challenge to our economy, here in Silicon Valley and statewide, that we have faced in decades."
Companies are responding to the power shortage in many ways. Large manufacturers have bought expensive diesel generators, which environmental regulators fear will contribute to air pollution. Oracle, the second-largest software company in the world, recently built a $6 million substation to carry enough energy from California's grid to power its 1.6 million square feet of office space. But diesel generators are on hand to keep the data center, the core of Oracle's Internet business, from crashing during a blackout, the company said. 
Many companies have also devised ways to quickly reduce their lighting and air-conditioning when utilities warn that power supplies are low.
The Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group, formed in 1977 by David Packard, a co-founder of Hewlett-Packard, created an energy task force, with 35 member companies, to protect the industry's interests and discuss conservation methods. Last week, the group supported a pilot program, created by the Electric Power Research Institute, located in Palo Alto, which allows companies to track their electricity consumption as it is used to better manage their power.
But many argue that the region's biggest shortfall is its lack of local power plants. Generating power locally is considered crucial for efficiency because the farther electricity has to go along wires, the weaker it becomes and the more grid space it ties up.
Gov. Gray Davis recently called the creation of new generators the key to keeping up with power demands. His administration has approved construction of nine new power plants, all outside Silicon Valley, which would add 6,278 megawatts to the state's supplies within five years.
Though Silicon Valley uses more than 2,900 megawatts on peak days, it produces fewer than 200 megawatts, through small plants at universities and private companies.
"Clearly, the San Jose area has to be willing to look at generation in its own area, and not just bring it from other places," said Patrick Dorinson, director of communications for the California Independent System Operator, which controls the power grid.
Two large development companies, the Calpine Corporation and Bechtel Enterprises Inc., are trying to build a 600-megawatt natural gas plant in Coyote Valley, one of the remaining undeveloped sections of San Jose. Tucked against a hill in South San Jose, where existing transmission towers already help carry power from Canada to Mexico, the $400 million Metcalf Energy Center, if approved, would direct nearly all of the power it creates into San Jose and its surrounding areas, a Calpine spokeswoman said.
"At some point, we've got to take responsibility for the power we need," said Steve Tedesco, president of the San Jose Silicon Valley Chamber of Commerce, which supports the project.
But Bechtel and Calpine have been stymied by a potent combination of resident and corporate resistance. The local neighborhood association and Cisco, which in October received approval to build its new headquarters for 20,000 employees less than a mile from the land being considered for the power plant, waged a successful lobbying campaign against the project, citing concerns about air quality and incompatibility with the surroundings.
Although Cisco's plans face their own challenge in a voter referendum as early as April, the company and the association, with the support of Mayor Ron Gonzales, persuaded the San Jose City Council to reject a petition to change the zoning regulations, which now limit the rural area to office space.
"We're not antibusiness or anti-development; it's simply a bad location," Elizabeth Cord, president of the Santa Teresa Citizen Action Group, said in an interview.
Accusing the neighborhood association of a not-in-my-backyard mentality, the developers have asked the California Energy Commission to approve the project despite the failure to procure a zoning change. Hearings before the commission began this week, with a final decision expected in May or June. The commission's staff has already recommended approval, calling the benefits to San Jose substantial.
Even if construction is approved, the plant will not be operating until the summer of 2003. In the meantime, industry analysts say, companies and the government must work together to both save energy and find new ways to quench the growing thirst for electricity.
"You want to grow an economy in a new set of directions, and the means just aren't there," said Mr. Quiroz, the Public Utilities Commission analyst. "Somebody is going to have to spend the money to provide a new infrastructure and beef it up."

HEADLINE: THE POWER CRISIS: THE FINANCES; 
The Money Trail In California's Energy Debacle

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
Where did the money go?
 Since last spring, California's two biggest utilities have spent $12 billion more for power than they have collected from ratepayers. With the utilities threatening bankruptcy, the Legislature called into emergency session, companies putting off expansion plans and residents braced for rate increases, the search for explanations -- or scapegoats -- has reached a fever pitch. 
 "Never again can we allow out-of-state profiteers to hold Californians hostage," Gov. Gray Davis thundered in a speech this week condemning power producers, before flying off to a Washington meeting called by President Clinton seeking solutions to the state's energy mess.
But understanding where the money went is a more complicated matter than pointing to a few rapacious corporations. For while billions have poured out of the state, that flow, many experts say, is an inevitable result of the ill-designed deregulation program that California put in place three years ago, at the behest in part of its now sickly utilities. 
Today, with storms knocking out transmission lines in the northern part of the state, California just avoided blackouts while state and federal officials and utility executives continued to try to hammer out a longer-term remedy.
Certainly, much of California's immense electric bill has been paid to companies based outside the state, with the owners of power plants and concerns that trade and market electricity capturing much of it. 
One of the power companies, Houston-based Dynegy Inc., had one of the best performing stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 last year, its shares more than tripling. Last month, the utility in Portland, Ore., Portland General Electric, abruptly withdrew a proposed 16.5 percent rate increase for its 700,000 customers, after calculating that it could raise the same millions by selling surplus power to California and other places. 
Analysts contend that some energy sellers fueled the crisis by bidding up prices. Though the marketers note that past inquiries have never found evidence of abuse, investigators from the state attorney general's office and other authorities are looking into charges of market manipulation.
Yet more than one-third of the electricity sold in the state by the companies now being demonized used to be controlled by Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison -- until the utilities were required to sell power plants as part of deregulation. The two utilities' parent companies -- PG&E and Edison International, respectively -- collected $3 billion from those sales, and they have made about $3 billion more selling power into California's overheated electricity market from plants they were allowed to keep.
Even the municipal power authority in Los Angeles -- considered a dowager when it held onto its plants while deregulation swirled around it -- has made an extra $200 million selling power over the last two years. 
None of this, in hindsight, should have been a surprise. Since deregulation was first approved four years ago, all of the players have pursued their self-interests.
The trouble is that the marketplace in which those interests have clashed turns out to have been ill-conceived. And a power surplus that made the utilities hungry for deregulation has turned into a shortage, with the state's booming economy straining both generating capacity and the natural gas supplies that run many of the power plants. Throw in a few untimely generator shutdowns and cold, dry weather in the Northwest that reduced the supply of hydroelectric power from that region, and the result is a recipe for a debacle.
"California designed the world's most complicated market that people said would not work well and which they've been trying to fix ever since," said Paul Joskow, director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Among other miscalculations, the obscure state agency that was supposed to ensure the reliability of the state's power grid instead has added to the volatility in prices, critics say. 
That agency, the California Independent System Operator, was intended to be the power buyer of last resort for Southern California Edison, Pacific Gas and Electric and the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, which is owned by Sempra Energy. But on some days of high power demand, it has procured up to 30 percent of the state's electricity needs. With its employees focused solely on keeping the lights on -- and with the bills to be paid not by itself but by the utilities -- critics say the agency was ripe to be outfoxed by the power suppliers.
"My people are not trained as traders or arbitragers," conceded Jim McIntosh, director of scheduling for the system operator.
When traders were asking $2,000 for a megawatt-hour of electricity, enough to light 1,000 typical homes for an hour, Mr. McIntosh and one of his bosses refused. 
But the price they settled on -- $1,500 -- was arbitrary, Mr. McIntosh acknowledged. Many of his colleagues, he conceded, believed that generators could produce that amount of electricity for about $250, even with higher natural gas prices.
The objective, he said, was to select a price that assured California had enough electricity. "No one wanted to make the decision on what was the right price to drop off people's service," said Mr. McIntosh, a former Pacific Gas and Electric executive. "You are putting a price on the health and safety of people."
Meanwhile, by freezing rates for the utilities' business and residential customers during the early years of deregulation -- in a move to protect consumers -- the state gave those consumers no reason to curtail power use even as wholesale prices rose more than fiftyfold at their peaks. 
California's energy problems took on crisis proportions only when San Diego Gas and Electric, having sold all its power plants, was freed to pass along its wholesale costs to customers last summer, driving bills up 300 percent during air-conditioning season. Unable to do the same, Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric have had to pay up to $1,400 a megawatt-hour for electricity, while charging customers about $64.
Meanwhile, the state's deregulation plan did little to encourage power plant construction -- no major plants have been built for 12 years -- even as power reserves drifted dangerously low. Utilities were discouraged from securing power supplies through long-term contracts. At the same time, state pollution-control laws idled some plants and forced power producers to buy expensive emissions credits for others. 
Even so, the energy squeeze of the last year was a boon for both power plant owners and electricity traders.
Reliant Energy, a Houston utility whose wholesale energy unit owns several plants in California, said it made $90 million in operating income from California alone during the third quarter of 2000 -- more than twice what the entire subsidiary made in the period the year before. The Calpine Corporation, a San Jose, Calif., company that operates plants in Northern California and elsewhere, in the third-quarter had per-share earnings that rose about 150 percent from a year earlier. 
The gains were not confined to the 50 states. British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority, the government-owned utility in Canada's western province, had revenues from its electricity-trading business increase nearly fourfold from April through September, to about $1.5 billion, in large part from sales to California. 
Large industrial users of electricity have gotten into the act, too. Officials at the Bonneville Power Administration, which sells wholesale power across the Northwest, say three aluminum producers will collect well over $500 million by shutting down operations and then reselling the electricity they buy under cheap long-term contracts. The proceeds will be split between ratepayers in the Northwest, employees at the plants and the companies.
As for the money that the parent companies of Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison have made from selling plants and electricity, company officials say the deregulation plan requires that those profits be applied to paying off the costs of nuclear and other facilities built long ago -- and not to today's power costs. 
Power generators, for their part, say their profits, however large, were earned fairly. 
At Dynegy, for example, pretax earnings from the operations that include its California plants rose to $106.4 million in the third quarter of 2000 from $22 million a year earlier, largely because of sales in California. 
But Rob Doty, the company's chief financial officer, said Dynegy made "very little" profit from the state in the fourth quarter, because of the high prices it paid for natural gas to run its power plants, emission credits and other costs. And he dismissed the charge that companies like his were abusing California's energy market, noting that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission had rejected such allegations in the past.
"That has been looked at several times, most notably by the F.E.R.C., and nobody has found any evidence of market manipulation and profiteering," he said. "It also ignores the fact that we have very substantial costs we face." Indeed, rising gas prices and worries about the California utilities' ability to pay their bills have knocked down the stock prices of Dynegy and some other power producers this month. 
However, a handful of studies suggest that power generators and marketers may have exercised undue influence in California's untidy market. Research that Mr. Joskow of M.I.T. and a colleague, Edward Kahn, conducted for Southern California Edison concluded that power generators "engaged in behavior to drive prices above competitive levels," Mr. Joskow said.
John Stout, a senior vice president at Reliant Energy, said his company studied California's market and concluded that it was competing energy buyers, not sellers, who drove up costs. 
But, he conceded, if out-of-state generators have an advantage, "it is because someone handed it to them."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Temporary Apartments for Corporate Executives

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Next month, residents will begin occupying the 56-unit apartment building nearing completion at 401 West 22nd Street in Chelsea. But unlike neighboring renters, they will not be decorating rooms or moving in furniture. They are leasing furnished apartments from one of the nation's leading suppliers of temporary housing for executives. 
 Execustay, the corporate housing division of the Marriott International hotel group, has leased all the units in the seven-story building at Ninth Avenue for two years from the developer, 401-402 Realty of Manhattan. Since Execustay signed the lease in the fall, it has in turn rented 85 percent of the studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom units to corporate clients, including Morgan Stanley, said David Lorenzo, vice president of the New York office of Execustay. 
 This is one of a handful of small residential buildings that providers of corporate housing are leasing to meet what they say is a continuing demand. Another is the six-story, 40-apartment building at 316 East 63rd Street, between First and Second Avenues, which was developed by M-1 Properties of Manhattan. 
Furnished Quarters of Manhattan, which specializes in corporate housing in the city, is leasing all the studio and one-bedroom apartments in that six-story building. Since it began marketing the apartments in October, it has rented them all, including 10 to Chase, said Steven Brown, a principal at Furnished Quarters. 
Companies use such housing for employees being relocated or attending training programs and needing to stay in Manhattan for a month or longer, and who want to be in a residential setting with some hotel amenities, like maid service. 
While whole buildings dedicated to corporate housing are scarce, there are others in which groups of apartments have been set aside for this use. For instance, 86 of the 520 rentals at the Ocean at 1 West Street in the financial district are being leased by Oakwood Worldwide of Los Angeles as furnished corporate apartments. 
A developer typically leases an apartment for at least a year to the corporate housing provider, who decorates and furnishes them. In some cases, the developers themselves have leased the units to residents. An example is Cambridge Development of Manhattan, which has turned the top 13 floors of the 16-story Romanesque Revival building at 56 Pine Street, a designated city landmark, into the Cambridge Club with 78 apartments. The lower floors of the building are now used as offices. 
Corporate housing has been on the rise since 1997, residential brokers say. That market, like the city's residential and lodging markets, has benefited from a strong local and national economy that has led companies to expand and to add employees, said Joseph Barbaccia, president of Joseph Gregory Marketing, a Manhattan brokerage firm that specializes in corporate housing.
He is also the rental agent for the Cambridge Club, where Salomon Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers leased the studio and one-bedroom apartments soon after they came on the market in the summer. Monthly rents are $2,850 to $4,450, on average.
Rising occupancy and room rates of hotels in the city have also helped increase the number of long-term quarters. Professionals in the corporate housing industry said the monthly cost for their units was 25 percent to 40 percent less than hotel rooms. 
For developers, the benefit is profit, said Andrew Heiberger, president of CitiHabitats, a rental brokerage firm in Manhattan. He said corporate housing providers often paid 10 percent more in rent than traditional tenants. Because the providers also furnish and maintain the apartments, he added, they reduce the landlord's operating expenses.
But what happens if the hospitality market flattens? While hotel occupancy rates were high in 2000, some market studies noted a slackening of the occupancy rate toward the end of the year.
Arthur B. Adler, managing director of the hotel practice at Jones Lang LaSalle, said his firm's studies led him to expect Manhattan hotels to remain at their current 84 percent occupancy rate at least through 2001. He added that even if there were a slowdown, it was unlikely that all corporate apartments would be dumped on the market at one time. 
Mr. Barbaccia added that in slower times, when companies start cutting back, they hire consultants for short-term assignments who will need corporate housing. 
Mr. Lorenzo of Execustay, which is leasing the entire building at 401 West 22nd Street, said it was the first time his company had taken over an entire building. "It will be the first real corporate housing in Chelsea," he added. 
He said monthly rents for the studios and apartments, with 530 to 950 square feet, were now $3,900 to $8,400, including weekly housekeeping, but change seasonally. 
With the addition of the Chelsea apartments, the company has more than tripled its apartment total in Manhattan in the last year. It now operates 750, Mr. Lorenzo said, and plans to bring that to 1,000 by the end of the year. 
At the 63rd Street building, on the site where the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance stood for nearly 50 years, Furnished Quarters is leasing all 40 units for three years, with two renewal options of three years each. Monthly rents for the studio and one-bedroom apartments, including weekly housekeeping, are $3,600 to $5,000.
Mr. Brown said his company planned to add 100 units this year to its inventory of 300 apartments, which includes brownstones. "Even if the economy cools, corporate housing is the more affordable alternative for companies," he said.
