HEADLINE: THE RULING ON THE SCHOOLS: THE SOLUTIONS; 
Answering Those Who Say More Money Can't Help

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The decision Wednesday overturning New York State's system of financing public schools was based on an assumption that has come under severe challenge in recent years: that the key to higher student achievement is more spending on schools. 
 Recent efforts at education reform, many of them led by conservatives, have started with the assumptions that poorly performing school systems are wasteful and inefficient and that no reasonable amount of money will make them significantly better. 
 "It's clear that we can't solve the education problem with more money," said Steven G. Rivkin, an associate professor of economics at Amherst College and a leading researcher on the issue. "The schools could do a lot better with the money that is now being spent. But you're not going to get a lot of improvement for a dollar of new spending without changing the underlying structure of the schools." 
Those reformers have tried to raise student achievement by improving standards and accountability and by promoting charter schools, vouchers and other market-related mechanisms. And they have held up the lower-spending parochial schools as an example of why money does not make a difference.
The changes they have made have improved student performance in some cases, but not in all. Some charter schools have failed and had to close and many others have produced results no better than the public schools they competed against.
In his decision ordering public school financing to be restructured, Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court in Manhattan drew a direct link between money and better schools. He did so, however, by making a distinction that is often ignored: that spending is meaningful only when the money is properly deployed.
"That is the key phrase regarding this issue," said Ronald F. Ferguson, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, who testified for the plaintiffs at the trial challenging the financing system. 
"The folks who try to deflect discussion away from the question of whether resources matter usually try to point out that there's a lot of waste in the system," Mr. Ferguson said. "But there's no reason to assume going forward that any new money will not be well spent. Plenty of people will be watching to see what changes result." 
A school district that chooses to spend money on patronage jobs is unlikely to have the success of one that puts a higher priority on the training of teachers. But the question of whether money makes a difference focuses less on whether a school system is bureaucratic and wasteful and more properly on where the money goes. The judge mentioned several ways of effective use of more money: hiring more teachers and thereby reducing class size, paying teachers more and thereby attracting better candidates, improving school buildings, and buying books and computers.
"Contrary to defendants' argument, increased educational resources, if properly deployed, can have a significant and lasting effect on student performance," Justice DeGrasse wrote. "There is a causal link between funding and educational opportunity."
The judge also swept aside several arguments against giving more money to the New York City public schools, saying it is irrelevant that their spending is already far higher than the national average. Given the higher costs of operating here and a student population that requires more help, such comparisons are unwarranted, he said.
In doing so, the judge discounted the testimony of Eric A. Hanushek of the Hoover Institution at Stanford, who is perhaps the foremost advocate of the position that money does not make a big difference.
Dr. Hanushek testified that his research sometimes found a negative relationship between spending and the number of students in various New York State school districts who received a Regents diploma, the highest graduating level. 
Among elementary and middle schools in New York City, he found that high-performing schools spent less money than did schools that performed lower. 
But the judge faulted that evidence, saying the studies did not take into account the cumulative effect of differences in spending over many years of schooling. In addition, he discounted studies that looked only at overall spending, rather than how much money goes to specific areas, like class size or teacher training.
The judge also took exception to the view that public schools should take a lesson from the city's parochial schools, although the state had said, in its defense, that the church schools did better while spending less than the public schools. 
According to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, the city's Catholic high schools spend about $5,000 per student and pay their teachers less than public schools do. Roughly 99 percent of the archdiocese's students graduate in four years, and nearly three-quarters pass enough Regents tests to qualify for the top-level diploma. Minority students make up two-thirds of the population, and more than half of all Catholic school students qualify for federal free-lunch programs.
Those results are vastly different from the New York City school system, which spends about $10,000 per student. Only half of its high school students make it to 12th grade in four years, and only 12 percent earn Regents diplomas. Minority groups make up 84 percent of the student population, with roughly three-quarters eligible for federal free-lunch programs.
But Justice DeGrasse said Catholic schools did not have special-education classes, which cost twice as much as general-education classes. Catholic schools also can expel students whom they consider serious troublemakers while public schools must educate everyone, the judge said. 
William C. Thompson Jr., president of the Board of Education, said student achievement would improve when the city got the money it had been denied. "For the last few years, we've seen the restoration of a school system that has standards, that demands results and is starting to focus on improving itself," Mr. Thompson said. The extra money produced by this case "will not be thrown away," he said.

HEADLINE: THE POWER CRISIS: THE SHORTAGES; 
Blackouts Are Narrowly Averted As California Struggles for Power

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
California barely avoided its first planned power blackouts across the state today, as longstanding electricity shortages and a storm that slashed output at a nuclear power plant nearly pushed the state over a precipice on which it has been teetering for months.
 In midafternoon state officials said the blackouts, which would have affected about 1.5 million people, were inevitable. But about 5 p.m., as demand rose toward the winter peak hours, the California Independent System Operator said it had barely managed to avoid the cutoffs by buying power out of state and persuading many customers to cut their use. 
 "At this point it looks like we'll make it," said Patrick Dorinson, the spokesman for the Independent System Operator, which has managed the state's power system since it was deregulated two years ago.
Jim Detmers, the managing director of operations for the system, said he was convinced this morning that the blackouts would be unavoidable because the power supply was only 2 percent greater than demand. 
The state, which normally must import about 15 percent of its electricity, has had to scramble nearly every day for six months to satisfy the enormous demand. But some planned shutdowns of generators for maintenance today, and the winter storm that forced a nuclear plant to reduce output, left the system with 15,000 megawatts less capacity than normal, a huge loss.
"That pushed us over the edge," said Kellan Fluckiger, the chief operating officer of the system. "I can't think of a day when I've seen that many megawatts off."
Some power users did suffer. The major utilities have some customers who have agreed to give up their power first when there are shortages in return for rates about 25 percent lower. Most of those interruptible customers, mostly large industrial and commercial users, lost their power early Thursday, officials said.
The state government also announced that it was slashing its own substantial power demands by 5 percent immediately, which meant that everything from office lights to huge aqueduct pumps were shut down to conserve energy and avoid or mitigate the emergency.
Some areas, like the cities of Los Angeles, Sacramento and Pasadena, were unaffected or little affected because they have municipal power companies. These municipal utilities operate outside of the state's deregulated system, and most have sufficient generating capacity.
While California has reached its most dire power warning stage, called a Stage 3 alert, several times since the energy crisis struck over the summer, this would have been the first time that the Independent System Operator would have ordered the next step, a planned process of switching off customers.
Almost pushing the state over the brink today was the near shutdown of the big Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, near San Luis Obispo, on the central coast.
Normally the plant generates 2,200 megawatts of power, but a major storm pushed up waves of nearly 20 feet today that forced massive beds of kelp into the big pipes that suck in seawater for cooling. Operators had to cut output to 20 percent.
In addition, a power plant in Montana that normally sells about 200 megawatts an hour to California was out of service today, the Independent System Operator said. Officials said they were not sure why.
Because of a quirk in the state's system of transmission lines, the blackouts would have had a greater impact on the north than the south. 
The problem is a transmission bottleneck in the Central Valley, near Bakersfield, known as Path 15, which cannot handle the same capacity as the grids to the north and south of it.
Since power normally flows from south to north in California at this time of year because of the colder weather, that slowed the transmission of power and forced customers in the north to absorb more of the blackouts. 
Given the strong warnings when the Stage 3 alert was declared at 8:50 a.m., most businesses prepared for the first shutdown ever.
For instance, late this afternoon, Agilent Technologies was bracing itself for a blackout at its corporate offices in Silicon Valley. About 400 employees planned to turn off computers, equipment and lights between 4:30 and 7 p.m., relying on generators for emergency lighting.
An Agilent spokeswoman said she expected the company's semiconductor manufacturing plant to avoid blackouts. The plant lies in Santa Clara, where companies like Agilent and Intel have an arrangement with the municipal power company.
The companies, which stand to lose millions of dollars in production costs if power fails, can keep their power if they reduce electricity consumption by 10 percent during emergencies like today's.
California has been running critically short of power since last summer, in part because of rapid population growth throughout the West and an increase in demand because of the robust economy. 
Very few new power plants have been built in the state over the past decade to meet this demand. California imports a large portion of of its electricity, and the rates that the utilities pay for this power on the wholesale market have been soaring, adding a financial crisis to the ongoing energy crisis.
Top state and federal officials have been meeting in Washington in recent days to try to hammer out a comprehensive solution to the problem. California's governor, Gray Davis, declared earlier this week that the deregulation plan was a failure and called for major state intervention in the power market.
Officials said that, though the blackouts were expected to last for just an hour and a half or so at a time, they underscored the fragility of a grid that powers the largest state in the country, with about 34 million residents, and one of the most economically vital and vibrant. 
Were it a separate country, California's economy would be the sixth largest in the world, yet residents, businesses and industries have had to contend with the threat of blackouts for more than six months.
The crisis has pushed the state's two largest utilities, Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, have been pushed almost into bankruptcy.
Under California's oddly crafted deregulation formula, the utilities must buy most of their power at unregulated prices on a state-run wholesale market. But the rates they can charge their customers are capped until March of next year.
Wholesale prices rocketed well above retail price caps last year, leaving the two big utilities with more than $12 billion in losses, a figure that is growing. 
In response to the financial strains, Pacific Gas and Electric told its employees today that it was laying off 325 people immediately and would lay off another 675 employees in the coming months. That comes after 180 layoffs in December.
The blackouts are planned to follow a highly complex procedure. The utilities assign customers in advance to various blocks.
The blocks are not geographic. John Nelson, a Pacific Gas and Electric spokesman, said the company spreads them out so that no community suffers more than another.
After the Independent System Operator gives the word, usually just minutes in advance, the utilities shut down their first block and wait to see if they must roll to the next one.
Operators of the system said that they anticipated less strain on Friday. But the system will be struggling for a long time.
"We don't have enough generating resources for our state, and those we do have are old and they break a lot," Mr. Fluckiger said. "I believe these difficulties will be with us for the next couple of years, until major infrastructure changes are in place."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Grim Reports From Hewlett And Gateway

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Investors in computer companies took a double blow to their already diminished hopes for 2001 late yesterday. Gateway announced disappointing fourth-quarter earnings and layoffs, and Hewlett-Packard said it would fall short of Wall Street's projections for its current quarter.
 Gateway, based in San Diego, in late November became the first company to warn that personal computer sales were surprisingly weak at the onset of the holiday shopping season. Yesterday, it said sales had not picked up in December as much as it had expected. This not only eroded earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31, but left the industry with swollen inventories that will hurt earnings prospects through the first six months of 2001. 
 "There's no way to sugarcoat the next several months," said Jeffrey Weitzen, Gateway's president and chief executive.
Gateway said that it would streamline manufacturing and consolidate its purchasing with fewer vendors as part of efforts to limit the earnings damage by cutting costs. Those moves will eliminate about 2,400 jobs, or 10 percent of Gateway's worldwide work force, and result in a $50 million charge against earnings in the first quarter of this year, the company warned.
The announcement from Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., and sells a far broader range of products, was in some ways more ominous. Carleton S. Fiorina, Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, had bucked the gathering gloom in early December by repeating previous projections that the company expected 15 to 17 percent revenue growth in the fiscal year ending April 30.
But yesterday, Ms. Fiorina said the company's revenue would grow in the low- to midsingle-digits in the current quarter ending Jan. 31, and that its earnings would be 35 to 40 cents a share, below Wall Street's consensus estimate of 42 cents. She also declined to reaffirm previous projections for the rest of the fiscal year.
"It's clear there's been a significant change in market conditions in recent weeks," Ms. Fiorina said. Not only has consumer spending in the United States been below company estimates, which she described as "conservative," but businesses have become more cautious about buying Hewlett-Packard's computers, software and consulting services.
Ms. Fiorina said that the company was running into weakening demand across the board in the United States and that it was not losing market share. "December was like somebody turned the lights out," she said in a conference call with analysts.
Hewlett-Packard's move to reduce expectations was no surprise, but it cut revenue growth projections more deeply than analysts had anticipated.
"Carly is shifting to a more cautious approach to try to regain credibility," said George Elling, who follows the company for Lehman Brothers.
The announcements came at the end of what had been a buoyant day for technology stocks on Wall Street. Hewlett-Packard had risen 63 cents, to $32.38, and Gateway had jumped $2.96, to $22.90. But after the announcements, both tumbled in after-hours trading, with Hewlett down as much as $2 and Gateway off as much as $3.39. Other stocks caught in the after-hours downdraft included Microsoft, Dell Computer, and Intel.
"We have an economic problem that is widening and deepening," said Donald Young, who follows computer companies for UBS Warburg. "A lot of high-tech companies are feeling it."
Gateway executives, in a conference call with analysts, said its problems were not entirely a result of deteriorating market conditions. The company said that it had not cut expenses fast enough in December and that it had fumbled a product introduction in Asia. But Gateway stressed that the financial problems did not give it any reason to second-guess its "beyond the box" strategy, which is aimed at shifting its emphasis from personal computers to selling a broad range of consumer electronic devices that will connect to computers and to the Internet. The strategy includes expanding its own chain of retail stores.
Gateway said it lost $94.3 million, or 29 cents a diluted share, on revenues of $2.37 billion, in contrast to a profit of $126 million, or 38 cents a share, on revenue of $2.55 billion a year ago. The loss in the recent quarter included a one-time $187 million pretax charge related to the declining value of Gateway's portfolio of investments in other technology companies. Excluding the charges, Gateway would have earned $37.6 million, or 12 cents a share, in the recent quarter, a decline of more than 68 percent from a year earlier.
As tough as the fourth quarter was on Gateway's profits, the current quarter promises to be even more challenging. Gateway said it lowered personal computer prices by 10 percent in December but had generally let other companies lead the way on price cuts. In the future, the company said, it plans to be a more aggressive participant in the unfolding personal computer price war even though it lost money on that part of its business in the recent quarter.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Clinton's Last Memo

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Memo to: The Arab Street
From: President Bill Clinton
 Dear ladies and gentlemen, over the last few years I've often written your leaders, but now that my term is ending I've decided my last letter should be to you, the Arab masses, the Arab street, who have paid such a high price for this ongoing conflict. 
 I'm going to be blunt. I've done all I could to build a fair, realistic pathway out of the Arab-Israeli conflict for both you and the Israelis, but if you want to continue fighting it out and avoiding a deal that gives you 95 percent of what you want, well, there's nothing more I can do.
But there is something I can say, and it's this: What troubles me most about the mood on the Arab street today is the hostility I detect there to modernization, globalization, demo cratization and the information revolution. What you do with the Israelis is up to you now, but what you do with your own societies is going to affect the stability of the whole Middle East. 
Where other countries are focused on developing world-class competitive industries, you are still focused on protecting your uncompetitive ones. Where others are aggressively trading with the world, you barely trade with each other. Where others are freeing their presses, you are still controlling yours. Where other world leaders are building their legitimacy by pushing education, most of yours are still building their legitimacy by pushing a religious conflict. Where others are seeking foreign investors in order to create jobs for their young people, you are driving off foreign investors with unfriendly bureaucracies and pursuit of a conflict that scares everyone away from your region. In an age when others are making microchips, you are making potato chips.
I would have thought that this reality would be a hotly debated subject among your elites, and I know some have raised it. But for the most part your intellectuals, pundits and parliamentarians, rather than fostering an honest debate, prefer to make excuses. When I ask Arab leaders why South Korea had roughly the same per capita income in the early 1950's as Syria or Egypt, and now South Korea is a highly developed country and Syria and Egypt are still developing, the answer I get is that the Arab states had to fight wars. Well, South Korea had a struggle with North Korea for decades. Another excuse I get is that the Arab states had population problems. Well, so does China, and it's been growing at 10 percent per year.
Your intellectuals seem more interested in protecting their perks, by coming up with excuses for the weakness of their regimes, rather than fostering an honest debate.
I realize that the issue of Israel, and who rules over the Muslim holy places in Jerusalem, touches the soul of the Arab street. I would not think of asking you to give up on controlling your religious sites. But I would urge you to consider asking more than one question. Who rules al Aksa mosque is critical for the dignity of every Arab and Palestinian Muslim in the modern world. But what sort of education you offer your kids, what sort of economy you build and what sort of rule of law you establish will also determine your dignity and standing in the modern world. You should be concerned with answering the old questions, but you have to recognize that they are not the only questions.
There has to be a balance. A society that forgets its roots will never be stable. But a society that is preoccupied with its roots, and is asking the question only of who owns which root, will never grow into the world or bear fruit. Your intellectuals don't care. They eat the fruit no matter what. They are protected by the regimes, while they keep you living only by the old questions and the old role models. In doing so, they ensure that you never reach your full potential. 
I understand you get frustrated with America. But when you follow the Arab elites into supporting Saddam Hussein, I don't understand. Forget about us, think about this man and what he has done to his neighbors, the poison gas he has used on his own people, the generation of Iraqis he has destroyed. Is this a role model? Is this the sort of Arab leader you want for your own societies?
I hope not. I hope one day soon I will see an intifada not only for an independent Palestine but for Arab education, for Arab free press, for Arab legality, for Arab democracy. An Arab street that can ask only one question will, in the end, not be a very nice place to raise your kids.
Sincerely,
Bill Clinton

HEADLINE: For Hillary Clinton, a Health Care Assignment 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was appointed to three Senate committees today, including one that has jurisdiction over health care, the very issue she tried to put her stamp on as first lady.
 Mrs. Clinton's appointment to the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee came as somewhat of a surprise, since she has been so closely identified in Washington with the Clinton administration's failed attempt to overhaul the nation's health care system in 1993. 
 Ranit Schmelzer, a spokeswoman for Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said Mrs. Clinton was chosen for that committee because of her expertise in areas like health care and education. She dismissed any suggestion that Mrs. Clinton would be a polarizing figure on the panel. "I think she will fit right in," Ms. Schmezler said. "She'll lend her expertise to issues, and she'll have a lot to learn."
The announcement of Mrs. Clinton's committee assignments offered an early indication of where New York's new senator will make her mark on Capitol Hill. In the days leading up to the announcement, some lawmakers said that serving on a committee with Mrs. Clinton would be a mixed blessing. They acknowledged that she could bring greater attention to their issues, but said they were also aware that her celebrity status could eclipse them.
The other high-profile committee that Mrs. Clinton was assigned to is Environment and Public Works. That committee is responsible not only for helping write the nation's environmental laws, but also for overseeing hundreds of millions of dollars in highway and other transportation money.
Mrs. Clinton's aides said the assignment was particularly valuable in part because the committee gives members the opportunity to direct federal money to their home states. Mrs. Clinton's predecessor, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, excelled at that when he served as the chairman of Environment and Public Works, so much so that former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo openly worried when Mr. Moynihan left the committee in 1992 to become chairman of the powerful Senate Finance Committee.
New Jersey's new junior senator, Jon S. Corzine, was also appointed to the Environment and Public Works Committee. 
In a nod to his Wall Street credentials, Mr. Corzine was also chosen for the Senate Banking Committee, which has jurisdiction over financial services, and the Joint Economics Committee. He rose from being a trader at Goldman, Sachs & Company to become its co-chairman, amassing a $400 million fortune, $65 million of which he spent during his Senate campaign.
Mrs. Clinton's third committee assignment is on the Budget Committee, which deals with an array of important fiscal policy questions but is not considered a powerhouse like the Finance or the Appropriations Committees.

HEADLINE: Helms Urges Foreign Aid Be Handled By Charities 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Senator Jesse Helms, the most powerful critic of foreign aid in Congress, said today that he would champion an increase in international assistance -- but only if all future United States aid was funneled to the needy through private charities and religious groups instead of a government agency.
 Mr. Helms, a North Carolina Republican who will return to lead the Foreign Relations Committee on Jan. 20, said he modeled his proposal after President-elect George W. Bush's campaign theme of empowering private relief groups to help the poor. If adopted by the administration and Congress, Mr. Helms's plan would mark the most decisive shift in 40 years in how America helps the world's downtrodden. 
 "The time has come to reject what President Bush correctly labels the 'failed compassion of towering, distant bureaucracies' and, instead, empower private and faith-based groups who care most about those in need," Mr. Helms said in a speech at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group. 
Gen. Colin L. Powell, Mr. Bush's choice for secretary of state, met with Mr. Helms earlier this week, and while General Powell expressed support for increasing foreign aid, an aide said he was not briefed on details of the senator's proposal. 
A spokesman for General Powell, F. William Smullen, was noncommittal tonight: "We've now seen the senator's comments, and we welcome his ideas and his contribution to the debate. We obviously need to study a variety of different issues." 
In his wide-ranging speech, Mr. Helms called on Mr. Bush to isolate and weaken Fidel Castro's government in Cuba, equip Taiwan's military with more advanced weapons, ratchet up pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, and ensure that Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are invited to join NATO. 
But his most provocative proposal was to abolish the Agency for International Development and shift responsibility for overseeing $7 billion a year in economic and humanitarian aid to a quasi-governmental foundation, which would deliver grants to private and community relief groups. 
The plan envisions replacing the aid agency and its 7,300 employees with a smaller, streamlined International Development Foundation with lower expenses. The secretary of state as well as relief groups would oversee the foundation's activities, Mr. Helms's aides said, to provide oversight and coordination with American foreign policy goals. 
"If we can reform the way in which we deliver aid to the needy," Mr. Helms said, "I will be willing to take the lead in the Senate in supporting increased U.S. investment." 
Relief groups voiced mixed reactions to the proposal, from cautious skepticism to stunned disbelief to enthusiastic support. Mr. Helms has long been a searing critic of American foreign aid, complaining, as he did today, that government-organized assistance has only "lined the pockets of corrupt dictators, while funding the salaries of a growing, bloated bureaucracy." 
But in the past several months, Mr. Helms has shown a new zeal for helping the world's poor, particularly in Africa. The 79-year-old senator has attributed his conversion of sorts to conversations with the Rev. Franklin Graham -- the son of the Rev. Billy Graham -- who runs a relief organization in North Carolina called Samaritan's Purse. 
Under his plan, Mr. Helms said, the groups that could receive grants include World Vision, Save the Children, Hadassah, Catholic Relief Services and Samaritan's Purse.
"I'm delighted to hear Senator Helms call for dramatically improving and increasing foreign aid to poor and hungry people," said the Rev. David Beckmann, president of Bread for the World, the nation's largest grass-roots anti-hunger lobbying group. 
But Bruce Wilkinson, a senior vice president for World Vision, which distributes $900 million in aid a year, 10 percent from A.I.D., to 100 countries, expressed concern that the long partnership between the government and private relief groups could be disrupted. "I really do applaud the moral commitment that Helms is demonstrating," said Mr. Wilkinson, "but at this point, the International Development Foundation is a very sketchy idea." 
Mr. Helms is resurrecting a proposal he made five years ago that ran into opposition and died in committee. Other lawmakers have proposed alternatives. Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who heads the Appropriations subcommittee that oversees A.I.D., has favored integrating the agency into the State Department. 
An A.I.D. spokesman said 37 percent of its bilateral development assistance goes through non-governmental groups, including faith-based ones. Since President Clinton took office, it has slashed its staff to 7,300 people from 10,000.

HEADLINE: Choice for Health Secretary Is Faulted on Tobacco Issue 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Tobacco opponents in Wisconsin and Washington say Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, who is President-elect George W. Bush's choice to head the Health and Human Services Department, has not vigorously pursued tobacco control initiatives, in part because of ties to executives of Philip Morris, the cigarette maker.
 As the parent corporation of two Wisconsin companies -- the Miller Brewing Company and Oscar Mayer Foods, a division of Kraft Foods -- Philip Morris is one of Wisconsin's largest employers. Mr. Thompson's aides and Philip Morris officials say it is appropriate that he has worked closely with company executives over the 14 years he has been Wisconsin's governor. 
 But tobacco opponents have raised concerns about Mr. Thompson's participation in two international trips financed largely by Philip Morris, as well as more than $72,000 in contributions to him from employees and executives of the company and its food and beer subsidiaries.
The contributions, made from 1993 to 2000, account for less than 1 percent of more than $10 million raised by the governor in that time. But those contributions represent the largest amount affiliated with any single company, according to the records compiled by Wisconsin Democracy Campaign, a nonpartisan group that tracks election spending.
Tobacco opponents also criticize some of the governor's policy decisions, like his vetoes of two bills, one in 1995 that would have banned smoking at Milwaukee's new baseball stadium and another in 1990 that would have permitted municipalities to enact tougher tobacco restrictions than those of the state.
"Governor Thompson has a pretty well-documented relationship with Philip Morris, and that causes us some concern," said Paul Billings, a spokesman for the American Lung Association, which is neither opposing nor supporting the governor's nomination. "As secretary of health, one of the most important issues he will be facing is the horrendous toll tobacco takes on the American public."
Mr. Thompson, a Republican, declined to be interviewed for this article, referring questions to a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush. The spokeswoman, Alicia Peterson, said, "Governor Thompson has a record of opposing youth access to tobacco and tobacco products." Ms. Peterson said Mr. Thompson had banned smoking on school grounds and allowed teenagers to participate in sting operations to expose retailers who sold cigarettes to minors.
Peggy Roberts, a Philip Morris spokeswoman, said the company had worked closely with Mr. Thompson because of Philip Morris's economic interests in the state. The company has nearly 7,500 employees in Wisconsin, but no cigarette manufacturing plants there.
Mr. Thompson, 59, is Wisconsin's longest-serving governor. He has earned a national reputation as a champion of programs to put welfare recipients back to work and to provide health insurance for the poor. Democrats and Republicans in Washington expect him to win confirmation with little trouble. 
Still, his record on tobacco policy is likely to surface in Senate confirmation hearings next week. Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said he intended to explore "the governor's views and record on issues like tobacco control."
If confirmed as secretary of health and human services, Mr. Thompson would oversee a vast agency. The department includes the Food and Drug Administration, which has tried to regulate tobacco products, as well as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, which guides states in developing antismoking initiatives.
Those initiatives, relying on money from a settlement with cigarette makers, have been controversial in Wisconsin, as in many states. Mr. Thompson has drawn criticism for the way he allocated money from Wisconsin's $170-million-a-year tobacco settlement. And while he has raised the cigarette tax several times -- most recently by 15 cents a pack in 1997 -- some say it is not enough.
The tax now stands at 59 cents a pack, but Bonnie Sumner, president of the Wisconsin Initiative on Smoking and Health, a nonprofit group that advocates strict smoking regulations, said she and other tobacco opponents believed that a tax of $1 was necessary to discourage young people from buying cigarettes. State officials said that 38 percent of high school students in Wisconsin smoke, as compared with 34 percent nationally.
"A 15-cent tax is a meaningless figure as far as decreasing smoking," Ms. Sumner said. 
Joe Leann, Wisconsin's health secretary, said critics like Ms. Sumner were short-sighted, and said they have ignored the governor's other accomplishments, which included offering smoking cessation clinics as part of the state's health insurance program for low-income families.
In 1996, when many states were contemplating filing suit against the tobacco industry for reimbursement of the cost of caring for injured smokers, the state's attorney general accused Mr. Thompson of dragging his heels.
Wisconsin did join more than a dozen other states in filing claims against the cigarette industry, and Mr. Thompson became a vocal supporter of the lawsuit. But he drew criticism when The Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel published telephone records indicating that in the weeks before the suit was filed, Mr. Thompson had placed a series of telephone calls to Philip Morris executives, including one to its chief executive, Geoffrey C. Bible.
The content of the conversation with Mr. Bible has never been disclosed and Ms. Roberts declined to discuss it. But she defended the relationship between the governor and the company. "It is important to our businesses in Wisconsin for us to maintain that relationship, and those businesses include food and beer," Ms. Roberts said.
Dennis Dresang, the chairman of the department of political science at the University of Wisconsin, said the news articles about Mr. Thompson's contacts with top Philip Morris executives had hurt the governor's image because "people were suspicious of the phone calls." That suspicion was raised again, Professor Dresang said, when trips Mr. Thompson took with company executives to South Africa and Australia were disclosed. 
The trips, in 1995 and 1996, were arranged by the National Governors' Association; Mr. Thompson was chairman of the group at the time. "There has been a bit of concern about whether the governor was promoting Wisconsin, or Philip Morris products," Professor Dresang said.
The trips were financed largely by Philip Morris through three nonprofit groups that promote free trade. Mr. Thompson said he learned of the company's involvement only later. In Australia, the delegation went scuba diving, and Mr. Thompson wrote to a Philip Morris lobbyist, John C. Lenzi, thanking him for taking "the scuba diving plunge with me" and encouraging Mr. Lenzi to visit the next time he was in Madison, the state capital. The correspondence was first disclosed by The Journal-Sentinel in 1997.
In an interview on Wednesday, Mr. Thompson's wife, Sue Ann, said it was "only natural" for him to maintain good ties with such an important corporate citizen. "I just know for a fact that he would not be influenced because of the dollars being spent on a trip or whatever," said Mrs. Thompson, the founder of a nonprofit women's health advocacy group. "Anyone who knows Tom knows that the decisions he makes are based on what's best for Wisconsin."

HEADLINE: Woman in the News; 
A Washington Veteran for Labor; a Tested Negotiator for Trade; Elaine Lan Chao

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Ever since she was 8, and a freighter bearing her family into New York harbor offered a first glimpse of the Statue of Liberty, Elaine L. Chao has concentrated on finding her place in America.
 Ms. Chao -- Chinese immigrant, Harvard graduate, former head of the Peace Corps and the United Way -- reached a new rung today in a fast-rising career, becoming President-elect George W. Bush's choice as secretary of labor. 
 Just two days after his first selection for the post, Linda Chavez, pulled out, Mr. Bush introduced a replacement in Ms. Chao, 47, saying she epitomized the values and dreams of hard-working Americans. Ms. Chao, who is now an expert on philanthropy at the Heritage Foundation, the conservative research institute, is widely sought after as a public speaker, fund-raiser and board member. 
"Elaine Chao believes deeply in the American dream because she has lived it," Mr. Bush said.
Ms. Chao thanked a litany of friends and relatives today for supporting her, most notably her husband, Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, whom she called "the love of my life." But her public remarks have made plain that she believes self-reliance is the essential engine of success.
She has said she opposes racial quotas and numerical goals, but emphasized the importance of giving everyone an equal opportunity. She advocates working to bring immigrants into the mainstream, and suggests that new citizens be given a course in what is considered appropriate behavior by most Americans.
Ms. Chao's views on affirmative action are likely to draw close scrutiny from minority and immigrant advocacy groups. As a participant in President Clinton's 1998 "Dialogue on Race," she criticized schools and companies that overlooked merit to meet diversity goals. 
"I think we should heed to the overall core value of this country that equal opportunity applies for all, and that should be the same standards for everyone," she said.
Asian-Americans, she said at a 1997 meeting of the National Commission of Civic Renewal, "have also been tremendously damaged by affirmative action." 
"Many Asian-Americans are excluded from minority procurement programs," she said. "They are not considered to be minorities in the full sense of the word -- positive and negative -- and quota systems in the best universities in this land exclude qualified Asian-Americans."
If confirmed by the Senate, Ms. Chao will probably confront several more mundane, but still controversial, issues affecting regulation of the American workplace. Among them are whether to rescind the Clinton administration's new rules on ergonomics in the workplace; whether to support the right of union members to withhold the part of their dues that is used for political purposes; whether to support more inspectors for safety, wage and overtime violations; and whether to back an increase in the $5.15 minimum wage.
In remarks to the press today, Ms. Chao (pronounced chow) said she would work to "protect, nurture and develop America's most precious resource," its working men and women.
Elaine Lan Chao grew up in New York, where her father worked three jobs, put himself through college, and eventually built a successful shipping business. She received a degree in economics from Mount Holyoke College, then went on to earn a master's degree in business administration at the Harvard Business School, which Mr. Bush also attended.
Ms. Chao worked as an investment banker at Bank of America and Citicorp before moving to Washington, where she received a White House fellowship in 1983. In that post, she met then-Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole, who later helped pave the way for her appointment as deputy secretary of transportation under President George Bush in 1989.
It was a cataclysmic year at Transportation. Ms. Chao was generally regarded as coping effectively with the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the San Francisco earthquake and Hurricane Hugo.
After a brief stint as director of the Peace Corps, Ms. Chao took a job that plunged her into a different sort of crisis.
In 1992, she took charge of the United Way of America after its president, William V. Aramony, resigned amid charges of financial improprieties and an outcry over his $390,000 salary. Ms. Chao undertook a tough reorganization, which included cutting her salary to half that of Mr. Aramony's, cutting the administrative budget by 30 percent and laying off a third of the staff.
She was widely praised for restoring the image of the charity, but did not escape without a controversy at her departure. When she announced she was leaving in 1996, several board members sought to present Ms. Chao with a privately raised bonus of $292,500. Amid a public outcry over the bonus, Ms. Chao ultimately refused it.
At the Heritage Foundation, she has provided expertise on civil society, the nonprofit sector and philanthropy. She has served on numerous corporate boards, including those of Clorox, Dole Food and Northwest Airlines. Since 1993, she has been married to Senator McConnell, who is perhaps best known for his opposition to campaign finance reform.
Ms. Chao displayed some political savvy today by placing early calls to labor leaders, who responded cordially.
"I can attest to her leadership skills, her integrity and her ability to bring together diverse interests," said Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America. "I believe she will be responsive to the needs of working families."

Elaine Lan Chao

BORN: March 26, 1953, in Taipei, Taiwan

HEADLINE: Man in the News; 
A Washington Veteran for Labor; a Tested Negotiator for Trade; Robert Bruce Zoellick

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
A visitor to Robert B. Zoellick's seventh-floor office in the State Department in the early 1990's might have mistaken the young diplomat for a college prankster. He stacked his coffee table with a parody of Time magazine and a picture book of rat-eating snakes. Felt posters of poker-playing dogs lined the walls.
 But that sophomoric sense of humor -- friends say Mr. Zoellick decorated his office that way to tease the gray-suited dignitaries who called on him -- is about the only thing impish about the man President-elect George W. Bush named today as his chief trade representative. 
 People who worked with Mr. Zoellick, 47, during two earlier Republican administrations describe him as a policy wonk whose sharp-edged negotiating tactics and mastery of details often won over, or wore down, his rivals -- notably over the past several weeks as he lobbied for the trade job and its role within the new administration. A confidant of former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, he rallied Western allies to back a speedy German reunification and finagled a compromise that led to the creation of the World Trade Organization. 
"He was the most impressive thinker of my time in government," said Richard Burt, a former assistant secretary of state. Derek H. Burney, Canada's former ambassador to the United States, called Mr. Zoellick a sharp-elbowed negotiator, but added, "in the end he won the argument through the power of his intellect, not the raw political power of the U.S."
In tapping Mr. Zoellick, Mr. Bush chose a Republican insider whose resume reads a little like an encyclopedia of diplomatic and economic abbreviations -- NATO, W.T.O., Nafta, G-7, APEC and Uruguay Round -- are among the many trade, military and economic groups, summits and negotiating forums in which he had a role.
That experience, though broad, was a largely behind-the-curtains preparation for what he will face as United States trade representative. If confirmed, Mr. Zoellick (pronounced ZELL-ik) will occupy a post that arguably has a higher public profile and more sensitive political mission than ever before. 
Mr. Zoellick will have to implement Mr. Bush's campaign pledge to work toward eliminating the remaining barriers to free trade throughout the Americas. He will also have to address mounting discontent among developing nations, some of which contend that the United States and other wealthy countries have betrayed free trade by refusing to dismantle import barriers that protect farm goods, textiles and steel.
"The overarching issue for him is going to be restoring American leadership of free trade," said Harold McGraw III, the chief executive officer of McGraw Hill Companies, who serves as chairman of the Emergency Committee for American Trade, a lobbying group.
The politics are complex. Lawmakers are split almost evenly on the wisdom of expanding trade, and unions have energized their members to oppose many trade agreements.
Some Bush advisers view the task of building a consensus for free trade as so essential that they considered selecting Richard W. Fisher, a Democrat who is the No. 2 trade official in the Clinton administration, for the top trade post. The Bush transition team also thought about stripping the trade representative of the cabinet rank the position has held for 25 years to streamline the way the administration managed the economy.
In the end, Mr. Zoellick had his way. People who know him said he pushed for the trade post and argued passionately that the trade representative should continue to sit with the cabinet. That things worked out in his favor stems partly from his public-policy credentials, his supporters said, and his circle of friends, which includes several prominent Democrats. But he also cashed in some chits from his lengthy service to the Bush family.
Under his mentor, Mr. Baker, Mr. Zoellick helped run two campaigns for President George Bush. Mr. Zoellick earned the nickname "the adding machine" for his number-crunching contribution to policy ideas that addressed what the elder Bush once called "the vision thing."
Mr. Zoellick served the president-elect in a similar way. He became one of Mr. Bush's foreign policy pundits, writing a stream of op-ed pieces and magazine articles that laid the groundwork for what he called a Republican foreign policy. 
He dissected what he saw as President Clinton's mistakes in dealings with China, Russia, Iraq and Japan. He pushed the theme that the new administration should avoid nation-building exercises like the United States role in Haiti and Somalia and in the Balkans, an idea Mr. Bush used in his debates with Vice President Al Gore.
Robert Bruce Zoellick grew up in Naperville, Ill., near Chicago. He attended Naperville Central High School and then moved East, attending Swarthmore College before receiving law and public policy degrees at Harvard University.
Mr. Zoellick joined the Reagan administration at the behest of Richard Darman, one of his former Harvard teachers who at the time served in the Treasury Department. He went on to become a close aide to Mr. Baker, working for him in the Treasury Department and then, during President Bush's term, at the State Department, where he became an under secretary for economic policy.
There, aside from his kitschy office, he was remembered for toting around yellow legal pads filled to the margins with his tidy penmanship, diligently laying out the pros and cons of strategy choices.
"He was the best prepared guy in the room," said Edward Djerejian, a former ambassador and State Department official. "He often had an outside-the-box solution for many issues."
But he is most widely remembered in foreign policy circles for being the United States' representative at the multiparty negotiation over the future of divided Germany. He persuaded the Bush administration to embrace German unity despite the qualms of allies and alarm in the former Soviet Union.
By defusing the potentially volatile issue of Germany, Mr. Djerejian said, Mr. Zoellick "gets a lot of credit for the fact that the cold war ended with a whimper."

Robert Bruce Zoellick

EDUCATION: Naperville Central High School; B.A., Swarthmore College; M.P.P. Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University; J.D., Harvard Law School.

HEADLINE: In New Hampshire, Clinton's Heart Is on His Sleeve 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 11 

 BODY:
President Clinton took a walk down memory lane today -- or to be more exact, down Elm Street -- in the center of a city that was so crucial nearly nine years ago to his presidential election.
 Mr. Clinton ducked into the Merrimack Restaurant, one of his haunts here in the 1992 campaign, and requested the same waitress, Jane Davis, who had served him then and had once written in the local newspaper that he was the best tipper of all the candidates who came through. 
 "He was presidential, even back then," Ms. Davis said. "He is a charming man and he didn't just shake your hand all stiff, like the rest of them." 
Continuing his nationwide farewell tour, Mr. Clinton, who is in the final two weeks of his presidency, visited the state that salvaged his presidential bid in some of its darkest moments in 1992.
As accusations of draft dodging and marital infidelity threatened to destroy his campaign, Mr. Clinton promised the people of New Hampshire that he would fight for them "until the last dog dies." Today, in a return trip to the city of Dover, he recounted his administration's achievements and declared that "the last dog is still barking."
Later, in Manchester, the president walked past stores along Elm Street that he said had been boarded up when he came through as a governor aspiring the presidency.
"It was a tough time eight years ago for our country when I came here," Mr. Clinton said. "It was also a fairly tough time for me. I was taking a whipping in the press and I was dropping in the polls. But I said then, and I would like to say again, that was nothing compared to the punishment that the people of this state and this nation were enduring."
Reminiscing about that first campaign, Mr. Clinton recalled meeting a man who had lost his job 30 days before his pension became vested and hearing a girl describe how she hated dinner because her unemployed father would always cry. He spotted an older citizen whom he had first met in a bingo hall in Dover, and told her, "I would say, ma'am, I've aged a lot more than you have in the last eight years."
Mr. Clinton held up the "Putting People First" pamphlet that his campaign handed out in 1992 and said, "The stuff that was in this book that people made fun of is now real in the lives of the American people."
Mr. Clinton's eyes welled with tears and he bit his lip when he was introduced at Dover High School today by Ron Machos Jr., a thriving small-business man who had been out of work with no health insurance and a sick son when he met Mr. Clinton on his first campaign. The president called Mr. Machos and his family "the symbol of what my efforts in 1992 were all about."
The early months of that year were tough ones for Mr. Clinton, whose campaign was floundering as he battled reports that he had evaded the draft and carried on a lengthy affair with Gennifer Flowers. 
Mr. Clinton ultimately finished second in New Hampshire, just behind Paul Tsongas, surprising the Democratic establishment and prompting him to declare himself "the Comeback Kid."
"I came here one last time as president to thank you for making me the Comeback Kid, and far more important, to thank you for making America the comeback country," Mr. Clinton said today. "Through all the ups and downs of the last eight years, I never forgot the lesson I learned from you hear in those amazing weeks in the winter of 1991 and 1992."
When he huddled with longtime supporters in the Manchester diner, he said another candidate had also learned from that experience in New Hampshire.
"One of the reasons Hillary did so well is she ran in upstate New York like how I ran in New Hampshire," Mr. Clinton said. "She talked to people about the economic challenges."

HEADLINE: THE POWER CRISIS: THE NEGOTIATIONS; 
Seeking Harmony to Quiet California Energy Turmoil

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
While Californians readied themselves for yet another day of possible power blackouts, negotiators in Washington continued today to try to hammer out a solution to the state's energy problems.
 Two days ago, President Clinton brought together federal and state leaders, utility executives and power generation representatives to discuss the crisis in California that has driven the state's two largest utilities to the brink of bankruptcy and threatens the state's economy. That group, which included Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, agreed that several issues needed to be addressed to solve California's problems. 
 Topics discussed today and in the seven-hour meeting on Tuesday included promoting long-term purchasing contracts between the utilities that use electricity and the power generators that sell it, and the willingness of creditors to give temporary relief while the utilities and state regulators sort out how to pay the $12 billion in electricity costs that the utilities have incurred since May. This weekend, the group is expected to reconvene to devise a course of action. 
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson told reporters in Washington today that a plan may not be ready by Saturday as planned, but that one of the options would be to give utilities 60 to 90 days to repay past debts.
Also on the agenda this weekend will be whether to allow the companies who make and sell electricity to enter into contracts to charge utilities 5.5 cents a kilowatt-hour for electricity. Utilities are currently allowed to charge consumers about 7 cents a kilowatt-hour, although they have been paying power producers an average of 35 cents.
In Washington today, people who attended the meetings said that representatives of producers would like to lock in that price for nine years, while state officials would prefer to limit that price to three years.
John Burton, president of the California State Senate, who attended Tuesday's meeting, said he supported the price being discussed. He said he wanted the state to buy electricity and then resell it to utilities, but did not want to be a guarantor of the utilities' debt. At a price of 5.5 cents, he said, "this would guarantee long-term stability and affordability."
Consumer groups have complained that any price negotiated now could look too high in the future if prices for electricity fall, a surety, they contend, as much as they have gone up.
"It all depends on the terms," said Harvey Rosenfield, president of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights in Santa Monica. 
Those on hand at today's meeting also included officials from the California Independent System Operator, which manages the state's power grid, as well as Treasury officials.
California utility executives from Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison have warned that bankruptcy is imminent, possibly by Feb. 1, if something is not done to relieve the cash shortage that has led them to suspend dividends and lay off employees. Financial ratings agencies, which monitor the utilities' health, are a step away from giving their debt a junk-bond rating, which would cripple their efforts to get more financing.
One of the most surprising aspects of the situation is that it took the intervention of the Treasury Secretary to broker a meeting about a crisis that many in California had predicted, but no one wanted to take responsibility for.
One person involved in the talks said that in November, executives from the Federal Reserve in San Francisco warned Treasury officials that trouble was brewing at the state's largest utilities, a situation that could have a negative impact on financial markets. Worse, said the individual, officials were told that relations between state officials and regulators at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the power generators, had grown so testy that the two sides were unable to work together.
Loretta Lynch, president of California's Public Utilities Commission, has repeatedly blamed the federal commission for doing nothing to admonish the power generators for high prices. James Hoecker, chairman of the federal commission, has told state officials repeatedly that they had to get their own house in order. At Tuesday's meeting, the two sat side by side but barely said a word to each other, one person who attended said.
Still, utility executives were heartened that all the parties are talking. "We've finally reached a point in the road where we have to come to some agreement," said Tom Higgins, a senior vice president for Edison International, the parent company of Southern California Edison.
At the same time that harmony was being attempted in Washington, Los Angeles officials said they wanted reassurances that Los Angeles would be repaid for any electricity it had already sold to the state. 
"We are not a charitable organization," said S. David Freeman, general manager of the Los Angeles Department of Power and Water. "We are not pulling the plug on anyone. We just want to be reassured that the money we are putting out is going to get reimbursed."

HEADLINE: IN A SWIFT ACTION, BUSH NAMES CHOICE FOR LABOR DEPT. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush moved swiftly today to replace his initial selection for labor secretary, naming a less outspoken conservative, Elaine L. Chao, who was an official in his father's administration. He also selected a Republican veteran of economic diplomacy, Robert B. Zoellick, to serve as the country's top trade negotiator, a post Mr. Bush said he had decided to keep in the cabinet. 
 Mr. Bush announced the appointments today without mentioning the revelations that sank his first choice for the labor job, Linda Chavez, and he somewhat testily defended his most controversial candidate, John Ashcroft, a religious conservative who is the attorney general designee. 
 "I want Americans to see this good man," Mr. Bush said, adding that he had recently held a "long talk with John" about how he would enforce civil rights laws -- an area that has been a particular focus of Mr. Ashcroft's critics. 
In another exchange, Mr. Bush made little effort to hide his annoyance at President Clinton, who questioned the legitimacy of the president-elect's victory on Tuesday night, saying "the only way they could win the election was to stop the voting in Florida."
Mr. Bush, asked about Mr. Clinton's comments, retorted, "He can say what he wants to say, but January the 20th I'll be honored to be sworn in as president." 
While Ms. Chao as labor secretary must deal with unions' suspicions of the Bush administration's intentions, Mr. Zoelleck, 47, must navigate divisions within the Democratic and Republican Parties over America's strategy in global trade negotiations.
Ms. Chao, 47, came to the United States at age 8 from Taiwan, was considered for a cabinet job and passed over two weeks ago. But as soon as Ms. Chavez withdrew, after it became clear that she had misled the Bush transition team and the F.B.I. by initially failing to disclose that an illegal immigrant had lived in her house and performed chores, the Bush team scrambled for a quick replacement whose background had already been thoroughly reviewed. Page A17. 
That quickly led them to Ms. Chao, a prominent conservative, who has raised concerns about the use of numerical goals and quotas in hiring, but unlike Ms. Chavez has not been an outspoken opponent of affirmative action.
In the previous Bush administration Ms. Chao served as deputy transportation secretary, and more recently she headed the United Way. She is also the wife of Mitch McConnell, the conservative senator from Kentucky who has led the opposition to campaign finance reform. One Republican objection to the reform bills is that they do not block unions from contributing; Ms. Chao would now be the administration's chief official dealing with those unions.
Today, Ms. Chao did not talk about how she would run the labor department. Instead, she focused on the story of her own arrival in the United States and her emotions sailing past the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. She described how she entered the third grade speaking no English and how her father worked to teach her every evening.
The selection of Mr. Zoellick was less surprising than Ms. Chao's. Among senior Republican officials in Washington, he is one of the few with deep experience navigating the turbulent waters of international economics. A committed internationalist, he was under secretary of state for economic affairs under former President George Bush. From that post he was a major player in the negotiations over the Nafta accord and was architect of a major agreement involving German reunification.
"Free trade is about freedom," he said today. " It's important for our economy but also for America's other interests and values throughout the world."
Mr. Zoellick is also a fierce Bush loyalist. He was called to Florida in November by former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has long been his mentor, to help Mr. Bush in the legal fight to retain his narrow lead in Florida. 
Behind the scenes, Mr. Zoellick won another battle: To preserve the trade representative's seat at the cabinet table, the subject of a fierce internal debate within the Bush transition team. Every trade representative since the Carter administration has held cabinet-equivalent rank, but Mr. Bush sought to reduce the cabinet's size. Meanwhile, other members of Mr. Bush's foreign policy team -- a field already crowded with Gen. Colin L. Powell, Condoleezza Rice, Donald H. Rumsfeld and Vice President-elect Dick Cheney -- were clearly leery of introducing another major voice on international affairs in the administration.
"We've been looking at the question of how much authority the treasury and the trade office have had in American foreign policy," one adviser to the president-elect said recently. But once the debate broke into the open, Mr. Bush's team came under intense pressure not to downgrade the trade representative's post. Members of Congressional committees with oversight responsibility for trade complained. And virtually every major American trading partner places a cabinet-level official in charge of trade talks -- many combine the job with foreign minister -- raising the question of whether they would negotiate with an American of lesser rank.
"This idea is madness," Charlene Barshefsky, President Clinton's trade representative, said earlier this week, as word of the internal arguments in the Bush camp spread. "No one would deal with us."
In the end, a senior Bush adviser said today, Mr. Bush concluded that "it was important to the agricultural community and to our friends in the hemisphere" to keep the post in the cabinet. Mr. Bush himself said that "the reason why the position needs to remain a cabinet position is because of the importance of a global economy."
By announcing the two selections today, Mr. Bush and his aides were clearly trying to put their first major setback, the failed candidacy of Ms. Chavez, behind them. While Ms. Chao has championed conservative causes, labor union officials were conciliatory today about her selection. They made it clear she was unlikely to evoke the kind of ideological objections that Ms. Chavez did, objections that sped Ms. Chavez's fall once she conceded a personal mistake.
Moreover, as the wife of a sitting senator, Ms. Chao will probably be treated with additional deference in the Senate confirmation proceedings. But Mr. Ashcroft and the designee for interior secretary, Gale A. Norton, are clearly headed for contentious hearings. 
Ms. Norton has been a strong advocate of giving states and local communities more authority than the federal government on environmental matters, and in 1996 speaking of her own effort to improve states' rights, she referred to the Confederate cause, saying "we lost too much" when the Union won the Civil War. "Bad facts make bad law," she said, meaning that when slavery, a bad cause, was linked with states' sovereignty, a good cause, the nation did too much to curtail state's rights. 
Mr. Bush, asked about the statement today, said: "She in no way, shape or form was talking about any value to slavery. And, you know, what happens in this town is the voices of the special interests like to tear people down."
He called any effort to read more into Ms. Norton's comments "a ridiculous interpretation of what's in her heart." 
Mr. Bush's strongest words were for Mr. Ashcroft, who he said he would lobby for directly if necessary.
"I picked John Ashcroft because he's a good attorney," he said. "He's going to be the attorney general. He's going to be the nation's lawyer, and he'll enforce the laws on the books."
Mr. Bush left Washington after the announcements for a final stay in Texas before his inauguration as president. He plans to turn his journey toward his inauguration into a piece of theater, stopping along the way for a huge outdoor rally in his boyhood home town in West Texas. 
Senior Bush advisers said that Mr. Bush would make his way from his ranch near Waco to Washington on Wednesday, but that his plane would first head west, taking a short hop into Mr. Bush's past. 
In Mr. Bush's home town, Midland, local bands would salute the president-elect with music, they said, and local figures would share their recollections about him. Perhaps, advisers said, a former elementary school teacher of his would say a few words.
Earlier today, in a meeting with 19 educators and business leaders, Mr. Bush said that winning Congressional support for his educational program would be his first order of business upon taking office.

"I hope it's the first bill we get out of the Congress," Mr. Bush said. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. A16)

HEADLINE: Too Many People 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Europe's Demographic Time Bomb" (editorial, Jan. 7): Yes, changing demographics will strain, if not bankrupt, some European countries' current pension schemes, but there is a larger phenomenon that argues in the opposite direction.
 Today's capitalist mantra is expansion -- of profits, consumers and economies. 
The basis for this prosperity model is continuing population growth. But declining birthrates in Western Europe and a few other mature industrialized societies reflect a contrary view. In these communities, people increasingly regard the ills of modern industrial society -- global warming and pollution, environmental destruction, species extinctions -- as the direct consequence of continuing population growth. 
 Expectations may have to change, together with the way affluent societies provide for their elderly. Sooner or later, we must face the bottom line and halt the population bomb.

DAVID SOSHOUX
Studio City, Calif., Jan. 7, 2001

HEADLINE: Energy and Efficiency 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Governor Pataki's Lean to the Left" (editorial, Jan. 6):
 There are many steps that Gov. George E. Pataki should take to reduce New York City's energy costs, risk of power outages and price spikes all while cleaning the air we breathe and stimulating economic growth. 
The answer is energy efficiency. 
 Through increasing financing for current state-run programs, the governor can help New Yorkers use energy more efficiently while maintaining the same level of service and comfort. Many other states pay for energy efficiency programs at much higher levels. Reducing peak consumption on hot summer days, for example, will lower electricity prices for all New Yorkers. Many effective measures could be quickly carried out and in place by this summer.

ALEXANDER L. PERERA
New York, Jan. 6, 2001

The writer is a research associate in the air and energy program at the Natural Resources Defense Council.

HEADLINE: Auction Houses Sweeten Deal 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL and RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
As they wait for a federal judge to give final approval to a $512 million class-action antitrust settlement, Sotheby's and Christie's have sweetened part of the deal they had agreed to in October.
 Under the original plan, the two auction houses charged with price fixing have the option of paying $100 million of the settlement in the form of discount certificates to future sellers toward commission fees and other charges. 
 But lawyers for some auction customers argued that such coupons were intrinsically worth less than cash and that it would take coupons with more than a face value of $100 million to equal the same amount of cash. 
With Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York scheduled to receive a report from court-appointed economic experts on the issue on Tuesday, the lead law firm representing the class of about 100,000 auction customers told the judge by letter on Thursday that Sotheby's and Christie's had proposed "a significant change" in the certificate plan.
The firm, Boies, Schiller & Flexner, said that the auction houses agreed that all unredeemed certificates would be redeemable for cash at their full face value when they expired five years after their issuance.
The sweetening of the offer was reported by The Wall Street Journal yesterday.
"We continue to think the coupons are worth their face value and this is another way to make that point," said Steven A. Reiss, a partner at Weil Gotshal & Manges, Sotheby's lawyers. "They're really the same as money."
Scott T. Kragie, a lawyer representing the auction customers Fataihi Company and Swicorp S.A., which have been critical of the settlement, called the new proposal "clearly a substantial improvement in the certificates." Yet, he said yesterday, "they remain far from $100 million in fair market value."
