HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
'What Sales Slump?' Foreign Makers Ask

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
For the Nissan Motor Company, it seems like a poor time to be thinking about expanding in the United States. Its troubles at home in Japan are forcing it to close five factories there. Meanwhile, auto sales are slowing sharply here.
 Yet Nissan has just begun work on a new factory in Mississippi to make full-size pickup trucks for the American market. 
 "A lot of people," Carlos Ghosn, Nissan's chief executive, said at a preview for the annual North American International Auto Show that formally opens here this weekend, "are telling me, 'You are getting into the U.S. market as it is going down? Are you crazy?' " 
Not in the least, he responds. The full-size pickup truck market in the United States, he said, is Nissan's single biggest opportunity for profit around the world. The market for American full-size pickups alone is more than half the size of the entire passenger vehicle market in recession-weary Japan. And just four companies -- General Motors, Ford, Chrysler and Toyota -- compete for the big money to be made in selling large pickups.
Besides, Mr. Ghosn added, the strength of the dollar against the Japanese yen makes it profitable to do business here despite current economic softness. "There is some slowdown in the U.S. market, it is true, but there is some compensation in the exchange markets," he said.
Just as demand in the United States is shrinking, Detroit automakers are facing the most serious assault on their home market in years. Japanese and European automakers have embarked on an investment binge in the United States, erecting factories from Indiana to South Carolina and from West Virginia to Mississippi in an effort to compete with General Motors, Ford and Chrysler in the highly profitable markets for pickups, minivans and sport utilities.
Foreign-car lovers who used to buy American when it came to full-size pickups, sport utilities and minivans are now finding that they can buy similar models, assembled in North America, from the same Japanese companies that have long sold them high-quality cars.
At the same time, imports are soaring. Korean automakers are rapidly taking over the American market for the smallest, cheapest cars. At the top of the market, Mercedes, BMW and other luxury cars from Europe are selling as fast as they arrive. And profits are excellent because the cost of making the cars has fallen sharply, in dollar terms, as a result of the weakness of the euro.
Together, more foreign-owned factories in the United States and more imports from Asia and Europe have produced a jump in the market share of foreign automakers. This, combined with the unexpected drop in American demand this winter, has caught Detroit with large inventories of unsold vehicles; General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler continued running their factories full tilt through the autumn, ignoring the first hints of a weaker market.
Now the Big Three are being forced to hunker down, making production cuts that are far deeper than the fairly modest 10 percent falloff in sales would seem to require. And these production cuts are slowing the entire industrial Midwest economy, which led the nation in growth through much of the last decade.
Ford has reduced planned first-quarter production by 17 percent from its level a year ago; G.M. has cut production by 21 percent and DaimlerChrysler by 26 percent. Ward's Automotive, an auto industry data service, forecasts that sales of American-brand vehicles this year -- excluding American-owned foreign brands like Volvo and Saab -- will be the lowest since 1992, when the country was just barely emerging from recession.
"We shouldn't debate too long on whether the slowdown is here -- it is," said John Devine, G.M.'s vice chairman. "The issue for me is much more of duration."
President-elect George W. Bush has been increasingly outspoken about the risks of economic trouble ahead. Auto executives say that proposed tax cuts would help raise demand for new cars a bit. But as industry executives have gathered here this week, there have been surprisingly few calls for government actions to assist the auto industry, such as encouraging the dollar to drop or threatening tariffs and other restrictions on imports.
When Bill Clinton won his first presidential election eight years ago, the domestic auto industry was still struggling while foreign automakers were thriving. The chief executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler met with the president-elect then to complain that the American dollar was overvalued against the Japanese yen. They also began secretly preparing a sweeping legal complaint, accusing Japanese automakers of unfair competition.
In an interview here this week, Rick Wagoner, G.M.'s chief executive, said that when he joined chief executives from other industries at a meeting with Mr. Bush a week ago, he mentioned that the dollar was too strong. But Mr. Wagoner said that he raised the subject only briefly, and added that he saw little chance that the industry might take the more aggressive approach of seeking higher tariffs on imported cars by filing trade complaints at the Commerce Department.
"It's not something we're putting a lot of effort into right now," he said. "So many of the manufacturers we traditionally fight against have developed U.S. manufacturing bases."
Complicating any attempt to form a unified industry strategy are the many foreign alliances the industry now has. G.M. owns Saab and has acquired stakes in Isuzu, Suzuki, Fiat and Fuji, the parent of Subaru. Ford owns Jaguar, Volvo and Land Rover and controls Mazda. And Chrysler, of course, is now little more than an operating division of DaimlerChrysler A.G., which also bought a third of Mitsubishi in October.
Dieter Zetsche, a longtime Mercedes executive recently installed by Daimler as Chrysler's chief executive, said that he thought the dollar should fall 10 to 15 percent against the yen and the euro. He said this was a DaimlerChrysler position as well, while acknowledging that his former colleagues at Mercedes were enjoying the profits from producing cars in Europe and selling them in the United States.
But he opposed any of the trade restrictions Detroit has favored in the past. "As I'm in favor of free trade," Mr. Zetsche said, "I cannot now raise my voice for protection."
While Motown dithers, though, automakers from around the world are shipping more vehicles here from factories in their home countries, making use of the dollar's strength to book fat profits in yen, euros and Korean won.
The Big Three have managed to keep their prices flat for comparably equipped vehicles. But foreign automakers have been actually reducing the prices for some models, partly because of the strong dollar. Toyota cut the price for the imported RAV4 sport utility vehicle last autumn by 3.7 percent, or $678. Toyota was able to reduce the price a year earlier for the imported Celica small car by 21.6 percent, or $4,745.
With aggressive pricing and new models, foreign automakers are confident that their sales will stay strong even as the overall American market slows. For 2001, said James E. Press, Toyota's executive vice president for North American sales, "We really think we will avoid a decline."
At Nissan, the determination to build full-size pickup trucks in the United States is even more striking given the gloominess about the American economy that prevails at Renault, the French automaker that controls Nissan and owns Samsung of South Korea. Louis Schweitzer, Renault's director general and top executive, said he expected the slowdown in the United States to prove enduring. "Will it be more than six months?" he said. "Yes, I believe."
American manufacturers are suffering from the weakness of the euro and yen, and have begun some quiet lobbying. But many are leery of publicizing the extent of the harm for fear that more investors will sell their shares, said Frank Vargo, vice president for international economics at the National Association of Manufacturers. 
In any event, John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman, was pessimistic about the prospects for any action by the incoming administration. "There's a strong belief that a strong dollar is good for everyone because it makes imports cheaper," he said. "Weakness in currencies is a problem for us, but we're going to have to live with it."
The only people talking about using trade laws against imports these days are at Solidarity House, the headquarters of the United Automobile Workers union. But while the union has the legal standing to bring complaints against importers, it has little influence with a Republican administration and has not filed trade complaints without the automakers.
The entanglement of foreign alliances is not entirely new in discouraging Detroit from seeking trade restrictions on imports. In early 1993, after Toyota threatened to cancel various joint ventures with G.M., the Big Three ended up deciding not to file their trade complaint against Japanese imports.
But Detroit mounted a big push for a lower dollar. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen did make several comments in the first few months of the Clinton administration that contributed to a decline in the American currency.
Detroit is not alone in having trouble devising a strategy on trade or the dollar. Japanese automakers have become leery of discussing the subject among themselves, because so many companies in Japanese auto industry groups are now controlled by foreign automakers, a Japanese executive said.
The first victims of the slowdown have been auto parts suppliers and their workers. Delphi Automotive Systems and Visteon, spun off in the last two years by G.M. and Ford respectively, have laid off several thousand workers already.
Not all suppliers are being hurt, however. Suppliers of auto parts that need replacing several times during the life of a vehicle, like tires, are faring better.
And suppliers in the South are benefiting from the steady expansion there of foreign-owned auto factories. In addition to the Nissan pickup factory in Mississippi, Honda and Mercedes are building factories in Alabama to produce minivans and carlike sport utilities. All three factories are aimed at market segments that American manufacturers have long dominated.
Nissan showed here a "concept" version of how its pickup might look, an aggressive, even menacing gray vehicle that strongly resembled a gray GMC concept pickup displayed here last year. A gaggle of G.M. executives who walked by the pickup were amused and dismayed by the similarities.
"It looks like Mad Max," said one of the executives to his colleagues.
"At least they could have changed the color," another remarked.
Another G.M. executive was more somber, noting that Nissan had said that it planned to market the full-size pickup mainly to households that already owned a Japanese compact pickup. Such households currently trade up to Detroit-built full-size pickups, the executive warned, adding that Nissan's marketing forecast was, "a polite way of saying it's aimed right down our throats."

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA ACTING TO RELIEVE CRISIS 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
A day after California narrowly avoided rolling blackouts across the state, Gov. Gray Davis attacked the simmering energy crisis by ordering a crash power conservation program and meeting with regional governors to map out comprehensive solutions.
 In an atmosphere of broad public mobilization, Mr. Davis ordered the government to slash energy use by 5 percent by Tuesday. State officials started programs that included replacing the bulbs in traffic lights with more efficient models and redirecting the power generated by a dam to the power grid rather than to pumps in state-owned aqueducts. 
 The state even sent out orders that janitors change the way they clean government buildings so more lights can be shut off at one time.
The flurry of activity created almost a wartime mood of general mobilization to battle the critical power shortages, although Californians remained skeptical about the entire situation. Page A11. 
"What we are doing now is really total behavior modification," said Claudia Chandler, a spokeswoman for the California Energy Commission, which is managing many of the efforts. "We have a lot of conservation programs, but this goes way beyond that."
At the same time, the State Assembly approved two bills today to provide longer-term solutions. 
One measure would restructure the boards of the two entities that oversee the distribution of power, the California Independent System Operator and the Power Exchange. The boards would consist of experts appointed by the governor rather than representatives of the power industry and consumer groups, as is the case now. 
Another bill would prevent private utilities from selling off more of their electricity generating plants.
Both bills must now go before the State Senate.
"We absolutely get the urgency of this," said Robert M. Hertzberg, the Assembly speaker, who said the Legislature was working in a bipartisan spirit to pass a range of bills in the coming days. "Government got us into this mess and government has got to get us out. We are laying the cornerstone for the restructuring of the entire power system."
He added that the Assembly had abandoned its usual method of operation, considering a large number of bills and voting on just a few, and was now far more focused and disciplined, working cooperatively on a smaller number of bills that would be passed quickly.
In Sacramento, Mr. Davis met with Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon and Gov. Gary Locke of Washington, and they issued a statement pledging a cooperative effort to solve the crisis, in large part through broad conservation programs. 
Much of California's power is imported from Oregon and Washington, and while some have expressed concern about how California was taking in energy from elsewhere during this crisis, today the governors offered mutual support and said they would even explore joint purchases of energy-efficient equipment.
The three also said they would focus on developing alternative energy sources and new technologies for generating cheaper power.
Perhaps most important, the governors called for federal action to cap soaring wholesale prices for electricity, something Mr. Davis has sought , with no success, for weeks. They urged the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to set the limits. Failing that, they said they would seek relief from Congress and the Clinton and Bush administrations.
After the two oil shocks of the 1970's and the birth of the environmental movement, energy conservation became such an ingrained way of thinking in many spheres of the economy that some companies said there was little further they could do. For example, Kinko's, which operates shops for photocopying, printing and other services, has not done anything in response to the recent energy crisis. Energy conservation "is already such an integral part of the company," said Maggie Thill, a spokeswoman at Kinko's Ventura headquarters. 
Since last summer, Ms. Thill said, the 75 Kinko's branches in California have drawn electricity from Green Mountain Energy, which derives some of its energy from renewable resources like wind and water. 
But under the plan announced by Mr. Davis today, the state will initiate a large education program that will urge people to take steps to cut demand and offer some incentives. On Monday, Mr. Davis announced a program to offer consumers rebates on energy-efficient refrigerators, washers and air-conditioners.
Mike Courtney, the state official who oversees maintenance of all state office buildings, said he was preparing a campaign that involved measures like reducing indoor winter temperatures to 70 degrees from 72 degrees and shutting off computers and placing others on sleep mode, so they would burn less power when they were not being used.
He said that janitors were being told to clean buildings differently. Instead of fanning out, they are being told to clean one floor at a time. That way, Mr. Courtney said, they can turn off the lights on the other floors and conserve power.
Mr. Courtney said that the state was already using roughly 8 percent less power now than it was a year ago because of various conservation programs, but that he still felt he could meet the 5 percent emergency reduction.
Ms. Chandler of the energy commission said that some big savings were being offered by the Department of Water Resources, a huge consumer. In one important measure, the department will change the way the pumps in certain aqueducts are used, turning them on mostly during off-peak hours. That will allow the department to shift power produced by its Orville Dam in Northern California to the general power grid at peak hours, boosting the available supply.
All of this came against a backdrop in which the threat of imminent blackouts subsided. On Thursday, the Independent System Operator had warned that planned blackouts might be required in late afternoon. It narrowly averted them because of a combination of spontaneous conservation and the purchase of emergency power from sources outside the state.
Today, the state was still on a so-called Stage 2 alert, in which the supply of power was just 5 percent greater than actual use. But no blackouts were expected and officials said the situation would probably improve next week. Several large plants that had been down or generating a reduced supply of power were now operating, the officials said, with more increases in power generation expected over the weekend.

 INTERNATIONAL A3-6

Clinton Prods Both Sides In Bid for Mideast Pact
Clinton administration officials are trying to instill a sense of urgency in Mideast peace talks by reminding Israeli and Palestinian officials that the incoming Bush administration will have a lot of other issues to tackle, and that the sometimes nearly daily mediation efforts of the Clinton years are likely to become a thing of the past. They have also sought to convince the Palestinians that this is the best agreement that they can expect from an Israeli government. A1

Mexican Extradition Ruling
A federal judge ruled that Mexico could extradite to Spain a former Argentine naval officer, Ricardo Miguel Cavallo, to face charges of genocide against Spaniards under Argentina's military dictatorship two decades ago. The decision could be unprecedented in international law, human rights experts say. A6

Top Hong Kong Official Resigns
The British-appointed head of Hong Kong's civil service, Anson Chan, who was widely viewed as a symbol of the former colony's determination to retain some autonomy under Chinese rule, resigned unexpectedly. Critics of the Chinese government said her departure renewed questions about Beijing's role in running Hong Kong. A6

Regrets on Wallenberg Case
Prime Minister Goeran Persson of Sweden apologized to the family of Raoul Wallenberg for "mistakes" made in handling the diplomat's seizure by the Soviets at the end of World War II. His apology followed a report by a panel that said Sweden's government should have pressed harder for answers decades ago about the fate of Wallenberg, who helped tens of thousands of Jews escape Nazi-controlled Hungary. A3

Romania's Orphanages Improve
A United Nations report has found that conditions in Romanian orphanages have improved significantly. Under international pressure, particularly from the European Union, the country has poured money and effort into improving the lives of the abandoned children Romania became infamous for in the early 1990's. HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SUN; 
PALM SPRINGS LOOSENS UP

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB; BERNARD WEINRAUB reports on entertainment for The New York Times in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
WILL KLEINDIENST, the exuberant mayor of Palm Springs, sat in his corner office of City Hall on East Tahquitz. The building -- with its fiberglass panels and corrugated metal roof and sand-blasted concrete block -- was designed by Albert Frey, one of several renowned modernist architects whose houses and hotels are coming back in favor in the desert city. Outside, passenger jets dip slowly from the cloudless sky down to the newly expanded Palm Springs International Airport.
 "Palm Springs used to be known as 'God's waiting room.' You came here to retire and, well, recreate," said Mr. Kleindienst, a 48-year-old city official. "We've made a concerted effort to broaden our base to make sure everyone can enjoy Palm Springs -- single or married, family or divorced, gay or straight, black or white. It's no longer just for the traditional wealthy." 
 A few miles away at the trendy Mediterranean-style Korakia Pensione, a group of private homes converted into a 27-room hotel, Douglas Smith, the owner, pointed out the various sites used for fashion shoots and nodded to an MTV crew. "Bloomingdale's just left," said Mr. Smith, who bought the property in the Tennis Club district of the newly gentrified Palm Springs in 1989. Three years later, he opened it as a hotel. The actresses Natalie Portman and Julianna Margulies had been recent weekend guests, as well as such stylish types as Tom Ford and Donatella Versace, the designers; Annie Leibovitz, the photographer; K. D. Lang, the singer; the actress Susan Sarandon; and one of the Dalai Lama's top associates with 11 monks. In short, it's not the kind of place where the traditional Palm Beach resident would feel comfortable.
"The town isn't necessarily hip," said Mr. Smith, "but there's certainly a quirky energy here. It's a weird place. Don't forget you once had Sonny Bono as Mayor. Liberace had a house here. You go to a club and there's a model from New York, a physician from Dallas, a lady in a tilted wig, some photographers from Europe and a Barry Manilow look-alike playing the piano. There's a live-and-let-live attitude that's part of the appeal. And don't forget you're in the desert: it's beautiful." 
Hip hotels -- most of them small and kitschy -- are booming all over Palm Springs, a sign that the city of more than 48,000 is in the midst of a resurgence that recalls the 1940's. At the time, the town, with its aura of seediness, even decadence, became a haven for movie stars like Frank Sinatra, Bob Hope, Dinah Shore, Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz and Bing Crosby, as well as such moguls as Darryl F. Zanuck, once they could put air-conditioning in their walled compounds. Earlier the Palm Springs Racquet Club, built by Charles Farrell and Ralph Bellamy in 1932 for the Hollywood crowd, served as a favorite hangout. (The club was also created to counter the restrictive code of top Palm Springs hotels that barred Jews and blacks.)
By the 1970's and 80's, the town's center, Palm Canyon Drive, had turned bleak and was cluttered with cheap restaurants and T-shirt shops. Many hotels were in disrepair. And newcomers and tourists were driving to the other towns in the Coachella Valley like Palm Desert, Rancho Mirage, Indian Wells, Coachella, Desert Hot Springs, Indian Wells, Indio, La Quinta and Cathedral City. (At Desert Memorial Park in Cathedral City there is a small gravestone lying flat on the ground that reads: "The Best Is Yet to Come. Francis Albert Sinatra, 1915 to 1998." Although outsiders often view these towns as part of Palm Springs, they're not. The newer towns are separate entities. But the weak real estate market and shaky tourism of that time proved, in some ways, fortuitous for the future of Palm Springs.
While many American cities in the 1970's and 80's were in the grip of urban renewal and bulldozing their recent past, Palm Springs had neither the money nor the desire to send wreckers into its neighborhoods. The result is that dozens of homes by the underappreciated and highly prolific Mr. Frey, who designed about 200 projects in Palm Springs, as well as such modernist architects as Richard Neutra and Rudolf Schindler, were left unscathed. These houses and others were picked up relatively cheaply by buyers, many from Los Angeles, 107 miles away, to restore as second homes or, in a few cases, to turn into hotels.
The newer hotels are a mixed lot. Perhaps the most elegant (and expensive) is The Willows, with just eight rooms, near the center of town. The Italianate-Mediterranean-style villa, at the foot of the San Jacinto Mountains, was once the home of Samuel Untermyer, an affluent lawyer from New York, who built the mansion in 1927. Marion Davies later lived there. Albert Einstein, a friend of Mr. Untermyer's, was a house guest. Clark Gable visited on his honeymoon with Carole Lombard. By the 1980's, the house had become a shambles.
Fade in to 1994: Two young emergency room doctors from Los Angeles, Tracy Conrad and her husband, Paul Marut, on a vacation in Palm Springs, saw the mansion for sale. "It was pretty much in a state of disrepair and we thought we could restore the house -- we love architecture and design," said Ms. Conrad. "It was way too big to live in. We thought we could make it a bed-and-breakfast. We were complete neophytes. We probably wouldn't have done it had we known. It was more expensive than medical school by far."
The result is a meticulously restored B & B with polished red-oak floors and distinctive rooms that are quite opulent, 1930's-style. One room, The Library, where Gable and Lombard stayed, includes a carved cherry fireplace, a private patio and a silver chandelier in the bathroom. The Einstein Room, where the great scientist stayed, includes Art Deco inlaid mahogany furnishings and a patio with French doors. 
"When we first bought the house people thought we were nuts," recalled Ms. Conrad. "The recession hit this town hard. But now real estate has gone nuts here. Palm Springs is the Hamptons of Los Angeles."
Only a few miles away on North Indian Canyon Drive, visitors seeking retro, 50's-style hotels (complete with Princess phones) would be welcomed at Ballantine's as well as Ballantine's Movie Colony. Opened last February, Ballantine's is one of the first hotels in Palm Springs to embrace kitsch and midcentury modernism. The 14 rooms, many quite small, as well as suites, are filled with period furniture by Eames, Knoll and others. Vinyl and Formica are everywhere. Blue Astroturf surrounds the pool. Classic 1950's B movies with Humphrey Bogart are shown in each room. 
Once called Mira Loma, and sometimes used as a rendezvous for movie stars and moguls who wanted to slip away from the nearby Racquet Club, the hotel was popular with guests like Marilyn Monroe and Veronica Lake. Now there's a Marilyn Monroe suite, where she once stayed, with photographs of the star and posters of her films, as well as an Audrey Hepburn Room, a Palm Springs 50's room and a French 50's room, with a red and orange shag pile carpet, Bertoia chairs and Leger prints on the walls. Some rooms have 50's chenille bedspreads, along with vintage toasters and radios. The Princess phones have a certain charm, but try getting messages. 
Sarah Robarts, a British painter and interior designer, owns Ballantine's with her husband, Fraser Robertson, a venture capitalist from Scotland. Ms. Robarts said the couple came to California from London a year and a half ago to change their way of life, visited Palm Springs and were entranced by the desert and the town. "Many of the smaller hotels were Southwestern or tacky," said Ms. Robarts. "There was nothing midcentury. There was a wealth of architecture, but it was mostly private homes. This hotel itself was pink and green, just awful. But Fraser said, 'Look at this architecture.' "
The success of Ballantine's led the couple to buy another building only a few blocks away and turn it into Ballantine's Movie Colony, the newest hotel in town. In one of the earliest buildings designed in Palm Springs by the Bauhaus-trained Albert Frey, it has 16 kitschy rooms decorated with original and reproduction 40's and 50's furnishings. 
"What surprised me about Palm Springs is that it's so different from the profile of being a very conservative place," said Ms. Robarts. "It's quite arty. There's a big gay community." 
Certainly the influx of gay tourists and residents has influenced Palm Springs. Like Key West, Fla., and Provincetown, Mass., the town is now a popular destination for gays. John Williams, co-owner of the INNdulge Palm Springs hotel in the mostly gay Warm Springs section of the city, and former president of the Desert Gay Tourism Guild, said there were now 34 gay hotels in the area, mostly in Palm Springs. Moreover, the Palm Springs Bureau of Tourism has made an effort to attract gay tourists. (Hotels catering to the gay market account for nearly 10 percent of the occupancy taxes collected from Palm Springs lodgings.)
Mr. Williams, walking around his hotel while several nude men swam in the pool, moved to Palm Springs from Hawaii in 1995 and, like many others, found the town affordable enough then to buy the property for a hotel. Now the increase in tourism -- and the purchase of homes -- has accelerated because of the prosperous economy in the 1990's. 
Curiously, Palm Springs has something of a split personality. The town often votes Republican, and presumably many of the wealthy golf crowd are conservative.
But the quirkiness of Palm Springs, coupled with the arrival of new residents, has given it a freewheeling spirit. Dr. Janice Lyle, executive director of the Palm Springs Desert Museum, the cultural bedrock of the town, began working at the museum 17 years ago. (The museum has just completed a highly successful exhibition of the artist and sculptor Duane Hansen.) "When I first came here," said Ms. Lyle, "I kept thinking, 'How am I going to live in this place?' Everything seemed so narrow to me. It's not that way at all now." 
The community's resurgence has also led, of course, to a restaurant revival. There are traditional high-priced restaurants like Le Vallauris and Johannes in Palm Springs and Cuistot in Palm Desert, and at the other end of the price spectrum very popular dining spots like Thai Smile and El Mirasol. A mid-priced, comfortable restaurant, Davey's Hideaway, with a traditional prime rib and rack of lamb type menu, is perhaps most typical of Palm Springs. On a recent night, the crowd mixed the casual and the slightly formal: tables of affluent couples with women wearing diamonds, several tables of three or four gay men, a family with children, and several young couples. The food was unfussy and straightforward, the mood friendly.
At the moment, the trendy crowd seems to favor, among others, La Provence in Palm Springs. And for a 1950's Palm Springs experience, order a martini at the bar of Melvyn's at the Ingleside Inn or the Bamboo Lounge of the Racquet Club, whose lobby is filled with photographs of such long-ago visitors as Lucille Ball, Clark Gable and Natalie Wood.
Despite its renewed popularity, it would be inaccurate to say that Palm Springs and the region are suddenly supercool and supertrendy. It's still a place with huge golf resorts, and buildings all over town seem crammed with surgeons, doctors, dentists and financial advisers. A visitor walking along a quiet stretch of Palm Canyon Drive, the main street, early the other morning was startled to see in the dawn dimness a brightly lighted storefront with nurses and dialysis patients visible through the windows.
The desert is still a mecca for golfers: there are more than 100 golf courses in the area. Visitors looking for tennis, health clubs and resort amenities favor such lush hotels as the 884-room Marriott Desert Springs Resort and Spa in Palm Desert, as well as the Ritz-Carlton and Westin Mission Hills Resort in Rancho Mirage and the Hyatt Grand Champions Resort in Indian Wells. There are also any number of spas, one of the more lavish being Merv Griffin's Resort Hotel and Givenchy Spa in Palm Springs. (After the actor Robert Downey Jr. was arrested there over the Thanksgiving weekend and charged with possession of drugs, reservations increased substantially.)
Stewart Weiner, editor of Palm Springs Life, a monthly magazine that covers the region, moved to the area from Los Angeles with his family in 1994.
"There's still a village atmosphere about this place, you still talk to strangers on the supermarket line," said Mr. Weiner. "But we're sort of the rage now. Golf's the rage. People are interested in midcentury modern architecture, Hollywood nostalgia, the 50's. I went to a restaurant last night and everyone was speaking French and German. That didn't happen a few years ago."

Hotels with an air of old Hollywood
The season is now in high gear in Palm Springs, and lasts until Memorial Day, when the desert temperatures start climbing. The Palm Springs Bureau of Tourism has a highly efficient Web site (www
.palm-springs.org). Hotel reservations can be made by calling (800) 347-7746.

Where to Stay
Among the smaller hotels in town is the sedately luxurious eight-room Willows, 412 West Tahquitz Way, (760) 320-0771 or (800) 966-9597, fax (760) 320-0780, Web site www
.thewillowspalmsprings.com, a villa with rooms filled with antiques; some have lush garden patios. The most expensive is the Marion Davies Room, with an imposing fireplace, elegantly carved king-sized bed and a chaise longue and silver chandelier in the spacious bathroom. Hotel amenities include a three-course breakfast and wine and hors d'oeuvres. A 30's-style pool adds to the ambience of old Palm Springs, or even old Hollywood. Prices in season range from $295 to $550. Weekend reservations are sometimes difficult to snare.
Several streets away is the Korakia Pensione, 257 South Patencio Road, (760) 864-6411, fax (760) 864-4147, made up of two villas, bungalows and guest houses. The 1924 Moroccan-style villa is especially popular with the trendy crowd, mostly from Los Angeles, some from New York. Across the street is a Mediterranean-style villa, once owned by the early screen star J. Carrol Naish. The atmosphere is sometimes sensual, sometimes commercial. (There seem to be frequent visits by fashion photographers and models.) Torches blaze by the pool at night; archways are draped in bougainvillea. The rooms have stone floors, feather beds and Mediterranean-style furniture. Rates: generally $119 to $369. 
The 14-room Ballantine's Hotel, at 1420 North Indian Canyon Drive, is about seven blocks from its sister hotel, Ballantine's Movie Colony, at 726 North Indian Canyon Drive, with 16 rooms and three townhouses. Reservations for both, (800) 780-3464; information, www.ballantineshotels
.com. At Ballantine's, the small rooms (and smaller bathrooms) are given 1950's touches. The Marilyn Monroe suite costs about $265 a night. For the same price, there is the 1950's musicals suite, with photos of Fred and Ginger and Gershwin, a Kelvinator refrigerator, Crosley radio and lava lamp. Other rooms, including the Douglas Fairbanks, Jr. Room (he used the former hotel on the site for assignations, according to a brochure), are less expensive (from $139). The newer, bigger Movie Colony, in a building designed by Albert Frey, also has a 50's theme. Rates are similar to Ballantine's, though townhouses cost $395.
INNdulge Palm Springs, at 601 Grenfall Road, (760) 327-1408, fax (760) 327-7273, a gay hotel in the Warm Springs section of town, has 22 rooms. Doubles are $109; $125 with kitchenette; suites $145 to $165. 

Where to Eat
There are dozens of restaurants in Palm Springs, with every price available. At the top end is Le Vallauris, 385 West Tahquitz Canyon Way, (760) 325-5059, an old-school French restaurant with a lovely garden. Specialties include seafood as well as beef and lamb. Dinner for two can cost at least $150 with wine. 
Somewhat less expensive and less formal, and popular with the new hip crowd, is La Provence, 254 North Palm Canyon Drive, (760) 416-7784, serving mostly Provencal cuisine. Dinner for two, about $115, with wine. 
A meal at Davey's Hideaway, a friendly steak-and-potatoes (as well as fish) restaurant at 292 East Palm Canyon Drive, (760) 320-4480, costs about $70 for two, with wine. 
And one of the most crowded and informal places in town -- with some of the best food -- is Thai Smile at 651 North Palm Canyon Drive, (760) 320-5503. Try the pad Thai noodles. Dinner for two, about $30, with beer. 
There are a half-dozen good Mexican restaurants around town, but the one that seems most popular among locals is El Mirasol, 140 East Palm Canyon Drive, (760) 323-0721. Pollo con mole and enchiladas verdes will satisfy cravings for Mexican food. Dinner for two, $30, with beer.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 18, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 14 about Palm Springs referred incorrectly to the training of the architect Albert Frey, who designed some 200 buildings there. A letter received on March 1 from Sandra A. Kocher, the daughter of Mr. Frey's partner, A. Lawrence Kocher, pointed out that while Mr. Frey was aware of architectural developments in Germany during the Bauhaus years, that he was not Bauhaus-trained. He studied in his native Switzerland.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 01-14-01; 
Produce Politics

BYLINE:  By Michael Pollan; Michael Pollan is a contributing writer for the magazine. His new book, "The Botany of Desire," will be published in May.

 BODY:
Whenever I go to the supermarket these days, I collect labels. No, I'm not saving up box tops in order to get a decoder ring from Battle Creek. The sort of labels I collect now promise something else, a slightly different decoding. Each of them tells me a little story about where the food I'm buying comes from and how it has been produced.
 "Organic" is the oldest and by now most familiar of these labels, and it's about to become even more commonplace, now that the federal government has finally issued its long-awaited, much-debated national organic standards. Sometime next year, a new green-and-white U.S.D.A. "organic" seal will begin to show up on everything from carrots to TV dinners and breakfast cereal, indicating that their ingredients were grown and processed without synthetic chemicals. But organic is just the earliest bud in what is beginning to look like a flowering of supermarket narrative. Lately I've seen labels informing me that the fish in the seafood cooler was caught in a sea-turtle-friendly net; that the coffee in the caffeine aisle has been "shade grown"; that the tea on sale next to it is not only organic but "fairly traded"; that the beef in the meat case was humanely raised; and that the apples in the produce section were locally grown by a farmer who treats his workers respectfully. 
 At first I wasn't certain whether this banquet of storied food was just a marketing gimmick or the first stirrings of a new politics of food. Superficially at least, the proliferation of eco-labels is of a piece with the trend toward "liberation marketing," in which almost everything is sold as an expression of the consumer's sense of social justice, environmental consciousness or moral virtue. But while it is true that casting the purchase of an iMac or a pair of Nikes as an act of political courage is a gesture worse than empty (particularly when the sneakers in question were made in a sweatshop), the stories now on sale in the supermarket strike me as belonging to a very different genre. These are stories about what used to be called "the means of production," and in a food system as troubled and opaque as ours, they can be radical indeed.
Ever since we began buying our food in supermarkets, the food chain that ostensibly links the American eater to the American land has grown steadily longer, more intricate and less legible; by now it is all but invisible to most of us. This is evidently the way agribusiness wants it, judging by the vigor with which they fight any effort to tell consumers more about how their food is made. It's not hard to see why: the stories about our food system that do get out don't do much for the appetite. There's the one about how genetically engineered StarLink corn deemed unfit for human consumption somehow found its way into tacos and breakfast cereal. Then there's the mad-cow story, which brought us the disquieting news that beef cattle in this country routinely dine not only on hormones and antibiotics but also on bits of other beef cattle (not to mention pellets made from their own manure).
Stories have a way of begetting more stories, and it is scary ones like these that have spawned the more pastoral tales told by the new food labels. The industry objects to eco-labels on the grounds that they constitute an "implicit criticism" of conventional food. They also point out that the spectacular growth of the organic industry during the last decade has been driven by "food scares." Exactly!
Food that comes with a story -- whether it's organic, fairly traded, humanely grown, sustainably caught or whatever -- represents a not-so-implicit challenge to every other product in the supermarket that dares not narrate its path from farm to table. To get some idea of the potential power of that challenge to an industry that has fought to nullify the word "organic" and now campaigns against proposals to label food made with genetically modified ingredients, consider a technology now in some supermarkets in Denmark. Packages of meat and poultry carry a bar code that, when scanned by a machine in the store, calls up pictures of the farm where the animal was raised, as well as information about its diet, living conditions, the date of its slaughter and so on. Imagine how quickly this sort of transparency would force a revolution in our food chain.
Indeed, the simple act of suggesting that such stories about our food are our business verges on sedition in an era of deregulation and free trade. It is one of the pillars of free trade that a country may not discriminate against any product based on the way it was made. "Dolphin safe" gives conniptions to the World Trade Organization, just as "Ulysses" once did to the courts. The W.T.O. doesn't like stories.
That a growing number of consumers apparently do is alarming or encouraging, depending on what you've got to sell or tell. One of the many triumphs of free-market thinking over the past few years has been to redefine "the public interest" as simply whatever the public is interested in buying. Under this convenient formulation, the consumer -- that one-dimensional economic actor beloved of world traders and food marketers -- trumps the citizen, and the corporation can pretty much do what it wants so long as it enjoys the consent of the shopper. What the architects of this so-called market populism could never have foreseen, however, is that the sharp distinction between the roles of consumer and citizen might blur, and that the citizen - that somewhat recherche character -- would actually show up in a supermarket one day. Well, here he comes now. Look for him in the produce aisle.

HEADLINE: FILM; 
In Theaters Now: The Asian Alternative

BYLINE:  By DAVE KEHR 

 BODY:
THE hyperkinetic Hong Kong action films of Jackie Chan could hardly have less in common with the contemplative, novelistic dramas of Taiwan's Edward Yang. But both belong to a phenomenon that has been called the "Asian Invasion," the sudden ubiquity of films from the Far East in art and commercial theaters, both here and in Europe. 
 In New York, Mr. Yang's "Yi Yi" ("A One and a Two") -- a many-layered, 173-minute examination of the passions and disappointments of a middlingly prosperous Taipei family -- was recently named best foreign-language film of the year by the New York Film Critics Circle and best film overall by the National Society of Film Critics. In Paris, Wong Kar-wai's aggressively stylish Hong Kong romance, "In the Mood for Love" (which opens in New York on Feb. 2), was one of last year's most successful commercial releases. And around the Western world, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," an elevated martial arts film from Taiwan's Ang Lee ("The Wedding Banquet"), is on its way to becoming the first Chinese-language film to break out of the art house and become a genuine popular success. 
 As it expands its run into America's shopping mall theaters, where subtitles are largely a novelty, "Crouching Tiger" will almost certainly become the highest-grossing foreign-language film of all time in the United States, surpassing the $58 million take of Roberto Benigni's "Life Is Beautiful." 
For its part, Hollywood has paid its ultimate compliment to the Asian cinema by luring away some of its leading talent. John Woo, whose innovative gangster films ("A Better Tomorrow," "The Killer") changed the face of Hong Kong filmmaking in the 1980's, is the director behind the blockbuster hit "Mission: Impossible 2," and the star he created, Chow Yun Fat, is now a regular in American productions. Yuen Woo-ping, a veteran martial arts choreographer, took time off from his regular employer, the Hong Kong star Jet Li, to create the stylized fight sequences for "The Matrix" and "Crouching Tiger"; his brother, Yuen Cheung-yan, did the same for "Charlie's Angels."
Clearly, Asia is much too big and complex a place for there to be a single, simple explanation for the current success of Asian films. But just as clearly, there is a new creative energy crossing the continent that can't be denied. China, Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and even several of the less economically privileged countries of the Pacific Rim (including Vietnam, Thailand and the Philippines) have all seen a dramatic increase in the number of their films selected for westward export. Where Asian films were once barely visible at international festivals (apart from those by the Japanese masters Akira Kurosawa, Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi in the 1950's and 60's), it is now practically mandatory for festivals to devote entire sections to surveys of recent Asian film.
Yet the surge in Asian films is unlike the revivals of national cinema that occurred in Italy in the late 30's, France in the early 60's and Germany in the mid-70's. There is no single, pan-Asian figure -- no equivalent to Rossellini, Godard or Fassbinder of the earlier movements -- to found a new style and, through the force of his originality, a new school. There is no new, single source of finance, as government was for European cinema in the 80's, that can explain the renaissances occurring in capitalist Taiwan and socialist Vietnam. And there is no new, devoted audience that has emerged to support Asian films in general: one suspects that the teenage fan of Japanese anime (the feature-length adaptations of Japan's sophisticated, adult-themed comic books) would have very little to say to the film festival patron shuffling into the latest formal study by Taiwan's Tsai Ming-liang (whose 1998 film "Hole" featured upstairs and downstairs neighbors spying on each other through a fissure in the flooring).
And certainly there is no single, monolithic Asian cinema. The cultural differences among the nations of eastern Asia are certainly as profound as those among the nations of Western Europe, if less obvious to Western eyes. The lush historical dramas that come out of Korea, like Im Kwon Taek's gorgeous "Chunhyang" of last year, have little in common with the down-and-dirty cop thrillers that are now in vogue in Hong Kong, or for that matter with Korea's own highly stylized crime films, like Lee Myung-se's recent "Nowhere to Hide."
But there is one thing that unites the new movies coming out of Asia: they are not Hollywood films, a major distinction in a world where alternatives to the big American machine have become unconscionably rare. Mr. Yang's "Yi Yi" displays a concern with the texture of everyday reality that no Hollywood film would countenance; Mr. Lee's "Crouching Tiger" displays a willful transcendence of that same reality that no American movie would dare.
More than new personalities or new styles, the Asian cinema offers a new perspective for viewers accustomed to Hollywood films, a grip on reality that differs in small but important ways. Hollywood has settled into a comfortable, unselfconscious, totally unintellectual postmodernism, which consists of recycling bits and pieces of old, half-remembered movies.
Just as George Lucas inflated his childhood memories of "Flash Gordon" reruns on Saturday morning television into the empty grandeur of the "Star Wars" films -- transforming naive art into formulas for heroic myth straight out of Joseph Campbell -- so have many of the American filmmakers who followed him mined their primal memories, scraping vague impressions of the cop movies, war films, detective stories and slapstick comedies (above all, the Three Stooges) they enjoyed as children into the ur-genre films that populate the multiplexes today.
FILMS like "What Women Want" or "Vertical Limit" spring not from any actual experience or observation but from the impulse to make, respectively, a Tracy-Hepburn romantic comedy or a mountain climbing adventure. The most chilling film in this regard last year was Ridley Scott's "Gladiator," a loose collection of plot cliches and stock characters gathered from the history of a largely forgotten genre, the sword-and-sandal epics of the 50's and 60's, rolled into one big ball. 
And now, with the dominance of digital special effects, filmmakers can create settings and spectacles every bit as synthetic as their recycled characters and situations. Just as the Coliseum crowds and roaring tigers of Mr. Scott's film dissolve into screenfuls of buzzing pixels when you look closely, so does the film's fiction fly away into fragments and references -- a bit of "Spartacus" here, a bit of "Ben Hur" there -- when you try to grasp it.
It is only in the last couple of years that Asian films have begun to exploit digital technology, a delay that has worked much to their advantage. When Jackie Chan leaps from a mountain wall onto a passenger balloon that happens to be passing by -- this amazing stunt occurs in his 1986 "Armor of God" -- there is no question that he is actually doing it; the risk is real, and the sense that death and disaster are genuine possibilities informs not just the scene itself but the whole sense of Mr. Chan's work. He is an adventurer, in life as well as in the movies, and he knows what he is talking about.
At 46, Mr. Chan is getting to the point in life where such exploits are no longer a possibility, but now that he is making American movies ("Rush Hour," "Shanghai Noon"), the insurance companies are hardly likely to allow him to continue taking risks. It is one thing to break a leg and hold up shooting on a modestly budgeted Hong Kong film; it's something quite different to suffer an injury and shut down a major Hollywood production. Inevitably, Mr. Chan will find himself on the same digital mountaintops conquered by Chris O'Donnell in the weightless, frictionless "Vertical Limit," where the only risk is running out of RAM.
What is true in action films is also true in domestic dramas, though in a different way. Edward Yang's "Yi Yi" is set in the concrete reality of present day Taipei, a city of glass boxes that could be almost anywhere on the planet. The film follows the fortunes of the Jian family, which appears to be breaking apart under the pressure of modern urban life. 
NJ (Wu Nienjen), the 40-ish businessman who is the de facto head of the family, feels disengaged from his job at a struggling software company; when his high school sweetheart (Ke Suyun) shows up, visiting from America, a door opens into a possible future. Meanwhile, NJ's wife, Min-Min (Elaine Jin), has left home for a Buddhist retreat, unable to cope with the devastating stroke her mother has suffered, which leaves NJ's teenage daughter, Ting-Ting (Kelly Lee), largely on her own as she tries to negotiate the pitfalls of a first romance. 
As a plot outline, "Yi Yi" doesn't differ much from "American Beauty," last year's Oscar winner for best picture. NJ could sit down with Kevin Spacey's Lester Burnham over a Scotch, and the two men could share their sense of hopeless alienation from their work, their barren relationships with their wives, their fantasies of romantic escape and their incomprehension of their teenage daughters.
Lester's wife, Carolyn (Annette Bening), finds an outlet for her romantic frustration not in Buddhism but in an equally demanding American discipline: the selling of real estate. And, just like Thora Birch's Jane Burnham, Ting-Ting finds herself with no parental figure to help her through adolescence; she finds her role model instead in a more assured, more attractive and apparently more sexually sophisticated girlfriend. Both films end, somewhat disappointingly, with tabloid-style incidents of violence, which the filmmakers link to the violence that courses through popular culture.
But "American Beauty" is a film that takes place within quotation marks, within a "perfect" American suburb, a "perfect" two-story Colonial house, a "perfect" nuclear family. The director, Sam Mendes, is a British stage veteran whose understanding of America seems based entirely on our exported sitcoms and soap operas; in trying to turn those abstracted, idealized images on their heads, he produces only an equally abstract cynicism: an attack on institutions that no one really believes in, institutions that exist only as conventions in entertainment formulas. They are the remains of the glorious middle-American iconography created by Steven Spielberg under, and in a sense for, the Reagan administration -- now threadbare and untenable but still with a certain resonance and authority.
In "Yi Yi," there is no such easy cynicism or ironic distance. At least to this non-Asian observer, Mr. Yang's image of contemporary Taipei has an authenticity that shakes off facile generalizations and condescending stereotypes. Though the film's world view is limited to that of its privileged characters (there are no visions of the shantytowns or impoverished mountain villages you see in the films of Taiwan's other leading director, Hou Hsiao-hsien), there is nothing in it that seems manipulated, exaggerated or cunningly art-directed. Rather than having ironic recourse to a Taiwanese Norman Rockwell -- or whatever artist might define that country's treasured complacencies -- Mr. Yang pushes aside conventions and goes directly to character. The Burnhams are defined by their wall hangings, the Jians by their relationships to each other.
It's suggestive, too, that "American Beauty" remains tied to the consciousness of Lester: he is its central character and narrator, and most everything in the film is seen from his point of view. Mr. Yang, like his colleague Mr. Hou and many other Asian directors, prefers a fluid point of view, one not tied to any particular character; his is a slightly set-back perspective that allows the audience members to choose their own identification figures, or shift their focus of identification as the drama unfolds. 
Mr. Yang and Mr. Hou have both been pioneers in a long-take, long-shot style; the camera, for example, will be positioned on the far side of a room, observing the characters for long moments without a cut or a close-up as they circulate around a dining room table or a tea room. No single figure is privileged above any other, and the focus is placed instead on the transactions between characters, on the gestures and speeches they make toward one another, on the way they approach, avoid and circulate. The opening sequence of "Yi Yi," set in a catering hall where a chaotic wedding reception is taking place, is a model in this regard; what we learn about the characters comes from how they sit, stand and converse with each other. For a viewer accustomed to the continual assault of Hollywood films, with their high-impact close-ups and rapid, analytical cutting, these Asian films seem blessedly calm, cool and respectful of the viewer's ability to make his or her own judgments and connections.
This intense but unruffled quality is common both to the art films of Taiwan and the popular entertainments of Hong Kong. Rooted in the stage tradition of the Chinese opera, martial arts movies have long remained conscious of the importance of an integrated, fully articulated space in which the action can be placed; the use of the widescreen, CinemaScope format, almost ubiquitous in Hong Kong movies, allows protagonist and antagonist to share the same space, to react with and against each other in much the same way Fred Astaire related to Ginger Rogers in their dance sequences, shot with an equally distant camera. It's a perspective that emphasizes continuity over fragmentation and grace above impact -- whereas the rapid cutting in an American action film like "Gone in 60 Seconds" or "Con Air" creates mainly a sense of being slapped in the face, forcefully and persistently.
Inevitably, Eastern and Western filmmaking styles are moving closer together. Though influences between the two have always been strong -- John Ford's westerns inspired Akira Kurosawa's samurai dramas, which in turn inspired Sergio Leone's Italian gunfighter sagas -- it is only in the last 10 or 15 years that video has made films widely available on both sides of the cultural divide.
In China, the young members of the so-called Sixth Generation of filmmakers (the sixth to emerge since the arrival of cinema in China), like Lou Ye ("Suzhou River," 2000) and Wang Xiaoshuai ("The Days," 1994), are reflecting the influence of European art house directors of the 50's and 60's like Michelangelo Antonioni and Alain Resnais, whose films were not shown in China at the time of their release. Suddenly, the Sixth Generation filmmakers seem fixated on themes of anomie, alienation and dissolving identity -- all maladies of individualism -- whereas the Fifth Generation directors, among them Chen Kaige ("Farewell, My Concubine," 1993) and Zhang Yimou ("Raise the Red Lantern," 1991), were concerned with social issues and reclaiming Chinese history. (A series of nine Sixth Generation films, including "Platform," Jia Zhang Ke's magnificent 2000 chronicle of post-Mao China, will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center from Feb. 23 through March 8.)
The most imitated figure among young Asian filmmakers right now is the maverick Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai. His almost psychedelically stylized films -- "Chungking Express," "The Days of Being Wild" -- blend inventive hand-held camera work (generally by the gifted Australian cinematographer Christopher Doyle) and oblique narratives (generally on themes of l'amour fou) into festival-winning, cult-spawning visual extravaganzas.
Mr. Wong's "In the Mood for Love," which won a best actor award for its star Tony Leung at last year's Cannes International Film Festival, is, as its title suggests, a mood piece about romantic longing. Most of the actual plot points in this tale of adulterous neighbors seem to have been deliberately snipped out of the final cut, leaving a kind of memory residue of stylish sexual frustration.
The object of Mr. Leung's pining -- an obsession shared by Mr. Wong's camera -- is the willowy Hong Kong star Maggie Cheung, outfitted in a series of high-necked, traditional Chinese silk dresses. Mr. Wong's eclectic approach -- half MTV, half Josef von Sternberg -- is strongly echoed in such films as "Suzhou River" and "Nowhere to Hide," and has proved distinctive enough to inspire at least one Hong Kong parody, Ko Sau-leung's "The Days of Being Dumb."
South Korea is the latest Asian nation to emerge on the international festival circuit. Its filmmaking is as divided as Korea -- between movies that look inward, hoping to find a sense of national identity in history and in traditional art forms ("Chunhyang" is a celebration of the traditional form of sung storytelling called pansori), and movies that look beyond national borders, struggling to form a new aesthetic based more on Western models.
Kim Ki-duk's "The Isle," Hong Sang-soo's "Virgin Stripped Bare by Her Bachelors" and Jang Sun Woo's "Lies" all use modernistic stylistic devices (actors who step out of character to speak to the camera, multiple points of view on the same event) to tell stories that deal with transgressive sexual themes, as if their makers meant to shock the Korean public out of the past and into the future. 
Still, no current film better represents the intermingling of East and West than "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," a film created by a consortium of New York independents, Hollywood studio money and Asian financiers. The director, Ang Lee, is a Taiwanese national who has lived in the United States since the mid-70's; the co-writer and producer is James Schamus, an American who also collaborated with Mr. Lee on "The Wedding Banquet" and "The Ice Storm." The cinematographer, Peter Pau, is from Hong Kong (where he photographed John Woo's "The Killer"); the editor is Tim Squyres, an American who has worked with Mr. Lee since his first feature, "Pushing Hands," in 1992. 
WITH its sources in the gorgeous, lyrical kung-fu films directed in the 60's and 70's by the late King Hu ("A Touch of Zen," "The Fate of Lee Kahn"), "Crouching Tiger" welds a Chinese story to American techniques. Where King Hu staged his aerodynamic sword fights with trampolines and fancy wire work, Mr. Lee makes extensive use of digital effects to send his characters spinning through the air. Hampered by the fact that his star, the immensely appealing Chow Yun Fat, is not a martial artist, Mr. Lee is forced to create his stunts out of fast cutting, doubling and digital intervention. The results are impressive, and the film has been entertaining audiences around the world.
And yet there is a self-consciousness in "Crouching Tiger" that nudges the film uncomfortably close to a postmodern bloodlessness. In a way, it is the kung-fu equivalent of "Shane," the 1953 George Stevens film that first turned the American western from a natural expression of American culture into something deliberately "mythical," with archetypes instead of characters, a quest instead of a story and a heavy, painterly sense of landscape that no longer allowed actors to move simply and organically through it but reduced them to compositional elements in a tableau.
"Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" is not as bombastic as "Shane" (Mr. Lee came closer to that with his 1999 Civil War western, "Ride with the Devil"), nor is it as proudly synthetic as "Gladiator." (Michelle Yeoh, a greatly talented martial artist, is always on hand to provide weight and authenticity.) Yet it is ambiguous enough to provoke a troubling question: Does the West love this movie because it is so profoundly Asian, or because it is not?

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 7

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Flemington, N.J.; 
Small-Town Feel, With Outlets

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
A HOLE-IN-THE-DOUGHNUT municipality surrounded by Raritan Township, the one-square-mile borough of Flemington is known for its outlet stores, pottery and cut glass. As the seat of Hunterdon County in the southern part of the state, the borough also has a rich history as the farming center that, at the turn of the century, was served by the Central, Pennsylvania and Lehigh Valley Railroads. In its heyday, 54 freight trains a day stopped in Flemington to supply produce and industrial goods to New York City and Philadelphia. 
 About 80 percent of the single-family houses were built before World War II. According to a local history, Flemington has one of the finest collections of Greek Revival houses in the nation, with 60 percent of the borough's structures -- including most of the houses -- in a district that is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. 
 The oldest house in the borough is the white clapboard Fleming Castle, built in 1756 by one of the earliest European settlers, Samuel Fleming, who was of Irish descent. 
Originally a tavern, the structure is now a private residence on Bonnell Street near the center of town. 
Everywhere, houses are being upgraded or expanded. Mayor Austin H. Kutscher Jr. notes that the borough has obtained a $200,000 grant from the State Department of Community Affairs, which allows it to offer residents loans of up to $10,000 each to upgrade historic properties.
Mayor Kutscher also says his administration is stressing economic development and downtown revitalization by streamlining the process under which commercial landlords are allowed to change the permitted uses of their buildings. Indeed, in the downtown business district, there are few empty stores.
Craig G. Proctor, a broker with Coldwell Banker Realty on Main Street, says that houses that are priced right in Flemington often sell within two weeks. He characterizes his customers as mostly executives, white-collar workers and business people.
"They want to live in Hunterdon County for the educational system, the rural nature and the job market," he said. "We are close to New York, Philadelphia and large employment areas of New Jersey. But they also like the small-town friendliness, the older homes and the convenience of a walkable main street."
At the end of December, 15 houses were on the market in the Multiple Listing Service. Their prices ranged from $97,000 for a small two-bedroom ranch that needs work to $499,000 for a six-bedroom, six-bath 19th-century Queen Anne-style house on Main Street that is now a bed-and-breakfast. The median price of homes that were sold rose 17 percent last year, Mr. Proctor said. 
There are 86 condominium town houses in two developments: the 56-unit Coppermine Village off Mine Street and the newer 30-unit Victorian Square off Walter Foran Boulevard. Homes in Coppermine bring $140,000 for smaller two-bedroom units to $165,000 for larger three-bedroom units; in Victorian Square, prices are about 10 percent higher.
FLEMINGTON has six large apartment complexes, with 668 units. The largest are the 164-unit Prospect Hills on Capner Street and the 182-unit Hunter Hills garden apartment complex off Garden Lane, both on the west side of town. Rentals throughout the borough range from $750 for small one-bedroom units to $1,100 for larger two-bedroom units.
Among the newer residents are Dan and Judi Morgan, who bought a four-bedroom Victorian on Broad Street a year and a half ago. Mr. Morgan works from home as a computer systems analyst, and Mrs. Morgan teaches in the local school system. 
"We moved from a home on a large lot in Raritan Township, where you don't know your neighbors and have to drive everywhere," Mr. Morgan said. "Now, we're in town, where you can walk to everything. It's really pleasurable to know your neighbors and the store owners. It's a sense of community."
Commercially, Flemington is split between its historic Main and Broad Streets and two outlet malls off Church Street: the modern brick 60-store Liberty Village, and Turntable Junction, an eclectic collection of a dozen old buildings transplanted into Flemington in 1965 to become an outlet shopping area. 
Among the most unusual shops in the historic section is Stangl/Pfaltzgraff Pottery, started on Mine Street in the early 19th century. Although they no longer operate, three conical brick kilns form the core of the structure -- a reminder of the way pottery was produced at the turn of the century, when the company was making 1,500 pieces of stoneware at the site daily. Another well-known local business is Flemington Cut Glass, a lead-crystal manufacturer that opened in 1902 and still has a shop off Main Street. 
The lone relic of Flemington's railroading past is the Black River and Western Railroad, a tourist train that starts just outside Liberty Village and is pulled by a 1937 steam-powered locomotive to nearby Lambertville. It operates from March 31 through Dec. 9; round trips cost $8 for adults and $4 for children ages 3 to 12.
The most famous structure in town is the former Hunterdon County Courthouse, a colonnaded white structure built on Main Street in 1828. In 1935, it was the venue for what was called "the trial of the century," in which a handyman, Bruno Hauptmann, was convicted of kidnapping and killing Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., the infant son of the famous aviator. Across the street is the Union Hotel -- a four-story 1877 brick structure with two-story gingerbread porches -- where the Lindbergh jurors were sequestered during the trial.
Now a restaurant and office space, the building is still used for annual re-enactments of the Lindbergh trial, which take place in October. Also on Main Street are a number of antiques shops, a tobacconist with a cigar-store Indian out front and Flemington Furs, which says it is the world's largest fur outlet. The borough has no supermarkets; residents do their food shopping in Raritan Township.
One of Flemington's attractions for the Morgans was its excellent school system. Mr. Morgan's 14-year-old daughter, Carey, is now in the eighth grade at the 1,160-student Reading-Fleming Middle School, which houses grades six through eight. Together with four elementary schools, the middle school makes up the 3,500-student Flemington-Raritan Regional School District, which it shares with the surrounding Raritan Township. 
AFTER middle school, the students go on to Hunterdon Central High School, which also includes students from Raritan, Readington, East Amwell and Delaware Townships.
The superintendent of schools of the Flemington-Raritan Regional District, Dr. Jack Farr, notes that the elementary and middle school system has both a wide-ranging special education program starting in kindergarten and a gifted-and-talented program starting in the third grade.
Spanish language instruction starts in the first grade, and computers are introduced in kindergarten. Each classroom has at least one terminal, and each school has a computer laboratory. 
The 2,740-student Hunterdon Central High School is on a 72-acre campus on Route 31 in Flemington. It includes four classroom buildings, a music building, a media center and a communications building that houses a student-run FM-radio station and a cable television station, which broadcasts local events. Advanced placement courses are offered in English, psychology, economics, calculus, biology, chemistry, physics, German and Spanish.
On last year's SAT's, Hunterdon Central's students scored a combined verbal and mathematics average of 1,073, which is 64 points higher than the state average. Of last year's 505 graduating seniors, 87 percent went on to two- or four-year colleges. 
The largest recreational facility in town is the five-acre Tuccamirgan Park, off Bonnell Street. It has playground equipment, picnic tables under a pavilion, a running path and a basketball court.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
A Major in Business With a Minor in Aviation

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
EVEN the most frequent of flyers have never heard of Amber Air, created last year to provide nonstop service between New York and Riga, Latvia.
 There's a good reason for that: Amber Air is a fiction dreamed up for a classroom project last year by four employees of Aer Lingus, the Irish national airline, . Their goal was to convince their bosses that investing in a one-plane start-up airline was a good idea. 
 As an extra-credit project, the same four students brainstormed something that flyers can actually appreciate: a new design for the Aer Lingus passenger lounge at Kennedy. Their design, which partitions the room into separate areas for work, entertainment and snacking, won out over a competing plan submitted by a team of architects. 
Both Amber Air and the lounge are outcomes of an Aer Lingus career-development program that blends a standard business curriculum with special attention to airline industry realities. The curriculum was developed by the Dowling Institute, a nine-year-old Dowling College program that creates customized training for about 20 Long Island businesses every year.
Last week, the four employees returned to the classroom to begin their third and final term. Over the next six months the students -- an administrative assistant, a clerk in the sales department, a food-service worker and a telemarketer -- will create temporary job assignments for themselves.
"It's a little like creating your own internship," said Jack Foley, the Aer Lingus executive vice president who developed the program in conjunction with Dr. Leo Giglio (pronounced JILL-ee-oh), a Dowling business professor, and Elana Stern, the institute's director.
A self-described "Brooklyn guy" who started out 25 years ago as a baggage handler at Lufthansa, Mr. Foley worked at several airlines before getting the chance to run the North American operations for Aer Lingus. "When I was at British Air," he said with a straight face, "I think my Brooklyn accent was a bit of a drawback."
The Aer Lingus program at Dowling provides employees with a chance for advancement. "I'd rather give opportunities to dedicated people who work for us than go recruit new people for every opening," Mr. Foley said. "The Dowling program makes it cheaper to train than recruit."
The airline is paying about $25,000 a term for this first group, but Dowling says the cost may go up for subsequent classes. The program is unusual in that enrollment is open to both managers and hourly workers, who attend classes in addition to doing their regular jobs. 
Dr. Giglio said he was a little surprised when nine of the original 13 students dropped out. "However, I'm really impressed by the dedication and achievement of the four who remained," he said. "We recognized that some students might leave the progam before completion, or change jobs afterward. It's a risk, but Jack said he's O.K. with that."
The four students said they were proud of completing two-thirds of a curriculum that proved more challenging than they anticipated. "Sitting home and doing assignments was pretty easy," said Nancy Gavin, the clerk. "Learning to work together in teams, that was more difficult."
The research and presentation skills required for the Amber Air project put their newly acquired training to the test, said Lara McCarthy, the administrative assistant. The students worked months on the project before making the presentation to Aer Lingus management. "We had so much information, we had to focus on which information communicated the facts we wanted to emphasize," Ms. McCarthy said.
The Aer Lingus training program began taking shape in the early summer of 1997, when the airline was planning to move from midtown Manhattan to Melville, to lower real estate costs while expanding space. 
"We had to become profitable, as the government of Ireland plans to privatize the airline," Mr. Foley said. 
Aer Lingus was part of a mini-migration of international airlines that left New York for Long Island during the last decade, said Robert Mann, an airline consultant in Port Washington: Lufthansa moved to East Meadow, Swissair/Sabena to Melville, and Varig to Valley Stream.
Aer Lingus completed its move from Manhattan to Melville in July and doubled its work force from 60 to 120. "Our North Atlantic service is growing, and we anticipate a number of managerial and professional jobs opening up," Mr. Foley said.
As recently as 1995, Aer Lingus, which is based in Dublin, sold fewer than 400,000 tickets to its two North American destinations, New York and Boston. But that figure has more than tripled, Mr. Foley said, as the airline added service to Washington, Newark, Chicago and Los Angeles.
Mr. Foley believes the Dowling training program supports the North American division's emphasis on employee development. "My choice is always to reward our workers when there's a career opportunity," he said. "Now, in today's tight labor market, the cost of recruitment makes this strategy economically important as well."
Often, he said, workers who are promoted through the managerial ranks lack fundamental skills in accounting, finance, marketing and personal communications. "The dilemma every company faces," he said, "is how do you move people around an organization -- people who are dedicated and hard-working -- if they don't have the training and experience to do the job?"
He rejected the traditional solution of paying for employees to take management courses at local colleges. "Too generic," he said. As for in-house training, such programs tend to reinforce conventional industry thinking, he believes.
So the fact that Dr. Giglio was not an airline specialist appealed to Mr. Foley, and Dr. Giglio, who has been a consultant to Long Island companies like Aeroflex Inc., Arrow Electronics and Dayton T. Brown Inc., developed a program that teaches business fundamentals within the context of the airline industry. 
While a conventional business can reshelve inventory for sale the next day, an airline cannot. "Our product is an empty seat that loses all value the moment the plane takes off," Mr. Foley said. "But you can't sell the seat for whatever you can get for it at the last minute. If you do that, you devalue the product and antagonize the 200 people who paid full value."
As they reassembled for their last semester, the four students and their instructor reminisced about last year's great success, the multimedia Amber Air presentation.
"I was glad we chose Riga rather than a city like Warsaw," said Ms. McCarthy, a Dubliner by birth. "Not only did the airline have no competition, but we couldn't be second-guessed. No one could hold up a competitor's report and say, 'You're wrong, and here are the numbers to prove it.' "
Mr. Foley said the quality of the presentation showed the Dowling program was a success and pronounced himself delighted.
Dr. Giglio remembered Mr. Foley as being a bit more than that. "Jack was almost in tears," he said. "He was that proud."
