HEADLINE: A Role Model for Urban Revival; 
Seeking to Turn Around Its Downtown, White Plains Looked to a Connecticut Neighbor

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH

 BODY:
THREE years ago, White Plains was a city in decline. The tax base had been dropping for more than a decade, and the office vacancy rate was more than 30 percent -- the highest in the world for cities of its size. "You could fire a cannon in the downtown area at night and not hit anybody," said Joseph M. Delfino, who became mayor in 1998.
 So the mayor and his aides looked for a model to help guide their efforts to bring the city back to life. They found one 15 miles northeast, in Stamford. The Connecticut city, after all, had been in similarly dire straits only a few years earlier, with its vacancy rate close to 30 percent, and the streets around its gleaming office towers empty and forbidding. But it had risen from the ashes with amazing speed, in part by building new high-rise residential towers and adding dozens of restaurants and bars in the downtown area. 
 "We looked very closely at what they did in their downtown," said Paul Wood, an aide to Mr. Delfino. The renewal plan White Plains arrived at -- rooted in new housing and entertainment in the downtown area -- is straight out of the Stamford playbook. There were other models, Mr. Wood said, but Stamford was the clearest, because it was so close and because its history has so paralleled that of White Plains. 
Although Stamford is much larger -- 37.7 square miles as opposed to 9.9 -- the two cities' downtown areas are of comparable size. Their demographic makeup, median income and daytime population -- roughly 200,000 -- are virtually the same. Both cities are viewed as the center of their respective counties, and both fall under the shadow of New York City, from which they began to draw corporations looking for safer and more suburban settings starting in the 1950's and 60's. 
Both underwent a similarly dramatic urban renewal, bulldozing large sections of their downtown areas and rebuilding them with vast office towers in the 1970's and 80's. Both built enclosed malls at roughly the same time; and those malls helped destroy the existing retail outlets on the city's main retail street, which was known, in both cases, as "little Fifth Avenue."
Both cities have also been held up as examples of what the architecture critic Joel Garreau has called the "edge city," a hastily built agglomeration of office towers and parking garages designed to accommodate the needs of cars more than pedestrians. But they also illustrate the ways city planners have tried to revitalize what had been viewed as cold, hostile settings.
On that front, even a casual visitor can see that Stamford has come further than White Plains. On a weeknight after 8, White Plains is virtually empty, its audible pedestrian signals -- designed for the blind -- chiming eerily in the silence. In the heart of the downtown, the old Macy's building remains vacant, and across from it are discount stores like The $1 Limit.
There are few young people on the streets, and none of the sleek coffee bars that have become almost ubiquitous elsewhere. It is as though the city's clocks had stopped in the last recession and never started again.
By contrast, Stamford's streets at night are often filled with patrons from dozens of new downtown restaurants, bars and the city's two multiscreen movie theaters. 
Stamford has also gained more than 1,000 units of residential housing downtown over the last five years, with 2,500 more units planned; and there are new security and sanitation workers to keep the streets safe and clean. The city's office vacancy rate is now about 7 percent. White Plains remains at 13.4 percent, though it has less than half of Stamford's 15 million square feet of office space, said Frank Tomasulo, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis, a real estate brokerage firm.
That comparison might seem humbling to a city that has often been viewed as Stamford's rival. But competition between the cities has mostly been mythological, said Edward Steinberg, who worked as a planner for White Plains and then for Stamford over three decades.
"The notion of competition between White Plains and Stamford has been for the most part in the minds of third parties," he said. "They were just doing similar things at similar times." 
Both cities were founded in the 17th century, and grew slowly over the years. 
White Plains, which has been the seat of the Westchester County government since 1778, was mostly residential, with some commerce and the county office buildings, while Stamford was a manufacturing town, shipping pianos, bicycles, locks and other goods to New York City from its Canal Street docks. 
By 1960, when they decided to participate in the federal urban renewal program, both cities encompassed a series of mostly wealthy residential neighborhoods surrounding a declining urban core. 
In both cities, urban renewal drew opposition. In White Plains, the 138-acre renewal zone -- the second largest in the country -- included the city's old commercial center and an old courthouse, parts of which dated to 1830. It also included slum areas and an old hotel called the Honeymoon Flats that was also a brothel, said Alfred Del Vecchio, who served as the city's mayor from 1976 to 1994, and has been a White Plains resident since 1957.
The Stamford urban renewal zone had a similar variety of old homes. 
"It's like an entire city vanished without a record," said Renee Kahn, the director of the Stamford Historic Neighborhood Preservation Program. "Many of the houses had seen better days, but it was very mixed and very interesting."
The cities chose different approaches: Stamford appointed a single developer, the local F. D. Rich Company, while White Plains chose to work with a variety of builders.
And Stamford built a number of huge, single-occupancy buildings to accommodate the corporations moving up from Manhattan. Frightened by a wave of crime and terrorist attacks on office buildings in New York City, GTE designed its new Stamford headquarters to be bomb-proof in the early 1970's, said Robert N. Rich, who supervised the entire renewal project. 
Although Stamford hired a number of renowned architects, such as Cesar Pelli, Arthur Erickson and Michael Graves, they designed similarly cold, fortress-like buildings that bore no apparent relationship to one another. Because of the city's proximity to the sea, parking garages could not be built too deep, so the new office towers tended to have several floors of parking at the base, with little attention paid to pedestrian access. The result was a strikingly forbidding landscape, where employees could come and go by car without ever touching their feet to the streets.
White Plains, which had drawn the first major corporate relocation from New York City when General Foods moved its headquarters to Westchester Avenue in 1954, chose not to build single-occupancy towers in the downtown area. But it did put up $1 billion of new construction between 1976 and 1986, including many office buildings that echoed Stamford's bomb-proof fortresses. 
"We were in such a rush to get everything completed that as a city, we sometimes didn't insist on a high degree of architectural excellence," said William A. Rose Jr., an architect who served on the citizens advisory committee for the Central Urban Renewal Project and later as a White Plains city councilman.
Christopher Bruhl, president of SACIA, the business council of southwestern Connecticut, said urban planners misunderstood what was happening in cities.
"The emphasis on automotive access to buildings, and the assumption that people would not venture out, was temporary," he said, "but it happened to be in full swing when White Plains and Stamford were doing urban renewal and deciding what to build." 
In both cities, planners hoped that putting a major enclosed mall downtown would lure people back to the cities' fraying retail area. Most malls, after all, were still being built in suburban locations in the 1970's. 
But as it happened, the 889,000-square-foot Galleria mall in White Plains, which opened for business in 1980, helped kill the old retail district on Mamaroneck Avenue, which once boasted such high-end stores as Bonwit Teller and B. Altman.
"The mall did, I think, sound the death knell for retail on Mamaroneck Avenue as we had known it," said Mary Anne Keenan, who served on the White Plains city council from 1974 until 1999. The Westchester mall, which opened in 1995 with 1.1 million square feet and high-end retailers like Neiman Marcus and Tiffany's, may have aggravated the problem.
The 900,000-square-foot Stamford Town Center (some locals prefer to call it "Fort Stamford") was built in 1982 on Boston Post Road, the only place between New York and Boston where the road is interrupted. The city planners said they wanted to help Bedford Street, Stamford's equivalent of Mamaroneck Avenue. 
But they made it into a one-way street, running away from the mall, while another street with no shops on it led into the enclosed mall, Ms. Kahn said. "It was like a giant black hole that sucked the life out of the businesses around it," she added.
When the recession arrived in the late 1980's, it struck both cities almost equally.
Stamford emerged partly through luck, when the state economic development director helped broker a tax abatement package to lure the financial giant Swiss Bank (now UBS Warburg) from Manhattan in 1994. The deal, which included tax breaks that could amount to $120 million over 10 years, so incensed New York City officials that they took out large advertisements in Connecticut newspapers to denounce Stamford's "blatant and unneighborly raid."
Ironically, the absence of a Fairfield County government may have benefited Stamford -- not just by keeping taxes down, but also by making the state more generous than it otherwise would be, said Mr. Steinberg, the planner who worked for White Plains and then for Stamford. 
Even though White Plains is the county seat, city officials there have rarely had a good working relationship with Westchester County, and New York State has not stepped in to help out with economic incentives until recently, he added.
Connecticut has also had a longstanding tax advantage. 
Until a decade ago, there was no income tax, and today that tax is lower than New York's, as are corporate and sales taxes. Although White Plains has one of the lowest property tax rates in Westchester, it is still almost twice that of Stamford.
Meanwhile White Plains, lacking a catalyst like Swiss Bank, saw its tax base decline steadily. The departure of Macy's from its downtown location next to the Galleria in 1995 was "a crushing blow," Mayor Delfino said. 
And several development deals fell through or stalled, including a proposal by Tishman-Speyer to build a 21-screen Loews movie theater on the Macy's site.
One important obstacle has been the city's zoning laws and review process, which are far more cumbersome than Stamford's. "All the businesses and developers I have spoken with over the past 10 years told me they didn't feel welcome in White Plains," Mr. Delfino said. 
One developer who owns properties in both cities said: "It's a much quicker process in Stamford. In White Plains, they just kill you. Everything is spot zoning. And there's too many people in the approval process."
Part of the problem, several developers said, is White Plains's often-fractious Common Council, whose six elected members review every proposed development. Because Stamford's government is more complex, with two elected representatives from each of 20 districts in addition to the mayor, the Board of Representatives, as it is called, rarely reviews proposals, making for a smoother process.
But in the last three years White Plains has embarked on an aggressive effort to reinvent itself. Although the council still has the power to slow projects, Mr. Delfino initiated a new "coordinated review" process for development proposals in 1998 that has been hailed as a vast improvement.
Builders now sit down at a table with every city official who needs to review a proposal, instead of being forced to go from office to office. "That process has streamlined what was a long, arduous task," said Salvatore Campofranco, senior vice president of Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, which owns property in both Westchester and Fairfield. 
And the state and county authorities, which had never offered White Plains much help with economic development, are now pitching in. "New York State is now more competitive than Connecticut in terms of offering incentive packages," Mr. Steinberg said.
That extra help has allowed White Plains to compete successfully with Stamford for the first time in many years, particularly in the area of information technology, where Westchester has long had an advantage because of I.B.M.'s presence in the county. Although the county has not drawn major employers on the scale of Swiss Bank, it has cut its vacancy rate by focusing on small and midsize firms, said Salvatore Carrera, the county economic development director.
In April 2000, for instance, Greenwich Technology Partners, an expanding network consultants and engineering company, moved its headquarters to White Plains from Stamford, bringing 90 employees.
Part of the draw was availability and price, said Greenwich's chief executive officer, Joseph Beninati. Stamford's low vacancy rate has helped to drive its average asking price per square foot of office space to about $34, while White Plains is about $27, Mr. Tomasulo said.
But the city, working with the county and the Empire State Development Corporation, also made an important difference. "Sal Carrera and Mayor Delfino were really helpful in terms of putting together economic incentives," Mr. Beninati said. "That was in substantial contrast to efforts by Connecticut and Fairfield politicians. They were sort of silent."
Another factor, Mr. Beninati said, was traffic: congestion on I-95 has become a serious problem for commuters, and White Plains has easier access to New York and the metropolitan area.
In fact, transportation has become a challenge for both cities. Although there is traffic on I-287 and the other roads that serve White Plains, including the Hutchinson River Parkway and the Bronx River Parkway, there are more alternatives than in Stamford, where the traffic on I-95 is almost unparalleled. 
And though Stamford has had an edge in railroad access, with four Metro-North tracks serving the city instead of the two that run to White Plains, the Stamford station -- currently undergoing a $100 million renovation -- does not have enough trains scheduled in the peak times, said Mayor Dannel Malloy of Stamford. 
Meanwhile, a plan to build a third track serving White Plains was approved in November by the Federal Transit Administration, and the work is expected to be completed in the next few years, said Dan Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North. White Plains already has better access to the Westchester County Airport -- a 10-minute drive from downtown -- and to the New York City airports.
Traffic problems have helped to tighten the housing market in both cities. Both have wealthy neighborhoods, though Stamford has more million-dollar homes, particularly in the area north of the Merritt Parkway and on Shippan Point, along the shore. And both have more poverty, and a higher concentration of ethnic minorities, than any of the surrounding suburbs.
Stamford's growth has also put pressure on its school system, which has a higher percentage of poor students and racial minorities and lower academic scores than most of its wealthier suburban neighbors, like Greenwich. 
The White Plains school district, with half as many students, has a similar demographic mix and is similarly overshadowed by Scarsdale and other high-scoring neighbors. But Mayor Malloy has made Stamford's public schools a major priority, spending more than $100 million on school construction and renovation in the past three years, adding a prekindergarten program that is available to all the city's 4-year-olds.
But as they build more housing in their once-lonely downtown areas, the most important distinction between the two cities may have more to do with urban atmosphere than roads, schools and taxes.
"Once these places are more or less equal, what determines who wins or loses is the squishy stuff -- soul, community, identity," said Mr. Garreau, who has continued to write and lecture about urban issues since the publication of "Edge City" in 1991.
And though Stamford could hardly be described as cozy, city officials have worked hard to make it more appealing. The Downtown Special Services District, established in 1992 and financed through a 5 percent surtax on property owners, has worked with the city government to prevent suburban sprawl and ensure that new developments are more pedestrian-friendly. 
It has also encouraged more retail and entertainment outlets. The city already has two movie complexes, and the Stamford Center for the Arts is now renovating and expanding the old Palace Theater, which along with the Rich Forum draws 250,000 people a year to live performances, said Sandra Goldstein, the director of the Special Services District.
The district has also added more security and sanitation patrols to keep the streets safe and clean. Crime has dropped 27 percent in the last four years, thanks in part to the innovative community policing strategies of Police Chief Dean M. Esserman, a former protege of a former New York City police commissioner, William J. Bratton.
The city's business leaders, conscious of Stamford's image problem, began working a decade ago to promote the city as a welcoming place to live, partnering with the Special Services District and sponsoring the Fairfield County Information Exchange as a news source. "We all worked together to create a framework for evaluating what needed to be done, largely based around the edge city concept," said Darrell Harvey, the co-chief executive officer of the Ashforth Company, a commercial real estate firm. 
Some of the things Stamford has done may not be realistic in White Plains. "Stamford is just far enough from New York that it can support its own cultural institutions," Mr. Steinberg said. "White Plains doesn't have any of that." 
That distance -- 49 minutes on the train as opposed to 37 -- may also help account for Stamford's greater success with creating high-density housing in the downtown area. Workers in White Plains, after all, can more easily commute from New York, or a number of surrounding counties. "People come to White Plains because it's a suburb, with the advantages of a city," Ms. Keenan said. "They don't want to live downtown."
Mayor Delfino, however, could not disagree more. 
"They got a 10-year jump on us," he said. "But we're planning to build 1,500 to 2,000 housing units right in the downtown area. We're on our way now."

The Ambience Of a Small Town
 For Daniel Bryan, a 25-year-old financial analyst who moved to White Plains from Stamford in August, the difference between the two cities is one of atmosphere: Stamford feels more like a small town.
"There's a downtown area where you can walk to a number of restaurants and bars, and it's a younger, more professional crowd," he said. Downtown White Plains has a grittier, more urban feel and lacks Stamford's movie theaters, he said. 
Other people who have lived in downtown Stamford tend to agree. "When you say the words 'corporate headquarters,' you imagine people all dressed up," said Robbie Monsma, who moved to downtown Stamford with her family last fall. "But there were lots of kids and older people on the street; I found it really charming." The difference is partly a matter of the distance to New York City. "White Plains is closer, so when I want to go out I just go into New York," Mr. Bryan said. 
And one thing is certain: White Plains, which has far less housing in its downtown area, is cheaper. "You definitely get more bang for your buck in White Plains," said Mr. Bryan, who is paying more than he did in Stamford but has a much larger apartment, he said. Despite its more run-down atmosphere, there are people who consider White Plains downright cozy. "I've never been so comfortable with my neighbors as I am here," said Jennifer Scharbach, who has lived in a $1,200-a-month two-bedroom apartment on Martine Avenue with her husband and two children for six years. ROBERT WORTH

HEADLINE: Bridge Loans Offer Smooth Passage Between Homes 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
BEFORE Lucien and Tiffany DiForte decided to move to eastern Pennsylvania from Staten Island, the couple went through the endless calculations that make home buying almost as much fun as an I.R.S. audit. The considerations included the sales price, property taxes and, because they have a 3-year-old son, schools. Since Mr. DiForte is keeping his job on Staten Island, as manager of P. A. C. Plumbing, Heating and Air Conditioning, the family also had to take into account his daily commute. 
 After satisfying themselves on each count, the DiFortes settled on an eight-room, two-bath house on a half acre in Easton, Pa., just across the Delaware River from New Jersey, and closed on the property last Monday. They still have to close on the sale of their five-room, one-bath town house in the Arden Heights section of Staten Island, a closing scheduled for Jan. 22. By paying $152,000 for their new house and selling their town house for $157,000, they are in solid financial shape -- at least on paper. 
 "But since we had to pay off a $17,000 balance on our home equity loan," Mr. DiForte said, "and because there were closing costs on the new house and costs to move, we took out a $45,800 bridge loan. With that we paid off the equity loan, and when we sell this house, we'll pay off the bridge loan and put the balance toward the mortgage on our new house." 
As the term suggests, bridge loans are short-term loans intended to bridge the time span between buying one house and selling another. Although those loans were once commonly part of a move from one home to another, they began disappearing in the late 1980's. What relegated them to the niche market where they dwell to this day were home equity loans and home equity lines of credit. 
Home equity loans typically provide funds at a fixed rate for a fixed period of time. Home equity lines of credit have variable rates and can be tapped into at any time. Either loan can be used for any number of things, including home improvements, consolidating or paying off debts, tuition or medical bills.
Equity loans soared after Congress passed the tax act of 1986, according to Keith Leggett, a senior economist for the American Bankers Association. That law eliminated deductions on interest payments on credit cards and on loans to buy cars and many other worldly goods, but continued allowing borrowers to deduct interest for loans on which their property was put up as collateral. Thus, bridge loans are also deductible, but they are usually made for only a couple of months and home equity loans can be repaid over decades.
In 1983, according to the Federal Reserve, 7 percent of all homeowners had some form of home equity loan or credit in addition to their mortgages, Mr. Leggett said. By 1988 that figure was up to 11 percent, and it had risen to 13 percent -- roughly nine million households -- in 1997, the latest year for which figures are available. 
Overall statistics about the number of bridge loans are nonexistent, because very few banks even make the loans and because reporting the statistics would hardly be worth the bother for the lending institutions that do. 
"We write only a few bridge loans a month," said Palmer Heenan, senior vice president of Weichert Financial Services in Morris Plains, N.J., which made the bridge loan to the DiFortes. "But those loans still have a place." 
This is so even though interest rates on bridge loans are often two percentage points higher than those for conventional loans and some lenders require borrowers to pay points as a loan-origination fee. (Each point is equal to 1 percent of the total loan.)
Worse, if the borrower cannot sell his current house, he may end up shouldering two mortgages and the bridge loan. In that case he may have to lower the asking price sharply. 
The lending company, too, could find itself at risk, and in possible legal trouble. "If the deal fell apart, the lender could be viewed as liable for allowing the borrower to encumber himself with so much debt," said Eric P. Declercq, a regional vice president for Countrywide Home Loans, a California-based company with 30 lending offices in the New York area. That is why financial counselors advise people thinking of taking out a bridge loan to instead sell their current house before buying another, even though that runs the risk of losing out on a dream house they might have an eye on. Another safeguard would be to make the sale of one's current house contingent on finding a new house, although that too is easier said than done in a seller's market.
Most bridge loans cover 80 percent of the overall value of the property, while equity loans often go as high as 90 percent. "But in order to get a new or bigger equity loan, you can't have your house listed for sale," said John Greco, the president of Darien Financial Services Inc. in Darien, Conn.
And applying for a new equity loan or a higher line of credit requires a new appraisal -- but "you can't get a new appraisal if your house is already on the market," said Moshira Namoury, president of First Fidelity Mortgage Bankers in Stamford, Conn. Ms. Namoury added that if borrowers with home equity loans want to refinance their first mortgages, "a lot of lenders won't allow them to if they've touched their home equity within the last 12 months." 
While people who already have a home equity loan can list their home for sale, Mr. Greco said, some lenders require the borrower to occupy the house for as much as six months before putting it on the market. In addition, if the loan is closed within six months, some lenders will require the borrower to reimburse them for the expenses incurred in opening the loan.
For many borrowers, the appeal of bridge loans is that they can borrow a larger amount than would be the case if they simply took out an unsecured loan. One reason is that the bridge loan is secured by existing property.
Another is the formula by which lenders calculate the size of the loan for which borrowers can qualify. That calculation is based on dividing borrowers' gross monthly income into their monthly housing expenses, including principal, interest, taxes and insurance. Almost all lenders make housing loans that most borrowers will be able to repay with no more than 33 percent of their incomes, while allowing another 5 percent of income to repay all other debt. For a bridge loan, most lenders do not use the bridge loan itself in calculating the debt. Instead, they require that a borrower have a signed sales contract for the existing home, or they require that the borrower pay six months' interest in advance.
But just because higher loans are available, lenders say that borrowers should apply for only as big a loan as they need. "The bridge loan is not usually for the faint of heart," Mr. Greco said. "It's usually for the more sophisticated buyer." Bridge loans are also appealing for borrowers who do not have a home equity loan or who have reached the maximum of their existing line of credit. They also appeal to that handful of investors who would rather take out a short-term loan for the down payment and closing costs of a new house than sell their stocks or bonds. 
Lenders justify the higher rates of bridge loans, when compared with home-equity loans, by citing a higher degree of risk. "They are fairly risky transactions, more so than on traditional owner-occupied properties," said Mr. Heenan of Weichert Financial Services. Weichert charges two points (that is, 2 percent of the total loan) and an interest rate two percentage points more for bridge loans than for more traditional loans, Mr. Heenan said, "because if the loan is outstanding for only a week, as some of them are, we need to be compensated for taking a risk." 
Bridge loans come in an assortment of shapes and sizes, although the usual term is 30 to 60 days. But Darien Financial Services, for example, makes them for 180 days, and borrowers need not have a existing relationship, as many other lenders require. Others will make them for longer periods. 
Weichert offers two types of bridge loans and only for terms of one year -- a first mortgage on which the borrower makes monthly payments of only the interest that accumulates between receipt of the loan and its repayment, or a loan secured by a second mortgage on the borrower's existing property. On second mortgages, Weichert will lend up to $100,000, compared with $400,000 on a first mortgage.
The recent bullish housing market has conspired against bridge loans. With homes selling as fast as they were put on the market and in some cases even before they were listed, many owners accepted the first inviting offer that was accompanied by a down payment, rather than wait the week to 10 days for a bridge loan to be approved. 
"When properties are still selling briskly, most sellers can still get a buyer pretty quickly," Mr. Heenan said. "But as the economy is throttling back, that may change." 
Bridge loans were once a routine part of the corporate relocation process -- that is, employees transferred to other cities who have an urgent need for loans to tide them over while they look for a new house as they try to sell their current one. 
In the 1980's, bridge loans were often the loan of choice. But in the strong economy of recent years, that pattern also changed. Most of the time the employer will advance the amount the employee needs for the house, said Ms. Namoury of the First Fidelity Mortgage Bankers in Stamford.
Even when bridge loans are offered as part of a corporate relocation, lenders are wary. "We only offer a true bridge loan to people being transferred by a Fortune 1,000 company, and we'll lend them 100 percent of the value of the home purchased," said Mr. Declercq of Countrywide Home Loans. "But the company must agree in writing to buy the house after a fixed period, usually six months, or carry the payments."
In such cases, the employee takes out a first and second mortgage to finance the full sales price of the new home, up to $500,000. Eighty percent is financed with the first mortgage; the remainder is available as a home equity line of credit for a fixed-term second mortgage. 
"This way we've protected the consumer, making sure they don't get in over their heads," Mr. Declercq said. "Then when they sell their house, they'll be able to pay off the second mortgage, leaving them with the 80 percent first mortgage and without having to incur any private mortgage insurance." That insurance, known as P.M.I., is required on any home loan for which the borrower puts down less than 20 percent.
Bridge loans are not limited to individual homeowners. "I do them on a small scale for friends who are builders and with whom we have a long-term relationship," said Nadine Malone, president of Madison Home Equities in Carle Place, on Long Island. "I recently made a $275,000 bridge loan to a builder in East Hampton who had just finished 90 percent of a million-dollar-plus house, but needed the loan to finish the plumbing and landscaping in order to get the certificate of occupancy." 
BY contrast, the average bridge loan provided by the American Mortgage Acceptance Company in Manhattan is $2 million -- not for single-family homes, to be sure, but primarily for the construction and mortgage financing of government-insured multifamily housing.
"Developers can go to the Federal Housing Administration and under a special program can get them to put up 90 percent of the cost of developing apartment buildings," said Stuart Boesky, the company's chief executive. "But then they have to ask themselves whether they can put up the other $1 million or so, and if not they come to us for a bridge loan." However, he added that bridge loans generally are getting harder to find, because "our environment is getting more risk averse." He added, "People want bigger and bigger returns to take risks." 
Mr. and Mrs. DiForte may have taken a risk of a different kind by deciding to move to Easton, but you wouldn't know if from talking with them. "The closing was painless," Mrs. DeForte said, before rhapsodizing about their new house with its sun room, dining room, living room, eat-in kitchen and second bathroom, spaciousness that she does not have in her other house.
As for Mr. DiForte's daily 130-mile round-trip commute by car back to Staten Island, neither of them sounded especially concerned. "It's only an hour and 15 minutes each way," he said. 
Besides, Mrs. DiForte added: "My mother takes a bus from Arden Heights to Manhattan, and it takes her two hours each day. God forbid how long it takes when there's an accident in a tunnel or on a bridge."

HEADLINE: Why Can't Hudson County Get Any Respect?; 
Despite Soaring Towers, Rising Property Values and Even a Light Rail, the Region Struggles to Polish Its Image

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
ON CLIFTON PLACE, where the rocky face of the Palisades mellows into a gentle slope overlooking this city's booming waterfront and trendy downtown -- the Margaret Hague Maternity Hospital looms like the mocking specter of a past that Hudson County would just as soon forget.
 It has been two decades since the last baby was born in the aging building. And 72 years after its groundbreaking, the what was a seven-story palace of pediatrics -- solidly built of brick and limestone -- is a deserted corpse. Most of the windows are smashed, and torn shades flap in the chill wind that that whips off New York Bay. Its arched main entrance is a wall of cinder block. 
 A few years ago a cyclone fence was put up around the decaying building to deter squatters and scavengers, but it was too late. In a thinly veiled reference to the Margaret Hague in his novel "Clockers," Richard Price, a chronicler of Hudson County's underbelly, described how junkies stripped the hospital interior of copper tubing to sell for scrap. 
"It's actually where I was born," said Officer Raymond Ortiz of the Jersey City Police Department, who lives in a multifamily house across the street from the hospital. 
Officer Ortiz said that the battered hulk where his mother gave him life 27 years ago did not bother him. "Sign of the times," he said with a shrug.
Frank ("I Am the Law") Hague, mayor of Jersey City from 1917 to 1947 and longtime leader of the Democratic Party in Hudson County, named the maternity hospital after his mother. And while there is no question that the hospital provided invaluable pediatric services -- often free to poor residents -- it was also exploited as a patronage mill with a large political price tag.
And just as the Margaret Hague -- inhabited by rodents these days -- stands as a symbol of the Hague machine and the ultimate ruin wrought by corruption, the failure to demolish the hospital or convert it into much-needed housing parallels Hudson County's inability to cleanse itself entirely of the stigma that Boss Hague and his ilk left in their wake.
While the county has made great strides, particularly along its stretch of the Hudson River known as the Gold Coast, even the county's proudest boosters concede that people in and outside New Jersey still envision Hudson County as something just short of Gomorrah on the Palisades.
"The perception is that nothing really good is going on in Hudson County," said Edward J. DeFazio, a longtime assistant Hudson County prosecutor and resident. "There's a certain disrespect for the county and its citizens.
Despite the intensive development in former waterfront wastelands -- resulting in soaring property values, the wholesale creation of jobs, cooperation among municipalities once known for bitter squabbling, and the virtual end of the old-style machine politics -- several factors have conspired to conceal Hudson's rebound.
Old perceptions do not seem to be stemming the flow of residents and businesses into the county. In Jersey City alone, the planning board has approved 11 million square feet of office space and 6,000 new residential units since 1997, much of that already under construction, said Tom Gallagher, the mayor's chief of staff.
"Jersey City is now known nationally as being one of the hottest real estate markets in the country, and a premiere location for both Fortune 500 companies and middle-class famililes," Mr. Gallagher said.
And as for the area's tainted history, he observed: "I don't think most people are aware, and when the do become aware of it, they see it as sort of a colorful part of the city's past."
Obviously, Hudson County's recovery -- like Newark's ballyhooed renaissance -- is due in part to the nation's economic surge in the 90's. Yet Newark's turnaround pricks at the pride of people in Jersey City, Hoboken and other parts of Hudson, who believe their gains have received much less attention.
If there were a physical embodiment of Hudson County, it would have to be County Executive Robert C. Janiszewski, who 55 years after his birth still lives here, in a condominium near the Exchange Place financial center.
Mr. Janiszewski, a former board member of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, once had higher aspirations, but he has since recognized the constraints placed on him by his place of birth. He recalled the opinion of one newspaper columnist while he was in the State Assembly that had he been from Bergen County, he would have been considered a gubernatorial candidate.
"There's probably not a month that that goes by," he said, "that I don't run into someone, 'Oh, I've heard your name. You're up in Hudson County, Jersey City, right? Oh, I haven't been there in 30 years. What's it like?' Or someone who says to me, 'Wow, I was in Jersey City recently, or Hoboken recently, or Weehawken recently, and Wow! And what's with this new train?"
He rules from a large, wood-paneled office in the Justice Brennan Courthouse on Newark Avenue, an imposing building named for the late Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan, who presided there as a state judge early in his career. It is hardly a surprise that Mr. Janiszewski is loquacious and impassioned in his praise of his county or that he is so plainly frustrated by its negative image.
Mr. Janiszewski sees the county's reputation problem largely as the media's making. In particular, he blames The Star-Ledger, New Jersey's only statewide newspaper, for failing to publish a Hudson County edition or to even cover the county regularly. Newhouse Newspapers publishes The Star-Ledger as well as The Jersey Journal, a daily newspaper available at PATH stations and at the Port Authority bus terminal in Manhattan as well as in Hudson County.
Mr. Janiszewski said he and potential advertisers had appealed to the newspaper for coverage, but had been told that the company did not want its newswpapers competing for the same news and advertisers. "It is not in our economic interest," Mr. Janiszewski said was the response.
Jim Wilse, editor of The Star-Ledger, could not be reached for comment.
"When the pumpkin patch gets picked in Hopatcong, that's a news story," said Mr. Janiszewski. But referring to the new Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line, he added, "When someone invests a billion dollars in Hudson County, it's a news blackout."
One result of the gap in coverage, he said, was that many voters knew little about the Hudson County politicians who aspired to statewide office -- Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City and Representative Robert Menendez of Union City, the fourth-ranking Democrat in the House.
"It's unfair to them and to the public in New Jersey that there is this curtain in the sharing of public information," he said, "leaving Hudson County in the recesses of someone's ancient memory, or to the pages of an old history book."
But, oh, what a history.
Still one of Hudson's most colorful and often-remembered political figures, Frank Hague ruled with a stern, patriarchal style, and was respected by many for delivering essential services to a largely poor, historically immigrant population. But the price could be high. He was said to take a cut of his appointees' salaries and was known to have political opponents roughed up or jailed. He avoided prosecution, conventional wisdom has it, by dealing only in cash, and grew wealthy on a salary of $5,000 a year.
Mr. Hague was also influential in national Democratic politics, and his allies included President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who could count on the county boss to deliver a large voter turnout. In return, Mr. Hague could count on federal largesse to finance the projects that propped up his regime.
To be sure, the reputation that has stuck with Hudson County took decades to earn and in all likelihood will live long after the Margaret Hague has been replaced by town houses. The list of indicted and convicted public officials is almost as familiar as the names enshrined in Cooperstown.
There was John V. Kenny, a Hague lieutenant who broke with his former boss and beat a Hague-backed incumbent for mayor in 1949, quickly setting up his own machine. Unlike Mr. Hague, however, who retired a free man, Mr. Kenny did not escape prosecution and was sentenced to an 18-month prison term for federal tax evasion.
Asked years later how Mr. Hague would have viewed the prosecutors who indicted officials after the death of the former boss, Mr. Kenny was quoted as saying, "If Hague were alive, he'd be in jail."
Again in July 1971, prosecutors struck pay dirt. Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City and seven other officials, including the county police chief, the city council president and the county Democratic chairman were convicted of conspiracy and extortion for collecting millions in kickbacks from companies doing business with Hudson County or Jersey City. The take, according to testimony at the trial of what was called the Hudson 8, was 10 percent off the top.
Then in 1991, Mayor Gerald McCann was removed from office after his conviction for real estate fraud -- though his supporters were quick to point out that the charges were not related to his office.
Of course, Jersey City, home to nearly half of Hudson's 550,000 residents, is hardly the only source of its folklore.
Take Bayonne, which was represented both in Congress by Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher, who in 1973 went to prison for income tax evasion linked to a political fund-raising scheme.
And in Union City, Mayor William V. Musto, who was also a state senator, was convicted of seeking bribes. And Mr. Musto's successor as mayor, Robert C. Botti, was convicted in a bid-rigging scheme involving school supplies.
Union City is also home to what was perhaps the nation's most corrupt union office, Teamsters Local 60, where a federal trustee was installed for 13 years starting in 1986 because of the ubiquitous presence of the Genovese organized crime family.
In Weehawken, where Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr played out their bitter political rivalry their infamous duel, former Mayor Wally P. Lindsey was convicted of trying to extort $600,000 from a builder.
In West New York, the arrest of 29 people in 1988 -- most of them local police officers -- was billed by the United States Attorneys office in Newark as the largest police corruption scandal in New Jersey history.
Not surprisingly, simply existing in the shadow of this abundance of public corruption has taken its toll.
"There can be psychological consequences," said Dr. Carlos Hernandez, an environmental psychologist who is president of New Jersey City University, Mr. Janiszewski's alma mater.
"Self-identity is tied into the physical environment to some degree," said Dr. Hernandez, who went so far as to say that said some academics even project their negative perception of the county onto the university. "It takes contact with the setting to realize what's actually occurring. And if you're not covered in the press and people are not coming to see firsthand what a great place this county is, certainly you're going to be dealing with antiquated perceptions."
To begin with, Hudson is largely a paved-over peninsula, with the Hudson River and Upper New York Bay to the east, Newark Bay and the Passaic River to the west, and the Arthur Kill, which barely separates Bayonne from Staten Island, to the south. It is bordered by land -- Bergen County -- only to the north. Even Essex County, to the west, sits across the Passaic River.
Indeed, Hudson might be viewed as an asphalt jungle so jammed that political skills are a requisite just to navigate the sidewalk. With 550,000 residents crammed into just 47 square miles, it is both the state's smallest county in area and its most densely populated. Its 11,837 residents per square mile is more than 10 times the statewide figure of 1,097, according to 1999 census estimates.
And if politics and its rewards offered savvy street fighters an escape from poverty, as it did for the young Frank Hague, Hudson was as likely a breeding ground as any for political corruption. Even in 1995, the latest year for which census estimates are available, Hudson's poverty rate of 17.3 percent of the overall population was twice the statewide average.
The cloud of corruption and intrigue that still hovers over Hudson County began gathering in this country's infancy.
Joan Doherty Lovero, chief librarian of the Jersey City Public Library, who wrote "Hudson County: The Left Bank" (American History Press, 1999) said the political corruption dates to 1870, when the treasurer of Jersey City, Alexander D. Hamilton, absconded with city funds and fled to Mexico.
Yet Ms. Lovero believes there is another explanation for Hudson's less-than-favorable image born of its geographic isolation, and that is its traditional economic ties to New York -- which continue to this day with its influx of financial back-office jobs -- and even the county's demographics, which set it apart from the rest of New Jersey.
"It was easy for people in the rest of the state to look with scorn on us, as we looked on them, because there were not that many ties that bound," Ms. Lovero said. "And we were the immigrants, and up until the World War II period, the rest of the state was pretty rural."
And Charles Cummings, the Newark city historian, insisted there was no rivalry between the state's two largest cities. Yet Mr. Cummings then proceeded to reel off a list of such cultural institutions as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the Newark Museum and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, which he said set Newark apart from Jersey City.
Even Newark's current mayor, Sharpe James, took a playful jab at Hudson County, poking fun at the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail system, the recently opened trolley line that competed with a similar proposal from Essex and Union Counties.
"I look at that line that they have, with the low ridership, that could have gone from Newark to Elizabeth, and I think they're doing pretty well," Mr. James said in a recent interview.
What might it take for Hudson County -- with its gleaming financial towers and high-rise apartments proliferating along the river and its trendy neighborhoods replacing blue-collar enclaves -- to leave behind its sullied past?
For Mayor Schundler, the answer to that question is crucial, for it could very well weigh on his current bid for the Republican nomination for governor. As it is, the ambitious mayor faces a daunting primary battle against the powerful State Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, who in a matter of days will in all likelihood have the advantages of incumbency as acting governor.
Mr. Schundler, who grew up in Westfield, must overcome not only a lack of statewide exposure, but Hudson's legacy of corruption. He is, after all, running for governor from Frank Hague's very office.
"He'll never make it," said Wylie Herbert, a native of Summit, who was seated at the counter of the Tunnel Diner just two blocks west of the Holland Tunnel. "Hudson County? They'll never pull a governor out of Hudson County. You've got to remember, for years Hudson County was the most corrupt county in the state. I don't know about now, but then."
The last politician from Hudson County to ascend to the position of governor was A. Harry Moore, a Democrat from Jersey City, who was elected to the last of his three terms in 1937. But it had been even longer than that since Jersey City elected its last Republican mayor -- in 1917 -- before Mr. Schundler won a special nonpartisan election among about 20 candidates in 1992.
"I'd argue there are still some people who have a negative view based on the fact that Jersey City was a difficult place to live," Mr. Schundler said. "The 70's in Jersey City, you had fires every night in downtown Jersey City, because the only way you could get any money for your property was to burn it and collect on the insurance. So you had massive abandonment, massive drug problems, massive crime problems."
But, he added: "Image typically does trail changes in reality. But you do get changes in image happening." 
Unfortunately, it was one of Mr. Schundler's own hand-picked appointees who contributed one of the more colorful chapters in Hudson's recent past. Before the authorities charged him in 1994, the Rev. R. L. Williams, a deputy mayor who also founded the Real Love Missionary Baptist Church in Jersey City, used a credit card issued to him as president of the Jersey City Public Library to run up $46,000 in improper charges, mainly at strip clubs in Manhattan and New Jersey.
Unlikely as Mr. Williams was to find real love in such places, he spent thousands of dollars many nights trying with money raised by overdue book fees and library subsidies from taxpayers. He received a five-year probationary term, but has spent a year in jail for violation of probation.
Hudson's stigma as a backwater has even stung the arts community despite zoning changes in Jersey City allowing artists to live in their studio spaces after improving them to comply with residential standards, even if other parts of the building do not.
Michael Fauerbach, who came out of a group of expressionist painters known as the Rhino Horn, said that before he moved to Jersey City from Tribeca 20 years ago, he himself was a snob when it came to trans-Hudson artists like Leon Yost, a photographer who had moved across the river from Manhattan six years earlier.
"I guess, like a lot of people, I felt like it was somewhat bizarre, like he had moved to the suburbs," said Mr. Fauerbach, who today is 58. "He might as well have moved to Kansas, as far as we were concerned."
Yet Mr. Yost, who publishes a calendar with photographs of county landmarks, said he missed those early days, before demand sent property values soaring.
"Some of us don't want any respect," he said, noting that he paid $14,000 for a three-story brick town house in 1974, when his property taxes were $600 a year. Now, Mr. Yost said, houses like his sell for more than $300,000, and, he added, "in two years we pay for our property tax what we bought our house for."
For Barry Zubrow, chief administrative officer and a managing director for Goldman Sachs, one of the many New York-based financial giants that have taken space along the waterfront, the only perception he or his colleagues have of Hudson County is of an attractive place to do business. 
"The honest answer is, we did not have that perception or impression in terms of the way Hudson County historically was," Mr. Zubrow said. "And so it was not a part of our analysis. The most important part of our analysis was that we think Jersey City is a terrific place to work."
Whatever the new realities, the old perceptions of Hudson are likely to linger, at least while the generations that lived through Hudson's scandals remain.
Sheila Simpson grew up the daughter of one of Hudson's most feared prosecutors, James Tumulty. Ms. Simpson, 56, who now lives in Chagrin Falls, Ohio, has memories not only of criminals and political rivals trying to get at her father through her, but also of federal authorities.
"I had I.R.S. investigators at my door, trying to get information from me," Ms. Simpson said. 
The past left such a mark that Ms. Simpson said she never discussed Hudson County or her father's reputation with her son, Scott. Then one day last summer he told her of an encounter he had with two elderly women from Jersey City.
"We were all at the beach one day, and Scott came home and he was just white, and he said, 'Was my grandfather an S.O.B.?' "
Thinking about it, Ms. Simpson said, "It's hard for me to judge, but I have to think that the reputation will always be sullied in my mind."
Could be, Mr. Janiszewski conceded.
"History is immutable," he said. "You can't change it. All you can change is the future."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Maplewood's Tangled Taxes

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD 

 BODY:
Maplewood has the well-scrubbed look of an ideal suburban village: a trim downtown with a small train depot hard by a tidy village green; substantial brick and clapboard homes with broad lawns; new cars and S.U.V.'s of German and Japanese vintage in the driveways and along the tree-lined streets.
 But inside many of those freshly painted houses, people are seething like never before. 
 In a mini-tax revolt that some say could escalate into an effort to recall the entire five-member township committee, groups are forming on such streets as Euclid Avenue, Walton Road and Wyoming Avenue over new property tax assessments with increases ranging from 25 percent to 85 percent.
Making matters worse, homeowners in other parts of town, including the newly installed mayor, could see their property taxes go down.
As one homeowner put it, "I've lived here 19 years and I've never anything like this." 
At a meeting one night last week for residents of Roosevelt Road, Morrow Memorial Church began filling up with people from neighboring streets and beyond in this township of 21,000.
"We have 30 families on the street, and I thought we'd get about 10 people, maybe 15, but we got somewhere between 170 and 200 people," said Kevin Friel, a 37-year old computer analyst who helped to organize the meeting. "I was actually trying to limit the size of the meeting so it would be more structured, so I was very surprised."
In response to the wave of complaints, township officials sought and were granted a two-week extension from Essex County for submitting the revaluations by a Jan. 10 deadline. In addition, the Maplewood tax assessor will have until mid-February to make any adjustments. The earliest the revaluations will be reflected in the tax bill is the third quarter of 2001, around August.
Nonetheless, township officials stand by the revaluations.
"We feel we did the right thing," said Vic De Luca, a member of the township committee who was sworn in as mayor on Jan. 1. "We ordered reassessment to bring fairness and balance to the property tax situation." But, he added, "It's also fair to say we did not expect the level of increases we are hearing about."
If the proposed valuations do eventually go into effect, especially hard hit will be young families who have stretched their financial resources to buy a house and older residents on fixed incomes.
"I feel terrible about it," said Sam Whinery, a 79-year old former operations manager for the Hammond Map Co. whose relatively modest, four-bedroom colonial on Beach Place in the Jefferson School area went to an assessment of $489,700 from $82,200.
Mr. Whinery, who has lived in Maplewood since 1924 and in his current house since 1968, said his taxes would increase 50 percent, to $12,977 from $8,393. "As a senior with a fixed income," he said sadly, "my ability to hold on isn't there."
Meetings like the one at Morrow Church have become commonplace, particularly on the west side of town in the Jefferson School area, where some of the more expensive houses are situated and taxes could more than double.
Some homeowners say they have been assessed for such amenities as air conditioning or additions to existing structures that did not exist. Others say the people who did the revaluations had not even been inside their houses. Still others contend that no one in authority could explain the process by which the firm that did the revaluations, Certified Valuations Inc. of Randolph, arrived at specific assessments.
Tempers are running so high that Terence Lowe, an organizer of the meeting at the Morrow Church placed an advertisement last week in a local weekly newspaper, The News-Record of Maplewood and South Orange, urging residents to join in a class-action suit against the township committee.
John Rountree, a 61-year-old printing company consultant who has lived in Maplewood for 36 years, said he was "shocked" last month when he received a new assessment on his four-bedroom Victorian. According to Certified Valuations, the value of Mr. Rountree's home had soared to $498,000 from $88,000, creating an expected tax increase of $5,000, for a total of $13,000 -- or a 61 percent increase.
With that, Mr. Rountree and a neighbor, Ken Swan, went to town hall and got the assessments for 41 houses along a stretch of Maplewood Avenue from the village center.
"We found there would be a 23 percent to 89 percent increase in taxes, with an average increase of 53.25 percent and an average increase of $5,000 a person," he said. 
When he met with a representative of Certified Valuations at town hall, Mr. Rountree said the person could not explain how his property was assessed.
"I went in and asked five simple questions," he said. "I got five, 'I don't knows.' "
In a telephone interview last week, a representative from Certified Valuations said there was no one available for comment.
Under state law, municipalities are required to reassess residential and commercial properties at current market value every 10 years. But Committeewoman Ellen Davenport said the last revaluation in Maplewood took place in 1981, and consequently the property was at about 36 percent of true value.
The township first began discussing revaluating properties at a public meeting in 1998, Ms. Davenport said. From there, it contracted with Certified Valuations, which had also been hired by the State Department of the Treasury to revalue properties in Newark. Last summer, she said, the company began assessing homes in Maplewood.
Initially, letters went out assuring homeowners that the revaluation would spread the tax burden more equitably to try to allay fears of a major tax increase.
But then, said Mayor DeLuca, most of Maplewood's properties went up fourfold. Of the town's 6,843 residential properties, 57 percent will pay about the same in taxes or a little less, 19 percent will get a moderate increase and 24 percent a higher increase, he said.
The value of 841 properties, he added, has gone up four-and-a-half to five times, 653 saw their properties increase in value five to six times, and 125 properties saw increases of more than six times.
As for Mayor DeLuca, the president of a foundation that awards grants to environmental groups, who lives in the southeast part of town near Irvington and Newark, the value of his house rose to $130,000 from $53,00, and his taxes went down $1,700, from about $5,500 a year.
"As a homeowner who is going to get relief," Mr. De Luca said, "I certainly don't want to see that relief given to me at the expense of destroying the town."
Bob Klein, a real-estate agent and former township committee member here, said the valuations probably rose as steeply as they did because they were done at a time when the housing market was booming.
"When a house came on the market, we got six or eight people bidding on it, and they drove the market up on those in the vicinity of the railroad station," he said. "Some were paying well over the asking price, sometimes $100,000 over what somebody was asking."
He added: "You don't assess property at the peak of the crest."
Many residents feel the town should try to postpone implementing the new assessments until the economy shakes out and the inequities can be worked out.
"Basically," Mr. Klein said, "people want them to hold off, rethink this, educate the public and do it next year."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Linda Ellenberg, Scott Rafferty

 BODY:
Linda Karen Ellenberg and Dr. Scott Joseph Rafferty are to be married today by Rabbi Yeshaia Charles Familant, who will perform a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish and Greek Orthodox traditions, at the Westin St. 
Francis Hotel in San Francisco.
 The bride, 35, was until recently the fund-raising director at the Allen-Stevenson School, a private school for boys in New York. She graduated from Princeton and received a master's degree in education from Harvard. She is a daughter of Joyce and Marvin Ellenberg of Moraga, Calif. 
 The bridegroom, 45, is the senior director of business development at SiRF Technology, a company in San Jose, Calif., that makes semiconductors for global positioning systems. He graduated from Princeton and received a law degree from Yale. He also holds a doctorate in economics from Oxford, and is a Rhodes scholar. He is a son of Angene and Joseph Rafferty of Washington.

HEADLINE: Pooling the Assets of Thoughtful Young Investors 

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
LONG before the Internet let teenagers play the stock market, at least two companies created mutual funds specifically for the under-20 crowd. And the companies have found that they can be a demanding bunch.
 The teenage shareholders of the $1.3 billion Liberty Stein Roe Young Investors fund enjoy sharing their opinions, said the manager, David P. Brady, who estimated that he receives several hundred letters a year. He recalls one from a 13-year-old girl that began pleasantly, complimenting him on the fund's performance. Then it continued: "I don't know why you own McDonald's. I don't go there, and my friends don't go there. It's just not cool." 
Mr. Brady wrote back, explaining that he had met recently with McDonald's management at its Hamburger University in Oak Brook, Ill., and was satisfied with the company's global and domestic strategies. Then he asked the crucial question: "If you don't go to McDonald's, where do you go?" Unfortunately, he said, she didn't respond.
Mr. Brady, 36, has run the fund since it started nearly seven years ago. It returned 20.7 percent a year, on average, from its April 1994 inception through Jan. 10 of this year, compared with 18 percent for its group, large-capitalization growth stocks, according to Morningstar Inc. Besides aiming for long-term capital growth, the fund teaches its investors about basic principles of economics and personal finance.
Its shareholders use surprising criteria to recommend stocks. One wrote: "I shop at the Gap because I like the clothes, and one just opened in my neighborhood, and because they give money for AIDS education programs."
Prompting from shareholders led Mr. Brady to increase his stake in technology stocks, alongside his traditional holdings like Mattel and Walt Disney. "As the fund developed and we received lots of shareholder letters, it became apparent that they wanted us to own more than bubble-gum companies," Mr. Brady said. "They wanted growth." The fund's technology stake is now 23 percent.
SHAREHOLDER comments also led Curt Rohrman, manager of the $250 million USAA First Start Growth fund, to buy certain stocks. The fund, which is also geared to young investors, teaches saving as well as investing. In monthly newsletters, the fund includes prepaid postcards soliciting comment; Mr. Rohrman receives about 250 a month.
One card came from a teenage boy who asked whether Mr. Rohrman could buy Boeing shares. "As I got halfway through the reply, telling him that I didn't own it, I stopped to do some research on the stock," Mr. Rohrman said. "I ended up buying it, and making money." 
That is not to say that all his investor suggestions are moneymakers: the fund lost money on another, AMC Entertainment, after buying a stake in December 1999. 
Mr. Rohrman, 38, has run the fund since it started in 1987. It returned 10.4 percent a year, on average, versus 13.7 percent for its peers through Jan. 10, Morningstar said.
He said he had fielded "a ton of questions" on technology stocks, the fund's biggest sector, at 42 percent of assets. About one-third of the questions, he suspects, are written by parents. "Sometimes," he added, "when I respond to investor questions, I'll say, 'You have great handwriting for a 6-month-old.' "
A year ago, as part of his interest in investor education, Mr. Rohrman visited the kindergarten class of his 6-year-old daughter, Sarah, to explain what he did for living. Clearly, his message got through. A week later, the Rohrmans got a puppy, which they named Molly. When Mr. Rohrman came home from work, his daughter said, "Daddy, you have to invest in a paper towel company" -- Molly had had an accident that covered the floor.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Reys and Butlers, Moguls and Kiters

BYLINE:  By SID FRIGAND; Sid Frigand served as the spokesman for Mayor Abraham D. Beame, the M.T.A. and the Port Authority. He lives in Greenwich Village.

 BODY:
THE 2000 census has found 281,421,906 people in the United States, but we still await the detailed breakdowns that offer a snapshot of who we are demographically and economically. New York simply won't sit still for a portrait. So why wait?
 The telephone directory is a gold mine of information about New Yorkers' diversity, genealogy, history and lifestyles. It not only tells us who we are but who we were. The clues are in our names. 
 Consider how many craftsmen left their mark and progeny listed in the Manhattan phone book: Goldsmiths, Coppersmiths, Silversmiths, Saddlers, Wainwrights, Tanners, Tinkers, Joiners, Turners, Bookbinders, Shoemakers, Weavers, Sewers, Glovers, Hatters, Potters and Glaziers. Barrel makers apparently were also gifted baby makers: witness the 720 Coopers in Manhattan's listing.
Service providers were also fecund forbearers. There are more than 2,000 Millers, 500 Bakers and almost 400 Carters. In lesser numbers are names like Butcher, Postman, Brewer, Printer, Pressman, Scribe and Scrivener. New York's preeminence in banking and commerce is mirrored by folks named Merchant, Trader, Stockman, Broker, Banker, Shipper and a multitude of Clerks and Clarks (with a nod to the Brits). There are also Buyers, Sellers, Moguls and, wouldn't you know, Sharks and one self-proclaimed Kiter.
Our rural heritage? Consider how many Hunters, Skinners, Farmers and Shepherds are recorded. Add to that Forester, Woodman, Axman, Scout, Thrasher, Comber, Miner, Herder and thanks to the growing Hispanic population -- 35 Caballeros. True to our tradition as seafarers, we have an Admiral, a Shipwright, a Sailor, three Mariners, four Pilots and three Rowers. From the professional callings we have several Doctors (and Medicos and Medici) and almost a dozen Nurses. In addition we have Advocates, Judges, Justices, Officers and Jurists, but only one Suer.
Our military lineage is highlighted by a General and several Generali, a Colonel, a Captain, Marshals and more than 50 Majors (Major Deegan absent). True to military inequities, there are 10 Riders and 600 Walkers.
Among the most diverse set of names are those reflecting royal households. We have Kings galore (730) and scores of Sultans, Kaisers, Koenigs, Res and Reys. Queens, Sultanas, Reinas, Reines and Reginas are well represented. Lesser royalty include Princes, Dukes, Earls, Barons and a Baroness, lots of Knights, loads of Lords and a Lady. Elsewhere are the castle's grunt workers: Pages, Heralds, Butlers, Cooks, Porters and Servers. Tending the estates are Gardeners, Grooms, Stablers, Falconers and even two Thralls (servant slaves).
As a center for the arts, New York has Painters, Dancers, Bards, Rhymers as well as a Poet. Musicians? We have Leaders, Maestri, Fiddlers, Fifers, Drummers and down in the orchestra pit Cello, Piccolo, Viola, Harp, Cornet, Guitar and Piano. The theater and side shows give us Players, Directors, Jesters, Barkers, Hams and Hamlets, Lears, a Macbeth, an Actor and four dozen Angels.
The city is also a sports town, witness such names as Boxer, Trainer, Coach, Pitcher, Fielder, Runner and more than threescore Fans. If the Jets come back to the city, we already have Passers, Blockers, Tacklers, Ends and Backs. On the links, we have Drivers, Putters and one self-confessed Duffer.
Among the more puzzling heritages are those that bear ecclesiastic names. Traditionally thought to be celibate, Popes, Cardinals, Priests, Abbots, Bishops and Monks abound. There are also Priors, Friars, Sextons and a Deacon. From the Middle East we find three Imams, one misspelled Rabai and a slew of Cantors. On a more esoteric note we boast Prophets, Sages, Swamis, Shamans and a Yogi. We also have a Cherub, Cherubini and a couple of Cupids. Darkly, we must admit to a few Warlocks, two Lamias (female demons), a Crone and -- wouldn't you guess? -- a Devil.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Lowering the Volume In the Valley of the Dogs

BYLINE:  By William Santiago

 BODY:
Handling sales calls became difficult with all that woofing in the background. Begging for scraps in the cafeteria became a bit much. 
Allergies flared. So, many once dog-friendly technology companies in and around Silicon Valley now ban dogs in the workplace.
 "Out of respect for our employees and customers who visit our offices, we don't allow dogs anymore," said Liz Aune, a spokeswoman for the Vicinity Corporation, a mapping software company in Sunnyvale, Calif. "When companies grow and it's no longer just your buddies working there, it requires policies like that to benefit everybody." 
 As many start-up companies have downsized or disappeared, and as profits have actually been deemed more important than indulgent perks, many survivors of the slumping new economy have rethought the canine question. 
Other Silicon Valley companies putting pup prohibition into effect include Excite@Home in Redwood City, Rainfinity in San Jose and Apple Computer in Cupertino.
The first dog at a Sacramento company, eMonitoringSolutions.com, was a Jack Russell terrier. It was later joined by an Irish setter, a miniature pinscher and others, which led to the unruly behavior that pack animals exhibit when they reach critical mass. "Now, we only allow the original terrier as a mascot," said Russell Trumm, a company spokesman. "It was important during our core business hours that there not be a lot of barking." William Santiago
