HEADLINE: Military Bestrides Turkey's Path to the European Union 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Turkey's powerful military, whose influence and economic reach are unparalleled in other democracies, is facing its toughest fight yet -- not on the battlefield, but in a struggle against those who want to remodel the country to enter the European Union. 
 Of all the reforms Turkey is being asked to undertake to join the European club, none would transform it as deeply as asserting civilian authority over the generals. 
 The outcome of the tussle between the military and those who demand change is important to more than Turkey. It will affect the balance of power in a strategic area between Europe and Asia, Christianity and Islam. Turkey, a NATO and American ally, fields the region's strongest army and is regarded as a bulwark against instability. 
Still, a senior European Union diplomat said, "in its present military-civilian configuration, Turkey would be unacceptable to the E.U."
"The Turks, " the diplomat added, "have to find a way to get the pashas out of politics." 
That task confronts the generals with the prospect of losing their well-known dominance of civilian affairs and their much less publicized but no less influential role in the country's economy. Both are changes they are prepared to resist.
Modern Turkey was founded in 1923 by a general, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, and his successors have staged coups three times in four decades, returning to barracks only after deeming affairs sufficiently secure to entrust to civilians.
After the most recent coup, in 1980, it was the military-backed government that drew up the 1982 Constitution that still governs Turkey. The document anointed the generals guardians of Turkey's secular government and territorial integrity, a mandate that has been interpreted broadly to cover almost any issue -- from the 15-year war against Kurdish separatists to pushing out an Islamic-led government in 1997. 
This week, President Ahmet Necdet Sezer -- whom opinion polls recently placed in the unusual position of being more popular than the traditionally respected military -- threw down the latest of several challenges to the generals, calling for the Constitution to be rewritten. 
Deputy Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz has said that change in the role of the military is inevitable as the country approaches European Union membership, though he carefully added that reforms would take time.
But the generals and their many supporters in government are resisting any major realignment, arguing that the strategic importance of Turkey in a rough neighborhood demands a powerful military.
"The conflicts and relations in the Balkans, Caucasus and Middle East require us to maintain strong armed forces with a deterrence capability," Defense Minister Sabahattin Cakmakoglu said in an interview.
European countries face far less hostility from their neighbors and do not understand the need for a powerful military in Turkey, he said.
The potential for tension between politicians and the military was further illustrated this week when the army was accused of meddling in government affairs through an investigation of corruption in the state energy department. 
Mr. Yilmaz, the deputy prime minister, remarked that government under the military would be more corrupt. Stung, the general staff swiftly responded with a statement accusing Mr. Yilmaz of "the greatest slander."
Turkish military experts and Western diplomats said in interviews that Turkey's armed forces represent a stable and uncorrupted element in a society whose politicians are often weak and where scandals are routine. 
"Believe me, we are not happy to be involved in all kinds of problems of Turkey," said Atilla Kiyat, who retired 18 months ago as an admiral. "The lack of civilian authority is forcing us to be involved in those kinds of issues."
In a coincidence seen by some as symbolic, the offices for the new bureaucracy created to guide Turkey's candidacy for the European Union sit squarely in the shadow of the eight-story headquarters of the National Security Council in Ankara, Turkey's capital.
The 10-member council, including the president, four cabinet ministers and the five top military commanders, sets the agenda on almost every important issue. It is an arrangement that many say enables the generals to dominate, because they present a united front while the ministers are often divided by fractious politics. 
The European Union identified the reduction of the council's role as a top priority for Turkey's membership. Volkan Vural, the country's general secretary for European Union affairs, said that the military supports membership and that the security council is already the advisory body the Europeans demand. 
"How this can be clarified, I don't know," said Mr. Vural, a veteran diplomat who is preparing a 900-page outline on joining Europe for government leaders this month. 
Indirect pressure to curtail the military is also coming from the International Monetary Fund, which asked the government last month to trim the budget for the armed forces as part of reforms in return for $7.5 billion in emergency aid.
The annual defense budget is about $9 billion, about 3.5 percent of the country's gross domestic product and four times the amount spent on education. Analysts say billions more are spent through mechanisms that are not reported in the budget. 
Turkey is currently on a military buying spree, shopping for about $10 billion in tanks, helicopters and airborne early-warning systems -- an illustration of the military's economic resources that are almost never discussed, even as the military's political involvement comes under increasing scrutiny. 
Military-owned businesses -- including a bank, 47 percent of a leading automobile maker and 10 percent of Turkey's cement-making capacity -- are among Turkey's largest enterprises and exist free from taxes. The businesses operate outside government control and profits pay for pensions, resorts, and other benefits for members of the armed forces, helping attract and retain top personnel and cementing the soldiers' elevated social standing. 
Through a large holding company called Oyak, the military has financial interests in 24 companies involved in manufacturing, automobile production, agriculture, construction and finance. It owns a bank, a supermarket chain, extensive real estate and 47 percent of Oyak-Renault, one of the country's two dominant automobile makers. 
Many of these businesses are partnerships with the elite of the economic world, from powerful and wealthy families of Turkey like Sabanci and Koc to multinationals like Goodyear and DuPont. The effect is to align the economic interests of the military and important segments of the business establishment.
Oyak, the Turkish acronym for the Armed Forces Trust and Pension Fund, was established by Parliament in 1961, after the first military coup, to provide economic benefits for military officers. 
Competing with Oyak and its estimated 30,000 employees can be tough. Although it was set up outside the government, the company is exempt from taxes and financed by payroll contributions from military officers and land donations from the treasury.
Describing the history of Oyak in 1998, Taha Parla, a professor at Bosporus University in Istanbul, concluded, "The civil servant on horseback already turned politician was further to become merchant, industrialist, financier and rentier."
The military also controls the Foundation for Strengthening the Turkish Armed Forces, a sister corporation established in 1987 that has interests in 30 defense-related companies manufacturing everything from aircraft and artillery to missiles and telecommunications systems. It employs an estimated 20,000 people and 80 percent of its income is donated to the armed forces.
Critics like Mr. Parla and Eric Rouleau, a former French ambassador to Turkey who wrote about the Turkish military's power in Foreign Affairs last month, argue that Oyak and its sister foundation blur the line between the private and public economies and help militarize the society. 
The traditional respect for the military is underpinned by a yearlong class that every Turkish 10th grader must attend, taught by a current or retired military officer using a textbook prepared by the military. Besides inculcating the principles of Ataturk, the course covers political events from the military perspective, concentrating on threats posed by Turkey's neighbors.
"The course has helped internalize the idea that the military has a space in civilian life," said Ayse Gul Altinay, a cultural anthropologist who interviewed dozens of students and teachers on the topic. "Even students who are critical of what the officer says still believe he is the most qualified to speak about these issues."

HEADLINE: Power of U.S. Draws China And Russia To Amity Pact 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
China and Russia are working on a treaty proclaiming friendship, the strongest sign yet of their shared unhappiness with the supremacy of the United States and its plans to build a shield against ballistic missiles. 
 There is no sign that China and Russia plan to enter a genuine alliance, with mutual pledges of aid in time of war, say Chinese and Western scholars and diplomats. 
 Both countries have privately reassured American officials that they still seek close ties with the United States, which offers them far greater economic and technological advantages than they offer each other. 
But their unusual effort to craft a more formal "strategic partnership," as the Chinese describe it, reflects the intensity of their concerns about American global power and especially about the proposal for a national missile defense, which Russia and China fear will put them at a military disadvantage. 
And it is a tangible sign of the changing and complex landscape that will face the incoming Bush administration, which has vowed to increase defense spending, forge ahead with missile defenses and treat China as a competitor.
"When two major powers share an identical view that the United States is the biggest threat to global security and their own security, of course the United States has to be concerned," said David Shambaugh, a political expert at George Washington University and the Brookings Institution in Washington. 
"But what are they going to do about it?" he said, adding that the treaty under negotiation is likely to be "hollow rhetoric." 
Over the last decade ties gradually warmed between Russia and China as each has sought ways to offset the economic and military might of the United States. "The United States is pushing the two countries closer, despite their long tradition of mutual suspicion," said Shen Dingli, an arms control expert at Fudan University in Shanghai. 
Chinese-Russian border disputes have been settled, and each side gains from Russia's sale to China of jet fighters, destroyers and other high-tech military goods it needs. Last year, Chinese and Russian leaders made joint statements of protest against American plans for missile defenses, calling them destabilizing. Both countries are nervous about the expansion of NATO and vehemently opposed the war in Yugoslavia. 
Some time last year they began discussing a more general statement of amity, and since meetings in December, they have begun studying proposed treaty language, Chinese officials told Western scholars. 
The contents have not been disclosed, but beyond a general statement of shared goals, possible subjects may include arms sales, economic ties, cooperation in space and their shared border, scholars said. A document may be signed later this year when President Jiang Zemin visits Moscow. 
While treaty discussions began before the American election, the idea may have gained attraction after the Republican victory. The Chinese have said that they expect Mr. Bush, despite a sometimes hostile tone, to discover the same advantages his predecessors did in cooperating with China. Still, Mr. Bush's apparent determination to build a missile defense has caused great worry. 
One goal in China, scholars said, may be to make it harder for Russia to cut a separate deal with the United States over missile defenses, something many experts expect. 
The United States has contemplated defenses only to counter small numbers of missiles, presumably fired by the likes of North Korea or Iran. But for China, which now has perhaps 20 long-range nuclear missiles in place, even a small-scale defense would virtually negate its ability to threaten the United States. An American shield could thus force China to spend far more money than it can afford, fielding a larger nuclear force than it otherwise would in a spiraling arms race.

PERSON: Dr. Milton I. Roemer 

HEADLINE: Milton Roemer, H.M.O. Advocate, Dies at 84 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Dr. Milton I. Roemer, a physician whose research on public health systems helped to shape health policy in the United States and other countries, died on Jan. 3 at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 84 and lived in Los Angeles. 
 Dr. Roemer retired in 1986 as a professor in the U.C.L.A. School of Public Health's Department of Health Services. 
 Research that Dr. Roemer (pronounced ROE-mer) did at U.C.L.A. has been praised for encouraging people to think about the providing of health care in the United States as a single system, not as a galaxy of individual hospitals and doctors.
He also advocated the creation of a national health program that involved government, said Robert J. Blendon, professor of health policy and political analysis at the Harvard School of Public Health.
Professor Roemer's advocacy in those fields was most notable in the 1970's when there were only a few health maintenance organizations in the United States. He was a supporter of H.M.O.'s, and he has been credited with encouraging their development.
He repeatedly spoke in favor of H.M.O.'s. In testimony in 1972 before the House Subcommittee on Public Health and Environment, he advocated the development of H.M.O.'s and federal support for them. He was a co-author of a 1972 study, "Health Insurance Effects: Services, Expenditures and Attitudes Under Three Types of Plan," which advocated more widespread use of H.M.O.'s in the United States. 
He was also known for what is called the "Roemer effect" or "Roemer's law" -- his view, articulated in 1959 and 1961, that, as The Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law put it in 1998, "when hospital insurance is widespread, increased utilization of hospital services seems to result from an increase in the supply of beds."
He compared medicine and health care systems in many countries, producing a two-volume work, "National Health Systems of the World" (1991 and 1993, Oxford University Press). 
He contended that national health insurance systems made for low inflation in medical care costs. In a 1987 interview, he said, "The idea of national health insurance has always been attacked as inflationary." But he said the rate of inflation for the United States health care system at the time was one of the world's highest, at 11 percent.
He criticized another aspect of health care in the United States in a paper he presented in 1978 at a meeting of the American Public Health Association. Noting that Los Angeles County had had a substantial drop in its death rate in early 1976 when numerous doctors there had withheld services to protest higher malpractice insurance premiums, he tied the decrease to a sharp drop in elective surgery and said there was mounting evidence that a decrease in elective surgery might improve life expectancy.
He was the sole author of 20 books and a co-author of 12.
A native of Paterson, N.J., he earned a bachelor's degree in public health from the University of Michigan, a master's degree in sociology from Cornell and his medical degree from New York University.
He joined the U.C.L.A. faculty in 1962, teaching health administration. Earlier he held various health administration posts with the United States Public Health Service, the World Health Organization in Geneva and the Saskatchewan Department of Public Health. He also taught at Yale and elsewhere.
He is survived by his wife, Ruth Roemer, an adjunct professor emerita at the U.C.L.A. School of Public Health; a son, John, of Manhattan; a daughter, Beth Roemer Lewis of Berkeley, Calif.; and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Pataki Plans to Tap Into Reserve Fund for Highways 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki, contending with voter rejection in November of a $3.8 billion transportation bond act, today proposed using one of the state's reserve funds to continue construction on two new highways upstate along with several other undisclosed projects.
 Mr. Pataki announced he would draw down about $250 million from a reserve fund for paying off debts to finance the projects as part of the transportation plank in his budget, to be unveiled Tuesday. 
 The governor and his aides declined to say which projects in New York City, if any, would be financed with the money, but Mr. Pataki made specific promises to upstate communities. Part of the $250 million reserve fund would be spent on the conversion of Route 17 into an interstate highway, as well as on construction of a new highway in western New York, the governor said.
"My plan keeps our commitment to key projects upstate, particularly the conversion of Route 17 to Interstate 86 in the southern tier and the construction of Route 219 in western New York," the governor said in a statement sent only to upstate reporters.
What the governor's plan will mean for New York City and its suburbs remains murky. Joseph E. Conway, a spokesman for the governor, offered vague assurances that city transportation projects would be included among "a variety of projects throughout the state."
"Specifics will be laid out in the days to come," Mr. Conway said.
In November, voters rejected a $3.8 billion borrowing plan that would have paid for a number of important projects both upstate and downstate. 
Among the city's projects were completion of the long-dormant Second Avenue subway and extension of the N train to La Guardia Airport. The list also included connecting the Metro-North railroad to Pennsylvania Station and the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal.
The rejection of the bond act left a gaping hole in the capital plans of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the State Transportation Department. Altogether, projects in the capital plans are worth about $34 billion over five years. 
While the infusion of $250 million might keep some of these projects afloat next year, it would not address the lack of funding for the following years, transportation officials said. But aides to the governor said that spending the $250 million from the state reserves was only part of a larger plan that Mr. Pataki would lay out Tuesday to save transportation projects.
The governor's chief Democratic adversary, Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the Assembly, declined through a spokeswoman to comment on the proposal. Aides to Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader and the governor's chief ally, said the Republican majority in the Senate would wait to see the entire budget before deciding whether to support the governor's plan.
Aides on both sides said there would be fierce negotiations over which projects would move ahead.
In 1997, Mr. Pataki and the Legislature created the reserve fund for cutting debt. It grew to $750 million by December 2000, when the governor used $500 million to pay off some old state bonds. He is now proposing to spend the rest to shore up transportation projects. 
The hole in the transportation budget is not the governor's biggest headache in the spending plan he must release this week.
On Wednesday, a Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, Leland DeGrasse, struck down the state's complex system for financing local public schools, saying that they failed to give New York children a decent education and, thus, discriminated against minorities, who make up the bulk of students in the city.
The governor is still contemplating an appeal of the decision, which would buy him some time, but he has also promised to urge fundamental changes to education aid in his spending plan.
Despite the cooling economy, budget makers on both sides of the aisle say the state is awash in money, even without the debt-reduction reserve fund. Money is still pouring in on the revenue side because of large profits on Wall Street last year. The state is expected to carry $1 billion to $2 billion in surplus revenues into the next fiscal year, added to nearly $2 billion in reserve funds.
One large question looming over the governor's budget is how much of those surplus and reserve funds he will try to save to dole out in 2002, when he faces a re-election campaign.
If he spends down the reserves this year to finance transportation projects and new school aid, he will have less available for new programs in the election year. If he salts away a significant amount, however, he runs the risk of a reaction from voters expecting more money for city schools and transportation.
The governor also urged the Legislature today to make a debt-reform law passed last year an amendment to the State Constitution.
Last May, Mr. Pataki held up passage of the state budget until Assembly Democrats agreed to a law that limited the amount of debt the state could carry, capping it at 4 percent of taxpayers' income. The law also banned the practice of letting state authorities sell bonds backed by state revenues without approval the voters.
Now, as he has in the past, the governor is calling for the law to become an amendment to the Constitution. An amendment would have to be passed by a majority of two separately elected Legislatures and then be approved by voters.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY; 
New Goalie, Old Result For the Sinking Rangers

BYLINE:  By DAVE CALDWELL 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Ron Low, the Rangers' coach, wearily leaned against a wall outside his team's dressing room this afternoon and said in a gravelly whisper that the latest loss in his team's fading season was not the rookie goaltender's fault.
 According to Low, the Rangers' problems, much like crab grass, have tunneled deeper and have spread wider than a leaky goaltending corps. The Boston Bruins whipped the Rangers, 4-1, before 17,565 at the Fleet Center today, and Low said afterward that he had noticed only a few players trying. 
 "The attitude of this hockey team sometimes scares me," Low said. 
Vitaly Yeremeyev, the 25-year-old goaltender from Kazakhstan who made his first National Hockey League start today, allowed Bill Guerin to score on Boston's first shot, which was not a shot in the classic hockey sense.
Guerin wristed the puck from a sideboard along the goal line toward the goal, and it rebounded off Yeremeyev's stick and the hip of Rangers defenseman Brian Leetch before trickling through Yeremeyev's legs. All of 33 seconds had been played.
"We didn't seem to respond very well after that," said Theo Fleury, who was one of few Rangers who played with any fire today.
That response, Low said, was why he was peeved: there were still 59 1/2 minutes remaining. What he saw after the goal, the first of two by Guerin, bothered him much more than the goal itself. "If we would have played our tails off and lost the hockey game, that would have been acceptable," Low said. "This was not."
The loss extended the Rangers' streak without a victory to nine games. The Rangers (16-24-2-1) are 0-7-1-1 since Dec. 18, 1-10-2-1 since Dec. 9 and 3-13-2-1 since Nov. 28. Their road winless streak is 11 games (0-10-1), the team's longest such streak since the 1965-66 season. They have slipped 9 points behind the surging Bruins (17-17-6-4), who reclaimed the eighth playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.
The Rangers, who have scored on only one of their last 46 power-play chances, gave up a power-play goal 13 minutes 49 seconds into the first period to Guerin, who found a spot among four Rangers, took a pass from Jason Allison and beat Yeremeyev from what Low judged to be no more than 2 1/2 feet. "We were very stationary," Leetch said. "We followed them a lot."
Low said, "That's what's missing from this hockey team right now -- the physical element."
The Rangers got back into the game when Radek Dvorak beat the Boston defenseman Hal Gill, then goaltender Byron Dafoe 17 seconds into the second period. Four minutes later, the Rangers yielded a short-handed goal, the first of two goals today by Mikko Eloranta. It killed any momentum the Rangers might have had.
Leetch fell behind the Rangers' goal and had the puck plucked from him by Brian Rolston. Eloranta stormed the slot and scored. Leetch could have blamed his fall for the goal, but he refused to. "I've still got to be in the position where I can make the play," Leetch said.
Eloranta scored his second goal on a breakaway 7:38 into the third period, and Low seethed. He said Yeremeyev, who had 20 saves, never had a chance to stop any of Boston's four goals.
"I definitely don't think he played his way off the hockey team," Low said of Yeremeyev.
Low said Mike Richter, who had his surgically repaired left knee drained on Wednesday, would probably be back in goal for the Rangers' home game on Sunday night against Minnesota. 
If only Richter could chase the blues by himself.
"If you're winning consistently, you're still going to have that flat game," Mark Messier, the Rangers' captain, said, looking for an upside.
This, Low said, is not a team that can afford any more flat games. Today was the day to start something new, and Low said he found himself saying the same old things. "I was definitely expecting a lot different look from this hockey team than what I saw in this game," Low said.

HEADLINE: Battle Over Developing a Scenic Mountain Tract 

BYLINE:  By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: BREVARD, N.C. 

 BODY:
A 2,200-ACRE tract in the Appalachian Mountains in western North Carolina that was the location for the movie "The Last of the Mohicans" is now the site of another kind of battle, this one between a developer of high-priced residential communities and the state of North Carolina. 
 Reaching across rounded-top mountains and accented with three celebrated waterfalls, the land has been condemned by the State of North Carolina, which took possession in October. 
 A South Carolina developer, James B. Anthony, the chief executive of the Cliffs Communities, had bought the property a year earlier, outbidding the Conservation Fund, a nonprofit group that was acting on behalf of the state. 
In the last decade Mr. Anthony has built three residential developments, some with lots selling for as much as $1 million, in the mountains of South Carolina. One of them is the Cliffs at Glassy, a golf course community at the top of the 3,000-foot Glassy Mountain in the northwestern part of the state. 
In August 1999, he paid $6.35 million for the 2,200-acre North Carolina tract, which had long been held by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company as a hunting and fishing preserve for entertaining clients. The chemical company sold the land in 1996 to the Brevard Land Company, a subsidiary of Sterling Diagnostics, a Houston company that makes X-ray film, and Brevard, in turn, accepted bids from prospective buyers. 
The Conservation Fund bid $5.5 million. When it condemned the property, the state agreed to pay Mr. Anthony $12.5 million. 
State officials say the land should be preserved because it includes Bridal Veil, High and Triple waterfalls (all featured in "The Last of the Mohicans," starring Daniel Day-Lewis). It is bordered by the 8,000-acre DuPont State Forest, which was sold by the company to the state at a discount in a number of transactions in the 1990's.
The state took over the land from Mr. Anthony after receiving thousands of letters reflecting both sides of the dispute, which also included an Internet campaign by a number of environmental groups.
The state is forming an advisory group to decide what to do with the property, which includes a number of buildings, including an unfinished lodge. For now, the site, which is about halfway between the cities of Brevard and Hendersonville, it is open to the public for hiking. 
Joseph H. Henderson, director of the North Carolina State Property Office, said the state had condemned the land when it became obvious it would not be able to reach agreement with Mr. Anthony on a whole range of issues, including a purchase price. 
Mr. Anthony said he had spent nearly $20 million to buy the property and make improvements to roads and buildings. He has repaired and built 10 miles of roads, started renovating a lodge and constructed an equestrian center. Several small vacant homes were restored as well. He intended to sell 100 homesites around 130-acre Lake Julia and 10 in another part of the property. 
He said he had proposed putting about 1,300 acres into a trust that would be run by three private colleges nearby. In addition, the land around the waterfalls would be protected and open to the public, he said. 
Within months of his signing the contract to buy the land in May 1999, about 150 people had placed refundable deposits of $1,000 each indicating interest in purchasing lots, he said. The sales prices for one- to three-acre homesites were expected to average $350,000. "The state had the opportunity to buy the property and didn't," said Mr. Anthony, who left a 20-year career as a lineman with a phone company in 1982 to become a developer. "It is totally unfair. This is politics at its dirtiest."
Mr. Anthony said he intends to fight the condemnation, not only because he considers the offer too low, but also because he believes losing the site will harm his business. "I want the land back," he said. 
ONE of the promises made to people who buy a lot in a Cliffs community is the opportunity to use the facilities at any of them, he said. He has sold 200 lots in other communities with the promise the owners could visit the North Carolina site. 
"We've never not delivered what we promised," he said. "This has really harmed our reputation and our name. How do we get that back?" 
The North Carolina property and a new concept of allowing property owners to use affiliated resorts in various places around the world were to be his company's focus for the next few years, he said. 
The first of these sporting clubs is to be in Chile. The company has purchased 6,000 acres with six miles of beachfront there, Mr. Anthony said, adding that his company does not intend to develop the resort sites beyond building places to stay. 
Mr. Anthony said sites in Belize and British Columbia would be included sometime in the next two years. The idea is to give owners a choice of winter and summer resorts year-round. 
Mr. Anthony said that the state's assertion that the property is pristine was disingenuous. "What they got was a development," he said, citing the construction his company had done. 
In addition, the site is bordered by one of Transylvania County's largest industries, the Agfa Corporation, situated at the western side of the property, separating Mr. Anthony's former land and DuPont Forest. Agfa, which makes X-ray film, bought the plant from Sterling Diagnostics but did not want the 2,200 acres that Mr. Anthony ultimately bought. 
The DuPont company owned all of the land in the area at one time, using it to entertain clients and also allowing a youth camp to operate there. DuPont officials and guests stayed in rustic lodges and cabins and hunted deer and wild turkey and fished for trout. 
Other resort communities are situated near public lands in the area. Lake Toxaway, a mountain lake community with homes valued as high as $3 million, is close to the recently created Gorges State Park. Transylvania County's largest employer, the Ecusta paper mill, a division of the P. H. Glatfelter Company, is at the base of Pisgah National Forest. 
Increasingly, western North Carolina has become popular for vacation homes and for retirees attracted by a climate that has four seasons but is temperate. 
Transylvania County officials had hoped the Cliffs development would be allowed to proceed. Already, nearly 41 percent of the county's land -- 99,481 acres -- is not taxed because it is state or national forest. Another 3 percent is owned by such other nontaxed entities as the county or schools, according to a report compiled by the county manager's office. 
Losing the Cliffs development, which would have been a $66 million investment, meant losing $425,000 in tax revenue a year. That represents about 1 percent of the county's annual budget of $33 million, said Arthur C. Wilson Jr., the county manager. "We fully agree that we need to preserve land, but we think we've done our part," he said. 
County leaders had spoken with state officials on Mr. Anthony's behalf, arguing that the state was needlessly spending money to preserve areas -- especially around the waterfalls -- that Mr. Anthony had agreed to preserve. 
Mr. Henderson said that state leaders felt that condemnation was the only option because under Mr. Anthony's proposal, public access to the waterfalls would have been limited to a 100-foot-wide path along the river. The proposal, he said, would also have resulted "in an upscale resort in the middle of a state forest."
The situation is of special concern, Mr. Wilson said, because the county's economy has been hurt in recent years by layoffs at its two largest employers: Agfa and Ecusta, which makes paper for tobacco products and Bibles.
"My personal feeling is we should have had an equitable situation where there could have been a development and some of the land was preserved," he said. "It would have been win-win." 
But others spoke just as forcefully against the development. Thousands of letters poured into state government offices from people all over the country encouraging officials to take possession of the land before it was ruined, according to Mr. Henderson. Many of the letters came from residents and leaders of environmental organizations in Henderson County, where a small part of the land is located. 
"We wrestled with what they offered," Mr. Henderson said of the development company's position, "whether it was truly acceptable to protect the natural resource and give the public access, and ultimately we concluded it wasn't."

HEADLINE: Compromise Plan Is Urged in Energy Talks 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Clinton administration officials pressed politicians, utilities and energy providers today to agree on a compromise plan to end the electricity crisis that has left California, the nation's most populous and richest state, on the brink of darkness.
 With Gov. Gray Davis and California lawmakers participating by satellite link, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers presided over an afternoon negotiating session here that participants said aimed to keep the state's main utilities financially solvent while arranging long-term supplies of power to address critical shortages. 
Participants said teams of negotiators had worked out compromise proposals to relieve the energy crisis by earlier today, potentially allowing the governor and power companies to reach a final agreement soon. But some participants in the talks warned that negotiations could continue through the weekend. 
"I don't think any of us expect to get to the finish line tonight," Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council, told reporters gathered at the Energy Department for the talks. 
"I expect us to have continued work over the weekend and over the holiday," Mr. Sperling said.
The goal of the talks was to smash through the logjam that has paralyzed California's power industry after partial deregulation in 1996. Amid severe shortages, the PG&E Corporation and Edison International, the state's major utilities, are paying far more to buy power than they are allowed to charge consumers to use it. They face $12 billion in debt and possible bankruptcy.
The situation became critical last week when a storm reduced power production and increased demand to the extent that officials warned that it might be necessary to shut off power to parts of the state. Any intentional blackouts would have been the first in California since military officials ordered lights-out to deny Japanese bombers easy nighttime targets during World War II.
Because of the electricity shortage and the financial troubles of utilities, out-of-state companies that sell power to California are charging exorbitant prices on the spot market for immediate delivery. Utilities say they cannot afford to buy power at those prices because under the deregulation law they cannot pass the increased costs on to consumers.
The state has accused power producers of price gouging. The producers say that California's problems are home-grown and that the prices reflect widespread shortages and fears that the state's utilities could collapse without paying their debts.
Bringing the negotiations to a successful conclusion is tricky, participants said. Mr. Davis will inevitably be faced with delicate political choices. On the one hand, he must work to lift the threat of power outages. On the other, California residents and businesses will ultimately bear the burden of any solution, perhaps by paying twice as much for electricity as they do now.
Consumers groups are fighting any agreement that would result in substantially higher electricity prices. They argue that the out-of-state producers have already pocketed a windfall from the state's power crisis and that residents should not pay more to help them profit more. 
Clinton administration officials said the federal government had no direct role in the matter. But the financial health of multibillion-dollar utilities and the threat of power shortages in the nation's technology center have raised concerns that California's problems could rattle the national economy, which already shows signs of slowing.
Mr. Summers, Mr. Sperling and other senior officials involved are helping to broker a compromise and to put pressure on both the power producers and the politicians to reach a settlement, administration officials said.
Mr. Davis, along with the governors of neighboring Oregon and Washington, have argued that the federal government should impose a price cap on wholesale power to rein in the volatile spot market.
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson said he favored a price cap. But that option was rejected by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, an agency that regulates electricity sales between states.
Under one possible compromise, the state would arrange long-term contracts to buy electricity on the wholesale market at fixed prices far below today's spot price. The state would then pass that power on to utilities to distribute to consumers.
Both utilities and power generators consider that idea workable, participants said. Utilities would be assured of recouping their costs under the plan, while generators would agree to sell power in coming years at prices well above those that prevailed a year ago, though far below panic prices today.
One outstanding issue is the length of those purchase contracts. Power generators have pushed for the contracts to last up to 13 years. The state would prefer that they extend for only a few years.
Negotiators have also considered a plan that would allow the utilities themselves to enter long-term contracts, participants said. Power generators would have to agree to allow the utilities to suspend debt payments for a grace period while they repair their finances.

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 DREAMER, by Charles Johnson. (Scribner, $12.) The story of a poor man whose striking physical (if not spiritual) resemblance to Martin Luther King Jr. lands him a job as a stand-in for the civil rights leader becomes an exploration into the soul of inequality and a probing inquiry into King's life and times. "Johnson takes bold creative risks," Dennis McFarland wrote here in 1998. "He delivers a lively tale that leaves the reader with enormous concerns to contemplate." Scribner has also reissued Johnson's first novel, Faith and the Good Thing ($11), a philosophical "Pilgrim's Progress" fable about a black girl's search for the Good Thing in Hatten County, Ga. In 1974 our reviewer, Annie Gottlieb, called this "a flawed yet still fabulous book, at its best a many-splendored and ennobling weaving-together of thought, suffering, humor and magic."

GREETINGS, Carbon-Based Bipeds! Collected Essays, 1934-1998, by Arthur C. Clarke. Edited by Ian T. Macauley. (St. Martin's Griffin, $16.95.) Just in time for the new millennium, this collection serves as an intellectual autobiography of the author of "2001: A Space Odyssey," showcasing his early advocacy of space travel and many other ardently promoted causes. "Arguably, Sir Arthur (he was knighted in 1998) has done more than anyone in the 20th century to explain science to the multitude," Gerald Jonas wrote here in 1999.

IN SIBERIA, by Colin Thubron. (HarperPerennial, $14.) A seasoned chronicler of the former Soviet Union journeys alone to Russia's vast, desolate northern plains, dropping by former labor camps, abandoned laboratories and other outposts that dot one of the most inhospitable places on earth. The author "is a sensitive and observant traveler who clearly respects the Siberians for the hardships they have endured," Ken Kalfus wrote in the Book Review in 2000. The same publisher has restored to print Among the Russians (originally published in 1984 as "Where Nights Are Longest"), an account of Thubron's journey by car to western Russia a decade before the collapse of the Soviet empire. "A subtle and humane writer, Thubron is able to capture the fleeting words and gestures that define a culture," S. Frederick Starr wrote here. "This tourist-author offers a harvest of insights that would be the envy of any sociologist."

MEMORIES OF A PURE SPRING, by Duong Thu Huong. (Penguin, $13.) This darkly poetic novel tells of a Hanoi composer whose marriage to a celebrated singer unravels after he is mistaken for a boat person trying to leave Vietnam following the war with America. Duong "employs flashbacks, multiple points of view and a haunting interplay of narrative and interior voices to construct her sadly beautiful tale," Philip Gambone said here last year.

THE NEW NEW THING: A Silicon Valley Story, by Michael Lewis. (Penguin, $13.) The new-capitalist entrepreneur Jim Clark is the subject of this profile of an anti-Organization Man whose drive to shake up the old order transformed Silicon Valley -- and perhaps the American economy. The result is "a splendid, entirely satisfying book, intelligent and fun and revealing and troubling in the correct proportions, resolutely skeptical but not at all cynical, brimming with fabulous scenes as well as sharp analysis," Kurt Andersen said here in 1999.

GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING, by Tracy Chevalier. (Plume, $12.) This novel's 16-year-old narrator goes to work as a housemaid for Vermeer in the Dutch city of Delft and is invited into the artist's studio, where she learns to grind paints and sits for a portrait. "Chevalier's exploration into the soul of this complex but nave young woman is moving, and her depiction of 17th-century Delft is marvelously evocative," Ruth Coughlin wrote here in 2000.

THE BOOK OF REVELATION, by Rupert Thomson. (Vintage International, $12.) A young choreographer is abducted in Amsterdam, imprisoned and repeatedly raped and sexually abused by three masked women. After his release, his career and self-image are shattered. The novel's premise is "made terrifyingly real by a hugely talented writer," Anthony Bourdain wrote here last year.

THE MADWOMAN IN THE ATTIC: The Woman Writer and the Nineteenth-Century Literary Imagination, by Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. (Yale University, $19.95.) This feminist study of eminent 19th-century writers like Jane Austen and George Eliot caused quite a stir when it was published in 1979. The authors "present the first persuasive case for the existence of a distinctly female imagination," Le Anne Schreiber wrote in these pages. Scott Veale

HEADLINE: The Bush Years; 
C.E.O., U.S.A.

BYLINE:  By James Bennet; James Bennet is a staff writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
As George W. Bush prepares to be inaugurated as the 43rd president of the United States, those who have not studied him closely tend to divide into two camps: the inspired and the appalled. The first group sees him as Prince Hal, a natural leader seasoned by his rapscallion youth; the second sees him as smug and callow, a Richard II attaining power by accident of birth. But whether they are pulling for Hal or scoffing at Richard, they cite the same biography: that Bush was an incurious student and an unsuccessful young man who just 14 years ago was sitting on top of a collapsing oil firm; that he opted out of the ideological and military conflicts of his generation; that he drank too much for many years; that his experience in public service consists of six years in the bully pulpit of a state with a part-time Legislature -- and that he spent two of those years running for president. It is kind of amazing, these people all say, when you think about it. 
 Bush, who prefers to be underestimated, has not done much to revise that story. When I sat in on a couple of his meetings in Austin just before Christmas, he was still joking with visiting congressmen about how very unlikely a candidate he once was for the Oval Office. That narrative, about an almost accidental president, makes snobs of Bush's critics and so provides the ultimate establishment scion some counterestablishment street cred. At least in its Prince Hal version, the narrative gives Bush something of a compelling back story -- the kind that Americans want in their presidents and one that manages to make a virtue of the notion that the highest hurdle he had to overcome in life was his own fecklessness. The details of that story are true enough. Bush has less government experience than any president since Warren G. Harding, and it took a self-confounding opponent, Bush's own well-placed family members, the entire Republican establishment and five justices of the Supreme Court to heave him over the threshold to the Oval Office. Yet the arc of the story does not do him justice. It elides a basic truth: that Bush has become a methodical, disciplined candidate and officeholder. After eight years of a grand improviser, the voters (or at least those five justices) have chosen a man with a plan. 
 Unlike Bill Clinton, Bush has always had a model to follow, and despite his black-sheep image he has always followed one. Self-created men like Clinton or Ronald Reagan have had to yearn and work for decades to reach the White House, but Bush knew the presidency was a possibility the way the sons of other men know it is possible to be a doctor or a mechanic. So, unlike Al Gore, whose father was denied even the candidacy for the vice presidency, Bush could afford to wear his ambition lightly, in the manner Americans prefer it worn. Yet he traced his father's path, step by step. That he sometimes failed where his father succeeded has obscured the more telling reality: that he watched, painfully, as his father failed, and he learned.
Bush had thought for years of running for governor of Texas, and when he did, he not only had his charm, family name and connections to rely upon but also tough, loyal advisers. He developed a precise, easily communicated plan, a four-part agenda: education reform, juvenile justice, welfare reform and tort reform, all bound together with a theme of economic opportunity and development. Once he won, Bush knew exactly what he would do, so when he ran again for governor he was able to declare himself a success. "I have done in office what I promised to do," he pronounced. By then, a bigger opportunity had come along. With a five-part plan -- fixing schools, cutting taxes, bolstering defense, reforming entitlements and turning more care for the needy over to "faith based" organizations -- Bush started running for president. 
This pattern explains why disappointment awaits the editorialists and Democrats who are saying that Bush should read in the split election result a demand that he ditch some of his agenda. It explains why Bush has gone to such bewildering lengths to insist that he has a mandate for his plans. It helps explain the cabinet selections he has made. And it helps explain why no one seems to know just what George W. Bush believes.
Bushes are more loyal to people than to ideas, which is why the Reaganites, who had it the other way around, never trusted them. Unlike the Kennedys or even the Rockefellers, their dynastic politics are bottomed less on an ideology than on an assumption of superior management: if someone has to run things, it probably should be a Bush. (The notion that they see nobility in public service is somewhat undercut by their willingness to trash government workers.) Hence, Bushes tend to seek executive rather than legislative positions. A key corollary is that Bushes will appoint the right kind of people. With his degree in management from Harvard, George W. Bush is even more systematic about hiring than his father was. He says that good management -- like his selection of Dick Cheney as his running mate -- makes good politics.
As Bush has introduced his proposed cabinet, he has given the nation a rolling seminar on management, sounding at times as though he were reading from a primer for aspiring child executives. "A good executive is one that understands how to recruit people and how to delegate," he said after he presented three designees in Austin right after the New Year. "How to align authority and responsibility, how to hold people accountable for results and how to build a team of people. And that's exactly what we're going to do. This is a team of people who'll be dedicated to doing what is right for America." Who but the most unpatriotic shareholder could argue with that?
The joining of delegated authority to accountability is the theme that runs through Bush's ideas about policy, politics and governance. It almost rises to the level of the vision thing his father never had. It is a management theory, not a political ideology, and as such it receives its clearest expression in foreign policy, which is less cluttered by domestic politics. It is one reason for the gray, retro cast of Bush's appointees to national security posts. Another reason -- which is no coincidence -- is that the first President Bush was judged a success in foreign policy. The son has never shown a compulsion to reject his father's model merely for the sake of doing so. 
In domestic affairs, this trust-but-verify accountability theory has public-policy consequences that align with the Republican agenda: Social Security money should be returned to you to invest as you see fit, with a lavish or straitened retirement your own responsibility; parents, not the federal government, should be delegated the authority for spending the government's investment in their children's education. Where the theory inconveniently does not fit -- take, for example, abortion, gay marriage or recount decisions by local canvassing boards -- Bush has been willing to take the ideological leap to toe the party line. Doing so allows him to manage the party's conservatives.
While Bill Clinton ran as a New Democrat by challenging his party on crime, welfare and the budget, Bush ran as a new kind of Republican by challenging his party not on substance but on style. He ignored the conflict between his traditional Republican "accountability" agenda and its packaging as "compassionate conservatism." 
Except to believers in the toughest of tough love, real accountability is not compassionate. It is financial ruin, dismissal from school or a job, denial of welfare benefits, the headsman's ax. At its core, Bush's governing formula was the opposite of Al Gore's paternalistic promise to "fight for you," but that contrast -- and the inherent contradictions -- never emerged with clarity because Bush kept insisting that his approach was also compassionate. And also because Gore's campaign stank. 
People were left confused about what Bush believes for another reason as well: all that talk about holding his appointees accountable for results has helped him avoid spelling out what he wants those results to be, if he knows. 
Never had Prince Hal demonstrated his method more clearly than after he vanquished Prince Al and the transition plan clicked into place. Less than two weeks into his compressed transition, Bush had already caught up to where Clinton was after seven weeks, according to Paul Light, who is studying the transition from the Brookings Institution in Washington. With no immediate fuss, Bush yoked competent pragmatists in foreign policy to competent conservatives in domestic affairs. Methodically taking command of the news cycle with a leakproof series of events, Bush embarked on the same kind of "front-porch campaign" that he used to create a sense of momentum for his presidential candidacy. Lawmakers, businessmen and community leaders thronged to Austin to appreciate in person what does not translate to the small screen: the Bush charisma. Thanks also to the Bush family's version of compartmentalization -- which is to hire a Lee Atwater or a James Baker to do the dirty work -- the president-elect successfully presented himself as the humble soul of bipartisanship. The cruel partisanship of Bush's effort in Florida vanished like the desert dew.
Getting to see Dick Cheney is not easy these days, even if you do not want a job. Cheney's staff first said that I might be able to catch a flight with him, then that I could not. Then they canceled one appointment, followed by a second. 
"It's crazy -- it's not true," Cheney said when I finally got to ask him about those stories and jokes about how he was really running things. He argued that it just looked that way, because Bush had to stay at his ranch during the Florida recount while the vice president-elect began setting up the transition. "But there's no question about who's running the show," he continued. "And from the standpoint of my visibility, that'll quickly fade. When we go down and do these press conferences, you guys don't ask me any questions. You know, they want to talk to the president." True, the appearance that Cheney was running things was already dissipating by the time I sat down with him. The underlying reality was murkier.
Cheney had just moved into the official transition headquarters two blocks from the White House. His spartan office had an extremely transitional and un-vice-presidential feel -- standard-issue desk, standard-issue small, round conference table, disturbingly vivid green carpet. He had one stack of papers and notebooks more than a foot high on the desk and another half as tall. On a ledge behind his desk was a large photograph of himself and Colin Powell standing on either side of Bush, all smiling in bright sunshine. 
An hour earlier, Bush, with Cheney silently at his side, announced four more appointments. As we spoke, Gov. Tommy Thompson was in the next room going through the first throes of discussing the legal, legislative and press matters involved in becoming secretary of health and human services. From the small conference table, we could sometimes hear laughter through the wall. Outside, two more secretaries-designate cooled their heels.
The power of Dick Cheney's presence seems to come from his iceman demeanor; his voice-of-God delivery; his outsize hands, which are constantly in motion and belie his scarcely inflected bass; and his resume: White House chief of staff at 34, five-term member of the House, secretary of defense. The telephone rang.
Funny -- I thought guys like Cheney had secretaries. "Excuse me," Cheney said. "This may be an important call." He rapidly crossed the room and snatched up the receiver. "Hello? Yes, right." It was evidently an operator assuring that Cheney was on the line, which could only mean a presidential call. The door was just closing as I heard him say, "Yes, sir, how are you?" He suddenly sounded less like the guy who hurls the thunderbolts than the one who caddies for him.
Back in the office again, I asked Cheney what quality made Bush the president, given that he had arguably less government experience than anyone he had selected for his cabinet.
"Well, but think of what he's done," he began mildly, then cleared his throat and leaned forward across the table. "He's the guy who went out and put his name on the ballot, got into the arena, captured the Republican nomination, devised a strategy to beat an incumbent vice president at a time of considerable prosperity in the country. None of the rest of us did that. And that's the test." He paused, and an index finger that had been tapping the table's surface began driving into it. "And somebody who is able to envision himself as president of the United States and put together the resources and the strategy to make it happen -- that's a hell of a leader."
This is Cheney's fifth transition, coming or going, and the first for Bush at the national level. But it is not Bush's first transition. In Texas, Bush selected Clay Johnson, a friend from Andover and an earnest former businessman, to screen his appointments. He instructed Johnson to consider only competence and the demands of each position, saying that he, Bush, would worry about the politics. And having set up his system and put it in motion, Bush stepped back -- way back -- and let it work. When I visited Johnson, I asked him how many times Bush had overruled him in Texas. "I think in the 4,000 appointments, or let's say 3,500 appointments," Johnson began, then paused to consider. "I think fewer than 10." Johnson argued that that was not a sign that Bush rubber-stamped his recommendations but that Johnson learned what Bush wanted and delivered.
Bush began planning for his presidential transition way back in 1999, in his characteristic way: by assigning the work to someone else. "The governor said, 'I would like you to figure out what we need to do starting the day after the election,"' recalled Johnson, who became Bush's chief of staff in Texas. "Come up with a plan -- talk to people that have done this before, read what you can get your hands on, confer with people, pick their brains and come up with a plan."'
Bush and Johnson rarely spoke about the planning before the election. "Occasionally, he'd come in and say, 'How are you coming on your project?"' Johnson recalled. "Kind of randomly, he and I would chat about it." 
From the beginning, Bush saw in Cheney a man who could run the transition for him. Cheney told me that Bush was thinking about his role in the transition when he asked him to be his running mate. In August, Johnson flew to Wyoming and spent a day outlining for Cheney the progress he had made. 
During the interview, Cheney offered the instructions he received from Bush after the election as an example of the kind of "clear assignment" Bush delegates: "Go to Washington. Start the transition."
I said that did not sound too clear to me. "Well, but it is if you think about it," Cheney replied. "It wasn't foreign to me. I've been through the process a few times."
Bush is famous for reading only the executive summary of reports, if that. His aides say he does not show interest in details, except occasionally to test their thoroughness. The danger is that he can become simply a spin-processor, passing on the bottom line that each adviser has provided him. Therein lies the importance of Cheney; Cheney sweats the small stuff. It is no coincidence that the sloppiest episodes of Bush's transition and his campaign revolved around details concerning the chief detail man. Bush went on national television in November and declared that his running mate was just fine, when in fact Cheney had had a mild heart attack. Similarly, months earlier, Bush's campaign fumbled for explanations when Cheney's voting record was exhumed after Bush announced that the man leading his search for a running mate would be his running mate.
Cheney said that he and Bush spoke by telephone four or five times a day. Bush set no quota for recommendations for each post, and for some, like State, there was only one. Bush's aides insist that he has used the same straightforward method for finding nominees in Washington
as in Texas: starting with the qualities he wants in a particular officeholder, considering the department's needs and then taking recommendations. That is not to say that traditional politics has not played a prominent role. Bush initially rolled out moderates, minorities and women. After conservatives had helpfully begun squawking about how moderate Bush seemed, he gave them the appointment they most craved, attorney general. He waited to announce that choice, of former Senator John Ashcroft, until the Friday before the Christmas weekend, when even political junkies had other matters on their minds. Bush went on to give conservatives the other cabinet posts they were most concerned about, Health and Human Services, Labor and the Interior. 
Still, Bush's critics will have a hard time portraying any of his appointees purely as political hacks. In fact, this transition has painted a portrait of an administration in which the only official who will need on-the-job training is the president. Andy Card, Bush's chief of staff, said as much in November in a television interview, as he described efforts to prepare Bush for Jan. 20. "We have a responsibility to make sure that he understands all of the workings of the White House and how the cabinet will have to work," he said. 
Bush's aides see the imbalance in experience as a sign of their boss's equanimity. They talk about him as though he were some sort of Zen priest. They marvel at his inner calm. They describe him as providing "guidance," not giving orders. "He understands time," said Mark McKinnon, who was a media adviser to Bush during the campaign. "I think he sees time as a really valuable commodity. So he doesn't like empty space. He doesn't like time used unwisely." 
Having watched a strong chief of staff, John Sununu, restrict access to his father, Bush chose Card, a less forceful presence. Bush believes his senior staff members must have access to the boss or they will become dispirited. But he does not want to hear from them too often. In Texas, he ordered his top advisers to return one another's calls first, in hopes that they would hash out consensus among themselves and develop a team ethic. Clinton sowed division in his staff to achieve creative tension, but Bush puts a higher priority on teamwork. And of course on loyalty. One Bush adviser told me that he had been informed by Austin that he had been welcomed into the "family"; then he called a couple of days later and asked me not to print his name, lest he be ejected. 
Bush's inner triangle -- Karen Hughes; Karl Rove, his chief political strategist; and Joe Allbaugh, his campaign manager -- made sure their boss's aides did not build themselves up at the expense of the greater glory of George W. Bush. You saw no "War Room" about the Bush team. It will not be so easy to keep a Powell, Donald Rumsfeld or Christine Todd Whitman in line.
Yet who can quarrel with picking experienced, qualified people? "He's got plenty of self-confidence," Cheney said of Bush. "He's perfectly happy to go get a Colin Powell to be secretary of state or a Rumsfeld to be secretary of defense." Cheney says that his own role has not been spelled out but that he expects it to be "very significant." He added, "That's what he wants." In fact, Cheney is likely to be an even more influential vice president than Gore -- which is to say, the most influential ever.
Despite his awesome advantages in life, Bush does not seem to feel much need to prove anything about himself. In that quality, he is like Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, who is credited with making solid selections for his own administration. Neither politician knows a lot about a lot, but each gives the impression of knowing that about himself, and of not letting that knowledge make him insecure. 
I had a glimpse of Bush's self-confidence a week before I met Cheney, on a trip to Austin just before Christmas. Bush turned to me before leaving the governor's mansion for a meeting with Latino leaders and asked, in his grammatically challenged Spanish, "Puedes hablado espanol?" Caught off guard, I replied, "I can" -- though my Spanish is badly decayed. Bush felt no need to exaggerate. He screwed up his face, dragging one eyebrow down and hiking up the other. "I can't," he confessed breezily. Then he grinned and was gone through the door. 
That day, as part of his front-porch offensive, Bush had invited some Congressional leaders on education -- Republicans and Democrats -- to lunch to discuss the issue uppermost in his plan. The meeting was closed to the press, but at the last minute Karen Hughes, doubtless recognizing a chance to display her boss in top form, arranged for me to sit in. The president-elect did not seem thrilled to see a reporter in the room. "Welcome," he said stiffly, frowning. Then his eyes crinkled: "Don't steal any silverware."
What followed over the next hour and a half was a demonstration of how Bush hopes to apply his political method to governing in Washington. Cheney is likely to spend a lot of time devising legislative strategy, Bush advisers say. But Bush will not delegate everything. He will use his personal and presidential charms to function as the chief salesman for his plans. 
Three round tables covered with white linen were wedged into the room, which had blue walls and a 20-foot ceiling. Over the mantels at each end, plastic greenery studded with ribbons, lights and silver stars rose in triangles that framed dusky oil paintings of departed Texans. In all, 19 legislators were gathered there. Cheney was elsewhere. The only woman among the legislators, Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, was seated at Bush's left. At his right hand was the energetic, burly leader of House Democrats on education, George Miller of California.
As Bush rose to start the discussion, he seemed nervous, and he began almost breathlessly. But he quickly warmed to his subject. "I am convinced we can work together," he said. 
Education is Bush's strongest policy suit, and characteristically beginning with first principles, he laid out the familiar George W. Bush formula. His first belief, Bush explained, was that the federal government should trust states to do the right thing on education. His second was that it should hold the states accountable for results. 
"There's going to be great political pressure on issues such as vouchers," Bush said wearily, punching the last noun with the peculiarly hard emphasis that he and his father are prone to use for the main thought in a sentence. He stated his position: if a state chose to embrace vouchers, federal money should follow any child in that state who went from public to private school. Then, saying he would not "hog all the air time," Bush called on the others to speak.
And as salad gave way to burritos and finally to cr<heart>me brlee, the legislators got into it. They talked about the politics of education, but they also talked policy. Some gave obsequious tributes to Bush, and everyone laughed too hard at his frequent japes. But most dwelled on which government programs worked and which didn't. They talked about the dangers to children who get routed into special education, the benefits of early literacy programs, the best ways to finance charter schools. It dawned on me that Bush was playing to any politician's deepest vanity: he was taking them seriously as substantive people who wanted to do the right thing. And for the moment anyway, they were rising to the occasion.
Bush did not give the impression of listening with his entire body, the way Clinton does. Nor, like Clinton, did he repeatedly speak up himself, demonstrating his command of the subject. He did not take notes, and he slouched deep in his chair, his chin pressing down into his hand. But he kept his eyes glued to each speaker, and when he weighed in he moved easily through the issues. He called on each legislator by name, often, in his towel-snapping way, barking out just a last name. 
Though Bush catered to each legislator's concerns, he left no doubt as to who was in charge. Still, he kept saying that education reform would be a joint effort. When one senator promised to "help you get off to a roaring start," Bush demurred. "Senator, I appreciate it," he said. "With all due respect, I want to correct you. It's 'get us off to a roaring start."' 
Television is not kind to the president-elect, his own advisers admit. It shrinks him. The microphone exaggerates his hissing sibilance and odd emphases. The camera in close-up makes his restlessness at a lectern look juvenile. In person, those same tics make him seem, if not overwhelming, at least real rather than insubstantial. Bush's lack of apparent pretense is his greatest political weapon. It saves him from seeming like a complete operator; without it, Bush, who is not a humble man, would seem like Uriah Heep, or perhaps Al Gore. Watching him, I saw that a critical part of that weapon's effectiveness is that Bush does not pretend that he is not acting politically, at least in these settings. "Why do you think he's sitting next to me?" he asked, when one congressman mentioned how important Miller would be to Bush's plans. Bush's technique is to warn people that he is trying to charm them as he charms them, and to make that warning part of his charm. But he also does not pretend that charm is enough to erase their differences; to do so would be to insult the very intelligence he is trying to flatter. There would be times, Bush repeatedly said, when they disagreed. "But that's O.K.," he kept saying.
Although Bush was out to court everyone in the room, his No. 1 target was clearly Miller. Throughout the meal, he flirted with him, referring to him as Big George. When Miller rose to speak, he warned that vouchers could jeopardize the federal government's duty to support schools in poor areas. By the time Miller concluded, Bush was in sync with him. "We have to make sure that those federal dollars get driven to the kids," Miller began, when Bush stepped in to complete the thought, "where they need to be." "Where they need to be," Miller agreed.
In his subsequent comments, Bush seized on an argument Miller made about the need for testing to establish which groups of students were learning. Bush became passionate, leaning forward and tapping his fingers on the table, starting the silverware jumping. "If you do not measure, you do not know," he said. The victims of poor accountability "are not the suburban kids," he said. "They're the inner-city kids. They're likely to be African-American kids in my state. Or kids whose parents do not speak English as a first language. It is so easy to quit!" 
Outside, once the group had assembled for the press, Miller was asked if vouchers had come up. They had, he said. "But much more happened today at this lunch than a discussion of vouchers," he continued. "This was really about President-elect Bush speaking in a very candid manner and a very forceful manner about, as he said, his passion that all children have an opportunity at first-class education."
In Washington, Bush's method -- his combination of planning, delegated authority and concentrated charm -- is going to be tested as it never was in Texas. In Texas, Bush's main job was appointing people, not managing a bureaucracy with influence over everything from agriculture to Zanzibar. 
Immediately after Bill Clinton won in 1992 with 43 percent of the vote, Bob Dole, then the Senate minority leader, declared that he would represent the majority, who "voted against" the new president. "The good news is, he's getting a honeymoon," Bob Dole said. "The bad news is that Bob Dole is going to be his chaperon." And that was while Clinton was making many of the same sorts of noises about bipartisanship that Bush is making now. Bush, who lost the popular vote and won the electoral vote on what he in another context might call legalisms, has not encountered any such overt partisan hostility. But whether he will win real cooperation from the Democrats is another question. At the meeting in Austin, he stacked the deck with centrist Democrats, the ones most susceptible to his ideas as well as his charm. Ted Kennedy, a leader in the Senate on education, was not in the room.
So far, Bush has demonstrated himself to be a quick wit but a terrible substantive improviser. This comes across when he is asked follow-up questions and, instead of expanding on an idea, or even using the standard politician's trick of wrapping the same idea in different words and regifting it, returns to a preprogrammed message. "We have one president, and our nation will speak with one voice, and the voice with which we will speak is the voice of President Clinton." Next question. "The nation needs to speak with one voice. We have one president." 
Bush's limited range was also demonstrated once the election deadlocked in Florida and he was forced to go off-plan and improvise. The results were not pretty. Recall those clumsy fake-Oval Office meetings, which one senior Bush adviser described to me as "kind of a disaster."
This raises the question of what will happen when Bush encounters a crisis not anticipated by his carefully laid plans. Here, his management theory, as he repeatedly reassured voters, guarantees that he will have good advisers. He will be called upon to decide among competing views, but it is impossible to know if he will farm out such tough calls to Cheney or even his father or rely instead upon his own much-advertised judgment. His self-confidence could turn out to be an asset or a devastating liability.
When one of his proposals got in trouble in Texas, Bush revealed an ability to cut his losses and jump to the front of someone else's parade. Already, the Bush camp is sending signals that he might retreat from his position on vouchers. He has also been wise in his choice of inheritance: a prosperous and peaceful nation. For those reasons, the smart money in Washington is betting that the Bush administration will bring less change than advertised. "Incrementalism will be the watchword of the Bush administration," predicted Marshall Wittmann, a senior fellow at the conservative Hudson Institute and a former appointee in Bush the elder's administration. "This is not zip-bam-boom. This is the gray-flannel, buttoned-down, corporate administration."
Bush's system of delegating authority will be put through its paces. For all his talk of accountability, I had a hard time finding any Bush adviser who could give me a concrete example of Bush penalizing someone who had failed to make proper use of delegated powers. As governor, Bush did not have the authority to fire department heads. In six years, he demanded the resignation of only one of his appointees.
Bush's disgust with the press will probably cause him more difficulty in Washington than it did in Austin. And particularly if the economy sours, the American public may not be as indulgent toward a 50-something president who keeps banker's hours as it was to an ancient king like Reagan. 
Though he may not think so, Bush does have a lot to prove. But Clinton grew in the job. He adapted it to himself and himself to it, and Bush, though less malleable, will probably do so as well. There are signs that he recognizes the possibilities of his office. After the meeting with Latino leaders, held at an Austin high school, I asked Bush what he had gotten out of it, expecting a Clintonian answer about the richness of policy proposals he encountered in such sessions. Instead, as he walked to his limousine, Bush talked politics. "It helps me set a tone," he said. 
I asked again: Wasn't there any specific policy idea that could come out of such a meeting? "There wasn't much to this, you heard today -- there wasn't a lot of specificity," he replied. Then he paused by his open limousine door and said he had had one interesting thought. It had occurred to him, he said, while he listened to an ophthalmologist in the group. "Maybe one of the things we need to do is to figure out how to get free eyeglasses to the poor," Bush told me. He made a eureka motion, touching an open hand to his forehead and snatching it upward and away. "That's just what popped in my head," the president-elect explained, "when I heard what he said."
Free eyeglasses for the poor? It sounded more compassionate than conservative. Maybe it was just an effort to charm someone he suspected of being an Eastern liberal. Still, it suggested that more than a new administration might be in transition. It may be that Bush will show that he can play outside his limits, both the limits he has placed on his agenda and his personal limits of experience and curiosity. Maybe he will show some imagination and take some risks. That, as Bush himself might say, is what a leader does.
