HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Cablevision, prosperous from shrinking, will welcome bids this week for Rainbow, its big programming asset.

BYLINE:  By Geraldine Fabrikant 

 BODY:
MOST independent cable companies have been expanding in the last two years, all the while throwing around terms like economies of scale, vertical integration and that catchall, synergy. 
 But Charles F. Dolan, the iconoclastic founder of the Cablevision Systems Corporation, has bucked the bigger-is-better trend by deliberately shrinking his company. 
 Shareholders seem to endorse his strategy. Since January 1998, Cablevision's stock price has risen 249 percent, outpacing other cable independents like Cox Communications and Comcast. The shares closed on Friday at $90, up $1.31. 
Tomorrow Mr. Dolan, chairman of Cablevision, the nation's seventh-largest cable company with three million subscribers, will begin receiving bids for the company's 74 percent stake in Rainbow Media, the cable programming operation whose brand-name services include Bravo, American Movie Classics and the Independent Film Channel. NBC, a General Electric unit, owns the rest of the company. 
Viacom, NBC, Sony, Comcast and the USA Networks are the likely bidders. And even though USA's chairman, Barry Diller, said he would not take part in an auction, some industry executives expect him to be involved in some way in the negotiations, with the price possibly exceeding $3.5 billion.
Mr. Dolan declined to be interviewed. But his timing may have something to do with the rich price that Viacom paid last year for BET Holdings, the parent of Black Entertainment Television. That $3.4 billion sale made a number of other cable programmers eager to capitalize on the value of their own programming assets. 
Yet while Rainbow could become Cablevision's biggest, flashiest asset sale, it would not be the first one. Without fanfare over the last three years, Mr. Dolan has sold cable systems in cities including Boston, Cleveland and Kalamazoo, Mich., raising a total of roughly $3 billion. Compared with a peak of 3.4 million subscribers in 19 states, Cablevision now has 3 million subscribers in only three states. 
Mr. Dolan's downsizing deals have fetched top dollar -- as much as $5,000 a subscriber for the systems he has sold. But for Cablevision, the bigger value is in the subscribers it has retained: relatively affluent households in tightly clustered markets in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut that have been willing to sign up for expanded packages of service in response to the company's active marketing. 
Revenue for the first nine months of 2000 was up 11 percent, to $1.47 billion, compared with the first nine months of 1999. Although the company lost $3.1 billion in that period, operating cash flow, the more relevant indicator for a cable company, rose 9 percent, to $624 million. 
Mr. Dolan "is betting that bigger is not necessarily better," said Tom Eagan, an analyst who follows cable for UBS Warburg and who supports the Cablevision strategy. "That is especially true if a cable operator becomes more vulnerable to satellite or has to overpay for subscribers."
Several analysts say the rising share price is also based on investors' hopes that Mr. Dolan, who is 73 and whose family controls Cablevision, will sell the company within a few years. By this theory, the Rainbow auction is the first step toward preparing Cablevision for sale. 
Wall Street's current support is in striking contrast to 1997, when Mr. Dolan raised investor hackles by making an enormous bet on the metropolitan New York market, buying the half of Madison Square Garden the company did not already own. The deal made Cablevision the full owner of the New York Knicks and the New York Rangers, as well as the MSG cable network. 
The purchase, coming when the company was already saddled with debt, exasperated some powerful investors who were weary of what they saw as Mr. Dolan's overly aggressive risk taking. But the bet has paid off. TV sports fans have helped give Cablevision the industry's highest monthly revenue per subscriber -- $53, compared with an industry average around $43, according to Karim Zia of Credit Suisse First Boston.
Despite all the good news, Jessica Reif Cohen of Merrill Lynch noted that Cablevision's stock still trades at a discount to estimated cash flow for 2001, when compared with the stocks of several other cable companies, including Charter Communications and Comcast. That discount may be a result of investors' qualms about another big, iconoclastic bet that Mr. Dolan is about to make. 
Cablevision intends to spend roughly $1 billion over the next three years to give each of its customers -- free of charge -- highly sophisticated digital, set-top boxes that will offer various interactive services, including video on demand, e-mail and enhanced TV. Capitalizing on the tight cluster of Cablevision systems, the company is also hoping to use the boxes to provide ticketing for sports events for its New York teams, as well as school information and other local services. 
The boxes will cost Cablevision $350 each. The plan to give them away is radically different from those of other cable operators, who charge about $10 a month if a customer wants a digital box, in addition to any fees for the services. But Cablevision is betting that a sufficient number of its subscribers will be willing to buy enough of the additional services that the boxes will pay for themselves.
"Our theory is that by rapidly deploying the technology, the company can amortize marketing costs over a broader base," said James L. Dolan, 45, who is Mr. Dolan's son and the president of Cablevision. That strategy, based heavily on local attractions and programming, partly explains why the company is willing to sell a national service like Rainbow. 
To be sure, the asset sales will help pay down a portion of the company's $8 billion in debt and preferred stock, reducing the financial impact of the big digital investment. And corporate bond specialists say that Cablevision's debt levels are not dangerously high and that its coming capital expenditures do not appear as risky as Mr. Dolan's earlier bets.
Bob Berzins, who follows the bond market for Lehman Brothers, said Cablevision could "borrow additional money without any problem."
Mr. Berzins said cable companies were not like telecommunications companies, which have been burning through cash with no certainty that their technology investments will pay off. With Cablevision's digital strategy, he said, "you can see a three-to-five-year path to getting free cash flow."

HEADLINE: Moscow 'Spy' Case Is Still a Mystery 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Aside from his wife, Edmond D. Pope probably had no greater advocate proclaiming his innocence on charges of spying in Russia than Representative John E. Peterson.
 In a telephone conversation, Mr. Pope described the congressman as "one of the two heroes" in winning his release in December after he was convicted of espionage. The other was his wife, Cheri. 
 Yet ask the congressman today whether Mr. Pope was spying, and the answer might be surprising. "I am going to be candid with you: I didn't know," said Mr. Peterson, a Republican former supermarket owner who represents the rolling woodlands here in central Pennsylvania where the Popes live. 
"I checked with a lot of people, with the military and with the C.I.A., and everybody said he is not a spy," he said. "Personally, I don't think he is, but I don't care. If you were spying for the United States government, would you want us to desert you?"
Mr. Pope, 54, was pardoned by President Vladimir V. Putin and is back at home on the outskirts of this college town, where until 1997 he worked for a research lab at Pennsylvania State University that specializes in defense contracts. 
A former Navy intelligence officer, Mr. Pope is only the second American in 40 years to be convicted of espionage in Russia. The first, Francis Gary Powers, the pilot of a U-2 spy plane that was shot down in 1960, was exchanged for a convicted Soviet spy.
Throughout Mr. Pope's ordeal, which began with his arrest in a hotel in Moscow last April, supposedly for trying to buy classified military information, American officials declared that he was an innocent businessman not interested in state secrets. They also insisted that his life was in danger because he suffered from a rare form of cancer that had probably worsened in prison.
A month after Mr. Pope's return home, considerable uncertainty surrounds both assertions. He is not dying. And although he may not have been a spy in the classic James Bond sense, he was a wheeler-dealer who was friendly with intelligence officials and who associates say would readily sell Russian military technology to the Defense Department if he could. 
Among his biggest clients was a former employer, the Office of Naval Research, which coordinates technology needs for the Navy and the Marine Corps. "It is where business and espionage meet," an intelligence official in Washington said of Mr. Pope's Russian endeavors.
Mr. Pope acknowledged during two telephone conversations that his cancer, in remission for some time, had not recurred during his eight months in Lefortovo Prison, just as his Russian physicians had said. 
He also indicated that he had not been mistreated in prison. "The media attention and public awareness is what saved me, not the State Department," Mr. Pope said, declining to give a broader interview.
Mr. Peterson acknowledged that no one knew during Mr. Pope's detention whether his cancer had returned, but that raising the likelihood was part of a strategy to win his freedom. "Having been a retailer, I know that good advertising is something boring, because you keep saying it until it becomes habit," Mr. Peterson said.
No American officials have suggested that Mr. Pope was employed by an intelligence agency as the Russians charged, but it is clear that the circumstances of his business dealings were not as free of suspicion as his supporters sought to portray them.
Since the demise of the Soviet Union in 1991, there has been a push in the United States to obtain Soviet-era technology and to ensure that important Soviet military know-how does not end up in the wrong hands.
Military, intelligence and business people who deal regularly with Russia said Mr. Pope's interest in cutting-edge Russian military technology placed him in a murky world where business people and academics sometimes do the bidding of the American military for profit.
If the Russians were nervous about sensitive military research getting into Western hands, as many Russian analysts contend, cracking down on someone like Mr. Pope, who had visited Russia more than two dozen times and had a broad network of contacts, would send a chilling signal.
"You have to recognize that the boundary is increasingly blurred between technology which has primarily peaceful purposes and technology which is dual use, military as well as civilian," said Sam Wilson, a retired general and former director of the Defense Intelligence Agency.
Mr. Pope's goal was to make money for himself and his contacts in Russia, associates said. And while he endeavored to work through approved channels, the nature of his dealings entailed walking a shifting line of authority.
His own lawyer in Moscow indicated that Mr. Pope could well have purchased classified information without even knowing it. Representative Peterson said he had received bizarre offers to assist Mr. Pope, including some from international armaments dealers. 
It was not uncommon, one of Mr. Pope's partners said, for Mr. Pope to be inundated with 100 unsolicited proposals from scientists on his arrival in Moscow.
"The typical negotiation over there went like this," said Keith McClellan, a lawyer and business partner. " 'We want a million dollars.' 'We will give you $30,000.' 'Sold.' "
Shortly before his arrest, Mr. Pope complained about being the object of pressure from the Russian mafia. And he was accustomed to being trailed by Russia's Federal Security Service.
Last year, one of Mr. Pope's companies, TechSource Marine Group, had a $178,000 contract with the Navy to study the propulsion system used in the Squall, a Russian torpedo. A spokesman said that the Navy was interested in the benefits for the military, but that Mr. Pope would be free to market his findings. Business associates said Mr. Pope was hoping to adapt the technology for passenger ferries.
Russian technology transfers had not yet amounted to a big money maker for Mr. Pope. Associates described his three firms as "virtual companies," with no permanent staff or offices and only a bare-bones budget for travel.
To keep afloat, Mr. Pope wore several hats during his Russian trips, negotiating deals for everything from titanium golf clubs to corrosion-resistant coatings. He even had a licensing agreement with Penn State to import Russian dolls with the college's insignia.
By the time he was arrested, Mr. Pope was pursuing information about an advanced fuel used in the Squall torpedo, which the Federal Security Service said crossed into the realm of state secrets. The information, associates said, related to a metal fuel that scientists believe could propel a variety of vessels -- not just torpedoes -- in oxygenless environments underwater or in space.
His client was the Applied Research Laboratory at Penn State, founded by the Navy after World War II and Mr. Pope's employer from 1994 to 1997. Last year the lab received nearly $70 million in contracts through the Office of Naval Research.
Throughout the eight-month campaign to free Mr. Pope, Representative Peterson said he had never spoken about Mr. Pope with officials at the lab, known as ARL. Mr. Peterson said he had not wanted to find out that Mr. Pope had been spying and thereby compromise his relationship with the lab or his efforts to free Mr. Pope.
"I represent ARL in the budget process in Congress and lobby every year for their contracts," he said. "They didn't contact me and I didn't contact them."
Was the research sought by Penn State classified? "I don't know that answer," he said.
The lab's director, L. Raymond Hettche, said Mr. Pope's mission had been to establish academic contacts for nonmilitary purposes, but he acknowledged that the lab was always on the lookout for technology with military uses. "The big thing now is spinning technology into the Department of Defense," he said.
Despite their long relationship, Dr. Hettche said, lab officials had no idea what else Mr. Pope was pursuing in Moscow. He said the university had not given Mr. Pope the money that the Russians said he had offered, on Penn State's behalf, to a scientist at the Bauman State Technical University in Moscow for classified research related to the Squall.
Dr. Hettche has on file four receipts signed by Mr. Pope, totaling $28,000, for technical reports purchased from Bauman, with titles like "Thermodynamic Analysis," but they are dated 1997.
One of the research lab's top scientists, Daniel Kiely, was with Mr. Pope when he was arrested. Dr. Kiely was questioned for several hours, and documents in his briefcase were confiscated. He was released only after he signed a statement in Russian, a language he does not speak. It was used against Mr. Pope in his trial.
"I knew a little of Ed's background and that stuff, and that the Russians probably think he is some kind of a suspicious character," Dr. Kiely said. "But I had no reason not to believe that everything we were doing was approved."
Mr. Pope is not talking about his ordeal. He has hired an agent and signed a book deal. He said on the telephone that the arrangement precluded him from speaking publicly about his experiences.
His friends say that the last year has exacted a heavy financial toll, and that Mr. Pope has one last shot at striking it big with his Russian connection.
"Right now, we all want to make sure his economic opportunities are optimized in getting this book published," Mr. McClellan said.

HEADLINE: Risks of Aid for Africa 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "How to Keep Peace in Africa Without Sending Troops," by Michael O'Hanlon (Op-Ed, Jan. 8): 
 President Clinton's Africa Crisis Response Initiative, which shifts resources to a few African militaries in the hope that they will take care of the region's humanitarian and peacekeeping responsibilities, has several risks despite its advantages. 
Because the resources will go to some militaries and not others, American aid could create or exacerbate regional military imbalances and insecurity. Since there are few international military threats, much of the hardware the United States provides could be used for domestic repression. American aid and the mission of regional peacekeeping could be used to justify the militarization of economies that can ill afford the expensive military forces. 
These risks can be lowered, and the problem of regional peacekeeping addressed, if the next administration chooses to do so.

NETA C. CRAWFORD
Medford, Mass., Jan. 8, 2001

The writer is an assistant professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

HEADLINE: A Battle for Control Of the Runways 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Mayor Presses Port Authority for Control of Airports" (news article, Jan. 10): 
 In the 1940's, Fiorello La Guardia and Robert Moses formed an unlikely alliance with the aim of developing modern airports for New York City. 
The authority they set up foundered because the city's capital capacity proved insufficient. The task fell to the bi-state Port of New York Authority, which summoned the resources needed to develop the largest regional airport system on earth.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's fulminations regarding a city takeover of Kennedy and La Guardia Airports break down for the same reasons La Guardia and Moses failed. With New York's huge backlog of critical infrastructure needs, the city will be hard pressed to come up with adequate capital for the airports' continuing renewal programs. 

ROGER J. COHEN
New York, Jan. 11, 2001

The writer was assistant director of the Port Authority's office of economic and policy analysis, 1992-96.

HEADLINE: JAZZ REVIEW; 
All-Stars Of Italy In Standards Of America

BYLINE:  By BEN RATLIFF

 BODY:
Italy has no shortage of serious and accomplished jazz players. In the United States, the ones we've heard of tend to be the avant-gardists; that probably says more about the natural aesthetic affinities of Italians than it does about how well they know mainstream American postwar jazz.
 But Italians can play straight-ahead jazz as well as anybody. That was amply demonstrated in the long first half of Friday night's concert at Town Hall, "Italian All-Stars," a non-avant-garde triple bill with guest stars organized by the directors of Umbria Jazz, the 23-year-old Italian jazz festival with a reputation as one of the best in the world. But playing it with distinction -- well, that didn't really happen. 
 The first half was given over to the Trio, made up of the bassist Giovanni Tommaso, the drummer Roberto Gatto and the pianist Stefano Bollani, augmented by a couple of young horn players as guests, the alto saxophonist Rosario Giuliani and the tenor saxophonist Daniele Scannapieco. Together they played American standards, Italian songs and originals by Mr. Tommaso, and their set brought to mind an average night at Small's: studious and classical, good as far as it was meant to go, but well shy of aesthetic clarity. The most individual voice was Mr. Bollani, who occasionally loosened his time and played in a floating rubato, then tightened up again to play fast. But there wasn't any original harmony to grab hold of or any captivating ideas of space in the rhythm section. Most of the playing was as efficacious and numbing as data entry.
That changed a lot with the next group, Doctor 3, one of those rare jazz groups that figure out a way to hit crowds where they live, semaphoring their crescendos in advance and then lobbing them out slowly and heavily. Their short, fizzy set wasn't profound, but they had the benefit of a rhythm section that made you listen. The drummer Fabrizio Sferra's patterns weren't nailed-down archaisms; they hung open, as if half the number of percussive hits were edited out. But material was a problem -- their medley included Elton John's "Your Song," which stays maudlin even with ingenious alterations to it.
In the concert's final segment, the trumpeter Enrico Rava made the Trio a quartet. He played a new work, the three-part suite "Federico e Giulietta," dedicated to Federico Fellini. For all of Mr. Rava's reputation and ability -- he was a serious avant-gardist until the 1970's, when he became a lyrical, economic player -- the piece quickly grew dull. Its themes were basic, built on nublike, singsong ideas, but they weren't enough. What gave the set any sort of teeth was the friction in harmonized lines and accompaniment between the young trombonist Gianlucca Petrella and Mr. Rava. Mr. Petrella, one of the evening's needed refreshers, had a sense of himself, playing desultory chatter and then switching to the clipped, rhythmic, annunciatory phrasing that showed he'd absorbed his Louis Armstrong.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rosario Giuliani played the tenor saxophone at Town Hall. (Jack Vartoogian for The New York Times) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Powell's Perspective

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Secretary of State-designate Colin Powell has his Senate confirmation hearing this week. I doubt Mr. Powell will say much about specific policies. What I'd listen for is whether he offers a big-picture view of the world, as we really don't know what his views are since he left Army service in 1993. 
 One way to think about Mr. Powell is this: He spent 35 years of his life with America Onduty, as a military officer. But for the past two years he's been associated with America Online, as a member of the AOL corporate board. So which perspective will Mr. Powell bring to his job as secretary of state -- the perspective he gleaned with America Onduty during the cold war or the perspective he gleaned with America Online in the post-cold-war? 
These are two different perspectives: America Onduty tends to see the world as being built around walls and America Online tends to see the world as being built around webs.
That is, America Onduty believes that U.S. foreign policy has been, and continues to be, about defending, erecting and bringing down walls. That means building walls of containment around enemies or rivals, from North Korea to Iraq to China. It means being largely indifferent to what goes on behind the walls of countries as long as they are not bothering us -- e.g., not really caring how Russia's internal reform plays out -- and it means working to bring down the last few walls of Communism around North Korea and Cuba.
America Online, by contrast, sees America at the center of an increasingly integrated global web -- a web of trade, telecommunications, finance and environment. For America Online U.S. foreign policy is about protecting that web from those who would disrupt it, strengthening that web and expanding it to others -- because, after all, America is now the biggest beneficiary of that web, since American products, technologies, values, ideas, movies and foods are the most widely distributed though it.
One way you preserve that web is by being prepared to defend it from those who would disrupt it, such as Saddam Hussein. Another way is by being ready to promote the expansion of free trade, to join with others in protecting the global environment, or to help with bailouts when key strands of the web -- such as Mexico or Thailand -- are threatened with financial crises that could infect the whole network. Still another way is by putting a higher priority on working with Russia to solve web problems that endanger us both -- such as nuclear or missile proliferation -- rather than expanding NATO's wall to Russia's border, thus making cooperation with Moscow impossible. 
The wall people, the America Onduty people, love the movie "A Few Good Men," particularly the closing scene where Jack Nicholson, the tough army colonel, sneers at Tom Cruise, the army lawyer who has Mr. Nicholson on trial for the death of a weak U.S. soldier on a U.S. base in Cuba during the cold war. Mr. Nicholson says: "Son, we live in a world that has walls, and those walls have to be guarded by men with guns. Who's gonna do it? You? . . . Deep down, in places you don't talk about at parties, you want me on that wall. You need me on that wall."
The web people, the America Online people, love the movie "You've Got Mail," because they know that in today's more integrated world we can, and do, get mail from all kinds of strangers that can suddenly change our lives. When Russia has a financial crisis now, we've got mail. When a networked world enables small terrorist groups to become super-empowered so they can blow up a U.S. destroyer in Yemen with a dinghy, we've got mail. When two Filipino computer hackers put their "Love Bug" virus on the World Wide Web and melt down 10 million computers and $10 billion in data in 24 hours, we've got mail.
For the America Onduty people, the world is divided between friends and enemies. For the America Online people, it is divided between members and non-members of the network. The America Onduty people focus on who's on America's terrorism list. The America Online people focus on who's on America's buddy list. 
Yes, these are caricatures. But there's something to them. They reflect two different ways of looking at the world. So which lens is Mr. Powell wearing -- the one he developed with America Onduty or with America Online?

HEADLINE: California's Energy Crunch 

 BODY:
As politicians in Sacramento struggled to find a stopgap solution to California's energy crisis, other parts of the United States began to wake up to the possibility that what was happening on the West Coast could happen to them. To the extent that California's crisis results from a uniquely disastrous set of miscalculations, it is unlikely to be repeated elsewhere. But it is a cautionary tale nonetheless, especially in big energy-consuming states like New York.
 There are two main problems in California. One is that demand from ordinary consumers and energy-hungry commercial sectors like Silicon Valley has stretched California's energy resources to the breaking point. The second is that California's two biggest distributors of energy, Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, are nearing bankruptcy because the wholesale prices they pay for electricity vastly exceed the retail prices they can charge their consumers. 
A desperate Gov. Gray Davis has now asked his legislature to approve a state-run scheme that seems the reverse of the free market promised by deregulation. The state, acting as middleman, will buy electricity at prices far lower than the producers of energy are charging now. Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison would then be allowed to sell that power to the public at slightly higher prices. 
That should help the utilities avoid bankruptcy. But it will not touch the underlying problem of supply and demand. As the Times columnist Paul Krugman recently observed, California's power crisis is "first and foremost a crisis of underinvestment." Some opportunistic politicians have blamed the state's strict clean-air rules, which they say deterred construction of new power plants and shut older ones down. But the real reason for the energy shortfall is that no new plants were built in the 1990's because prices were low, supplies were plentiful and producers wanted to wait until they better understood the new era of deregulation.
Since April 1999 almost 6,300 megawatts of new plants (equivalent to about 13 percent of California generation today) have received approval from state authorities, despite those allegedly onerous environmental rules, and at least 7,000 megawatts are poised to follow. But while this flurry of investment activity will ease shortages down the line, it has come too late to avert the present mess.
The second crisis -- the squeeze on the big distributors -- also stems from poor decision-making. California's deregulation law freed the wholesale market from government price constraints. But the prices that local utilities could charge consumers remained under state control. So when a surging economy and a spike in natural gas costs sent wholesale prices through the roof, companies like Pacific Gas and Electric could not pass these costs on to their customers. This, in turn, meant that consumers had no incentive to economize.
New York has not made the same mistake. Con Ed, for example, which mostly abandoned the generating business so it could become a retail distributor, is permitted to pass along increases in costs to consumers. Except for a painful "spike" last summer, these increases have so far been modest. But New York still has a potential supply-and-demand problem. At the moment there are more than 50 applications to build new power plants here. The state must move these projects along expeditiously while insuring that they are constructed and situated in an environmentally responsible manner. 
Meanwhile, Albany must find ways to increase energy efficiency. Programs to encourage energy-efficient buildings, appliances and generating equipment, which thrived in the Cuomo era, have lapsed under Gov. George Pataki, who has otherwise been attentive to environmental matters. On this score, California has done a far better job than New York. About 10 percent of its energy comes from "renewable" sources like wind power, and its legislature has created a $5 billion fund for energy-efficient investments. Albany can learn as much from California's innovative strategies as it should learn from California's appalling mistakes.

HEADLINE: Before Leaving Health Agency, Shalala Offers a Little Advice on a Big Job 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
After eight years as secretary of health and human services, Donna E. Shalala has a little advice for the Republicans who will soon replace her and thereby inherit vast responsibilities for the nation's health and welfare.
 Medicare reform, as promised by the Bush administration, "is not so easy," Dr. Shalala said with a rueful laugh. 
 Transforming Medicare into a largely private health care marketplace of competing health plans sounds great in the abstract, she said, but the devil is in the details: how it will affect the lives and finances of the elderly, their doctors and hospitals. And what once seemed like sure-fire solutions no longer look so promising. 
"Do I think there are some different approaches that are worth taking a good hard look at? Yes," Dr. Shalala said. "But I also want to know what the impact is, in very different areas. 
"And I'm not as sure as everybody else is about managed care any longer. And I started out as their biggest fan."
In just a few days, Dr. Shalala will leave the office she has held longer than anyone else, overseeing a 61,000-employee agency that administers Medicare, Medicaid, the basic welfare programs and an array of health research institutions. She will turn it over to Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, someone she worked with in her days as chancellor of the University of Wisconsin.
"It's sort of nice to turn it over to someone you know," Dr. Shalala said, adding that she would leave him the painting of the Wisconsin Capitol that hangs over her desk.
Mr. Thompson has a reputation as an innovator in overhauling welfare, and as a champion of giving states more flexibility and discretion in the management of social welfare programs. But what is important, Dr. Shalala suggested, is not that Mr. Thompson comes in with the mind-set of a governor, but that he comes in with the mind-set of a Wisconsin governor.
"He comes from a state that's very progressive, that has had quality delivery systems and that's very creative," Dr. Shalala said. "What I would say to him is be careful that you don't make laws for the Wisconsins of the world."
While President-elect George W. Bush spent much of the fall campaign attacking the Democrats for a love of big government and promising to turn more responsibilities over to the states, Dr. Shalala said that she made no apologies on that front.
"To me, it's a fundamental debate about federalism," she said. "It depends on what you believe you should have a national government for. I believe that justice and opportunity ought not to be determined by geography -- or by country of origin or by your parents' income."
The federal role, she argued, "is to reduce variation."
To conservatives, of course, that sounds like redistribution of resources.
"That's exactly what we're talking about," Dr. Shalala said, with nary a flinch. "Redistribution defines us as a country. That's what the national government does. But it ought to be in a limited way, just for the fundamentals. And in debating what those fundamentals are, we define what the country is about, what our character is about, what we care about."
One definition, she noted, was provided by former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, and is now emblazoned in the lobby of the health and human services headquarters building that bears his name: "The moral test of a government is how that government treats those who are in the dawn of life -- the children; the twilight of life -- the elderly; and the shadows of life -- the sick, the needy and the handicapped."
Dr. Shalala, who is 58, was long considered one of the last liberals in an administration often dominated by the so-called New Democrats. She urged President Clinton to veto the welfare overhaul legislation passed by a Republican-led Congress in 1996, but he did not. 
When asked her greatest regret on leaving office, Dr. Shalala replied, "That we didn't put health care for low-income working families, and child care for them, in place before we did welfare reform. If we had done those things universally for all low-income workers, child care and health care, it would have been so much easier to do welfare reform. It would have reduced the unevenness in welfare reform."
With the country seemingly headed into an economic slowdown, the first under the new welfare law, with its strict time limits for assistance, does she worry?
"Oh, I think everybody's worried," she said. "Even those who wanted the bill signed. We need to make sure we have something in place, preferably not the old welfare safety net, but something new and more imaginative that bounces people into training, for example, as opposed to back into a welfare system."
Dr. Shalala, known for maintaining her ebullience throughout eight years of partisan turmoil in the Clinton era, said she was leaving with a clear sense of accomplishment.
"I like to say American children are healthier and wealthier as a result of the president's actions," she said, citing an array of initiatives including immunization efforts and the Children's Health Insurance Program.
Dr. Shalala also noted that during the Clinton years, "we invested in the scientific infrastructure in this country in ways that will pay off for years to come." The National Institutes of Health, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the other "great scientific agencies of this country" are, she maintained, "in the best shape they've been in in years."
She added, with a smile, "I'm proudest of the things that my successors will take credit for."
The most ambitious undertaking of the Clinton administration in domestic policy was the failed effort in Mr. Clinton's first term to pass national health insurance, which would have guaranteed every American the right to health care. Dr. Shalala said she thought the idea would become politically viable again only if "there's a coalition of American medicine and American business" demanding it.
She added that she believed there would probably be some kind of overhaul of Medicare, the 35-year-old insurance program that is the last bastion of traditional, fee-for-service medicine. Many analysts inside and outside the Clinton administration agree that it needs to be modernized before the great wave of baby boomers begins to retire.
But Dr. Shalala suggested that the model embraced by Mr. Bush during the campaign -- giving older people a fixed amount to buy coverage from traditional Medicare or a competing market of health maintenance organizations -- had real problems.
The amount that the elderly would get would be tied to competitive bidding among the plans, and critics say it would very quickly fall short of the cost of joining traditional Medicare, meaning the elderly would be forced into managed care.
"You can't drive up the cost of fee-for-service as a way of shoving people into managed care and say that's fair competition," Dr. Shalala said. "Because there are many places in the country and many individuals who need that fee-for-service option.
"Managed care has not yet demonstrated that it can handle very complex -- handicapped and disabled -- people, for example, and it's not every place."
She still believes in "organized care," she said, but "it may be a different model of organized care than we have now," perhaps with more control and leadership by doctors. Moreover, Dr. Shalala noted, the turbulence among health maintenance organizations in the Medicare market in recent years has "turned off" the elderly. Many such organizations have pulled out, saying the Medicare market was not profitable enough.
She added that she believed the Medicare program should have more competition in it, as long as traditional Medicare was protected. But, she said, efforts in the Clinton years to set up demonstration projects to explore a more market-driven Medicare were routinely opposed by local health care providers in alliance with their congressmen.
As befits a survivor, Dr. Shalala has already offered some practical advice to Mr. Thompson.
"I told him when he went to the White House for a meeting he should go early and stay late," she said, adding that his relations with White House staff could be as important as his relations with members of Congress.
During Dr. Shalala's tenure, the White House kept a close grip on both the health care and welfare initiatives. She acknowledges the pulling and tugging of that relationship, but added, "Once we got through the health care reform period, it smoothed out."
Dr. Shalala, who had a long career in academia, including eight years as president of Hunter College in Manhattan, is to become president of the University of Miami this spring.
"I've had a great time," she said, with a smile, and then she headed off to another going-away party.

HEADLINE: The Yoke of Capitalism; 
Czechs Coming to Terms With a Heap of Bad Debt

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: PRAGUE 

 BODY:
Eleven years ago, the Velvet Revolution brought Communism to an end in the Czech Republic. The way Kamil Ziegler figures, it will take another six years to dig out from the excesses of capitalism.
 Mr. Ziegler is the departing chairman of this country's biggest and fastest-growing financial institution: Konsolidacni Banka, the government-owned bailout agency. Thanks to an ambitious effort to clean up and sell off the country's bankrupt state-owned banks, Konsolidacni and various affiliates are sitting on a mountain of $8.62 billion in nearly worthless loans. 
 The assets here include more than $200 million that one bank lent to an Austrian investment firm that turned out to be a Ponzi scheme. They include millions of dollars squandered at Zetor, which sold tractors at below cost to a distributor who was also the company's biggest shareholder. And they will soon include more than $1 billion in bad loans from a bank that was raided and seized last June by government antiterrorist squads. 
Very little of this stems from the Communist era. Most flows from the mistakes made in the first heady wave of Czech capitalism, when Czech leaders portrayed themselves as devout believers in free markets and chided Western European governments for being rigid and bureaucratic. State-owned banks lent freely to well-connected industrial companies, only to discover years later that about half their money had been wasted.
Today, almost all the big Czech banks have been taken over by foreign institutions, from Erste Bank of Austria to GE Capital. But the mess the Czech banks left behind remains in Czech hands -- specifically, on the books of Konsolidacni Banka -- and nobody at the bank or in the government is quite sure what to do about it. Indeed, foreign bankers complain that the government is undermining the fiscal SWAT team it recently created to save or dispose of the most troubled companies. Konsolidacni is now the biggest creditor and often a major shareholder in some of the Czech Republic's largest conglomerates. Beyond that, it holds thousands of smaller loans on hotels, restaurants, office buildings and even car-repair shops. Its portfolio of debris has more than doubled the last two years, to about one-quarter of the Czech Republic's gross domestic product. And the numbers are expected to swell by an additional $2 billion, to $10 billion, in the next few months, as the Czech government sells the last of its big banks.
"Our mission is simple," said Mr. Ziegler, who has run Konsolidacni Banka for two years and plans to leave next month for a senior job at an Austrian bank in Prague. "We want to destroy ourselves as quickly as possible. We want to dispose of our assets in the shortest time possible, minimizing the cost to taxpayers. The job should be done in six to eight years."
But running Konsolidacni Banka is like trying to sell off a pile of rubble even as the dump trucks keep coming. Compounding the problem, many of the biggest debtors are also among the country's biggest employers, making it politically difficult to force much-needed restructuring.
Selling the loans to outside investors has been painfully slow. That is because the agency's antiquated information systems make it hard for investors to know what is actually available and because the government is reluctant to sell its loans at a tiny fraction of their nominal value, which is all the market will bear.
Last month, the government abandoned one of its most innovative efforts. Hoping to create something akin to a SWAT team to fix up and sell the nation's most troubled conglomerates, the government hired two investment banks, Lazard Freres and Latona Associates of Hampton, N.H. They were put in charge of a new entity called the Revitalization Agency and told to make their money from the profits of restructuring.
Just one year later, the bankers are threatening to pack their bags because the government refused to let the agency acquire the conglomerates' debt. Besides worrying about being properly compensated, the investment bankers fear that the restructuring plans will be subject to political interference again.
"We will not continue working with the companies unless we are certain that we will have enough decision-making autonomy," said Michael Saran, executive director of the Revitalization Agency. The the bankers and the government are trying to negotiate a new agreement by the end of January.
The problems of cleaning up Czech industry provide a sobering lesson for other Central European countries. After the peaceful overthrow of Communism in 1989, the center-right government of Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus embarked on a rapid privatization program, in which it distributed shares in big national enterprises to Czech citizens. Mr. Klaus, an articulate and witty former professor, portrayed himself as a devout believer in deregulation and free markets. But he had little interest in creating the legal infrastructure.
Czech companies were allowed to remain opaque to creditors and shareholders, and opportunists quickly snatched up the shares at rock-bottom prices from fellow citizens unfamiliar with equity ownership. They seized control of companies like Skoda Plzen, the big engineering conglomerate, and Tatra, a truck manufacturer.
Not to be confused with Skoda, the Czech automaker taken over by Volkswagen, Skoda Plzen, with 11,000 workers, had been a reasonably healthy company with products ranging from nuclear power turbines to machine tools. After being privatized, it bought companies that produced locomotives, heavy trucks and sugar mills and built a factory to make aluminum cans. By 1999, the company was losing millions of dollars a day and was delinquent on most of its bank loans.
Other major companies experienced similar declines. Those problems weighed heavily on the banks, largely because Czech bankruptcy laws made it almost impossible for banks to seize property that had been used as collateral for loans. The banks were also woefully inexperienced about analyzing a company's underlying financial strength and based their decisions largely on its record of previous repayment.
"People didn't have any system for early warnings," said Radovan Vavra, chairman of Komercni Banka, the country's biggest bank, which is in the process of being privatized. "The old system did not encompass questions about financial stability. It only took into consideration the payment morals of the customer. But if the first time you get nervous is when a customer misses a payment, it's probably already too late."
Mr. Vavra, a former senior executive at Citibank in Prague, joined Komercni last April, when the bank was losing about $240 million a year and had a huge portfolio of problem loans. Its biggest customer was an Austrian company called BCL, which said it was a fast-growing commodities trader but was actually losing money and borrowing to repay old loans. By the time bank officials recognized the problem, Komercni had lost about $200 million.
Komercni's problems are not unique. The worst case may well be Investicni a Postovni Banka. Nomura International, a subsidiary of Nomura Securities in Japan, acquired 49 percent of I.P.B. in February 1998, with much of the balance apparently held by people linked to I.P.B.'s Czech management.
Czech officials charge that top management systematically looted I.P.B., which had about $7 billion in deposits in 1999, by making questionable loans and transferring more than $1 billion of assets to shell companies worldwide. For example, regulators said that the bank sold shares in the country's leading brewery to a company controlled by Nomura, which Nomura later sold along with another Czech brewer to a South African brewer.
Last June, rumors about I.P.B.'s precarious condition caused a panic among depositors, who lined up by the thousands to withdraw their money. On June 17, antiterrorist police surrounded its headquarters as government officials seized control. A few days later, the Czech National Bank and the Czech finance minister transferred all of I.P.B.'s assets to the Ceskoslovenska Obchodni Banka, which is controlled by KBC Bancassurance Holding of Belgium.
Nomura executives have denied they did anything wrong and have announced plans to sue the government for illegally seizing Nomura property. And they have strong support from Mr. Klaus, the conservative former prime minister, who has denounced the government's action as a "bank robbery."
Government officials say I.P.B. was utterly bankrupt. A preliminary audit suggested that its bad loans totaled at least 40 billion korunas ($1.08 billion), but most analysts say the total will be almost twice that. Those sour loans will be transferred to Konsolidacni Banka.
"It is very unpleasant, but I knew that these actions were necessary," said Pavel Mertlik, the finance minister. "The bank had served like a grant agency. There were customers who hadn't been paying on their loans for years. It was incredible."
Most industry executives agree with Mr. Mertlik and praise him for moving swiftly to clean up the banks. "I think the cleanup has been quite thorough and professional," said Zdenek Bakala, chairman of Patria Finance, one of Prague's biggest brokerage companies.
It has come at a price, however, and the price keeps growing. Before Erste Bank agreed to buy a 52 percent stake in Ceska Sporitelna last summer, the Czech government agreed to assume more than $800 million in bad loans, about 45 percent of Ceska's entire loan portfolio -- and to accept bad loans that had not been discovered at the time.
The privatization of Komercni Banka will be even bigger. The government has already bought about $2 billion of the bank's bad loans and recently agreed to guarantee another $500 million. Four Western European banks -- Credit Agricole and Societe Generale of France, HypoVereinsbank of Germany and Unicredito of Italy -- are now bidding for the government's 60 percent stake in Komercni, which could sell for more than $1 billion.
Such sums will do little to cover the mountain of rubble left behind. Thus far, Konsolidacni has sold off only a sliver of its loans. To speed things up, Mr. Ziegler, the chairman, is for the first time bundling loans into a single package of 20 billion korunas ($538.8 million) and taking bids from foreign institutions.
But even if that works, it would amount to only a fourth of the new bad loans that would be added to the pile this year. Officials say they would be happy to recover just 10 percent of the missing money. But even that raises anxiety because the bailout bank paid about 60 percent of face value for many of its loans.
"They can't just sell the loans for 5 cents on the dollar, because it would be politically unacceptable," said Paul Gilbert, a senior manager at PricewaterhouseCoopers in Prague.
Jan Hanousek, director of the Center for Economic Research and Graduate Education in Prague, is convinced it will be many years before the government works its way through the mess.
"I would be more optimistic if Konsolidacni went and sold some assets lock, stock and barrel, but they haven't done that yet," he said. "With them, it's always like waiting for Godot."

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
Bring On the Nanobots

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS

 BODY:
Our topic for today is the State of the State speeches. This month virtually every governor in the nation takes to the podium, surveying the past, proposing plans for the future, and boring the audience into insensibility. I have just read this year's addresses from about half the states, and the experience was far less enjoyable than my previous project, which involved going to North Carolina and flying in an extremely small plane over lakes full of hog manure. 
 No wonder the average citizen of the United States regards state government as the political equivalent of tooth-flossing. Most of these speeches sound like a meeting of the Bad Bureaucrats Club. Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming, in a typical effort, announced that: "In math, nearly one-third of our kids are at or above proficiency. That's higher than the national trends unless you consider that the national trends and the Wyoming results are the same under the NAEP." The governor of Virginia insisted on referring to his state as "the Digital Dominion." 
 There must be a secret organization that dictates the way these things are supposed to go: 
* Quote Abraham Lincoln (alternate choice: Thomas Jefferson). 
* Recall past triumphs: taxes cut, criminals incarcerated, etc. Congratulate self for not getting state into a mess like California (alternate choice: Florida). 
* Announce that education will be the most important priority. Mention that Bulgarian students are beating us in math. Introduce Algebra Initiative. 
* Call something "bold." 
* Stress plans to bring state into the New Economy. Brag about Web site. Mention genetics and, if possible, "nanotechnology." 
* Conclude that the state of the state is . . . strong! Anything more than one or two words here smacks of desperation. ("Opportunity is the state of the state in Mississippi, America's State of Promise.")
When you read a whole bunch of these speeches at once -- which of course nobody in her right mind would ever do -- you wonder how so many states can accomplish the same goals at once. Are there enough nanotechnological researchers to go around?
To be fair, some governors did seem to put a little extra effort into perking up their delivery. John Hoeven of North Dakota (Theme: The New Economy) opened with a welcome historical reference to his last formal speech "a few days after getting butted in the head by a horse at the Taylor Horse Fest." Jesse Ventura (Theme: Bold Reforms for a New Economy) was, not unexpectedly, more lively than your average chief executive. He delivered a very energetic explanation of why it was particularly unfair to tax people on the basis of the amount of money they made or the property they owned. He also won the Most Unusual Citation award by quoting Arnold Schwarzenegger.
Christie Whitman (Theme: I'm Outta Here) used a Revolutionary War musket as a prop, and there is nothing that recaptures a somnolent audience's attention more forcefully than a governor waving a weapon. But the winner in the visual aid category had to be Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, who went through the contents of a school bag. Mr. Huckabee was particularly interesting on the subject of paste. ("It was good to eat when everything else failed.") 
Mr. Huckabee actually had a few moments when he appeared to be trying to make a real connection, recalling how when he was a raggedy little kid, he wanted to be a teacher because teachers had decent cars and nice clothes. And for predictions you don't hear every day, you've got to hand it to the governor of Iowa, who envisioned a world where "rosemary is used for more than adding flavor to food." 
The rest of the governors were generally interesting only when they were mad about something. "I will not let some bureaucrat in Washington give away our power because California wasn't smart enough to plan ahead," said Jane Dee Hull of Arizona, in an impressive display of ability to work and play with others. And the governor of Idaho must have perked up some ears when he denounced the Clinton administration for trying to reintroduce "flesh-eating grizzly bears" in the wilderness.
In conclusion I can only say that the children of today are the adults of tomorrow. And some, one hopes, will grow up to become speechwriters.

HEADLINE: Screenwriters May Walk Out Over Film Credit and Respect 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
Since Hollywood's golden days in the 1930's and 1940's, writers have often earned extravagant sums but little respect. 
 The most famous writers -- F. Scott Fitzgerald, William Faulkner, Raymond Chandler, Dorothy Parker and Ben Hecht -- reported the horrors of Hollywood to their friends in New York. They told of being rewritten by producers, ignored by stars, abused by studio executives and robbed of respect by directors who took credit for the entire film. 
 Actually, writers' grievances in Hollywood haven't changed that much.
But now a new generation of writers is placing the old complaints on the negotiating table. They are prominent among the issues on which their union, the Writers Guild of America, is threatening to strike on May 1. 
To the fury of directors, the writers are seeking to end the kind of dismissive treatment symbolized by the comment in the 1930's of the legendary studio executive Irving Thalberg: "What's all this business about being a writer? It's just putting one word after another."
What the writers demand would create nothing less than a sea change in the culture of Hollywood, where studios go to great lengths to placate directors. The demands themselves are a testament to the lowly status of the writers, more than ever. They want to overhaul a way of life that elbows them out of the possessory credit -- the credit that directors take that reads "A film by . . ." They want to limit the use of such credits, and they want to be employed while a film is in production so that they can make changes in the script -- and not have directors and stars tinker with their lines.
They also want to watch the "dailies," the scenes that were made that day. On a more symbolic level, they want their names to be included on the cast and crew lists for their films so they will be invited to events like premieres.
Complicating the negotiations, film and television company executives are seeking to walk a delicate line between the demands of the writers and the objections of the directors. In Hollywood's heyday, great producers like David O. Selznick and executives like Thalberg and Darryl F. Zanuck ruled over film production. More recently, with the studios' power in decline, directors have taken over virtually full control.
Accordingly, studios and television networks, in the current negotiations, take the views of directors very seriously. And now with at least a half-dozen cable television networks aggressively making the kinds of middle-budget films that studios once made, the conflict between directors and writers has flared in that arena, too.
The grievances stem in part from the influx of younger directors into films from the worlds of television commercials and music videos, where writers play minimal roles. Screenwriters feel even more marginalized.
For example, possessory credits are routinely taken not only by a top director like Steven Spielberg but increasingly by first-time or unknown filmmakers whose agents demand it. Studios happily give the credit as a sop instead of paying a young director a higher fee.
"Writers have been saying for several years that the way they've been treated in films has actually been getting worse, not better," said John Wells, the president of the Writers Guild of America West and a highly successful executive producer of television series like "E.R." and "West Wing."
"The assumption that the writers should be part of the creative process has deteriorated," he added.
To some degree, the writers themselves are to blame for their plight, because of their historical contempt for the screenplay form. Robert Towne, who wrote such classic films as "Chinatown," has said that this attitude began when novelists and playwrights came to Los Angeles to "condescend to knock out a script in a couple of weeks for big bucks so that they could go back to their daytime job and do some really serious writing."
Tales of writers' woes in Hollywood are embedded in the culture. Top writers may sell scripts for $2 million -- or earn $150,000 a week to add some humor or sex or action to a script. But they are often treated poorly. Robin Swicord, a screenwriter, told of a reading of her script adaptation of the 1994 movie "Little Women." Before filming, she said she was asked to sit outside the closed door of the room where the actors rehearsed. At various points, she said, the director stepped outside and gave her notes on what to change.
"I finally left -- it was too insulting," said Ms. Swicord, who also wrote "The Perez Family" and other films. The director, Gillian Armstrong, is in Australia making a film and was not available for comment.
A number of screenwriters, fearing retribution, said they would only discuss their experiences if their names were not used. One said he was allowed to attend a reading of his script but the director warned him not to look at the actors. The director, he said, feared that the actors would look to the writer for approval of how they were reading their lines.
Another writer told of two-page advertisements in large newspapers that listed the positive comments of critics about a recent blockbuster film. But whenever the critics cited the name of the writer, it was omitted. The reason? The director had disagreements with the writer during filming, and was getting even.
Some grievances among writers may seem petty, but underscore their sense that in the caste system of Hollywood they are treated like untouchables. At events like the Golden Globes, writers often sit in Siberia. When a film ends production, and the cast and crew celebrate at a nightclub or restaurant, writers are often forgotten in the invitation list. At parties after film openings, tables are traditionally reserved for the stars and their hangers-on, as well as producers, directors and studio executives. Never the writer. On a more significant level, top writers never earn a percentage of the film's earnings -- or "first dollar gross" -- in contrast to top stars, directors and producers.
In fairness, not every writer feels beleaguered. Eric Roth, an acclaimed and highly successful screenwriter who won an Academy Award for "Forrest Gump," said he had generally strong, collaborative relations in recent years with directors like Robert Zemeckis, Michael Mann and Robert Redford. "Sure, I've had bad creative experiences with a director, but we just part company," he said. "That's the end of that."
At this point the directors, who clearly see their dominance in making movies threatened, are outraged. Last week Jack Shea, president of the Directors Guild of America, sent a letter to his 12,000 members, citing the "severe and far-reaching implications" of the writers' demands. The proposals, Mr. Shea said, "would seriously impact a director's ability to deliver a product on time, on budget and within his or her creative vision."
Brett Ratner, who, at 30, is one of Hollywood's most successful young directors ("Rush Hour," "The Family Man"), is not about to share his prerogatives."I'm a collaborative person; I always work with the writer," he said. "But the only person in the process who is on the film from the very beginning to the very end is the director. The writer delivers the script and his work kind of ends. Yes, making movies is collaborative, but the director is the one who leads the troops. When there's someone else also making critical decisions, then it starts to get confusing about whose vision it is."
But Woody Allen, the contemporary director who arguably most deserves a possessory credit, refuses to take one, even though he writes and directs his mostly personal films. Mr. Allen called such credits "pretentious and not necessary."
Some directors defend the possessory credit up to a point. Barry Levinson said he did not take a possessory credit on his first film, "Diner," even though he wrote and directed it. "I didn't take it until later on -- it's something to be earned," he said. "It should mean something. A credit that reads 'A Martin Scorsese film' means something."
Similarly, Irwin Winkler, who directed such films as "Guilty by Suspicion" and "The Net," said that the credit had been "terribly misused," and he had qualms about taking it on his second film, a remake of "Night and the City" written by Richard Price. "I shot the script that he wrote -- I didn't develop it," Mr. Winkler said. "Frankly, if possessory credits were not given out as freely as they are, I wouldn't have taken it."
The writers' demands are part of a menu of issues as the entertainment industry faces a series of potential strikes that could cripple film and television production, starting in the late spring.
Besides the writers' threatened strike, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, representing 135,000 actors, are scheduled to walk out on June 30. The Writers Guild and the executives of the studios and television networks -- called the Alliance for Motion Picture and Television Producers -- are set to begin two weeks of talks on Jan. 22.
The writers also have a series of financial demands, mostly involving pay increases for videocassette and DVD sales, as well as payments from overseas markets for television writers.
But the nonmonetary issues are driving the protests of the Writers Guild, representing 11,000 writers on the East and West Coasts. "The major issue is about respect," said Daniel M. Petrie Jr., a former president of the Writers Guild on the West Coast and the screenwriter of, among other films, "Beverly Hills Cop" and "The Big Easy."
"There's a culture in Hollywood that devalues the contribution of the writer to a film," Mr. Petrie said. "In some ways, it's more dysfunctional today than it's ever been."
Barry Meyer, the chairman and chief executive of AOL Time Warner's Warner Brothers, and Robert Iger, the president and chief operating officer of Walt Disney, who are serving as spokesmen for the studio and network negotiating teams, said they expected the overall strike talks to be arduous.
"Many of the issues are resolvable, but I don't think we can have a resolution of the creative issues without the full consultation of the Directors Guild," said Mr. Meyer, a low-key and respected Hollywood figure. "A dialogue between the writer, the director and the production companies is the most productive way of getting things going. Is it complicated? Of course it is.".
Mr. Iger is bracing himself for an ordeal. "This is going to be a long and difficult process," he said. "I'm neither optimistic nor pessimistic."
Not all directors, of course, are averse to keeping writers on the set and listening to their suggestions. Louis Malle, the late French director, once insisted to his producers on "Atlantic City," the 1980 film, that he wanted the screenwriter, John Guare, on the set. "If you have someone on the set for the hair," Mr. Malle said, "why would you not have someone for the words?"

HEADLINE: CLINTON IS CALLING FOR MORE SCRUTINY OF MAJOR AIRLINES 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
In the wake of recent deals that would consolidate the airline industry in the hands of a few giant carriers, the Clinton administration plans to issue a last-minute call to police the industry more closely. 
 In a speech this evening in New York and at a news conference tomorrow, the departing Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater intends to release three studies criticizing the state of competition in air travel and laying out a blueprint for how the government can improve the situation, according to senior administration officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. 
 But after receiving strong criticism from the airlines, some academics and the White House itself, and with less than a week left in the Clinton administration, Mr. Slater will stop short of issuing guidelines first proposed three years ago that would have put airlines on notice about how aggressively they could respond to low-fare competitors. 
The officials and others who have read or been briefed on the studies said that they argue that the airlines use a wide variety of tactics to suppress competition, including frequent-flier program bonuses, payments to travel agencies and exclusive corporate contracts. 
The studies also contend that the big airlines exploit their dominance of many major metropolitan airports to charge high fares, rebutting arguments by the airlines and some academics that such premiums have been overstated.
Mr. Slater is expected to say that the new research lays the economic and legal foundation for the Transportation Department to use its authority more aggressively to promote competition. 
"They are now making the claim that they understand the problem much better and plan to use the department's enforcement powers," said one person who was briefed by administration officials.
The original guidelines proposed in 1998 were intended to prevent large carriers from driving weaker ones out of business by temporarily lowering fares and adding capacity.
The major airlines may breathe a sigh of relief that the administration has decided not to issue the guidelines, but they are not likely to be happy with Mr. Slater's parting shot. 
Michael Wascom, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, the industry's principal lobby, said yesterday that the domestic airline industry was among the most competitive in the world. 
"Anticompetitive actions are against the law, period," he said. "Our members have and will continue to comply with the law." 
Several of the small carriers and consumer advocates who long backed the original guidelines said yesterday that they were not disappointed by the administration's decision to abandon them. The administration's new approach, they said, identifies a broader set of unfair practices by big airlines and therefore could be more effective.
"The D.O.T. has it within their authority to do something," said David Neeleman, the chief executive of JetBlue Airways, a new low-fare airline based at J.F.K. in New York. "As the industry consolidates and there are fewer and fewer players, I would hope the D.O.T. would step up and be a little more vigilant."
Of course, that will be up to the incoming Bush administration. A spokesman for the Bush transition team, Scott McClellan, would not discuss details of plans for promoting airline competition. 
But some people think that the new administration will have difficulty avoiding the issue of airline competition, even if it wants to. 
Several representatives and senators in both political parties, including Senator John McCain of Arizona, have taken a strong interest in the industry, spurred on by angry constituents and, in some cases, by their own unhappy travel experiences. 
In addition, Norman Mineta, a Democrat and Mr. Bush's choice for Transportation Secretary, has extensive experience with aviation, including the issue of competition.
Last week's announcement that American Airlines plans to buy Trans World Airlines and some of the assets of US Airways as part of a plan to smooth the purchase of the rest of US Airways by United Airlines raised an outcry from many lawmakers. 
The deal would leave American flying about half the domestic passengers at Kennedy. "Anytime you have a competitor that controls 50 percent of the market, you worry about them controlling the market," Mr. Neeleman said. 
The Bush Justice Department will also inherit the first predatory-pricing lawsuit against an airline since the industry was deregulated 22 years ago. The suit, filed in 1999, contended that American Airlines drove competitors out of its Dallas-Fort Worth hub in the mid-1990's by cutting prices below cost and offering more flights. After the competitors left, the government said, American promptly raised fares and reduced flights. American has denied the accusation. The trial is scheduled to begin in May. 
Since deregulation, the Transportation Department has had strong powers to police the industry. But it has been reluctant to use them. The agency first decided to devise new competition rules after the airlines themselves asked for guidance in the late 1990's. But after a draft of the guidelines was announced by Mr. Slater, the big airlines strongly attacked it, arguing that the department was exceeding its authority and usurping the antitrust laws. 
The airlines spent millions of dollars lobbying Congress in 1998, which directed the Transportation Department to delay issuing the rules until the Transportation Research Board, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, conducted a study.
The resulting 1999 study by a committee of 11 academics, lawyers and former airline executives "noted some alarming trends against healthy rivalry" in the industry and urged the government to take "decisive steps" to increase competition. But it also concluded that the proposed guidelines were flawed and warned that they "could lead to regulations that would stifle competition more than encourage it."
Some White House advisers agreed. They were joined by the Justice Department, which feared the guidelines would muddy its authority as the enforcer of antitrust laws. The administration had the added incentive that labor unions, which Vice President Al Gore was counting on in his bid for the presidency, also opposed the guidelines. They viewed them as a bailout for nonunion airlines that could hurt the major carriers, which are highly unionized.
Finally, after nearly three years, the Transportation Department came to agree last month with the critics who said the guidelines were too narrow and too rigid. "To come out with hard-and-fast rules has been discarded as not right for the industry," one administration official said. "It could be harmful to the very people we are trying to assist."
But one study Mr. Slater is expected to cite concludes that relying on antitrust laws alone cannot preserve competition and that the department has the authority to act.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Politicians Stand in Way Of Harlem

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
THE good news for Harlem, as you may have read on Martin Luther King's Birthday, is that people are still eager to fix up homes there despite the neighborhood scandal involving the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. The bad news is that politicians and bureaucrats still want to lend a helping hand.
 Local politicians and HUD officials are still committed to giving preference to nonprofit groups over private developers and speculators. Instead of simply auctioning off buildings and vacant land to the highest bidder, officials are determined to pursue larger social goals. As Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, put it last year, "The highest bidder does not necessarily know what's best for a community." HUD officials say they're trying to "do the right thing." 
 What is the right thing for the community? To New York politicians, the answer is always "affordable housing," and their developer of choice is a nonprofit group. Never mind that the current scandal in Harlem involves nonprofit groups that milked a HUD loan program and then abandoned the properties they were supposed to be fixing up. Since the scandal broke, city politicians have been promising to spend more money on subsidies to nonprofit developers.
Never mind that the neighborhoods being revived were built without HUD loans or the efforts of nonprofit groups. Politicians and housing advocates assume that private developers can't do the job anymore. The conventional wisdom is that the market can't provide affordable housing because it's not profitable to build or renovate housing in poor and working class neighborhoods.
But the conventional wisdom doesn't jibe with the current reality in Harlem. Now that housing prices in nearby neighborhoods have shot up so dramatically, buyers are willing to spend more than $500,000 for a Harlem brownstone. The market wants to redevelop Harlem. It's politicians who are standing in the way. They say gentrification reduces the supply of affordable housing, when in fact just the reverse can happen.
If a couple from, say, Morningside Heights buys a boarded-up brownstone in Harlem, it starts a chain reaction. A couple from Kingsbridge in the Bronx might move into the family's old apartment, and then the Kingsbridge place is occupied by someone from a slightly poorer neighborhood, and the chain reaction continues, affecting poorer and poorer people at each step.
BEFORE long, a dozen families might move into better housing thanks to that one rehab job in Harlem, all at no cost to the taxpayer. All the families have climbed what Howard Husock calls the housing ladder, a process that encourages people to acquire bourgeois values instead of hoping to luck into a subsidized home.
"Why do we think it's a good idea to arbitrarily reward a few low-income people with homes they couldn't afford themselves?" asks Mr. Husock, a housing scholar at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government.
"Our society is structured to give you an incentive to work and save and stay married so you can climb to a better home in a better neighborhood," Mr. Husock said. "We shouldn't send the message that the way to do that is to win a lottery."
Mr. Husock also faults housing reformers for trying to permanently designate certain buildings and blocks as low-income housing. "There's a cycle of decay and regeneration of neighborhoods just as there is in forests," he said, "and a city will die if you disrupt that process."
That process gradually transformed Harlem as Dutch farmers gave way to Irish squatters and then to developers catering to Germans and Eastern Europeans. An "improvement organization" of whites (who probably claimed to speak for "the community") tried to keep out blacks, but landlords were too eager to rent rooms to the highest bidders of any race.
Today the high bidders could help reintegrate the neighborhood, economically as well as racially, yet the prospect does not have local politicians rhapsodizing about a gorgeous mosaic. Maybe they really are just dedicated to neighborhood preservation.
Or maybe there's also another kind of preservation at work. Politicians who fight for affordable housing, after all, are accustomed to being remembered at election time by the tenants and nonprofit groups that get the subsidies. People who pay for their own homes might not be so grateful. What's good for Harlem is not necessarily good for Harlem's politicians.
