HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
An Impact Player, in Life and in Death

BYLINE:  By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
IN the modest, red brick First Baptist Church in the tough part of Far Rockaway, Queens, the organist and the drummer struck up "The Sidewalks of New York" as the mourners for the funeral service yesterday began to file in. It is a bouncy tune, recalling sweet old days, but to the ears of some, and amid the tears, the song never sounded so sad. 
 It was on a sidewalk of New York, after all, not far from this church, that the 17-year-old boy lying in the half-open coffin in the wood-beamed church was shot to death. He had been trying to be a peacemaker in a neighborhood dispute last Wednesday when he was shot in the face by a 19-year-old fellow he had never before met. 
 The boy in the coffin was Thomas Kareem Johnson Jr. He was a senior at Christ the King High School. He was the football team's captain and star running back and an all-league selection. He was an excellent student. He had received recruiting letters from colleges like Harvard, Yale, Penn, Navy, Temple and Hofstra. The principal of the school, Michael Lynch, said that on Tommy Johnson's last math test, he received a 99, a score he never got to see.
Inside the coffin, Tommy Johnson wore his maroon Christ the King football jersey, with the white No. 5.
Three busloads of students arrived from Tommy's school and filled the balcony of the church. Hundreds more family members and friends crowded into the pews and stood along the side aisles. Others jammed into the basement or stood outside on Redfern Avenue, listening to the service over speakers. There were also a few reporters on hand, as well as some television crews on the street.
"If Tommy hadn't been a football player," said the clergyman Rubin Mitchell, who delivered the eulogy, "he would have been just another statistic, one of many young boys and girls who get murdered on these streets regularly. Something has to be done about it. The communities have to work together. 
"Some of the children have parents who are only 14 years older than they are. Some are raised by grandparents and great-grandparents. And there's this whole culture of admiration for the thug life, as they call it. What's happening is a tragedy beyond description."
A reading teacher at Middle School 198, across the street from where Tommy Johnson was shot, Mary Dever, said, "Even for parents who are at home for the kids -- and most want the best for their children -- some are afraid to even come to P.T.A. meetings because of the drive-by shootings." 
Tommy Johnson's parents, however, were very much involved. 
"They gave order to Tommy Johnson's life in an environment of disorder," said Maxine Schack, who represented the Neponsit Adult Day Health Care center, where Thomas Johnson Sr. was a driver and attendant. "And you always knew when it was 3 o'clock, because Mr. Johnson was calling his home. He was a father who needed to know where his children were."
Tommy Johnson had said that his dream was to get an education, maybe play pro football, too, but earn enough to buy his parents a home away from this neighborhood.
His parents, Thomas Sr. and Juanita Johnson, sat in the front row, within a yard or so of their son. They sat with their other children: a daughter, Tierra, 15, and two sons, Travis, 10, and Tysean, 4. An usher in nurse's white stood in front of Juanita Johnson, sometimes fanning her with a small fan, other times dabbing the tears from her eyes.
Juanita Johnson is a civilian worker in the nearby 100th Precinct. And members of the precinct were in attendance, to pay their respects.
One person who spoke during the service, Congressman Gregory W. Meeks, began by looking at the parents. "Thank you for a job well done," he said. And the congregation erupted in applause. "You raised a young man who's a shining example of life. You raised a young man who will have made an impact on our lives henceforth. Just look at all the people here who have been moved by him."
The murder of Tommy Johnson occurred after he and three cousins had tried to settle a misunderstanding over a girl. According to the police, Charles Sealey, unemployed and with four arrests, pulled out a .380 semiautomatic handgun and fired a series of shots. One struck Tommy Johnson, killing him immediately.
Early Saturday morning, Sealey gave himself up to the police. He was accompanied by his parents.
"Now we have two families destroyed. Why?" Thomas Johnson Sr. had been quoted as saying. "The whole community is torn up. We're loving people. We go to church, we did the right things, but when you're living with thugs and hoodlums it's hard."
The choir sang gospels. The congregation provided harmony. The eulogies from community, clergy, family were moving. And a young man with a world of potential and possibilities lay dead. There were more tears as mourners filed past the open casket.
The organist and drummer began to play the spiritual "By and By." An elderly woman, Lucille Foster, was given the microphone and began to sing, with a beautiful, powerful voice that rang out through the church:
In the land of perfect day, 
When the mists have rolled away,
We will understand it better by and by,
By and by.

HEADLINE: Seeing Hardship Through a Windshield; 
Truck Drivers Feel a Recession Coming, Mile After Weary Mile

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF

DATELINE: MANADAHILL, Pa. 

 BODY:
They wandered in off the road reeking of diesel and themselves. They had driven in from around the country, from the stockyards and the swamps and the steel mills. Some had driven 800 miles all day and night to land in this truck plaza.
 The highwaymen were nail-bitten and listless, their eyes half closed from cigarette smoke and fatigue. They sat in the "tweakers' lounge," a dreary room with rows of chairs and a large-screen television. This is where truck drivers -- some strung out from the road, others from pills and most from cigarettes -- wait to wind down. They try to sleep only because the government makes them stop. After eight legal hours of sitting idle, they were off again to another town, another load, on roads linking everything together but their lives. It was 1 a.m. 
 These drivers were the lucky ones. They had a load and a destination, and the only thing that was really wrong with them was overeating. It was the other truckers standing out by the electronic strip poker machines who were in the straits. Some had been waiting a day and a half here, just outside Harrisburg and about 160 miles southwest of Manhattan. They were stuck at the major routing hub for all goods moving from points north, south and west, goods destined for the metropolis. 
They were waiting for a load and they were rested. But the digital load board near the lounge, advertising jobs in the area, told them what they already knew; there was nothing to carry.
When you are paid by the mile, there is one law of the road and one law only, said Robert Strong, a road-worn Cajun from Shreveport, La. "If the wheels ain't turning, you ain't making money." 
Many of these working Americans, like Mr. Strong, have no education beyond some high school. They might read a book now and then when they can't sleep or the weather shuts them down. They might read a little of the newspaper, usually the sports pages. They get some of their information from television, but most of it comes from around the coffee counters at the truck plazas. They couldn't tell you who Alan Greenspan was, but they could tell you this. If this is not a recession, it is close to one.
"I ain't seen it this bad in years," said Rick Hummelbaugh, 52, a barrel of a man whom the other drivers call Dead Eye. "You got so many guys here sitting longer between loads. And out there on the highway I'm noticing less car carriers, less rolled steel, less lumber and less insulation. It don't look good is all I'm saying." 
Economists are not ready to call it a recession. The economy is still growing, but at a slower pace. Automobile sales were off 18 percent last month from a year ago; single-family-home starts fell by nearly half a percentage point in November, their third straight monthly decline. Moreover, 178,000 manufacturing jobs were lost last year, 62,000 in December alone. 
The trucking industry is one of the first to notice the signs when the American economy is retreating. "We knew the economy was in trouble six months ago," said Donald Broughton, a transportation analyst with A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
"Eighty percent of all goods in this country move by truck," Mr. Broughton said. "If you're looking for an indication of where the economy is going, take a look at what's going on on the highway."
Mr. Broughton said that more than 1,350 companies with five trucks or more went bankrupt in the third quarter of 2000, nearly double the record set in the previous quarter.
Industry experts attribute the failures to rising diesel costs, insurance rates and wage pressures. But a decline in goods being shipped is a major factor.
In tonnage, the trucking industry was off 7 percent from July through September compared with the same period a year before. One fallout from the downturn is that people making a marginal living hauling these goods are being pushed to the brink, idling longer in truck stops like this, hoping to make ends meet.
"I don't worry about going home no more," said Texas Terry Adams, a truck owner who wears a beard and cowboy hat and leases his labor and rig to a trucking company. "The dispatcher don't even try to route you home no more. They just want to keep you chained to the wheel. Keep you moving. So I don't worry about it no more. When I got to go home I just go home. I'm my own man."
J. R. Bartz, who has been running his own truck since the 60's, said: "I used to worry about that too -- going home. But my ex-wife took the house, so I don't worry about having a home." 
Truck drivers tell their children about the good part of the job, forgetting to tell them about the bad. They talk about freedom and call themselves the last of the cowboys. They make their world sound as if it were an extension of the Wild West, and it is, in some ways. They see themselves as the last of the unhenpecked heroes, willing to go anywhere at any time. They are willing to thumb their noses at the law and make 2,500 miles in two days if the money is right.
That is the good part. There is plenty of bad. The broken marriages. The kidney stones. The loneliness. The pay. Their world is through the windshield, and when they see a young couple pass them by, they wish they had a bit of that, too. They might think about that couple for the next 50 miles.
Since the industry was deregulated in 1980, the wages and the quality of life has spiraled downward for the trucker while the hours worked have doubled. The new rules allowed free entry into the carrying market, eliminated indirect routes, to protect the carriers, and at the same time did away with collective rate-setting.
Before deregulation, the industry worked much the same way the airlines work now, by a hub-and-spoke system. A driver might run from Gary, Ind., to Detroit and back, and be home in time for dinner. Another driver might then take the cargo from Detroit to Cleveland and so on.
Hub-and-spoke drivers are now just a small part of the overall carrying market. The rest, called long-haul drivers, might now load up in Jacksonville, Fla., drive to Harrisburg, drop a load there, pick up another in Pittsburgh and continue to Los Angeles. Most are required by their companies to work three weeks straight before getting a day off.
Deregulation has resulted in lower shipping prices, but it has also brought down the wages of the drivers. Although employment in the trucking industry has increased by 3.9 percent since the early 80's, real annual earnings for drivers, adjusted for inflation, have dropped 30 percent, said Prof. Michael H. Belzer, associate director of the Trucking Industry Program at the University of Michigan.
Truck drivers are exempt from the Fair Labor Standards Act, meaning they are not entitled to overtime. The average driver now makes about $40,000 a year.
"Typically these guys make about 31 cents a mile," Professor Belzer said. "By law they can only work 10 hours straight. Then they must rest 8, and then they can work 10 hours again. They have to cheat to make it."
Federal law says that all work time falls under the 10-hour rule. So, in order to save driving time, a truck driver will typically omit loading and unloading time. When you get paid by the mile, four hours at the loading dock leaves just six driving hours, so many drivers do not log these hours in the book.
About 400,000 long-haul trucks are on the road, 160,000 of them owned by individuals. For these owner-operators, whose expenses come out of their own pockets, life has become a faucet of misery with no stopcock. 
There are a few rules in the trucking world. Never run out of tobacco. Keep emergency food and water stored in your rig. Stay out of New York City; the traffic will eat you and your time up.
Wayne McMillan, 50, an owner-operator, was sitting around the truck plaza drinking quarts of coffee while waiting for a call about a job.
"Times are real tough," he said. He is barely meeting the payments on his rig. "I'm waiting for the times to get better." He thought about what he had said for a moment. 
"Come to think of it, they said these were the best times we ever knowed. But when I got into it 30 years ago I was making the same money I'm making now and I was home on the weekends."
Mr. McMillan scratched it out on a napkin, basing his calculations on a four-and-a-half-week month.
Expenses (per month)
Truck payment: $1,600
Tires: $190
Oil and Filters: $200
Permits/Taxes: $200
Truck Insurance: $150
Load Insurance: $100
Fuel: $2,500
Tolls: $200
Misc.: $200
Total: $5,340 per month
Revenue: 10,000 miles a month @ $1 per mile = $10,000
Net Income = $1,036 per week @ 90 hours per week = $11.50 an hour.
"That's not a whole lot considering I live in my rig 24 hours a day, seven days a week," he said. "And now I'm sitting here with no work. I'm going to lose that truck if it keeps up."
And they talked around the coffee counter for hours, moaning about the economy and their bank notes and the unappreciated plight of the worker. The waitress let them know they were not the only ones suffering. Her tips are down 20 percent.
It went like this late into the evening until Mr. Strong's pager went off. It was his company calling.
He soon came back with his head down. He had a load. Long Island. 
The men at the counter laughed at him. "You gonna make $78 for 10 hours' work, boy."

HEADLINE: Keeping the National Light Bulb Turned On 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: LOVELAND, Colo., Jan. 15 

 BODY:
Shortly before 11 a.m. today, a red phone rang here at the Rocky Mountain Regional Office of the Western Area Power Administration. Someone was calling to notify officials that California had just gone to a Stage 1 energy alert. Fifteen minutes later, the red phone rang again, with worse news: Stage 2.
 The calls did not exactly generate sweat on the brows of John Moore or Tom Woods, the duty officers at the time who were managing the flow of electricity across the region they serve, which includes parts of Colorado, Wyoming, Utah, Montana, Nebraska and Kansas. The same thing has happened often during California's current energy crisis. The alerts mean that California's energy surplus at the moment has grown so thin that energy companies are looking to buy additional supplies to meet unanticipated demand. 
 But in a larger context, the calls served as the latest reminder that energy problems in one state can affect others, owing to the intricacy, complexity and inter-connectedness of America's energy grid. 
If it seems that consumers in California are the only ones screaming about soaring energy costs, that is only because there are more of them -- California uses one-third of all the energy produced in the West. The same steep price increases are occurring nationwide because no matter where electricity is produced, most of it costs about the same and it all flows through the same regional grids of electrical lines.
"It's always a problem of stability," said Mark Fidrych, a security specialist whose staff monitors the operations here and at similar regional centers in California and Oregon. "If the next bad thing occurs, the problems cascade."
The flow of power produced in the western third of the country is controlled by 31 centers like the one here. All but four are operated by private utility companies or local governments. The operations here and those in three other regions are run by the federal Energy Department. But they all perform, essentially, the same functions, and that is to manage the flow of energy in such a way that supply and demand remain about equal.
In Western states, it has become an increasingly large challenge in recent years for reasons that include unexpected weather patterns like drier winters in the Pacific Northwest and longer hot spells in the Southwest, population shifts to California and the Southwest, a strong economy that has encouraged new businesses to start and old ones to expand and, of course, the glitches in California's efforts to deregulate its energy system.
Those conditions have taken on greater influence at a time when the construction of power plants has waned -- especially in California -- and the rising demand for power is taxing the existing plants throughout the West. All are taken off-line periodically for routine maintenance. But now, more of the older plants are developing problems that require unscheduled maintenance.
Those factors have led to a sharply rising demand on energy supplies and rising prices, which are borne by most utility companies, no matter what the demand may be in the area they serve.
While the economics of electricity are played out among energy producers, middlemen, utilities and increasingly angry consumers, the mechanics of delivery occur in the quiet of control rooms like the one here, a high-technology maze of computer screens, wall-mounted monitors, telephones, illuminated grids that represent power lines across the region and television screens tuned to the Weather Channel. Imagine NASA without the rockets.
The center here manages the flow of electricity generated by 50 power plants. Whether produced by hydro-electricity, nuclear fuels, natural gas or coal, the energy they generate is pumped into the grid and, ultimately, drawn off by utility companies according to schedules of estimated need that the companies submit to energy brokers by the hour.
For the center's workers, the trick is to match the need with the supply, which is done through computerized adjustments. A constant flow of data, which appears on the wall of monitors, shows them how successful they are. At an adjacent bank of computers, other people monitor the performance of equipment.
Most days progress smoothly, but problems arise, as when a falling tree or ice storm snaps a line, causing a disruption. That requires adjustments to the system so that electricity can spread evenly across the grid, rather than overload other lines, causing more disruptions.
But as demand for energy is growing so are problems.
"We're seeing outages that we've never seen before," said Joel Bladow, manager of the center here. "With changes in the market the way energy is bought and sold, more and more we're seeing bulk transactions of energy over longer distances, like California buying energy from Wyoming. We had one instance recently where a plant in Utah tripped off-line, overloading a line between Utah and Colorado that was rated to carry 680 megawatts. All of a sudden, it was over 800, so we had to take quick action."
"If we hadn't," he added, "another line might have tripped out, and we can only plan for so many things going wrong. If too many things go wrong, we're in trouble."
Perhaps the surest measure of the monitoring operations is how often the digital clocks at the operations center have to be recalibrated. When too much energy is flowing through the regional grid, the clocks speed up. When the flow is down, they slow. In either case, when the clocks are off by as much as two seconds, they are adjusted.
"We adjust them very, very, very frequently," Mr. Fidrych said with a laugh. "Now, maybe 20 times a month."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Hall helps manage electricity at the Rocky Mountain Regional Office of the Western Area Power Administration, in Loveland, Colo. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hopes Fade That More Salvadorans Will Be Found Alive 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
Hopes dwindled here today for finding more survivors trapped under tons of earth in a suburb after the earthquake on Saturday set off a landslide. 
 Officials said that by their estimates more than 600 people had been killed, and some reports said the number still missing was as high as 4,000. 
 Many of the dead were in Las Colinas, a neighborhood of Santa Tecla, a suburb of San Salvador where a housing development was obliterated by a wall of earth that came crashing down a hillside. 
In the town of Comasagua, an area southwest of here that has been inaccessible to rescue workers, local reports said there had been a landslide that might have buried many more victims. The government of El Salvador asked Colombia to donate 3,000 coffins to help bury the dead. 
There was also widespread damage, clearly visible during helicopter flights by relief workers, in several towns in Usulutan Department, southeast of the capital. With many towns still without running water, public health specialists have begun to provide assistance and post-disaster counseling.
In the town of San Agustin, the red tile or zinc panel roofs of many houses have partly or completely collapsed, exposing the interiors to the elements. On every block, one or more houses have been reduced to adobe and wood, and the interior of a church has crumbled behind its facade. Throughout the streets and fields, residents sought shelter under sheets of blue plastic propped up by poles.
"Except for this area, I think some houses have held up well," said Kenneth Ellis, the director of the local mission of the United States Agency for International Development. "But I think that there is a strong disaster in Usulutan."
Aftershocks continued throughout last night, although they have grown shorter and weaker. At least five of the aftershocks since Saturday have had a magnitude of 5.4 or more.
Rescue workers, including specially trained units from other countries, continued to comb through the dirt and debris in Las Colinas today. The scene was more orderly and without as many gawkers or well-intentioned volunteers as during the first two days.
Bullzdozers and backhoes pried loose clumps of earth as rescue workers shoveled into crannies and craters in a vain search for survivors. Every so often, bodies were plucked out of the ground, placed on stretchers and taken away for identification by relatives or sent to a morgue.
Concern over a series of tremors in Las Colinas led officials to evacuate the residents of several damaged houses on the edges of the huge landslide that buried about 80 percent of the neighborhood's houses. A scooped-out area on the hillside marked the place where the deadly landslide began.
The police also secured a four-block zone in the area to protect household belongings, although reports of theft or looting have been virtually nonexistent.
"The most important thing right now is to save lives," said Interior Minister Mario Acosta Ortel. "It is a matter of time before there is a new avalanche on the houses that have been left standing."
Officials, who have begun to compile damage reports from about 80 percent of the country, said the temblor had left no part of the nation untouched, although compared with the number of deaths in Santa Tecla, loss of life elsewhere was minimal.
Emergency shelters have been set up in health clinics. And bodies, some of them mangled from the effects of the quake and the bulldozers that worked to clear the area, have begun to be sent to morgues.
A sprawling tent city has sprung up at El Cafetalon, a recreation field in Santa Tecla where volunteers have been sifting through piles of donated clothing and distributing food and setting up medical care. 
Two and three families huddle under each hastily built tent of plastic and split bamboo, some of them finding their way to the camp after having had to sleep outdoors since the quake. All day, television stations broadcast appeals for food and clothing, as well as reports from stranded residents of villages who have yet to be visited by relief workers or who are desperately trying to contact relatives.
With rampant -- and unfounded -- rumors of tidal waves or worse, officials have issued appeals for calm.
The United States has sent five helicopters from an American military base in Honduras to assist with aerial damage assessments and recovery efforts. With emergency housing becoming a priority, American relief officials met this morning with representatives of private aid groups to begin planning for rebuilding efforts.
Local work has been hampered, rescuers and others said, by a lack of coordination among the various agencies and volunteers who showed up to help. The national emergency center got off to a slow start when it had to be relocated after its original site suffered structural and other damage.
Communications have also been spotty, since cellular phone service has been intermittent in some areas.
The damage from the earthquake may surpass that from Hurricane Mitch, which devastated much of Central America in 1998. It is a heavy burden on this country, which emerged from a 12-year civil war in the early 1990's.
"It's not just Mitch," said Rose Likins, the ambassador from the United States. "Many Salvadorans are still recovering from the conflict. The peace accords were signed in 1992, and Salvador is a model in making that a reality. Salvadorans are very resilient. I have every confidence they will weather this as they have other crises."
Maria Arely Abrego and her four children now wonder where they will go since their house collapsed on Saturday. They spent last night outdoors before setting up a makeshift home on a Santa Tecla soccer field.
"I really have no idea what we are going to do," she said. "Maybe we can go back and rebuild the house, but I think there isn't any opportunity for us there, so maybe we should do something different."
Nearby, her 9-year-old son, Luciano, knew one thing was already going to be different.
"There won't be any football games this Sunday," he said, chomping on a piece of chocolate.

HEADLINE: Struggling Salvadoran Workers Try to Aid Homeland in Crisis 

BYLINE:  By TINA KELLEY

DATELINE: GLEN COVE, N.Y., Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The Salvadoran day laborers of this Nassau County city are learning that winter is the worst time for a natural disaster to hit their homeland. These are the months when there is little or no work, so they try to live off their summer savings. Now they are also trying to scrape together help for their families, some of whose homes and lives were destroyed in an earthquake over the weekend.
 Fermin Martinez, 33, from Santa Ana, El Salvador, learned from his wife that his family's home was destroyed in the earthquake Saturday, which measured 7.6 on the standard seismic scale. Luckily, he said, his family was outside the house at the time. 
 Mr. Martinez had just wired $300 to his family -- his wife, six children, eight brothers and father -- to help them survive and rebuild, he said today. Now he is left wondering how he will pay for rent and food.
The work that sustains him during the warmer months, when he cuts lawns and does landscaping, has dried up, and he has not been able to find a job in 15 days, he said today, as the Rev. Allan Ramirez, who was speaking to immigrants about the quake, translated. 
"We lost everything, just down to the ground," Mr. Martinez said. "Now we will try and rebuild, if God allows us to. Now we will have to see, we will have to start all over again. I want to sleep, but I can't even close my eyes. I keep thinking someone has died and they don't want to tell me, and I wonder." His eyes were shining, and he looked away.
Mr. Ramirez, of the Brookville Reformed Church, later offered to help Mr. Martinez pay his rent.
Around Long Island and the New York region, groups are organizing to send help to El Salvador, where 600 people were killed in the quake and perhaps thousands more are missing.
Merchants in Hempstead have been collecting canned goods to send. Cayetano Moran, who owns La Union restaurant in Hempstead, said he had spoken with the Salvadoran Consulate about holding a benefit at his disco to help the earthquake victims.
And Danilo Guirola, vice consul of the Salvadoran Consulate on Long Island, held a meeting tonight in Hempstead in which private and governmental groups formed a committee to raise money for the earthquake victims.
The vice consul urged people to donate money through the American Red Cross by calling (800) HELP-NOW and earmarking gifts for El Salvador. 
Because of downed phone lines and widespread electricity disruptions, many Salvadorans in the metropolitan area have not yet heard how their relatives have fared.
"I don't know anything about my family because calls are not getting through there," said Lucindo Bonilla, 38, a day laborer from Anamoros who is worried about his three sons. "I need to know what happened."
At My Store on School Street in Glen Cove, the shopkeeper, Carlos Barajas, said only one or two of 20 callers there had succeeded in speaking with family members in El Salvador. "They're frustrated," he said. "This is two days without knowing anything." 
Henry Villatoro, 19, who works at El Tazumal, a restaurant on Glen Street here, said that his parents had left New York on Wednesday to visit family members in Santa Tecla, where the worst landslides occurred, but that they had been turned back because the area was considered too dangerous. 
The Salvadoran Mass at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove was packed on Sunday, he said, and he could tell from the number of customers he had that the economics of the immigrants had changed over the weekend.
"Right here it has been kind of slow, because a lot of people are sending money," he said, looking around the restaurant. He suspected that members of the one family eating there had no relatives in the earthquake because they looked happy, he said. He was right; they are Honduran.
In Hempstead, at the Musica Latina store on North Franklin Avenue, Gloria Roca said the only way to get in touch at first with her Salvadoran relatives in their town of Santiago y Maria was through cellular phones. 
"My family had a bakery, and the whole thing went down," she said, adding that a grocery was also destroyed. "Supposedly, the bank and the hospital had pretty bad damage. 
"Every time we talk to them, they say things are still moving right now, 6 or 10 times a day. People don't go inside because they're scared." 
In Glen Cove, Mr. Martinez said he would like to visit his homeland now but could not afford to. "How would I come back here?" he said. "At least here I can work and make money." 
Mr. Martinez learned that the cathedral in Santa Ana had been destroyed, as well as the Church of the Calvary. But he was relieved to hear that his family had survived. "Thank God that they are O.K., it's just that they are so frightened," he said.
"I feel very afflicted," he said. "What am I going to eat now that I had to send them what little I have?"

HEADLINE: Equality for All New York Schools 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The laudable decision by Justice Leland DeGrasse of the State Supreme Court requiring a new system of financing education in New York State (front page, Jan. 11) needs to be supplemented with funds for a study to determine which educational programs provide the most "bang for the buck" in improving student achievement in reading and in mathematics. 
 We need to compare the improvement attributable to increased spending on books to that attributable to increased training of teachers; to compare providing school buildings in good condition to providing preschool or free lunch; to compare providing special reading or mathematics programs to providing computers in classrooms; to compare reducing class size to providing in-service teacher training.

LAURA RANDALL
New York, Jan. 11, 2001

The writer is professor emerita of economics at Hunter College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Equality for All New York Schools 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "State Judge Rules School Aid System Is Unfair to City" (front page, Jan. 11):
 New York has created high-stakes Regents' exams in many subject areas, thus creating standardized educational ends across the state. 
The means, or educational financing, to reach these ends are anything but uniform, resulting in less money for the students who needed it most -- the economically disadvantaged minority students from New York City. 
 Unfortunately, any movement toward equality of financing will undoubtedly face opposition from suburbanites, who pay a disproportionate share of the taxes. However, suburbanites should support any effort toward equality of financing, not only because it fulfills the American ideal of equal opportunity, but also because it will likely result in lower taxes later to pay for child welfare agencies, law enforcement, prisons, drug intervention programs and Medicaid.

ALEXANDER CAMARDA
New York, Jan. 11, 2001

The writer teaches social studies at a New York City public school.

HEADLINE: MANHATTAN RENTS STARTING TO DROP AFTER LONG CLIMB 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
Manhattan's skyrocketing apartment rental market has turned around and started drifting back toward earth. For the first time in seven years, many landlords are reducing prices and some are even offering to pay broker fees, allowing tenants to save thousands of dollars.
 Real estate brokers say there are many more apartments languishing in their computers, unrented. And to many of them, the city no longer seems to be immune to the economic slowdown that has been affecting other parts of the country. Vacancies started accumulating in the fall, the brokers say, after the Nasdaq plummeted and dot-coms began failing. 
 Right now, agents say, many people who would have been looking for bigger and better apartments are biding their time. 
Even as prices begin to stabilize or drop, rents remain higher than they were two or three years ago.
But suddenly, "owners will be negotiable," said Ruth McCoy, executive director of Feathered Nest, one of Manhattan's largest rental agencies. Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate, agreed. From Park Avenue palazzi to East Village walkup studios, he said, rents are "absolutely more negotiable throughout the marketplace." 
The change in rental prices and negotiability follows a leveling off of co-op and condominium purchase prices reported over the summer. But many agents say the trend is even more pronounced for rentals.
At the Halstead Property Company, Brian G. Edwards, the director of leasing, said that activity -- people looking and renting -- has "fallen off fairly severely" in the last six months. "The wheels haven't fallen off the bus," he said of Manhattan's rental market. "But they're pretty squeaky right now."
Douglas Elliman, a major city brokerage firm, reported that prices for one-bedroom rentals had fallen 10 to 12 percent and that two-bedroom rents were down 8 percent, according to Marge Pearson, the executive in charge of residential rentals at Elliman. 
At Citi Habitats, the city's largest rental agency, one-bedroom apartments that were once $3,300 a month are now listed near $2,700; studios that once brought $2,200 to $2,400 now bring $1,950 to $2,000. The agency has about 5,000 listings, said Andrew S. Heiberger, the company president. "That's double what we had about six months ago," he added.
Most brokers agree that since October, "special offers" to tenants and rental agents have increased. Mr. Edwards said Halstead's 54 agents had been barraged by landlords' offers of markdowns and bonuses. One recent flier offered $1,000 off the first month's rent for apartments in a new building at Rutgers Street and East Broadway on the Lower East Side.
"Not a day goes by when we don't get a pile of e-mails or faxes from landlords, reducing prices," Mr. Edwards said on Thursday, brandishing a stack of markdown offers from that day. "And every day, I get calls from the owners of new buildings, asking where the agents are. The agents are sitting at their desks, waiting for the phones to ring."
Just last Thursday, Joseph Moinian, the developer of 1 West Street, a new building, gave a catered party for agents and tried to persuade them, with promises of bonuses, to bring their clients.
Within the last few months, the number of discretionary renters -- those who are not forced to move but want a bigger or nicer apartment -- fell off significantly, Mr. Edwards said. "The majority of our renters are now people who have to move: people who are relocating, selling their apartments here or getting married, or divorced."
Landlords who last June could pick and choose tenants, along with which calls to take from agents, now fax listings across Manhattan. "Bring Offers!" shouts a faxed listing for a loft on East 12th Street. "New Lower Price!" reads a landlord's fax for a parlor floor in a brownstone on West 9th Street.
"As per our conversation," one Upper West Side owner wrote in longhand, "please lower our rental to $2,900 for this weekend's ad" -- down from $3,100. 
At the still-unfinished Trump World Tower, near the United Nations, one broker is offering a $2,000 bonus to the agent who finds a renter for apartment 10E, a two-bedroom, for $9,500. Across town, Lee Moncho, an English investor who owns one of Donald Trump's new condominium apartments on the Upper West Side, said that last spring, he could have rented his two-bedroom for $6,950 a month. Last week, Mr. Moncho settled for $5,000. "I wanted a warm body -- and secure money," he said. "I'll take that any time."
Though the number of leases signed typically declines around the holidays -- Mr. Heiberger estimated an average of 10 percent -- this year it is down 15 to 25 percent at several brokerage firms that keep statistics on rentals (many do not).
Agents are quick to point out that not every building or apartment has been affected. Buildings in secondary locations, neighborhoods that have less of the cachet and amenities of Greenwich Village, the Upper West Side, Carnegie Hill or other prime areas, were among the first to feel the tug toward price reductions. But even in those prime areas, agents say, landlords have become negotiable, lowering rents in individual deals. "The biggest drops are in the older buildings, where one-bedrooms were overpriced at $3,700, $3,800," said Ms. Pearson of Douglas Elliman. Ms. McCoy of Feathered Nest emphasized that apartments were still renting, although prices were "more conservative." 
Some real estate agents say they welcome the price adjustments. Marilyn Harra Kaye, president of Prudential MLBKaye International Realty, said the reductions, which she documented in a score of examples, were "a healthy thing."
"We've been losing renters to Westchester, to New Jersey and to the other boroughs for so long that rents coming down in Manhattan is good news," she said.
As newcomers frightened by Manhattan's high rents turned toward the outlying boroughs and other locations, prices rose significantly there, but still remained lower than in Manhattan. In the prime Park Slope section of Brooklyn, prices soared, but one-bedrooms were still 25 percent lower than in Manhattan, said Mark L. Pipes, a rental agent with William B. May Real Estate. In the commuter neighborhoods of New Jersey, rents may be even cheaper. While prices may be starting to stabilize in these outlying areas, they have not started to drop, brokers say. Only in the high-rent parts of Brooklyn Heights are landlords slightly more negotiable these days, Mr. Pipes said.
In Manhattan, one bedrooms that rent for less than $2,500 move fast. "Anything under $2,500 for a one bedroom still flies off the hook," Mr. Heiberger said. "Studios under $1,800 fly, too." 
Mr. Heiberger told cautionary tales of landlords and co-op owners who wanted to sublet last year, but who held out too long. "One guy on 11th Street between Fifth and Sixth thought he could get $20,000 a month," the agent said. "He held out all summer. He turned down offers of $16,000 and $17,000. In December, he took $9,800."
In July and August, Ms. Pearson said, rental prices were still climbing 15 to 17 percent over the previous year's figures through most of Manhattan -- with gains of 20 to 22 percent in buildings downtown. "Rises like that are definitely a thing of the past," she said last week. "And the owner paying the fee? We haven't seen that in years."
Rents will probably go up again eventually, predicted Michael Moran, the listings and operations manager at the Corcoran Group -- but probably not before they have further dipped, especially in certain areas. "Within the next 12 months, there will be close to 10 new buildings opening in the downtown-west area," he said of the Chelsea section, between West 20th and 30th Streets. "This will surely bring down rents, and I am sure landlords will be more flexible in lease terms."
After stock values tumbled in the late 1980's, rents stayed high for two years. "This time, the landlords are responding much more quickly," Mr. Edwards said. 
Manhattan's landlords are "positioning themselves to avoid surprises," Ms. Pearson said. "The market will shake itself out."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Nestle Seen as Ready to Buy Ralston Purina

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

 BODY:
Nestle, the world's largest food company, has agreed to acquire the Ralston Purina Group, the leading producer of pet food in the United States, for $10.1 billion in cash, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday. 
 The boards of both companies approved the deal yesterday, the executives said, and the transaction is expected to be announced today. 
 Under the terms of the deal, Nestle, whose products range from Perrier bottled water and Alpo dog food to the candy bars that bear its name, will pay $33.50 for each share of Ralston, a 36 percent premium over the closing price of $24.63 on Friday. The markets were closed yesterday in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday. 
Neither company would comment on the deal, which gives Nestle control of well-known brands like Purina Puppy Chow and Meow Mix. But analysts agreed that it provided Nestle, of Vevey, Switzerland, which had more than $46 billion in sales in 1999, with a way of weaning itself away from dependence on comparatively slow-growth foods like candy while strengthening its hold on the promising pet food business.
The prospective deal was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.
In the last year, a flurry of mergers has reduced the food industry to a handful of primary competitors, all seeking to establish strength through scale. But Nestle's acquisition of Ralston, which had $2.76 billion in revenue in 2000, is the first major consolidation in what has been, until now, a relatively fractured and competitive pet food industry.
By adding Ralston's nearly 27 percent share of the pet food market to the 18.6 percent it already commands, Nestle, the maker of Fancy Feast and Mighty Dog, leaps from a fairly distant second place to the industry's dominant company. Its closest competitor, Mars Inc., the family-owned company that makes Pedigree and Whiskas, holds less than a 15 percent share -- potentially raising red flags with regulators. 
"I think Nestle is going to have a big problem with antitrust issues on this one," said Kieran Mahon of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney in London. "Their market share is going to be far too high for the Federal Trade Commission's liking." Such concerns might be allayed, were Nestle to sell some of its brands.
Underlying the deal is the reality that cat food and dog biscuits represent some of the best prospects for growth in a struggling food industry. With consumers cooking less and snacking more, companies from Kellogg to Campbell have watched with dismay as some of their simplest meals to prepare, like cold cereal and condensed soups, steadily lose their standing in a marketplace hungry for convenience.
But the trend toward eating out more often hardly applies to pets, and with the dog and cat population growing around 4 percent a year -- roughly twice the rate of humans -- the market to feed them has blossomed. In the last year, pet food sales have grown 5.3 percent, according to Information Resource Inc., a market research firm in Chicago. That is more than twice as fast as the sales of food for people.
One reason for the pet food boom is that pet owners, feeling flush in the strong economy, have been more willing to indulge their animals with the market's tastier, more nutritious and, of course, more expensive offerings. And even though consumers are buying more generic sodas and cereal for their families, they have turned premium brands and pet treats into one of the fastest-growing segments of the pet food industry. 
"There's a lot of pampering going on," said Jaine Mehring, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "But we don't know whether if and when there's an economic slowdown, that will change." 
Ralston Purina, one of the few big food companies to sit out the industry's consolidation trend last year, is particularly well positioned in the shift toward premium-price nutrition. Sales of the company's stalwart but somewhat mundane brands like Puppy Chow and Dog Chow have fallen in the last year, but its premium line of dog food, Purina One, was one of the industry's best performers, with sales that grew almost 10 percent. Purina's dog biscuit and treat business also grew nearly 10 percent, bolstered by the ever-greater inclination to do well by the family pet. 
Once a diverse company itself, with everything from cereal to ski resorts, Ralston, based in St. Louis, has spent the last several years paring itself down to focus on pet food and kitty litter. In 1998, it spun off its animal-feeds business as Agribrands International, then did the same with its Eveready battery division last April.
Newly winnowed to its fast-growing pet food business, Ralston became a potential takeover target almost immediately. Although Nestle had spent the last two years casting off its ancillary brands and backing away from acquisitions at a time when most of its rivals were seeking them out, analysts say it was now forced to move swiftly. 
"If Ralston Purina went to Procter & Gamble or Colgate, that would be potentially damaging for Nestle," said Sylvain Mossat of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. 
Buying Ralston provides Nestle with a chance to realize the 4 percent annual growth that it has chased for almost a decade, but has narrowly failed to achieve. Only 20 percent of Ralston's sales come from overseas markets, and analysts widely expect Nestle to use its presence in virtually every country to turn the Purina name into a global powerhouse. 
Nestle would also be expected to strengthen its bargaining position with retailers, one factor that has driven food companies to consolidate. Pet food is an important item for supermarkets and discount stores like Wal-Mart because it can be hard to find elsewhere and, thus it brings consumers into the store. But unlike some other drivers of store traffic, like eggs, pet food sales offer a sizable profit to retailers, a factor they are likely to consider when negotiating prices with major producers like Nestle.

HEADLINE: Designee Takes a Deft Touch And a Firm Will to Treasury 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
When Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary-designate, became chief executive of Alcoa Inc. in 1987, the Rust Belt company's prospects were so dim that it had one foot out of the aluminum business and was facing an uncertain future, if it had one at all. 
 A dozen years later, when Mr. O'Neill retired, Alcoa was the world's biggest and richest aluminum producer, its new headquarters were winning architectural raves, its bottom line was fat and its shareholders were happy. Alcoa's stock was Wall Street's hottest performer that year, besting such investor darlings as the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation. 
 Just how Mr. O'Neill, a bureaucrat turned businessman, revived Alcoa's fortunes provides a glimpse into the man who has been designated to carry out -- and influence -- the Bush economic plan at a time of increasing financial uncertainty and general business unease. 
At Alcoa, Mr. O'Neill engineered a financial turnaround through such deft moves as promoting worker safety as a way of improving productivity, setting corporate goals that seemed unrealistically high but were ultimately attained, breaking down bureaucratic walls with a minimum of corporate bloodshed and melding new technologies with old ones as he expanded the Alcoa empire across the globe.
At times so quiet as to seem almost meek, Mr. O'Neill displayed a firm determination to pursue long-term strategic goals even if it meant forsaking short-term profits or breaking with industry practice. On the flip side, this single-mindedness gave Mr. O'Neill a reputation for not suffering fools easily and for displaying a doggedness that could, at times, border on the inflexible and made it hard to build consensus. 
"Paul O'Neill took a very difficult situation and turned it into a winner," said Ira Millstein, a New York lawyer and an adviser to corporate boards. "And he did it through a number of bold steps."
When other companies lowered aluminum prices to make a quick dollar, Mr. O'Neill instead cut Alcoa's production. Where other companies were run by fiat, he managed by articulating shared corporate values and building internal consensus. Where other companies made profits their No. 1 goal, Mr. O'Neill chose productivity and worker safety. And where others begged Washington for protectionism, Mr. O'Neill offered creative alternatives.
"Paul is a very strategic thinker," said Judith M. Gueron, an Alcoa director. "To move an ocean liner like Alcoa in a new direction, he had to have an overall message that would inspire, and he had to build coherence and enlist the passions of his staff. He was very canny in all that."
His strategy paid off. Alcoa reached new heights of profitability, and Mr. O'Neill pulled off the remarkable feat of making money in an industry that was losing it.
"Many on Wall Street look like heroes because they made money when the market was rising," said John Tumazos, an industry analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, a Wall Street broker. "Paul took Alcoa's stock from $5 to $40 at a time when aluminum prices were falling. He created enormous shareholder wealth when everyone in the industry was on a downhill slide."
On the surface, Mr. O'Neill, who dropped out of college at 19 to marry (he later graduated from Fresno State College), hardly seemed destined for the executive suite. A bureaucrat for 16 years, he rose through the arcane world of systems analysis to become President Gerald R. Ford's deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget. While there, Mr. O'Neill, who declined to be interviewed for this article, cemented friendships with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Dick Cheney, the vice president-elect, and Donald H. Rumsfeld, the defense secretary-designate, all of whom were Ford administration officials.
"We were working on god-awful economic problems and everything looked bad," said Paul W. MacAvoy, a Ford economic adviser who is now a Yale University professor. "Greenspan. Cheney. Rumsfeld. They were all there. Time and again, Ford would turn to Paul and say, 'Is that right?' And in his quiet, direct way, Paul had the answers. He could be asked about shoe imports and Paul would know the number."
Those Oval Office connections paid off, 10 years later, when Mr. Greenspan, then an Alcoa board member, was part of a group that recruited Mr. O'Neill to become the first outsider to head Alcoa in its hundred-year history.
At the time, Mr. O'Neill was a new director on the Alcoa board and president of the International Paper Company. In a quiet boardroom coup orchestrated, in part, by Mr. Greenspan, Alcoa's top managers were all taken to lunch at an elegant Manhattan club and ousted. Mr. O'Neill was tapped to perform the alchemy of turning Alcoa aluminum into cash.
"We wanted someone with fresh eyes," said Franklin Thomas, an Alcoa board member. "Paul was someone who asked targeted questions, was persistent in his attention to the issues and wouldn't take an answer he thought was mechanical or prepared. He wanted people to think on their feet and anchor their thoughts with data."
Immediately Mr. O'Neill took Alcoa's focus away from an ill-fated diversification plan and back to its core business. He broke up Alcoa's "command and control" structure and replaced it with 20 autonomous units to respond to customers and report to him directly. He wiped away symbols of corporate excess, eliminated the corporate limousine and began to fly commercial class.
He immediately turned down a membership in a prestigious Pittsburgh golf club because it banned women and blacks, and he forbade the use of Alcoa money for dues at clubs that discriminated. He moved out of the executive suite and into a cubicle like everyone else.
But mostly, he figured out how to make money -- not by cutting costs or the payroll, but by improving factory productivity and making worker safety his top goal. In addition to being an altruistic goal, his push on worker safety had bottom-line benefits. He argued that a production process that was so flawed that workers got hurt was one that could not turn out high-quality products efficiently and cost-effectively.
"Every speech he made began with a discussion of safety," said one Wall Street analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "He'd go visit investors and talk about safety. They could care less and he's off for 20 minutes on it. But he would say, 'I'm trying to create a cultural change. If I can unify employees on the obvious issue of safety, I can unify them behind return on investment and assets.' "
Mr. O'Neill's attention to safety was so acute that he would often begin speeches by pointing out where the fire exits were.
He won over the unions by telling workers that if they worked smarter and more efficiently, productivity gains would not cost them their jobs. He promised to expand Alcoa's business to keep them employed, and he did so through joint ventures, international acquisitions and new aluminum product lines. When he came to Alcoa, the work force numbered 59,000; when he left, the company had 140,000 employees in 36 countries.
"The unions feared that if productivity improved, half the workers would get fired," said Daniel A. Roling, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company. "O'Neill told them he would grow the business. They grudgingly accepted and then improved productivity dramatically and cut costs."
George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said Mr. O'Neill's emphasis on worker safety was "very sincere" and "one of his strong points." Mr. Becker said he also welcomed Mr. O'Neill's selection since "he understands the need to manufacture things and he's not from Wall Street."
In addition, Mr. O'Neill aligned everyone's financial interest with Alcoa's. He devised an innovative "floating dividend" program providing shareholders with higher dividends in years of exceptional profitability. Rank-and-file factory workers received profit bonuses, and executive pay was tied to profitability.
Once Alcoa gained financial stability, it went on a buying spree, picking up depressed former state-run aluminum makers in Hungary, Italy and Spain as well as taking over the No. 3 domestic producer, Alumax Inc., and then buying its main rival, the Reynolds Metal Company, in August 1999. The Reynolds deal was made three months after Mr. O'Neill retired as chief executive, although he was still the company's chairman. 
Everyone got rich under Mr. O'Neill's tenure -- including Mr. O'Neill. Alcoa's revenues grew to $16.3 billion in 1999 from $9.8 billion in 1988, and the company's market capitalization -- the value of its outstanding shares held by stockholders -- rose to $30.5 billion from $4 billion. 
Last year, Mr. O'Neill took home $36.1 million from Alcoa: a $950,400 base salary, a $2 million bonus and $33.1 million in stock options that he exercised. He also holds options on millions of Alcoa shares that the company values at $86.3 million in government filings.
Most important, Mr. O'Neill bucked the boom-and-bust cycle of aluminum prices by not cutting prices when the competition did -- even if it cost Alcoa in the short run. And he did not raise prices when others did, fearing that customers would seek cheaper alternatives. He correctly reasoned that Alcoa would do best with stable prices.
"Paul turned Alcoa into a company that would be profitable, even when the other companies in the industry weren't," said Marina Whitman, an Alcoa director and an economist. "He wanted to adopt pricing policies to even out the hills and valleys and convince customers it was in their best interest to to have stable pricing. Paul was convinced that not only were big drops in prices a problem, so were big rises."
He also reached out to the United States government. In 1993, when a ravaged Russian industry began dumping cheap aluminum on world markets and prices plunged, Mr. O'Neill went to Washington.
His argument to the Clinton administration was that Alcoa could bring an antidumping suit against Russia and probably win. But, fearing protectionism, he suggested an alternative. Mr. O'Neill voluntarily cut Alcoa's annual aluminum production by 25 percent and urged the administration to press European countries to cut production voluntarily as well. He reasoned that if global output shrank, prices would rise.
In order not to violate international antitrust law, the effort had to be taken government by government. In the end, six nations, including Russia, signed a memorandum of understanding to cut aluminum output, and prices stabilized. The cutbacks had the added benefit of causing many inefficient European aluminum plants to close.
"Paul had to convince the government to do it, so he wouldn't go to jail for restraint of trade," Mr. Tumazos said. "What he proposed was not unlike the kind of agreements made during currency crises and monetary fund bailouts."
In 1994, Mr. O'Neill joined with four other industrial chief executives to meet with White House officials and argue that the economy could be allowed to grow at a faster pace through lower interest rates without triggering inflation. It is a position Mr. O'Neill repeated in his first news conference as treasury secretary-designate -- and one certain to please corporate America.
But on other questions he would face as treasury secretary, his corporate background offers few clues. While he sharply cut Alcoa's debt, he has made no statements on the debate over tax cuts versus deficit reduction. As an exporter he would be expected to favor a weaker dollar, but he has made no statements on this question either.

HEADLINE: Forstmann, Buyout Firm, Agrees to Buy Citadel Communications 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

 BODY:
Forstmann Little & Company, the leveraged buyout firm, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire Citadel Communications, one of the nation's largest radio broadcasters in midsize markets, for about $1 billion in cash, executives close to the talks said.
 The board of Citadel, which owns 143 FM stations and 66 AM stations in 44 markets nationwide, approved the sale late last night. The transaction is still subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission and shareholders. 
 The deal, which includes the assumption of $1 billion in debt, should be a boon for Citadel, which has been on an acquisition spree. The injection of capital from Forstmann Little will help Citadel continue to gobble up stations and refinance the substantial debt it built during its buying binge. 
Still, Forstmann Little will face enormous challenges with its first investment in more than a year. It is buying into an industry that is dependent on a strong advertising market just as the economy is beginning to sour and companies begin to trim their advertising budgets.
For Theodore J. Forstmann, however, buying at the bottom is the only way to buy, and he is ready for a possible downturn in advertising.
"We're prepared for a not exactly exciting patch here," Mr. Forstmann said in an interview. "We've accommodated it. But we've got a lot to do and now we can do it in the peace and security of a private company. It couldn't get a lot bigger as a public company."
Indeed, Larry Wilson, Citadel's founder and chief executive, said he began considering a sale after he spoke with Mr. Forstmann in October about the company's future as a public company. "The choppy public market, the debt level and facing the possibility of a slowing economy made me consider selling out," Mr. Wilson said.
Under the deal, Forstmann Little will pay $26 a share in cash for each share of Citadel, a premium of 48.6 percent over the stock's price of $17.50 on Friday. The stock market was closed yesterday in observance of Martin Luther King's Birthday.
Forstmann Little plans to finance the transaction with $1.5 billion from its equity and subordinated debt funds in addition to a $500 million loan from affiliates of J. P. Morgan Chase. Mr. Forstmann's capital structure allowed him to take on Citadel's debt at a time when most other leveraged buyout firms are struggling to finance deals with junk bonds.
For Mr. Wilson, who founded Citadel in 1984 with two radio stations in Tucson, the sale will allow him to "not worry" while he stays on to "build this thing." Indeed, Mr. Wilson, a former lawyer and accountant, may be more like a investment banker than a broadcaster, wheeling and dealing his way into control of 209 radio stations.
Mr. Forstmann has completed 27 major deals, including buying Gulfstream Aerospace, General Instrument, Topps baseball cards and Dr Pepper. He said he thought that more acquisitions through Citadel could be possible. "If a big opportunity comes along, it might be a whole different company in two years," he said.
But for now, at least, it may be tough going. In fact, the strains on the advertising climate may already be showing. Citadel missed its third-quarter earnings estimates as its loss widened to $11.2 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $2.8 million, or 9 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. However, sales rose 55 percent, to $78.2 million from $50.5 million.
But Mr. Forstmann insists he is a long-term player. When asked what his exit strategy might be, he said he had not thought of one yet.
Citadel was advised by Credit Suisse First Boston.
