HEADLINE: Killing for the Glory of God, In a Land Far From Home 

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MILLER

DATELINE: PANJSHIR VALLEY, Afghanistan 

 BODY:
Muhammad Khaled Mihraban, a polite, soft-spoken 26-year-old Pakistani, thinks he has already killed at least 100 people. Maybe more; he isn't really sure.
 "My goal was not to kill," he said. "But I had a line to follow, an Islamic ideal. I knew that Muslims needed their own country, a real Islamic country." 
 Mr. Mihraban found that country when he came to Afghanistan in 1992. Having decided "to consecrate my life to jihad" while studying Islamic law at Punjab University in Lahore, he said, he joined a Pakistani militant group that was fighting India in the disputed province of Kashmir. His training took place in Afghanistan. 
"We learned how to plant mines, how to make bombs using dynamite and how to kill someone quietly," he recalled.
A gifted student, he was soon asked to train others in group camps near Khost. "But I wanted to act, not teach," he explained. So after a stint waging war in Kashmir, he returned to Kabul to fight alongside the Taliban forces that control most of the country.
Mr. Mihraban, who was captured by the rebels fighting the Taliban in northern Afghanistan, said in an interview in a bleak prison that if he were released, he would "stay right here and fight again for Kabul." If he were asked to do so, he said, he would go to London, Paris or New York and blow up women and children for Islam. "Yes, I would do it," he said quietly, without hesitation.
If the international terrorism that has haunted Americans for the last decade has a home, it is Afghanistan, the place that comes closest to the extremists' ideal of a state ruled by the strict code of Islamic law.
Afghanistan is an inspiration, an essential base of operations, a reservoir of potential suicide bombers and a battle front where crucial ties are forged. It is also, American officials say, where Osama bin Laden is experimenting with chemical weapons.
Participants in nearly every plot against the United States and its allies during the last decade have learned the arts of war and explosives in Afghan camps, authorities say, including the defendants in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa.
The Central Intelligence Agency estimates that as many as 50,000 to 70,000 militants from 55 countries have trained here in recent years. The agency says the Taliban permit a wide range of groups to operate in Afghan territory, from the Pakistani militants who trained Mr. Mihraban to Mr. bin Laden's organization Al Qaeda (Arabic for The Base). Middle East officials said that as many as 5,000 recruits have passed through Mr. bin Laden's camps.
American and Middle Eastern intelligence officials believe that Mr. bin Laden maintains a network of a dozen camps in Afghanistan that offer training in small arms and in explosives and logistics for terrorist attacks. The officials said the embassy bombings, which killed more than 200 people, were rehearsed on a model built to scale at one of Mr. bin Laden's Afghan camps.
One camp, according to those officials, is educating a new generation of recruits in the uses of chemicals, poisons and toxins.
Within the last year, trainees at the camp, which is called Abu Khabab, have experimented on dogs, rabbits and other animals with nerve gases, the officials said. Recruits have also fashioned bombs made from commercially available chemicals and poisons, which have been tried out on animals tethered to outdoor posts on the camp test range, according to surveillance photographs and informers' reports. 
"The role of Afghanistan is now absolutely clear," said Michael A. Sheehan, the former coordinator of the State Department's Office of Counterterrorism, who in late December became assistant secretary general for peacekeeping operations for the United Nations. "Every Islamic militant we've looked at goes scurrying back there for sanctuary. Afghanistan, and to a lesser extent Iran, are the only major sanctuaries left."

The Training
Where Recruits Study Tactics and Explosives
Middle Eastern officials estimate that in the last six months, more than 100 men recruited by Mr. bin Laden's and affiliated groups have been trained at the camp, which is named after the Egyptian militant who runs it, Midhat Mursi -- whose nom de guerre is Abu Khabab.
The camp is part of a large complex of such training sites known as Darunta, about eight miles from Jalalabad, an Afghan eastern provincial capital, down a dusty road that runs atop an old stone dam of the same name. According to Western and Middle Eastern officials, a cache of chemicals is stored in the reinforced caves of nearby mountains and naturally protected underground tunnels.
Abu Khabab's graduates in the last year include Raed Hijazi, the Jordanian-American whom Jordan has convicted in absentia as a ringleader of the failed plot to attack tourists in Amman during the millennium celebrations. 
Mr. Hijazi, whom the Syrians arrested in October and sent back to Jordan, has described his advanced training on explosives to Jordanian investigators, according to Western officials. He has told investigators that a key lieutenant of Mr. bin Laden helped arrange his trip to Afghanistan.
A rare reference to the explosives training at the Abu Khabab camp appears in the sealed indictment of Nabil abu Aukel, a Palestinian arrested last June by Israel.
Israel has accused Mr. Aukel of collaborating with Hamas, or the Party of God, the militant Palestinian organization, and several Arab-Israelis on plots aimed at military and civilian targets inside Israel. The indictment, a copy of which was provided by Steven Emerson, an American expert on Islamic terrorism, states that Mr. Aukel, a Palestinian, received advanced training in explosives using chemicals at the Abu Khabab camp in March 1998.
The camp leader warned Mr. Aukel "never to discuss the nature of the training," the indictment says. Israeli officials said Mr. Aukel's arrest marked first time Israel had uncovered an Al Qaeda cell inside its borders.
At the urging of the United States and Russia, which also sees a threat from Afghan training camps, the United Nations recently imposed the harshest economic sanctions on Afghanistan to press the Taliban not only to evict Mr. bin Laden and his senior entourage, but also to close down all the militant camps to foreigners.
The Taliban, or "students of Islam," who rule all but a sliver of Afghanistan, deny that they harbor terrorists or those who train them. Wakil Ahmad Mutawakil, the Taliban foreign minister, said the pressure to expel Mr. bin Laden was both "insulting and useless." Mr. Mutawakil denied in an interview in November that Mr. bin Laden was financing the Taliban, saying he had become a "very poor man." Mr. bin Laden, the foreign minister said, could not possibly be planning terrorist operations since his activities were "closely supervised by Afghan guards."
Mr. Mutawakil recently invited a New York Times reporter to visit any location in Afghanistan identified by Western officials as part of Mr. bin Laden's network.
But Taliban officials in Afghanistan ultimately barred the reporter from visiting any of the locations. At Darunta, the reporter was stopped several miles from the gates of the complex. After five days in Kabul, Jalalabad and environs, the reporter and her Afghan-American interpreter were politely escorted to the border and told to leave Afghanistan.

The Inspiration
Afghanistan's Appeal As a War Zone
The Afghan cause has inspired several generations of young men determined to wage holy war. Thousands came here in the 1980's to fight the Soviet forces in response to a fatwa, or religious order, from leading Islamic scholars. Thousands more have come since then to help the Taliban expand their power, or to be trained for jihads elsewhere. 
Taliban officials boast that they have imposed true Islamic rule, cleansing Afghan society of Western influence. Since their capture of Kabul in 1996, they have among other things banned education for girls and most work for women, and instituted harsh punishments for blasphemy, playing cards, watching television, listening to music and trimming one's beard.
Mr. bin Laden arrived in Afghanistan in 1996 after he was expelled from Sudan. American officials and Afghan opponents of the Taliban say their loyalty to him has been well earned. The officials say Mr. bin Laden provided the Taliban with some of the cash they used to buy off local warlords in their march to power.
His financial support of the Taliban is said to continue. Several diplomats and aid workers in Afghanistan estimated that he had put up millions of dollars -- one diplomat's estimate was $40 million -- to rebuild roads destroyed in the war against the Soviets and the ensuing civil war. 
Mr. bin Laden is also said to be providing the Taliban with military help.
Ahmed Shah Massoud, commander of a group of rebels in northern Afghanistan, said in an interview at his headquarters that he was fighting a unit of soldiers specially trained by Mr. bin Laden, the 55th Brigade, which includes some 700 Arabs and other militant Muslims. Mr. Massoud said he had captured brigade members, whom he called the most seasoned fighters.
Despite financial aid and weapons from Iran and Russia, Mr. Massoud's alliance lost ground to the Taliban last year. His forces are now confined largely to the northern region's impregnable Panjshir Valley with its soaring, snow-tipped mountains and dazzling vistas.
Mr. Massoud said his soldiers were holding some 1,200 Taliban prisoners, 122 of them foreign Muslims. There are Pakistanis, an immigrant to Pakistan from the Burmese province of Arakan, Yemenis, Britons and Chinese Uigurs, among others. Interviews with several of them illustrate the attraction that Afghanistan still has for militants around the world.
Mr. Mihraban, the young Pakistani, comes from the town of Chaghi, in the province of Baluchistan. His gentle eyes and polite manner gave no hint of the fervor that had led him to this stark prison in the harsh, craggy mountains of the Hindu Kush. 
His trip to Afghanistan began when he joined Harakat ul Mujahedeen, a group whose dedication to unlocking India's grip on Kashmir has landed it on the State Department's list of terror groups. He trained first in 1992 at the Salman i Farsi camp in Baktiah, Afghanistan, which was run by Harakat. He said he also fought in Tajikistan.
Obeida Rahman, 21, a Yemeni from Sana from a poor family of 10 children, had his living and training expenses in Afghanistan paid for by the teachers at his madrassa, or religious academy. They had urged him to fight in Afghanistan against his family's wishes, he said. He had relished his training. "When you have a gun, you're free," he said. "You feel as if you can do anything."
Abdul Jalil, 21, from Kashgar in Xingiang Province, China, said that despite his capture, he was glad that he had come and fought in Afghanistan on the $1,000 his father, a farmer, gave him to study. "I still want to create an Islamic state all over the world, God willing," he said. When he is released, he said, "I will go fight a jihad in China."
The goal of returning home to continue the jihad is common among the prisoners. Julie Sirrs, a former Defense Intelligence Agency analyst who has interviewed many of the non-Afghan prisoners held by Mr. Massoud, said nearly half belonged to groups that the State Department has designated as terrorist. None had ever met Mr. bin Laden, they said, but he was their hero. Ms. Sirrs, now an independent consultant, financed her own studies of the prisoners. 
In an interview at one of his camps in the Panjshir Valley in late summer, Mr. Massoud said his prisoners had been deluded into believing that they were fighting a jihad in Afghanistan by helping the Taliban.
The prisoners, he said, are in fact "sinners" for conducting terrorism and violating Islam's injunction against fomenting division within Muslim ranks. "My message to those fighting in Afghanistan now is that they will never get God's blessing for what they are doing in my country," he declared.

The Enablers
How Islamic Schools Urge Students On
American officials acknowledge that they have limited influence over the Taliban, who they say have a powerful regional ally in Pakistan.
Relief officials and Afghans said they saw soldiers in Pakistan Army uniforms fighting for the Taliban last summer and fall. The witnesses reported that Pakistani Army buses with blackened windows and burlap-covered trucks filled with weapons and supplies routinely crossed into Afghanistan heading for the front near Taliqan, a northern town that the government captured last fall. 
Mr. Massoud and relief officials in Afghanistan said the Taliban were finding it ever harder to recruit fighters for the civil war and had even encountered armed resistance to their recruitment missions in different towns and villages. The Taliban forces, he asserted, are increasingly dependent on Pakistani soldiers and students sent to the front to fight for the Islamic cause. 
Pakistan denies that it has sent soldiers to fight alongside the Taliban. But diplomats, relief workers and Afghans interviewed in Kabul and Jalalabad insist that Pakistan has provided not only weapons, logistical and other assistance, but soldiers as well.
"Some soldiers apparently came to fight; others for just a look-see at real fighting," said a United Nations official who visited areas near the front during the offensive. "The Taliban were doing quite badly at first. But there is no doubt that Pakistani support gradually turned the tide."
There are also suggestions that Pakistani authorities have pressed students to fight for the Taliban. One relief worker who visited the Indira Gandhi Children's Hospital in Kabul in late June said that all of its 400 beds were filled by Pakistanis wounded at the front, some as young as 15. Several patients said that they had been sent to fight by their religious academies, many of which closed for the summer battle season, leaving impoverished students with no place else to go. A doctor at the hospital said Chechens, Yemenis and Saudis were among the patients.
American officials say they have little leverage over Pakistan. The United States cut off military aid in 1990 after the Pakistanis detonated a nuclear bomb.
With no ally in the region to help, the Clinton administration has mounted a wide-ranging diplomatic campaign to isolate the Taliban militia from the world community. The effort bore fruit late last year when the United Nations, prodded by the United States and Russia, expanded economic sanctions on Afghanistan -- a change that will take effect on Jan. 19.
Senior American officials said that for all their concern about the threat of terrorism, the administration never explicitly offered the Taliban what they most want: formal diplomatic recognition. In its dealing with the Taliban, officials said, the administration promised only that relations would dramatically improve if they expelled Mr. bin Laden and Al Qaeda's leaders and barred foreigners from the camps. 
Officials said they decided against directly offering recognition, because, they said, the administration had profound reservations about the Taliban's abuses of human rights, particularly of women. 
Senior officials also felt that they could not trust the Taliban to deliver on their promises, citing what they called repeated "lies" from the Afghan leadership about Mr. bin Laden's status.
In late December, President Clinton's top national security advisers gathered in Washington to consider the next steps against the Taliban, including possible military action.
A senior C.I.A. official told the group that the bombing of the destroyer Cole in Yemen in October 2000 appeared to have been organized by Muhammad Omar al-Harazi, a longtime member of Al Qaeda also involved in an earlier attempt to destroy an American warship, The Sullivans, as it passed through Aden in January 2000. Mr. Harazi founded the first Al Qaeda cell in Saudi Arabia and was arrested in 1997, accused oftrying to smuggle antitank missiles into the kingdom. Between the failed attack on The Sullivans and the bombing of the Cole, officials said, Mr. Harazi fled to an Al Qaeda guest house in Kandahar, a Taliban stronghold. The C.I.A. said this evidence did not conclusively establish that the group ordered the attack.
Several officials at the meeting opposed military action on the ground that it would achieve little and would make Americans targets of further terrorist attacks. And officials said a military strike could even be counterproductive, enhancing Mr. bin Laden's public standing among militants. "Making him a hero is the last thing we want to do," said one senior American official. 

Holy Warriors

SUNDAY -- The making of an Islamic terror network.
MONDAY -- A look inside a plot that could have crippled Jordan's capital.
TODAY -- What motivates the jihad's young recruits.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Tuesday about Islamic militants who train in Afghanistan misstated the reason the United States cut off military aid in 1990 to Pakistan, which supports the government of Afghanistan. The United States suspected Pakistan of developing nuclear weapons; Pakistan's detonation of nuclear devices did not occur until 1998.
Because of an editing error, the article mistranslated Hamas, the name of the militant Palestinian organization linked by the Israelis to a man they arrested, who trained in Afghanistan. The name, an Arabic acronym, stands for Islamic Resistance Movement, not Party of God. Hamas is also an Arabic word for zeal or enthusiasm.
The article also misspelled the name of the region in China from which some members Uighur ethnic group have gone to fight in Afghanistan. It is Xinjiang, not Xingiang.

HEADLINE: Tears and a Confession From Another Rev. King 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The pressures of being the youngest daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were sometimes too intense for her to bear, the Rev. Bernice A. King told a reverent crowd at her father's old church today, in an unusually frank confession marking Dr. King's birthday.
 "It is difficult being the daughter of such an awesome man, to be his child and to live with the criticism and the ridicule, the persecution and the misunderstanding," said Ms. King, 37, speaking at her family's annual King Day service in the historic pulpit of the Ebenezer Baptist Church. "Sometimes I feel like backing off and honestly saying to hell with it all. But God has commissioned and commanded that I be true to what he has given me in this great legacy." 
 Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and four children have come under criticism in recent years for what is sometimes seen as a stingy guardianship of his legacy, in particular for suing news organizations and scholars who use excerpts from his speeches without paying the family. Members rarely discuss the issue, but today, in a passionate and apparently impromptu address in the old church that set other family members weeping, Ms. King forcefully defended the family's actions.
"It's difficult and it's challenging when people desire in their own way to exploit the message and the mission of Dr. King for their own personal gain," she said. "Yet when we seek to perpetuate the legacy in the way the Holy Ghost has told us to perpetuate it, and we just so happened to be blessed financially by it, it saddens me that people are confused. If it were your daddy, what would you do?"
The family's only desire is to ensure that Dr. King's legacy is presented properly, Ms. King said -- not to gain financially from its merchandising.
"It ain't about the money," she said. "If it were about the money, I would be wealthy today. If it were about the money, we wouldn't be here today. It's really about a heart to serve."
Ms. King, who was 5 when her father was assassinated in Memphis, is the only one of the four children to have followed her father into the ministry, and is often said to have inherited his oratorical gifts. She is assistant pastor at the Greater Rising Star Baptist Church in Atlanta, and travels widely delivering speeches and sermons on issues relating to Dr. King's message of justice and nonviolence.
Other family members who spoke at the service, along with prominent elected officials, stuck to more traditional themes of political action and economic justice. Coretta Scott King called for an end to mandatory minimum sentences, the elimination of the death penalty and the cancellation of Africa's debt to the West.
Gov. Roy Barnes of Georgia said that Maynard Jackson, the former mayor of Atlanta, should be chairman of the Democratic National Committee, a post Mr. Jackson is seeking. Senator Max Cleland of Georgia said a flawed voting system was undermining Dr. King's goal of universal enfranchisement, and said he would introduce a bill providing grants to states to eliminate punchcard voting machines.
The keynote speaker, Andrew Young, the former Atlanta mayor and United Nations representative, said it was time that supporters of Vice President Al Gore recognized that George W. Bush was about to become the country's legitimate president, even as they continued to criticize a flawed balloting system that might have produced that result. That does not mean, Mr. Young said, that blacks should support Mr. Bush's ideas or nominees.
"I know John Ashcroft," he said, speaking of Mr. Bush's choice for attorney general. "He really is a nice guy. We've worked together on some things pertaining to Africa. But he just isn't supposed to be attorney general at a time like this."
Mr. Young called on the Bush administration to work harder to bring the country together, and by the same token he called on black leaders to pay more attention to the problems and concerns of white people living in poverty.
None of the Kings at the service spoke about the current effort to change the Georgia flag, which is dominated by the Confederate battle symbol, although Jack F. Kemp, the former Republican vice-presidential candidate, said it was time to end such symbols of disunity. Dr. King's oldest son, Martin Luther King III, was at a ceremony in Philadelphia today, and told reporters that the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, his father's civil rights organization that he now leads, would call for economic sanctions against Georgia if the flag was not changed in the current legislative session.
But it was Bernice King who had the most emotional effect on the crowd. While others may miss the teachings of a great civil rights leader, she said, she had to struggle with simply wanting her father back.
"Daddy, I'm going to try my best to let you go and allow God to have his way in my life," she said, as many on the pulpit wiped away tears. "Even though from time to time I have a little anger and bitterness and a little disappointment, and feel a little bit abandoned, I'm going to press on to the mark of a higher calling in Christ Jesus, and I'll see you soon on the other side. And we will have a great and true celebration."

HEADLINE: Clinton's One Big Idea 

BYLINE:  By Robert Wright; Robert Wright, a columnist for Slate, is author of "The Moral Animal" and, most recently, "Nonzero: The Logic of Human Destiny."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
According to one standard view, President Bill Clinton began his presidency with big ideas and ended it with little ones. After health care reform collapsed and welfare reform began working its way through Congress, he had run out of ambitious proposals and so confined himself to crowd-pleasing, small-bore policy initiatives: school uniforms, cell phones for neighborhood watch groups, a zillion targeted tax cuts.
 As the season for appraising Mr. Clinton's legacy reaches its climax, this stereotype shows signs of sticking. Some pundits explicitly complain about the lack of a grand unifying theme in his presidency, while others just fail to find one. 
 But I think that future historians will have no trouble finding a unifying theme in the Clinton years, and that its importance will become only clearer as the decades pass. At a pivotal moment in history, Mr. Clinton steered the Democratic Party through a dangerous crossroads, shaping its identity as momentously as Franklin Roosevelt did. 
I'm not talking about Mr. Clinton's much-discussed pulling of the party toward the center of the ideological spectrum. Welfare reform was important, and so was the administration's overall fiscal discipline, but these things are reversible. 
I'm talking about the party's choice between economic nationalism and global economic engagement. Here Mr. Clinton has put Democrats on a course that will be hard to abandon and that could ultimately serve their constituents in ways many prominent Democrats still don't appreciate.
It is easy to forget how deeply the Democratic Party was divided over the North American Free Trade Agreement and the subsequent creation of the World Trade Organization. Today, seven years after Nafta was supposed to have begun ruining the American job market, the unemployment rate is so low that only the stiffest of recessions could boost it to pre-Clinton levels. And the low inflation rate -- which leaves Alan Greenspan free to fight any recession -- is due largely to imports from low-wage countries. So, naturally, Democratic protectionists in Congress -- or "fair traders," as they call themselves -- have quieted down.
But even as old-style Democrats admit that Mr. Clinton's free-trade agenda proved sub-apocalyptic, they still don't acknowledge his larger accomplishment. By ushering in the W.T.O., he has laid the rudiments of a system of global governance that, if wisely nurtured, will decades from now protect America's low-wage workers and its natural environment.
Before the World Trade Organization, the regime that "governed" global trade -- the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- had no teeth. Today the W.T.O., by adjudicating trade disputes and authorizing sanctions against violators, arguably constitutes the most effective body of world governance in the history of the planet.
Of course, this is exactly what some on the left have faulted Mr. Clinton for. The W.T.O., in addressing subtle, non-tariff barriers to trade, can trample on cherished liberal policies: export subsidies designed to help American workers, laws aimed at saving sea turtles from the nets of foreign fishermen.
Yet in the long run, this very intrusiveness is the best hope for preserving the values of liberal Democrats. Free trade, left ungoverned, can yield the infamous "race to the bottom," dragging down environmental standards and wages in affluent nations. The way to blunt this effect is to append labor and environmental standards to trade agreements. But unless those agreements have teeth in the first place -- as in the judicial machinery of the W.T.O. -- there is no point in appending anything to them.
It will be years before meaningful labor and environmental accords are part of the world trade system. But they are being talked about much more seriously now than eight years ago, and powerful political actors, ranging from labor unions to international environmental groups, are mobilizing behind them. 
This is the big difference between now and 1993. Back then, liberal demands that Nafta include tough labor and environmental accords were largely disingenuous -- a way of torpedoing the whole accord. Today, people on the left increasingly accept that America is embedded in an international trade regime and realize that steering the regime itself leftward is the object of the game.
Dick Gephardt, the House minority leader, symbolizes the transformation. When he ran for president in 1988, I couldn't have supported him, for fear that he would be a captive of his protectionist constituency. But I could see voting for him in 2004, because a Gephardt presidency would now be locked into global economic engagement. Not joining the W.T.O. was a realistic political option, but leaving it isn't. 
By thus shrinking the policy menu, Mr. Clinton has saved the Democratic Party from an increasingly marginal existence as the anti-globalization party, a party that denies the world's destiny rather than shape it, a party faithful to its ideals but unable to realize them.
It's paradoxical that the wing of the Democratic Party Mr. Clinton confronted and subdued calls itself "progressive." The progressives of a century ago, like Teddy Roosevelt, recognized that technology was inexorably expanding economic activity from the regional to the national level, and they responded by carrying economic regulation to the national level. They passed national antitrust laws and food-and-drug laws and gave new forms of government support to national labor unions.
The analogous insight today is that with technology driving economic organization well beyond national scope, progressive governance has to catch up. Many on the left still haven't seen this, but Mr. Clinton has.
To be sure, he may not have seen it right off the bat. Even as late as 1998, he supported legislation that would have prevented the administration from including broad environmental and labor standards in "fast track" trade agreements. But he has since spoken approvingly of equipping the W.T.O. with such standards. And, in an important, if largely symbolic, precedent, the free trade agreement with Jordan, signed last year, is the first American trade agreement to include labor and environmental protections in the main text. (Such provisions are also part of an inchoate trade deal with Chile that the new administration will inherit.) 
If Mr. Clinton's progressive internationalism took a while to crystallize fully, it was nonetheless a natural expression of his identity. From the beginning, his embrace of technological change and of economic engagement with the world reflected his longstanding credentials as a New Democrat and, in a vaguer sense, his instinctive optimism and inclusiveness. 
And, anyway, presidents who do great things rarely have them clearly in mind on Inauguration Day. F.D.R. threw a bunch of policies against the wall, and the ones that stuck became the New Deal. Lincoln didn't enter office bent on freeing the slaves, and his early performance as commander in chief of the union forces was hardly auspicious. In the presidency, as in most jobs, being smart and persistent will go a long way.

HEADLINE: Bush Plans to Stress Effects Of Economics on Security 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush plans a major change in his National Security Council, adding economics experts to involve it far more in the economic changes that have caused upheaval around the world.
 Mr. Bush, who described his plans on a hike on his 1,600-acre ranch on Friday in Texas, said he had asked his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and his chief economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, to "share a desk" that would work to coordinate America's foreign policy objectives with its economics strategy. 
 "It's a way to make sure the economic people don't run off with foreign policy and vice versa," Mr. Bush said, apparently referring to the major role the Treasury Department has had over the last eight years in setting policy toward China, Japan and, to a lesser degree, Russia. 
"Globalization has altered the dynamics in the White House, as well as between the White House and the Treasury," he said. "We have to respond to that." 
In a telephone interview today from her home in California, Ms. Rice said that she and Mr. Lindsey would jointly run a staff that would deal with two sorts of issues, international economic policy and coordinated responses to the types of crises that have erupted in Mexico, Asia and Russia, crises that have frequently brought down governments. 
The staff would be "physically located within the N.S.C. offices," she said, but would report both to her and to Mr. Lindsey.
Mr. Bush's plan appears to be an effort to build upon, but also substantially alter, President Clinton's crack at the same problem.
In 1993, Mr. Clinton created the National Economic Council, a White House unit that he initially described as an equivalent, and a counterweight, to the long-established National Security Council. The N.E.C., as it was called, became a strong force in developing domestic economic policy, and was particularly powerful under its first chairman, Robert E. Rubin.
But when Mr. Rubin became Treasury Secretary in 1995, some of that agency's influence moved with him. In size, budget and influence, it never grew to rival the security council, and often both agencies engaged in classic Washington turf battles.
A version of the economics council will still exist, and Mr. Lindsey will run it. But international economic issues will belong to a separate staff, run by a deputy assistant to the president, reporting to the heads of both councils. 
"International economic issues are still not as integrated as they should be in the national security process," Ms. Rice said today. "So we are going to try to do this in as seamless a way as possible." 
But she added, "we are still thinking through the details."
Before Mr. Clinton took office, other administrations talked about making the national security directorates more savvy about economic forces. But that effort was often halfhearted, and forgotten as soon as a military crisis arose that focused attention elsewhere.
The pressure has grown, however, as it has become obvious that the Central Intelligence Agency and the State Department have been slow to reorient themselves toward the challenges of economic interdependence -- and slow to hire or promote staff members with economics skills. 
The C.I.A. was widely criticized for having failed to identify the internal economic rot that contributed to the breakup of the Soviet Union in the administration of Mr. Bush's father. After the fall of the Berlin Wall, senior officials of the agency talked a great deal about reorienting their mission to protecting America's economic lead, and they devoted considerable resources to studies of how foreign governments use under-the-table payments to steal business from American companies. 
The intelligence officials also provided more resources to American trade negotiators, at one point going as far as listening in on the telephone conversations of Japan's minister of international trade and industry during tense negotiations in 1995 over American access to the Japanese automobile market.
But the United States has repeatedly been taken by surprise by economic crises that created political risks. 
The Mexican peso crisis crept up unnoticed here, and in 1997 and 1998, the C.I.A. and the State Department's economics officers also failed to detect early signs of the currency crisis in Asia that ultimately spread to Indonesia and brought down President Suharto, the country's leader for more than three decades.
But investors with billions of dollars at stake in Mexico and Asia missed the same signals.
"Mexico and Indonesia are very good examples of areas where we needed more overlap with the National Security Council," said Mr. Lindsey, who opposed the Mexican bailout -- though Mr. Bush supported that move -- and the American efforts to contribute to the Asian bailouts. 
"Indonesia was complex economically," he said. "But clearly the results have not worked out very well for security and stability in Southeast Asia. That's a case where we needed more security policy views from the start."
Ms. Rice said the Treasury Department would continue to play a major foreign policy role and noted that Paul O'Neill, the treasury secretary designate, has extensive business experience in international markets. 
Republican officials said the leading candidate to be Mr. O'Neill's deputy was Kenneth W. Dam, a law professor at the University of Chicago. Mr. Dam was a top economics official in the Nixon White House and, at one point, executive director of a group intended to coordinate domestic and international economic policy. He was also a deputy secretary of state in the Reagan years and a senior executive at I.B.M.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Different Bush, Same Bible
Like father, like son; and like Jimmy Carter, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Warren G. Harding and George Washington.
 A Masonic lodge in New York expects the Bible that will be used when president-elect GEORGE W. BUSH takes the oath of office on Saturday to be one used at five previous inaugurations, including his father's in 1989. That Bible, a 234-year-old King James version published in London, is owned by St. John's Lodge No. 1 of the Ancient York Masons. JULES GARFUNKEL, a past master of the lodge and one of three members of its Bible Committee, will carry it to Washington for the inauguration. 
 Mr. Garfunkel said that the lodge offered to let Mr. Bush use its Bible as soon as it became clear that he would be the 43rd president. "We had some inkling that he would say yes because his father had used it," he said. "Barbara Bush held both Bibles, their family Bible atop ours. The historical context is that it's the very Bible that was used by our first president at his inauguration in Federal Hall in Manhattan in 1789. We're just carrying on that tradition."
The Bible's velvet-lined carrying case got a new handle at the White House 12 years ago. The old handle broke apart on the way to the inauguration of Mr. Bush's father, Mr. Garfunkel said. "They sent it down to their workshop and replaced it," he said. "Try to get that kind of service anywhere else."
Mr. Garfunkel said he would leave for Washington on Friday and return late Saturday. No parties?
"No, we haven't been invited," he said. "Our function is to transport the Bible. We'd like to view the parade, but that's about it."

Alone in a Booth
Some portrait photographers have their subjects sit in a cavernous studio while they aim their spotlights and focus their lenses.
Not Andy Warhol, it turns out. HOLLY SOLOMON, the subject of a huge Warhol that went on display at the International Center of Photography at 1133 Avenue of the Americas at 43rd Street last week, said Mr. Warhol worked from images taken in a coin-operated photo booth.
"I met him at 47th and Broadway," she said. "He picked the machine in the photo booth. He wanted the one with the highest contrast. Then he left me there, with about $60 in quarters. I brought those photo-booth pictures to him at the Factory. And let me tell you, it's pretty boring to do that many photo-booth photos."

Designs on Space
ARIE L. KOPELMAN, the president of Chanel. and the chairman of the Winter Antiques Show, laughed off the notion that dot-com jitters and Wall Street turbulence might hurt sales at this year's show, which opens Thursday.
"The dealers are up for it," he said at a warm-up party for the show's Young Collectors Committee the other night, "and despite some glitches, the economy is in good enough shape that it will not impact the dealers." 
So people can still afford to shop at the show?
"It is important that the price range isn't limited to $300,000 tables," he said. "One of the things that distinguishes this show is that many, many people come to this show thinking, 'This may be the year I'll go home with a little goody tucked under my arm.' "
What little goody might he be looking for?
"Something I can't live without," he said. But he added, "We really don't have room for anything else. I see something I like and my wife asks, 'Where are you going to put it?' If I can't answer that question to our mutual satisfaction, then it's a pass."
Across the room, COCO was asked about what her husband had just said. "We do have veto power over each other's choices," she said. "And we really don't have room for anything else."
 JAMES BARRON

HEADLINE: Chrysler Said To Map Plan For Recovery 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler's strategy for reviving its troubled Chrysler unit will involve eliminating thousands of white-collar jobs, canceling the development of marginally profitable vehicles and sharing auto parts between Chrysler and Mitsubishi, people involved in the automaker's planning said.
 But the strategy, scheduled for presentation to DaimlerChrysler's supervisory board in Germany on Feb. 23, is likely to call for the closing of few if any factories, nor will it rely on blue-collar layoffs, company executives said in interviews today and over the last week. 
 Chrysler could announce some cost-cutting steps before Feb. 23, as the automaker seeks to improve its financial performance, said Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's new chief executive. "We will need the impact for this year as soon as possible." 
DaimlerChrysler is under acute pressure to shore up Chrysler's results quickly. The division lost $512 million in the third quarter and is estimated to have lost as much as $1.25 billion in the fourth quarter.
As reported two months ago, a few of the company's top executives would like to sell part or all of Chrysler, essentially undoing the merger two years ago of Daimler and Chrysler. But Jurgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chairman, ruled that out againtonight at the Automotive News World Congress, a trade conference.
The net cash reserves of DaimlerChrysler's auto production units dropped to zero at the end of the year from 6 billion euros, or $5.71 billion, at the end of September. The company attributed the drop to one-time expenses, including acquisitions.
Mr. Zetsche, a former Mercedes executive sent to Chrysler two months ago from Germany, declined to discuss any details of the plan he would present to the supervisory board next month. But other executives involved in Chrysler's planning said that deep job cuts were certain, particularly after the decision by General Motors last month to eliminate 10 percent of its white-collar jobs. What is not clear yet, the Chrysler executives said, was the precise number of jobs to be eliminated and whether actual layoffs would be involved, as opposed to relying on buyouts and attrition.
DaimlerChrysler executives who insisted on anonymity said that the company's leaders were also leaning toward the adoption of a new vehicle design and engineering strategy that would make greater use of Mitsubishi, in which DaimlerChrysler took a one-third stake in October.
Under the new strategy, which has been rumored for several weeks, vehicle development staffs would probably be divided into four teams: a luxury- and large-car team dominated by Mercedes, a midsize and small-car team shared by Chrysler and Mitsubishi, a sport utility vehicle and minivan team mainly run by Chrysler and a commercial vehicle team overseen by Freightliner, a DaimlerChrysler subsidiary based in Portland, Ore. But in an interview tonight, Mr. Zetsche said any overhaul of corporate structure would not be allowed to dilute the distinctiveness of each company's brands and designs.
Mr. Schrempp said tonight that Chrysler and Mitsubishi might share some car underbodies. Pierre Gagnon, the chief operating officer and executive vice president of Mitsubishi's North American sales division, said that discussions on cooperation were under way in Tokyo between Mitsubishi and Chrysler but had not yet produced specific changes in the United States.
A big problem ever since Daimler and Chrysler merged in November 1998 has been the refusal of Mercedes executives to share vehicle underbodies and other parts with Chrysler so as to achieve greater economies of scale. The assignment to Chrysler of two longtime Mercedes executives, Mr. Zetsche and Wolfgang Bernhard, the latter as Chrysler's chief operating officer, has prompted a renewed effort to find synergies that will not dilute the Mercedes brand.
For instance, Mr. Bernhard said, Mercedes produces seat subframes in a more efficient, less costly way than Chrysler, so Chrysler will adopt the Mercedes approach. The savings could reach $46 a seat, he said.
In early December, Chrysler asked its auto parts suppliers to reduce by 5 percent the prices they charge on all shipments, starting at the beginning of this year. The demand has provoked resistance from some suppliers -- and even threats to stop shipments as soon as the end of this month, which could cause assembly lines to shut down. Mr. Zetsche said tonight that this would not happen.
Mr. Zetsche said that Chrysler would not take any hasty steps to close factories permanently, because it is very hard to switch the production of a vehicle from one factory to another. "Potential changes in the structure of our plants are not for next month," he said, but will depend on long-term changes in Chrysler's product lineup to make it easier to produce any vehicle at more factories than is now possible.
Chrysler faces this problem most acutely in the production of the PT Cruiser. The gangster-styled vehicle is assembled only at one plant in North America, in Mexico, that can meet just a small fraction of demand. Yet the Chrysler factory in Belvidere, Ill., that assembles the Dodge Neon, on which the Cruiser is based, has been idled repeatedly this winter because of slow demand.
The problem is that the Cruiser is seven inches taller than the Neon, making it two inches too tall for the Belvidere assembly line.
The strongest candidate for closing over the next several years remains the nearly century-old Chrysler factory in Toledo, Ohio, that makes the Jeep Cherokee and Wrangler. Chrysler has built a new factory nearby to assemble the Jeep Liberty, which will replace the Cherokee this summer. The new factory is close to the old one, partly to allow workers to transfer easily. 
Another candidate for closing is a light truck assembly plant in Windsor, Ontario, where Chrysler used to build large Ram wagons. Until recently, it planned to build a large Dodge sport utility vehicle at the plant that would compete with the Chevrolet Suburban. Under a 1999 labor agreement with the Canadian Auto Workers union, Chrysler committed itself to spending several hundred million dollars to construct a large building for the high-speed automatic painting of big vehicles.
The building was almost finished, and most of the money spent, when Chrysler abruptly stopped most construction on it recently, said a DaimlerChrysler executive who insisted on anonymity. Chrysler has not decided what to do with the factory, the executive said. The labor agreement required that the paint shop be erected, he joked -- but the automaker was not required to use it.

 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

U.S. Allies Assert Bush Should Not Quit Kosovo
Senior NATO generals, United Nations officials and Western diplomats said in interviews that the American role in Kosovo was as crucial as ever and that they regarded President-elect Bush's expressed desire to pull American troops out of the Balkans as both ill-timed and damaging. A1

Economics and Security
President-elect George W. Bush plans a major change in his National Security Council, adding economics experts to involve it far more in the economic changes that have caused upheaval around the world. Mr. Bush has asked his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and his chief economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, to "share a desk" that will work to coordinate foreign policy objectives and economics strategy. A10

Effort Against Hiding Wealth
The Clinton administration plans to announce voluntary measures meant to deter foreign leaders and their associates from hiding money in the United States. A11

El Salvador Earthquake
Hope for finding more survivors trapped by the temblor that struck suburban San Salvador on Saturday dwindled as the death toll rose to at least 600, with some estimates of the missing as high as 4,000. A3

Israel Reacts to Settler's Death
Israel canceled a negotiating session with the Palestinians and sealed off the Gaza Strip after a Jewish settler was found shot to death. A3

Setback for Taiwan Leader
Taiwan's highest court ruled that President Chen Shui-bian's government had acted improperly in halting the building of a $5.5 billion nuclear power plant that his Nationalist predecessors approved. A6

World Briefing A10

OBITUARIES A21

Kwang-chih Chang
The Harvard anthropologist known for his work on Chinese civilization of the Bronze Age was 69. A21

NATIONAL A14-19

On King's Birthday, Bush Seeks to Build a Bridge
President-elect George W. Bush, who won only 8 percent of the black vote, told an audience at a mostly black elementary school in Houston that he would honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s legacy by working to improve public schools and give all Americans a chance at success. A19

Senate confirmation hearings begin today for Mr. Bush's proposed attorney general, John Ashcroft, whose record on racial issues is expected to come under fire. To counter any notion of racial insensitivity on Mr. Ashcroft's part, Republicans have lined up some black supporters. A18

The Legacy on Her Shoulders
The pressures of being the youngest daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were sometimes too intense for her to bear, the Rev. Bernice A. King told a reverent crowd at her father's church in Atlanta, in a frank confession marking Dr. King's birthday. A14

EDUCATION

Flawed Science Textbooks
Twelve science textbooks widely used in middle schools across the nation are riddled with errors, a study led by a North Carolina State University researcher found. A17

ARTS E1-12

3 Museums Form Partnership
The directors of the New York-based Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna and the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, announced a new collaboration. E3

Children's Literature Awards
Richard Peck received the Newbery Medal for his story collection "A Year Down Yonder," and David Small got the Caldecott Medal for his illustrations of the presidents of the United States in "So You Want to Be President?" by Judith St. George. E9

NEW YORK/REGION B1-7

Manhattan's Soaring Rents Have Lost Momentum
Many landlords are reducing rents for the first time in seven years, with some even offering to pay broker fees. Real estate brokers say vacancies started accumulating after the Nasdaq plummeted and dot-coms began failing. One real estate executive said prices for one-bedroom rentals had recently declined 10 to 12 percent. The large rental agency Citi Habitats said one-bedroom apartments that had been listed at $3,300 a month were now near $2,700. A1

Marking King's Birthday
Two gatherings honoring the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. -- one led by Mayor Giuliani at Gracie Mansion and the other, in Harlem, by the Rev. Al Sharpton -- illustrated deep differences in interpretations of King's legacy. B1

Prospect Park Attack
A gay man was stabbed in Prospect Park in Brooklyn in what appeared to be a recurrence of last summer's string of bias attacks on men in an area of the park used as a gay meeting spot, the police said. B4

Neediest Cases B5

SPORTS D1-8

Taking One From the Team
Marcus Camby threw a punch at San Antonio's Danny Ferry late in the Knicks's 104-82 victory, but wound up colliding with Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy, who needed about a dozen stitches over his left eye. D1

FASHION B8

SCIENCE TIMES F1-12

Forming Highly Dense Matter
Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory, on Long Island, said they had used a particle accelerator to smash nuclei of gold atoms together to make the highest-density matter ever created in an experiment. A19

Health & Fitness F7

BUSINESS DAY C1-12

Closer Monitoring of Airlines
Senior Clinton administration officials said Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater would make public three studies decrying the state of competition in air travel and laying out a blueprint for how the government could improve it. But he will stop short of issuing some guidelines that drew criticism when first proposed three years ago. A1

Nestle-Ralston Purina Deal
Nestle, the world's largest food company, was said to have agreed to acquire the Ralston Purina Group, the nation's leading maker of pet food, for $10.1 billion in cash. C1

Chrysler's Recovery Plan
DaimlerChrysler's strategy for reviving its troubled Chrysler unit will involve eliminating thousands of white-collar jobs, canceling the development of marginally profitable vehicles and sharing auto parts between Chrysler and Mitsubishi, people involved in planning said. C1

Buyout Firm in Radio Deal
Forstmann Little, the leveraged-buyout firm, is expected to announce today that it will acquire Citadel Communications, one of the nation's largest radio broadcasters in midsize markets, for about $1 billion. C1

Business Digest C1

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section A; Column 6; Editorial Desk; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 63 words

HEADLINE: A Global Greenhouse 

 BODY:
To the Editor: 
 John Podesta, President Clinton's chief of staff, defends the administration's record on global warming (letter, Jan. 10). But it is true that economic globalization, and the resulting shift of manufacturing to less regulated regions beyond our borders, has increased the total generation of greenhouse gases on our planet.

BELA LIPTAK
Stamford, Conn., Jan. 10, 2001
